DOC.HEAD: Government Warns Strikers But Work Stoppages Spread
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs to CORRECT spelling of Chamorro's first name to Violeta sted Violetta
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of workers on Thursday joined a 4-day-old strike organized by pro-Sandinista labor unions, disrupting banking, postal and telephone services nationwide. Police made no effort to dislodge strikers from government buildings, and there was no indication that negotiations between the government and strikers would take place. The U.S.-backed government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has declared the strikes illegal, saying they are politically motivated. The government accuses the Sandinistas of fomenting the labor unrest to undermine Mrs. Chamorro's economic recovery program. On Wednesday night, seven pro-Sandinista strike leaders were detained for two hours, including Lucio Jimenez, the secretary-general of the Sandinista Workers' Central. The government said it was meant as a warning to other labor leaders to obey the law and not cause disorder. The Sandinistas say they are supporting the strikes because the new government's policies are threatening the gains of their revolution. They contend the government has broken its promises not to fire public employees, and say the unions are entitled under the constitution to a say in making national economic policy. Public employees won a 100 percent salary increase and other concessions during a crippling Sandinista-led strike in May. Despite the government's warning, the work stoppages continued to spread. About 3,800 telephone and postal workers joined the strike Wednesday night. Operator-assisted international calls were not going through, which caused considerable difficulties because most Nicaraguans do not have direct-dial capability. Telex service continued normally. The telephone and postal workers were staging what their leaders called a ``crossed arms strike,'' similar to a sit-in. On Thursday, about 12,500 bank employees began a similar strike action. Banks were open but no service was available. About 3,500 employees at the ministry of agriculture also went on strike Thursday, union leader Jose Angel Bermudez said. Radio Nicaragua reported Wednesday night that thousands of farm workers had also gone on strike. Ramiro Guardian, vice-president of the Council of Private Enterprise, a major business group, said the strikes were preventing the planting of cotton, an essential crop in Nicaragua. He blamed the labor protests on ``hot-headed Sandinistas.'' Strikes continued Thursday at other government offices, including the customs service and the foreign, labor, construction, transportation, commerce and finance ministries. Air traffic controllers at Sandino International Airport threatened to strike, and electrical workers announced they may begin scaled cuts of energy to the country. Students at most universities were also on strike. On Wednesday, students briefly took over the state-owned Radio Nicaragua and National Television System to read statements in favor of the strike. Jimenez claimed some 80,000 workers in both the public and private sector were on strike as of Thursday. But estimates of the number of strikers by the Sandinista-led unions have been exaggerated since the strike began on Monday. Ariel Bucardo, president of the Farmworkers' Federation, said 1,000 members of his group were en route to Managua, the capital, to support the strikers. He said his union wanted the government to repeal laws allowing the return of some land confiscated by the Sandinistas to the original owners. The Sandinistas redistributed some 5 million acres of land, most of it held in absentia by wealthy Nicaraguans who fled abroad during the Sandinistas' 10 years in power. Mrs. Chamorro's new economic plans include returning most state-owned companies to the private sector and reorganizing the government _ both moves likely to cause job reductions. The Sandinistas led by Daniel Ortega were defeated in the Feb. 25 elections by Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Protein May Trigger Unwanted Clots, Study Suggests
With PM-Aging Reversal, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Potentially fatal clots that develop after surgery may be triggered by high levels of a blood protein, suggests a study published today. Mice that carried a human gene to make them produce excessive levels of the protein developed clots in their tails and hind feet, researchers reported. If further research confirms the link, patients at risk for clotting may be identifiable before surgery by measuring their levels of the protein, said researcher Laurence Erickson of The Upjohn Co. in Kalamazoo, Mich. At-risk patients could receive preventive therapy and researchers may someday find a way to lower a person's level of the protein as a preventive step, he said. The protein, called plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 or PAI-1, normally keeps the body from destroying clots prematurely. The clotting condition is called deep venous thrombosis. Clots appear in veins, usually in the leg. They can kill if they break free and travel to the heart or lung. Clotting can appear after major surgery, in cancer patients and people with an inherited tendency to develop them. The condition is treated with anti-clotting drugs. Between 200,000 and 300,000 cases occur in the United States each year, with perhaps 20,000 or more deaths a year, said venous thrombosis researcher Dr. Philip Comp of the University of Oklahoma. Comp said he believed it would be difficult to manipulate PAI-1 levels to prevent the clotting disorder. As for indicating patients at risk, he said high levels in the blood may signal conditions unrelated to the risk. Even if high levels were related, he said, only a small percentage of people deemed at risk would probably get clots anyway. Erickson and Upjohn colleagues presented their study findings in today's issue of the British journal Nature. The mice were given the extra PAI-1 gene before birth. Clotting appeared shortly after birth, and resolved after production of PAI-1 fell back to normal.

DOC.HEAD: Men Make Less Sperm in the Summer: Is it the Heat?
With PM-Aging Reversal, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When the weather heats up, sperm production goes down, and this may explain why fewer babies are born in the springtime, according to a study today. While the study documents that men produce less sperm during the summer, it does not definitely explain why. Population experts have long noticed that fewer babies are born in the spring months than at any other time of the year. The researchers, based at the Chemical Industry Institute of Toxicology in Research Triangle Park, N.C., dismissed one obvious explanation for the summertime dearth of conceptions. They said that ``the available evidence'' does not support the idea that because it's so hot, people simply have sex less often in the summer. What they found instead was that ``semen quality'' deteriorates during the summer. ``This phenomenon may account at least in part for the reduction in the birth rate during the spring in regions with warm climates,'' the researchers concluded. The study, directed by Dr. Richard H. Levine, was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. It was conducted on 131 men in steamy San Antonio, Texas. All of the men worked outdoors at least part of the day. Their sperm concentrations were one-third lower in summer than in winter. About 18 percent of their children were born in the spring, compared with almost 30 percent in the fall. ``There can no longer be any doubt that concentration-related measures of semen quality are reduced during the summer,'' the researchers wrote. Exactly why, however, is unclear. High temperatures interfere with the testicles' ability to make sperm. But in this study, summer sperm production was lower even in those who spent part of the day inside in air conditioning. So torrid summer weather may not be the whole answer. ``The immediate implications of these findings is that although sperm counts are lower in the summer, the mediating factor is not the heat of the summer,'' wrote Dr. Peter J. Snyder of the University of Pennsylvania. In an editorial in the journal, he suggested another possible explanation: Maybe it's the extra daylight, not the heat, that makes men less fertile in the summertime.

DOC.HEAD: `PG-13' Library Card Would Limit Kids to Children's Room
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: See Dick and Jane run _ as long as it's not from the children's room to the rest of the Oak Lawn Memorial Library, where trustees have adopted a ``PG-13'' library-card policy. Beginning in September, parents of children under age 14 will have the option of a library card that would restrict their young to the children's room of the library. Period. Time magazine _ in the periodical area _ would be off limits. Ray Bradbury's book, ``Fahrenheit 451'' _ in adult fiction _ would be out of reach. So would ``Who's Who'' _ upstairs in the library's reference section. Trustees say in an age in which children are bombarded with violent and illicit images, the card will give parents the option of confining their children to appropriate reading material. Parents who aren't interested in the special card may still get cards for their children that will give them free rein of the library. ``I think the issue here is parental rights,'' said Dave Gallagher, a seven-year trustee of the library who voted in favor of the plan at the board's June meeting. ``As far as I'm concerned, the whole policy puts in into the hands of the parent and takes it away from the library, a government body,'' said Gallagher. ``The parent has a choice _ and that's the key word here, choice.'' Under the plan, kids wishing to leave the library's L-shaped children's area would be required to show a staff member their card. If they have the special juvenile card, they will not be allowed to leave the room. The proposal, which passed 3-1 with three members absent, has met with the approval of some parents. ``I wouldn't get the cards for my kids, but I wouldn't criticize the board for issuing them,'' Grace Kreten said last week as she browsed through the children's section with her children, 10-year-old Kelly and 6-year-old Peter. ``If you're on top of things as a parent, then the library doesn't have to be,'' Mrs. Kreten said. Twelve-year-old Jason Pollard, a fan of sports books, shrugged when asked about the new policy, saying, ``I don't care what they do.'' Others questioned the wisdom of the policy. ``The library should be a place where everything is available,'' said Donna Kordas, who regularly brings her four children, ages 2 to 15, to the only library in this suburb south of Chicago. Oak Lawn librarians declined to discuss the new policy. Oak Lawn is not unique in instituting such a card _ nearby Arlington Heights has a similar system already in place. Officials of the American Library Association said they feared the cards were a bad precedent. ``If just one parent signs that card that denies child free access in the library, we've been set back,'' said association president Richard Dougherty. ``Kids who read succeed. Anything that puts barriers in front of that is not good,'' he said. The association does not keep statistics on how many of the nation's 103,000 libraries have such systems, although the trend has been away from them, said Judith Krug, director of the association's Office for Intellectual Freedom. ``But every once in a while, like in Oak Lawn, the trend is reversed,'' she said. Some child and adolescent psychiatrists also questioned the proposal. ``The more children read, the better off they are,'' said Dr. Aaron Esman, an adolescent psychiatrist who teaches at Cornell University Medical College in New York. ``It almost doesn't matter what it is. ``For libraries to discourage children from reading is inappropriate developmentally and culturally disastrous.'' A non-profit organization called Friends of the Oak Lawn Library said it would lobby with the board to reverse its decision. ``Ours is a very open library,'' said Monica Stock, secretary of the group. ``How do they know that a child has that card? Are they going to mark them with a Scarlet A?''

DOC.HEAD: Potential Lawyers Sleep Away in Florida Camp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report; LawCamp is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The 30 youths from around the country assembled at this summer sleepaway camp are here to study torts, not sports. Welcome to the National LawCamp, the child of a recently graduated lawyer's shock, bewilderment and fear during his first weeks of law school. The camp offers students an introduction to law study without the intense grade competition, the imposing professors personified by the late John Houseman in the movie ``Paper Chase'' and without the hefty cost. ``One of the things I saw was that a lot of students use their first year of law school to see if that's what they want to do,'' said camp organizer Chris Salamone, a Fort Lauderdale litigator who got his law degree two years ago from nearby Nova University. The three-week camp is aimed at letting students know what they're in for at law school for $1,995, compared to typical tuitions that run into five figures. The campers range from age 15 to the mid-20s. And if they're certain that's what they want, the camp should give them a headstart on the often-mystifying law school experience, said Salamone. His father, Anthony, has 30 years' experience running summer sports camps, mostly in New Jersey, and is helping get LawCamp going. The students, staying on the Barry University campus in this Miami suburb, will find out about the heavy workload and the competition in a law career, Salamone said. Legal ethics also will be stressed. ``We're not all Michael Cusacks,'' Nova law professor Michael Flynn, referring to an ``L.A. Law'' television lawyer, told students as the camp opened Sunday evening. ``We spend very long hours. It's very hard work, that's all.'' Ellis Rubin, one of Miami's best-known defense attorneys, was the camp's first guest lecturer. ``You have to pay your dues. You have to put in extra hours. It's very difficult to break in,'' Rubin said. ``If you reach a point where you're valuable to other people, then you will receive your reward.'' Rubin, an attorney 39 years, said that only in the past 15 years has he earned a comfortable living. If after hearing such de-glamorizing accounts students decide against a law career, Salamone said, they have saved law school tuition and ``spent three weeks in south Florida and you will know more law than 99 percent of Americans. So that can't hurt.'' The campers will be taught by law professors who then stay around to study with them and answer questions. Salamone said that law professors often are inaccessible, leaving beginning students confused and scared. Law school concentrates on analysis and procedure, rather than the simple answer-oriented teaching most students are used to, Salamone said. ``Law schools don't tell you what they're doing, they just do it,'' Salamone said. The camp also offers mock trials and a Law School Admission Test seminar and sample test. ``It's perfect for this time in my life,'' said Jennifer Edwards, a Florida International University junior who hasn't decided on a career. ``I'm not really sure what I'm going to do. I'm hoping this will kind of push me over the edge.'' Sixteen-year-old Voselyn Williams, a senior at Miami Archbishop Curley-Notre Dame High School, plans to become a corporate lawyer. She sees the camp as good preparation. ``I don't want to go into anything blind,'' she said. As with any summer camp, there are field trips: to the Broward County Courthouse, jail and crime lab. It's not all statute books and case studies. Time is planned for pool lounging, softball, volleyball and something that could come in handy after the future lawyers send their clients' bills out _ a martial arts demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Mecca Tragedy: How It Happened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Moslem pilgrims who crowded into the Mo'essem tunnel in Mecca were hurrying to perform the ritual of ``stoning the devil,'' the climax of the annual pilgrimage, or hajj. Many were running to their deaths. What was supposed to be a joyful celebration by 2 million Moslems from around the world suddenly became a nightmare of trampled bodies. Saudi Arabian officials said 1,426 pilgrims died Monday, trapped in the stampede in the 600-yard-long tunnel. Hundreds more were injured. The monthlong pilgrimage, which every Moslem must make once, was coming to its end. Religious fervor was high. It was the first day of the three-day Eid al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice, that marks the prophet Abraham's willingness to sacrifice his son to God. Three piles of stonework represent the three devils who tried to tempt Abraham away from sacrificing Ishmael as a demonstration of his faith. The hajjis _ the men in seamless white ceremonial robes as required by Islamic custom, the women in specially tailored clothes covering them from head to ankle _ were eager to get to the stone-throwing site in a bowl-shaped vale hemmed in by rocky, scrub-studded hills. The tunnel _ 30 feet wide and 25 feet high _ is carved out of the Mo'essem Mountain to funnel the pilgrims to the holy site. At one end is the tent city where Pakistani and Indonesian hajjis were camped out after the ceremonies in Mecca, birthplace of the prophet Mohammed and Islam's holiest shrine. The other end leads to the stoning arena, called Gamarat Aqabah. Nearby, there is a slaughterhouse, used by the hajjis to kill hundreds of thousands of sheep during the three-day feast. It was 10 a.m. when disaster struck. Thousands of hajjis who had already stoned the devil were returning from Gamarat Aqabah on a pedestrian bridge from which they had cast their pebbles, heading for the tunnel entrance. Under the pressure of the human tide, the railing on the bridge collapsed. Seven pilgrims tumbled 25 feet off the bridge into the crowd of people coming out of the tunnel. The bodies crashing into the throng touched off panic. Only those at the entrance of the tunnel knew what had happened. Behind them, pilgrims continued to move inside. Soon the tunnel, which has a capacity of 1,000, was jammed with what authorities later estimated at 50,000 pushing, shoving pilgrims. Pilgrims heading for Gamarat Aqabah were also ignorant of what had happened, and they kept thrusting forward. Soon those trapped inside the tunnel began screaming. The panic spread like wildfire. Witnesses said many feared terrorists had struck, as they did in Mecca last year when a series of bombings killed one man and wounded 16 others. In 1987, more than 400 people were killed in riots that Saudi authorities say were instigated by Iranian militants. Soon after the accident at the mouth of the tunnel, there was a power failure. No one knows exactly why. The lights went out and the ventilation system went off. The temperature in the open was 112 degrees. The tunnel became a furnace. People began to faint, particularly the elderly, in the suffocating congestion. Men and women tried to claw their way out in the darkness, trampling over the fallen. It was the same outside. ``No one could go forward or back. ... People were falling on each other, the bodies piling on each other ... There was a mad rush and screaming,'' an aide to the Interior Minister, Prince Nayef, said on Saudi television. One survivor said: ``It was terrible. People were rushing in opposite directions. When one stumbled, scores trampled him ... and hundreds fell on top of them in no time.'' Another, a Lebanese, sobbed: ``I was pushed and fell over about 20 corpses. Others were still pushing in two directions and walking on top of me. May God forgive me for trampling on the others.'' As the scale of the disaster became evident, security police forced their way through the sea of pilgrims to rescue those trapped in the tunnel, which by then had become a tomb. They sealed off both ends of the tunnel and threw ropes inside to pull out anyone who could grab hold. They also threw in plastic bags of cold water for those trapped to drink until they could be reached. First aid squads treated hundreds of victims on the spot. Ambulances nosed through the crowds, taking the injured to hospital, the dead to the morgue. The wailing and weeping soon diminished, replaced by a numbed quiet. For Islam's faithful, dying in Mecca is supposed to be a joyful thing. But for those who lost relatives and friends, there was the ordeal of going around Mecca's 10 hospitals looking for them, trying to find out if they were dead or alive. One man woke up in a hospital bed after being unconscious for 24 hours, shouting for his wife. No one knew where she was. Four young Egyptian men with bloodshot eyes stood outside a morgue seeking word of a missing companion. They had been about 10 yards from the mouth of the tunnel when disaster struck. Their friend had been ahead of them. They never saw him again.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Freed by Robbers After Surviving Russian Roulette
DOC.TEXT: Robbers freed a policeman after he survived a Russian roulette ordeal during a bus hijacking, police said. Authorities said police Cpl. Antonio Dionisio was on a bus that was flagged down and taken over late Tuesday by five gunmen in suburban Valenzuela. When the robbers discovered Dionisio was a policeman, they took his six-chamber revolver, removed all but one bullet, and told him that he could go free if he survived the fourth squeeze of the trigger. ``You are a policeman. You ought to die. But I will give you a fair play. If you survive this game, I will give you back your life,'' a witness quoted a robber as saying. To the astonishment of the robbers, Dionisio squeezed the trigger four times without the weapon firing. The robbers let him go, police and witnesses said. The robbers escaped with money and valuables from the passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Heading for Showdown on Arts Endowment's Fate
DOC.TEXT: Amid escalating warfare between arts supporters and religious conservatives, the fate of the National Endowment for the Arts may be decided this summer in a bruising House floor fight. Legislators on both sides agree that when Congress votes on whether to extend the federal arts agency's life for another five years, it almost certainly will impose restrictions on the content of works that receive tax-paid grants from the endowment. The furor began more than a year ago with criticism of NEA support for exhibitions of sexually graphic images by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. In recent months, it has erupted in a barrage of emotional newspaper and radio commercials, letter-writing campaigns and court battles. Endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer, caught in the cross-fire since he took office nine months ago, came under renewed attack last Friday when he overruled an NEA panel's recommendations and rejected grants to four avant-garde ``solo performance theater artists.'' The People for the American Way Action Fund, a liberal lobbying group, said Frohnmayer's decision ``has the smell of politics all over it'' and was intended to placate right-wing critics of the arts endowment. One of the rejected artists, John Fleck of Los Angeles, charged that ``there's a strong movement going on to wipe out different voices, to have a homogeneous voice that suits certain people's morals.'' Solo performer Rachel Rosenthal of Los Angeles reportedly refused to accept her $11,250 endowment grant, saying the four rejected artists were among the best in their field. ``Why should I be considered clean and they're considered dirty?'' she asked. Ms. Rosenthal also refused to sign a controversial pledge that she would not use endowment funds for obscene, indecent or blasphemous art _ a condition imposed by Congress last fall at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Endowment officials say that of the 2,000 grants awarded so far this year, 670 artists or arts institutions have signed the agreement and received government money, 12 have signed the pledge with letters of protest and a half-dozen have rejected grant awards. The rest haven't yet responded. On the same day he rejected the four grants, Frohnmayer told an audience in his home town of Portland, Ore., that the stakes in the mushrooming controversy were high. ``A remarkable experiment that has lasted the last 25 years and has so enriched our country is indeed threatened with either extinction or severe crippling because of 20 images out of a million we have funded,'' he said. Frohnmayer, who opposes the Helms amendment, said the arts community must share the blame for the bitter controversy that imperils the endowment, an independent, $171-million federal agency whose arts grants must be matched by local private funds. ``We've acted much like spoiled children asking our parents to continue sending us money regardless of what we do, how we spend it or whether we are prepared to be held accountable,'' he said. NEA officials refused comment on published speculation that Frohnmayer might resign after the endowment's reauthorization bill passes Congress. When asked during his Portland speech if he planned to resign, Frohnmayer answered firmly, ``No way.'' Although no date has been scheduled for House action on the NEA bill, arts lobbyists expect a vote sometime before legislators begin their month-long summer recess in early August. Three or four major proposals circulating among House members include a conservative plan for severe restrictions on NEA grants and a major overhaul of the endowment that would shift a substantial portion of grant funds directly to state arts councils. Some conservatives favor abolishing the endowment. At the heart of the debate are conflicting arguments over the government's proper role in supporting the arts. The arts community and its supporters contend that restrictions on NEA grant recipients amount to government censorship. That argument is rejected by conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists, who say the real issue is the taxpayers' right to decide where their money is spent. The conflict is dramatized in toughly worded newspaper ads and radio spots sponsored by People for the American Way and its nemesis, the Christian Coalition led by evangelist Pat Robertson, who was a conservative presidential candidate in 1988. ``Do you want to face the voters in your district with the charge that you are wasting their hard-earned money to promote sodomy, child pornography and attacks on Jesus Christ?'' Robertson asked in a full-page letter to members of Congress that was published in The Washington Post and USA Today. People for the American Way put such performers as Colleen Dewhurst, Kathleen Turner and Garrison Keillor on the air to counterattack. ``Imagine a world in which millions of people are at the mercy of a small band of extremists, in which works of art are subject to government censorship and freedom of expression is a crime,'' said Miss Dewhurst. ``Now stop imagining. Welcome to America, 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Ms. Richards Asks: Where's Claytie?
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ann Richards is not just looking for votes, she's looking for her opponent in the Texas governor's race. She's looking for GOP nominee Clayton Williams, the millionaire oilman and rancher who calls himself ``just a working cowboy.'' Ms. Richards, the two-term state treasurer, claims that Williams has been ducking her since he made a series of embarrassing remarks about women, rape and youthful visits to prostitutes. ``The only way Clayton Williams can win is if they keep him from being in the public eye, if they can keep him from talking to the press, if they can take him only to places that are very staged, where he is not given access to the press,'' she said. Williams shrugs off her barbs. ``We're ahead in the polls. I'm going to work to stay that way,'' he said. Williams for weeks declined to agree to a debate with Richards, but last week the two candidates finally began trading proposals about when, where and how to face off. ``We don't schedule our campaign for her convenience,'' Williams spokesman Gordon Hensley said of Richards. ``We're starting to rock and roll in this campaign and she's still slipping and sliding.'' Williams drew fire in late March when he compared rape to bad weather. He said that if it were inevitable, ``relax and enjoy it.'' Then during a visit to the White House, Williams said he felt uncomfortable running against a woman. ``I said I didn't want to be his mother, I just want to be governor,'' Ms. Richards retorted. Finally, Williams admitted to The Houston Post that he had been ``serviced'' by prostitutes in his youth. Aides insist the colorful Republican hasn't lowered his profile. Both candidates have spoken to many of the same groups _ just at different times. Williams has maintained an active pace, they say, including a trip to Mexico for trade talks, a Dallas fund-raiser featuring President Bush and a fast-moving trip to the Texas coast when the supertanker Mega Borg threatened to dump 38 million gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. ``Any time you move from a primary to a general election, there are certain dynamics of news coverage that change. It's important for us to make sure that when you have an event, you go out and discuss particular issues,'' Hensley said. The most recent public opinion poll, published in late May, gave the edge to Williams. The Texas Poll, conducted for Harte-Hanks Communications Inc., showed the Republican running ahead, 46 percent to 38 percent, with a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The poll also found a ``gender gap'' in which men more strongly supported Williams while women looked more favorably on Richards. Williams, who spent $6 million of his own money in a $9 million primary race, is repeating one tactic that helped him win the GOP nomination. He began airing television commercials late in June, more than four months before the November election. Ms. Richards said she wouldn't try to match the early ads. ``One reason is it costs too much money and the public's memory is short,'' she said. ``There are two sides to Clayton's going up (on TV) early. The good side is that they must feel like they need to. The bad side is I know how much TV can drive (poll) numbers.'' One issue sharply dividing the two candidates is abortion. Williams, who opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest or danger to a woman's life, assailed Ms. Richards for opposing legislation that would require teen-agers to get parental consent. ``Ann Richards has allowed the liberal, feminist pro-abortion groups to set her agenda,'' he said. Ms. Richards responded: ``Government has no business interfering in our lives any more than is necessary.'' The two also duel over who is more qualified to be governor. Williams maintains his experience in the oil, gas, cattle and banking industries gives him the business perspective needed to control a government that spends $24 billion a year. ``I'm an outsider and not part of the Austin establishment. A Williams administration will challenge the status quo,'' he promised. Ms. Richards links Williams with another millionaire Republican oilman, retiring Gov. Bill Clements, who had no earlier experience in public office. ``We've played games all these years (by) electing someone who is not a part of government. And you've seen the results of that. They cannot make the system work,'' Ms. Richards said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds Barden. An AMs separate moved on Hart as a0560, and on Boggs on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: Maurice Girodias
DOC.TEXT: Maurice Girodias, who battled with censors while publishing ``Lolita,'' ``Candy'' and other erotic best sellers, died Tuesday of a heart attack he suffered while giving a radio interview. He was 71. Associates said he was stricken during an interview at Jewish Community Radio studios in Paris. Girodias, the founder of Olympia Press in 1953, published first editions of works by Henry Miller, Lawrence Durrell, Samuel Beckett, Vladimir Nabokov. William Burroughs, J.P. Donleavy, Nikos Kazantzakis and Jean Genet, among many others. Accused of promoting pornography, Girodias had numerous confrontations with French censors in the 1950s and 60s, spent several days in prison, and eventually was banned from publishing any further books in France. He lived in exile in the United States from 1964 to 1974, when he was expelled in connection with a political novel which had former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger as a main character.
DOC.HEAD: Marion Rice Hart
DOC.TEXT: Marion Rice Hart, an adventurer who sailed around the world and made seven solo flights across the Atlantic, died Monday of pneumonia at age 98. She didn't start flying until age 54, but went on to earn worldwide acclaim for her feats. Hart was born Oct. 2, 1891, in London. She married mining engineer Arthur Hart, and the couple lived in Arizona and California before divorcing. Hart piloted her single-engine plane non-stop across the Atlantic at age 61. She later flew all over the United States, Europe, Asia, Africa and South America, and made at least six more solo flights across the Atlantic, the last at age 83. In 1936, Hart cast off for what became a three-year voyage sailing around the world on her 72-foot ketch. Books she wrote about her exploits include ``I Fly as I Please,'' ``How to Navigate Today'' and ``Who Called that Lady a Skipper.'' She died at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley.
DOC.HEAD: Phil Boggs
DOC.TEXT: Phil Boggs, who dominated U.S. diving competition during the 1970s, died Wednesday of lymphoma at age 40. The 1976 Olympic gold medalist in springboard diving died at his home after a seven-month bout with the cancerous blood disorder, his wife said. The first aquatic athlete to win three world championships, Boggs was the three-time world champion in springboard diving, and won nine U.S. national championships in the 1970s. The Akron, Ohio, native praciticed law in Miami and was active as a public speaker, and a commentator for CBS Sports and ESPN. He was president of U.S. Diving, a national governing board, in 1980-'84, and had been president of the Legend National Corp., which offers retirement services.
DOC.HEAD: Karl Allison
DOC.TEXT: Karl Allison, director of planning and development for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. and formerly a Broadway producer, died Wednesday in Perugia, Italy, at age 42. Festival spokesman Tom Kerrigan announced here that Allison had a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday. Allison joined the board of directors of Spoleto Festival U.S.A., a celebration of the arts in Charleston, S.C., in 1988 and later took the staff position. In January he planned a benefit at Lincoln Center here that raised $321,000 for the festival in the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo. His credits as a Broadway producer include ``Blithe Spirit'' with Richard Chamberlain and Geraldine Page, ``Wild Honey'' with Ian McKellan, ``You Can't Take it with You'' with Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst and ``Aren't We All'' with Rex Harrison. He produced the long-running off-Broadway hit ``Greater Tuna.''
DOC.HEAD: Olive Ann Burns
DOC.TEXT: Olive Ann Burns, author of the 1984 novel ``Cold Sassy Tree,'' died Wednesday at age 65. She had been ill with lymphoma since 1975, and was hospitalized for several weeks before her death at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta. Ms. Burns had said her illness prompted her to write ``Cold Sassy Tree,'' a novel about small-town life in north Georgia in 1906. The book became a Book-of-the-Month Club alternate selection in 1984, and is listed by the New York Public Library as one of 200 books recommended for teenagers. The book was made into a cable television movie in 1989. She and her late husband, Andrew Sparks, had worked for Atlanta Weekly, a Sunday magazine once operated by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, and for a time she was a free-lance writer and advice columnist for The Constitution. She is survived by son John A. Sparks of Colorado Springs, Colo.; daughter Becky Sparks of Atlanta; brother William H. Burns of Atlanta; and two sisters, Margaret Turn of Bushkill, Pa., and Jean LeGrand of Conyers.
DOC.HEAD: Hans-Rudlof Kurz
DOC.TEXT: Swiss military historian Hans-Rudolf Kurz, who headed an international inquiry into the World War II past of Austrian president Kurt Waldheim, died Friday at age 75. Kurz chaired a commission of five historians that the Austrian government named in 1987 to investigate allegations that Waldheim had links to Nazi war atrocities. The panel's report found no evidence Waldheim was involved in war crimes though Kurz publicly called the findings ``not encouraging'' for the Austrian president. Kurz was an adviser to five defense ministers during a 40-year government career and reached a colonel's rank in the Swiss army. His first book, on the structure of the Swiss army, was published in 1953. His obituary in the Bern newspaper Der Bund said he had been hospitalized for several weeks, but didn't give a cause of death.
DOC.HEAD: J. Curtis Barden
DOC.TEXT: James Curtis Barden, a retired vice president and chief financial officer of Media General Inc., died of a heart attack Tuesday at age 59. Barden retired this year from Media General, parent company of Richmond Newspapers Inc. and other media holdings. A certified public accountant, Barden was named assistant controller of the company in 1967. He became vice president 10 years later and was appointed chief financial officer in 1983. Before joining Media General, Barden was an accountant at the firm Andrews, Burket & Co. in Richmond. Barden, a Richmond native, died in a local hospital. He is survived by a son, James C. Barden Jr., and a sister, Mrs. Lucille Wright.

DOC.HEAD: Receding Water Poses New and Bigger Problem _ Erosion
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: After the floodwaters drained away, Shahar Banu and her grandson returned to their village and found the earth slipping under their feet. Megaiya's land is eroding fast. As it does every year, the latest deluge by the monsoon-swollen Jamuna River and the receding water ate more loose topsoil this summer. But now the erosion is threatening the village itself. ``The countdown to destruction has started,'' said Hedayetullah al-Mahmud, a civil administrator at Megaiya in the northern Sirajganj district. This summer's flood washed away thousands of huts and weakened the foundations of the few concrete buildings in the village of 3,000 people. District officials fear that in five years the erosion will trigger the collapse of the region's oldest establishment, a school built in 1919, as well as a college, a hospital, a granary and at least 50 shops. Annual flooding is a major problem in Bangladesh, a low-lying delta crisscrossed by hundreds of rivers. Tens of thousands of tons of rice, the staple of Bangladeshis, are lost to the encroaching rivers every year and the government reports hundreds of deaths. The country is one of the poorest in the world, with a per capita income of $160. When there are no floods, Bangladesh's 110 million people are often reeling under drought. The coastal areas are buffeted by frequent hurricanes. ``Flooding is a problem which brings temporary sufferings. But here in our area river erosion is the main problem,'' said Abul Kalaam Azad, a local official in Megaiya. Mrs. Banu and her 15-year-old grandson are resigned to the fate. ``Only Allah can help us. We have nothing else,'' said Mrs. Banu, a 55-year-old widow. Besides Megaiya, erosion is threatening the neighboring Kazipur area, also in Sirajganj district, Azad said. Sirajganj, 60 miles northwest of the capital Dhaka, was the worst-hit in last month's floods. More than 600,000 people were stranded in the Sirajganj district and another 200,000 in neighboring Bogra. People fled their inundated homes to take refuge atop levees and on the roofs of brick and cement houses. Most houses in the impoverished district have mud-coated bamboo walls and thatched roofs that wash away within a few hours whenever the Jamuna floods. Azad said the Jamuna has destroyed at least 20 villages in the past three years, displacing 30,000 inhabitants. Many of them resettled in neighboring districts or moved to cities, he said. Last month, the Jamuna overflowed in at least 43 places during its 185-mile journey from the hills in the north to the southern delta on the Bay of Bengal, a Water Development Board official said. Officials say privately that government efforts to tackle the annual deluge in the countryside have been half-hearted. They say the focus of the flood control measures has been Dhaka, a city of six million people, which was badly hit by floods in 1988. At least 1,400 people died nationwide in that year's floods. Government officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said President Hussain Muhammad Ershad's administration has spent the equivalent of about $31 million to build a giant earthen dam around Dhaka. In Megaiya, many residents are preparing to move. On Sunday, workers began emptying the 13-year-old granary and shopkeepers shifted their wares to another place one mile away. ``In another five years the building we are sitting in may be gone if the river continues its destruction at the current rate,'' al-Mahmud, the civil administrator, said. Government officials and local activists apparently have no solution yet to the erosion. ``We think we will have to live with it,'' Azad said.

DOC.HEAD: Hormone Injections Reverse Sagging Flesh and Flabby Muscles of Old Age
DOC.TEXT: Hormone injections can reverse some of the damage of aging on the body and give people back the firmer flesh of their younger years, a study released today says. Researchers found that injections of human growth hormone, a once-rare protein made through genetic engineering, will help old people build up sagging muscles, take off flab and grow more youthful-looking skin _ turning back the clock as much as 20 years in just six months. However, they caution that the treatment is not the fountain of youth, and should not be used routinely until questions are answered about its long-term effects and possible hazards. And while it will firm up bodies, it will not undo many of the other ravages of aging, such as failing eyes and dying brain cells. It's also expensive, with the costs of medicine alone for an average man running more than $10,000 a year. The pilot study conducted at the Medical College of Wisconsin involved 21 healthy men 61 to 81 years old: 12 received the shots, while nine received no treatment for comparison. The volunteers who got the shots said treatment made them look better and feel stronger, and their wives agreed. ``What we saw over six months was that several of the body composition changes (of aging) were reversed,'' said Dr. Daniel Rudman, who directed the study. ``These represented the reversal of one or two decades of aging with regard to these factors.'' Overall, the men's lean body mass, which is mostly muscle, increased 9 percent. Their fat tissue decreased 14 percent, and their skin became 7 percent thicker. Until now, doctors have given this treatment, known as human growth hormone, mostly to children whose growth is retarded because they don't make enough of the protein. However, the body's production of growth hormone also slows as people reach their 30s. In about one-third of people, it virtually stops by age 60. ``This study is an early investigation of whether it may be useful to treat this very, very large number of elderly people who have stopped secretion of human growth hormone,'' Rudman said. Such routine treatment would be expensive. The hormone cannot be given in pill form, and in this study people received three injections a week. The size of the dose depends on the patient's weight. Treating a 155-pound man for one year would cost $13,800 in medicine alone. Rudman's research was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. While the study found no serious side effects from the hormone, the volunteers' blood pressure and blood sugar levels rose slightly. Rudman said doctors should be cautious in giving the hormone to elderly people who already have these problems. Rudman said he expects the treatment to be used first for relatively short periods to build up the bodies of frail elderly people, such as those about to undergo surgery. He said the therapy probably would not make people live longer, but could improve the quality of life. Stronger muscles and healthier skin should result in better mobility, fewer falls and less skin sores. To prevent, rather than reverse, the effects of aging, treatment might need to start when people are in their 30s or 40s. Rudman said much more research into the possible benefits and hazards will be necessary before such therapy becomes common. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Mary Lee Vance of the University of Virginia described the work as ``an important beginning.'' But she cautioned, ``Because there are so many unanswered questions about the use of growth hormone in the elderly and in adults with growth hormone deficiency, its general use now or in the immediate future is not justified.'' Among the questions that remain are safety issues about its effect on metabolism, whether it actually improves muscle function, at what age treatment should start and how much of the hormone people need.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Medicare Not To Blame For Failing Rural Hospitals
DOC.TEXT: Most rural hospitals that have gone out of business were losing money because of their high operating costs rather than inadequate government subsidies, congressional investigators say. Hospitals and members of Congress have blamed a disparity in Medicare payments to rural and urban hospitals for the financial plight of many rural facilities. But a report by the General Accounting Office appears to support the Bush administration's contention that rural hospitals are losing money primarily because their costs are too high. ``Medicare was not a major factor contributing to the financial decline and closure of most rural or urban hospitals that closed between 1985 and 1988,'' said the report released this week. Three-fourths of the failed hospitals either profited from Medicare patients or lost less money from treating them than other patients, the report said. Under pressure from the health care industry, Congress last year decided to phase out the differential in Medicare payments to rural and urban hospitals over five years. The gap was cut from 12 percent last year to 8 percent this year. Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., argued that inadequate Medicare payments had cost rural hospitals money and ``reduced the health services to rural Americans.'' Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., introduced legislation this spring to eliminate the differential altogether next year. Most of the troubled hospitals are located in the central United States, according to GAO studies. Some 48 percent of the 140 rural hospitals that closed from 1985 through 1988 were in Texas and other south central states and 22 percent were in the north central region. Failed rural hospitals usually are small and have low occupancy rates, which contribute to their high operating costs, the GAO said. Hospitals that closed had occupancy rates 35 percent to 52 percent lower than facilities that remained open, the investigators said. The investigators did say they could not rule out that Medicare may have contributed ``disproportionately'' to the demise of some of the hospitals. The Department of Health and Human Services' inspector general found last year that more than 40 percent of rural hospitals made money on the Medicare program because they operated at lower costs than other hospitals. Hospitals that were losing money tended to be smaller, have lower occupancy rates and bigger staff-to-patient ratios and keep patients longer, according to that study.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Expects Banner Year for Farm Income
DOC.TEXT: Large increases in sales receipts for both crops and livestock are adding up to what the Agriculture Department sees as a banner year for farm income. As charted by USDA economists, farm sales receipts make up the lion's share of gross farm income. Big production and strong prices mean fat receipts. Government payments, income from custom work, sales of forest products and other miscellaneous cash sources account for the remainder. On the other side of the ledger are farm expenses, the costs of producing crops and livestock. Feed, seed, fertilizer, interest and all the other related items go into that column. In 1990, according to the department's Economic Research Service, farmers nationally may gross a record of $162 billion to $168 billion from crops and livestock sales, up from $158 billion in 1989. Livestock sales are expected to be in the range of $84 billion to $87 billion, while crops sales are forecast at $77 billion to $81 billion. All figures are rounded. Not all products will share in the 1990 gains, however. The national figures also cloak the inequities farmers always face from one part of the country to another, from one commodity to the next. ``Soybeans probably will be the only major crop showing smaller cash receipts in 1990,'' says economist Diane Bertelsen. ``Soybean prices are expected to be down about 15 percent from a year earlier. And with little change in production, soybean receipts are likely to be off 4 percent.'' Bertelsen, writing in the July issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said farmers will probably boost their sales of corn and other feed grains by $2 billion to $4 billion from last year. ``Fall corn prices are not expected to weaken as much as previously expected, so the annual price could remain near last year's average of $2.40 to $2.45 per bushel,'' she said. The price outlook reflects increased estimates of exports and domestic feed use, despite a possible boost of 5 percent to 10 percent in production this year. Tight supplies also are a contributing factor. Wheat production is expected to rise one-third this year, while prices probably will be down 15 percent to 20 percent from last year's level. Cash receipts for wheat, cotton, fruits and vegetables may be up less than 5 percent from 1989. Bertelsen said total livestock receipts in 1990 are forecast to rise by as much as $3 billion from last year to the forecast range of $84 billion to $87 billion. ``Reduced pork production and tight supplies are pushing hog prices up more than 20 percent from last year's average, while relatively stable beef production is likely to lead to a 3 percent to 4 percent increase in prices,'' she said. Thus, cattle and calf receipts may be up by as much 8 percent from last year, while hog sales may rise by 20 percent. Poultry production is forecast to be up by about 7 percent in 1990, although price declines of around 6 percent or 7 percent ``probably will keep total poultry and egg receipts flat at about $15 billion,'' Bertelsen said. Looking at expenses, the analyst said that prices of feed grain are showing less weakness than had been expected. In the first quarter of this year, economists thought the index of prices paid by farmers for feed would decline by 20 percent this year. But now the decline is expected to be only half of that, about 10 percent. As a result, 1990 spending for feed may decline only slightly this year and remain within $1 billion of 1989's $24 billion. ``Uncertainty about feed costs may be behind producers' cautious approach to expanding herds, despite higher hog and cattle prices,'' Bertelsen said. Spending for manufactured ``input'' items used in production, overhead and operating expenses probably will increase 3 percent to 5 percent this year. Interest expenses are expected to remain near $15 billion for the third consecutive year. Meanwhile, direct government payments to farmers probably will drop $2 billion or more to around $8 billion to $10 billion. After adding up all the sales receipts and other figures, deducting expenses and making other adjustments, farmers nationally are expected to have a net cash income this year of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $54 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. By the agency's reckoning, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Some commodities sold actually may have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the agency says ``net farm income'' may be in the range of $47 billion to $51 billion, compared with last year's record of $49 billion. Net farm income is used to measure the value of agricultural production, whether sold or stored, in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other allowances.

DOC.HEAD: Family Will Be Tired of Tires, But a Bargain's a Bargain
DOC.TEXT: The only thing standing between the Mosleys and their dream home is about 250,000 tires. But Willie Mosley Jr. and his family figure the 2.47 acres of land they bought at a constable's auction Tuesday is a bargain at $313, despite the mountain of work they face clearing away the radials discarded on the property. ``We're just working people,'' said Mosley's wife, Carol. ``Where else are we going to be able to buy a piece of land for $313, and all you have to do is clear some tires off of it?'' Johnson County officials had foreclosed on the property because previous landowners owned back taxes. Officials then discovered the tires that litter the landscape, piled up to 10 feet high in some areas. Health officials gave the county until Oct. 1 to remove the tires or risk fines of $25,000 a day. But the Mosleys discovered a 2-year extension was available. No one else bid on the property and Mosley got it for the $313 at which Constable Steve Curlee started the bidding. The Mosleys plan to put a mobile home on the property, 30 miles southwest of Dallas. And for the next two years, Mosley, his wife, their two teen-aged sons and three married daughters and sons-in-law will cut up tires with chainsaws and lug them away in a truck the family bought. The family hopes it will not have to saw up all the tires, though. ``There's a number of things you can do with them,'' Mrs. Mosley said. ``Some people need tires for playgrounds. Or people who want them to put around racetracks. Anybody who wants them, send them out here. They're free for the taking. ``Just don't bring any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Frank Sinatra celebrated American Independence Day by performing in the country that still sometimes thinks of the United States as ``the colonies.'' ``I asked my agent if it was smart to book an act in London on July 4th,'' the 74-year-old Sinatra said during his show Wednesday night at London Arena. The audience laughed and applauded warmly as Sinatra broke into the opening bars of ``Strangers in the Night.'' For more than an hour, Sinatra sang his favorite tunes, including ``My Way,'' ``New York, New York,'' and ``A Foggy Day in London Town.'' He sipped a glass of bourbon between songs, stopping at one point to toast the bandleader _ his son, Frank Sinatra Jr.

Former President Jimmy Carter gave President Bush mixed reviews after accepting Philadelphia's $100,000 Liberty Medal. ``I've been extremely disappointed in President Bush on environmental issues,'' Carter said Wednesday after the gala Freedom Festival at Independence Hall. ``In almost every case he's come down basically on the same positions as James Watt,'' said Carter, referring to the controversial interior secretary under Bush's predecessor, President Reagan. ``But on other things, in national affairs, I think Bush is doing a great job,'' Carter, a Democrat, told reporters who asked for his assessment of the Republican administration. The birthplace of the Declaration of Independence celebrated the nation's birthday with a giant cake, a parade, a concert and fireworks. Carter helped Mayor W. Wilson Goode cut the cake, which was then distributed to thousands of spectators. The former Georgia governor said he would use the Liberty Medal prize money for humanitarian causes. The prize was established in 1988 by We the People 2000, a nonpartisan group of civic and business leaders. Bell Atlantic Corp. has underwritten the cash award.

Veteran actor and stage director Jacques Lassalle has been named to head the prestigious French theater company Comedie Francaise. He succeeds Antoine Vitez, who died in April. The appointment was announced Wednesday. Lassalle, who turns 54 this week, has directed the National Theater of Strasbourg since 1983. In 1967 he founded the Studio-Theatre in Vitry, outside Paris, which he directed until 1983. Lassalle said he was ``moved and honored by the warm welcome'' he received from the Comedie Francaise troupe. He said he would maintain the 1990-91 program of performances planned by Vitez.

Country-rock star Jerry Jeff Walker sported an ``Ollinger's Plumbing, Heating and Air Conditioning'' T-shirt on stage to acknowledge the plumber who cajoled him to give a concert here. ``I like a man who knows what he wants and goes and gets it,'' Walker, who also traded his beige felt cowboy hat for a maroon North East baseball cap, hollered to the screams and shouts of 250 fans who packed his show Tuesday night. Walker, 48, catapulted to fame in 1968 when he recorded the now-classic ``Mr. Bojangles.'' Other hits include ``L.A. Freeway'' and ``Up Against the Wall, Redneck.'' Chuck Ollinger got the idea of a Walker show in this village on the shore of Lake Erie so he and his buddies could have front-row seats to hear one of their favorite singers. Ollinger called Walker's agent and struck a deal that Ollinger would put half the money up front. The amount was not disclosed. ``It was a spur-of-the-moment kind of thing,'' said Ollinger, 36. But with the help of a local radio station and word-of-mouth advertising, the $18 tickets sold out in four days.

DOC.HEAD: Exuberant Conductor Keeps Symphony Orchestra Rocking
DOC.TEXT: Don't expect to doze listening to the Peoria Symphony Orchestra. Exuberant conductor William Wilsen's blend of the classics and rock 'n' roll from the likes of Frank Zappa keeps audiences hopping. The 12-year conductor of the orchestra founded in 1898 said he breathes new life into symphony standards by Mozart, Beethoven, Bach and Brahms by mixing them with works by contemporary U.S. composers. ``I feel obligated to keep music alive and not a museum for music of the 17th and 18th centuries,'' he said. ``I ask my audience to keep an open mind.'' Wilsen is a large, barrel-chested man who works into a sweaty frenzy during rehearsals and performances alike. He's known for boisterous bobbing and jumping on stage as he urges his musicians to greater heights. To him, music is something both earthly and divine. ``It's as close as I get to God, and I want others to move my audiences the way the music moves me,'' Wilsen said. His boldness isn't always welcomed by often-staid symphony fans, said William Seeback, president of the Illinois Council of Orchestras. ``Audiences like to hear the masterpieces _ the 19th century European traditional compositions. Bill tries to program contemporary composers as well to show where we are in the 20th century,'' Seeback said. ``It isn't always safe programming.'' Wilsen said the high point of his career was last summer's concert in Bodensee Festival in Konstanz, West Germany, which drew seven curtain calls and rave reviews. ``We went home feeling pretty damn good,'' Wilsen said. ``Those were sophisticated audiences. Often, they can be closed-minded, even stultified audiences. I think we showed we're a very decent orchestra.''

DOC.HEAD: Father of Rap Star Bobby Brown Charged with Rape
DOC.TEXT: The father of U.S. rap music star Bobby Brown has been charged with raping one 16-year-old girl and assaulting another in a Brisbane hotel room, police said today. Herbert James Brown, 60, was granted bail of $40,000 (U.S.) after appearing in Brisbane's Magistrate Court today. He was not required to enter pleas to charges of unlawfully detaining and raping one girl and assaulting another. Senior Magistrate Peter Mitchell ordered Brown to appear in court for an Aug. 20 hearing. The court was told that Herbert Brown has been accompanying his son on an Australian tour. Police said Herbert Brown met one of the girls, both 16, at a nightclub on Wednesday and that she accompanied him back to his hotel room. Herbert Brown has denied having sexual contact with the girl, the court was told. Police said another girl in the room was assaulted by Herbert Brown but fled and called for assistance. Bobby Brown, a former member of the group New Edition, won awards for best male vocalist and best album for ``Don't Be Cruel'' at the 17th annual American Music Awards in January. The album has sold 5 million copies.

DOC.HEAD: Happy Birthday, USA: America Celebrates from Sea to Shining Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf 4 with additional injuries in Connecticut celebration. SUBS grafs 25-27 with 3 grafs with quote and updates on injuries. Picks up 28th graf pvs., `In Philadelphia ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX4,LA2,AB2,AT2
DOC.TEXT: The weather was hot as a firecracker, but Americans turned out by the millions Wednesday to celebrate the birth of their nation on the Fourth of July with pyrotechnics, parades and picnics. In California, a quarter of a million people got up early or stayed up late to watch a fireworks display over Santa Monica Bay by dawn's early light. ``America's Birthday Cake'' _ a giant pastry big enough to serve 25,000 people _ was cut in Philadelphia, where it all began 214 years ago. Former President Carter received a medal and $100,000 award, and urged Americans to work anew for freedom and equality. Holiday festivities took a sad turn in Connecticut, when 19 people were injured Wednesday night when an errant shell from Torrington's Independence Day fireworks display shot into the crowd, authorities said. A 3-year-old suffered multiple burns. American flags, always in abundance on Independence Day, were an especially hot item this year. Flag merchants in New York and a small-town Louisiana mayor said the flag-burning issue had made showing the flag more popular. ``Some people are burning them up. We're hanging them up,'' said Glenmora Mayor Tyrone Dale, whose central Louisiana town of about 2,000 people flew 50 flags in a special display on Main Street. ``It's been a banner year, and that's not just a flag company joke,'' said Steve Sevits, vice president of sales for the Uneeda Flag company near Albany, N.Y. Parking was patriotic at Six Flags Over Texas in Arlington, where teen-age attendants took it upon themselves to get motorists to park by color in red, white and blue lines of cars. ``The guests realized what they were doing, and got just as much enjoyment out of it as the parking lot attendants,'' said Six Flags spokeswoman Sherry Hatfield. Spectators braved the baking sidewalks of Chicago's Michigan Avenue to watch a four-hour Shriners parade, while townspeople in Taylorville gathered for an Independence Day bash featuring a singing circuit judge. It was hot, hot, hot almost everywhere. Baltimore sizzled at 100 degrees, and New York burned, where at 92 degrees it was the hottest day of the year as 800,000 people headed for the beach at Coney Island. It was 105 degrees in Enid, Okla. High-temperature records for the date were snapped in Erie, Pa., where it was 97 degrees, Milwaukee (also 97), Syracuse, N.Y. (95) and Detroit, (98), and tied or broken in other cities in the East and Midwest. ``I would say it's a scorcher,'' meteorologist Bob Laplante said in Charleston, W.Va., where the high was 92. ``There's much more humidity today, too. That makes it doubly worse.'' When darkness eased the heat a bit in New York City, 1.3 million people cheered Macy's annual fireworks display on the East River. It wasn't all fun, fireworks and parades. The Veterans of Foreign Wars, the Paralyzed Veterans of America and AMVETS organized a midday rally in a park in St. Petersburg, Fla., to push for better health benefits. At least 2,000 veterans, many in uniforms bedecked with campaign ribbons and carrying flags or wearing flag-lapel pins, attended the rally under warm, sunny skies. ``We've had all we can stand. The system is underfunded and we're not going to take it anymore,'' said VFW Executive Director Larry Rivers. At the Spirit of America Festival in Decatur, Ala., former hostage Frank Reed, who was released in April after 44 months of captivity in Lebanon, received the annual Audie Murphy Patriotism Award. In Washington, D.C., spectators on the Mall between the White House and the Capitol were entertained by musical performances. A free concert at the Capitol was planned for the evening by the National Symphony Orchestra, followed by a fireworks display at the Washington Monument. The estimated 250,000 people who crammed Santa Monica and adjacent beaches for the ``Dawn's Early Light'' fireworks display were also treated to a performance by the Los Angeles Pops Orchestra. Patty Gleeson watched before starting her morning job as a waitress. ``They were really great, and the beach was just packed,'' Ms. Gleeson said. ``It was worth getting up early.'' The display was moved from night to early morning three years ago to cut down on gang violence. But two people were wounded Wednesday in shootings police blamed on gangs, one critically. Three men and a teen-ager were arrested in the shootings. Dianne Hollen of Venice Beach stayed up after her performance as a local standup comic. She found the spectacular ``kind of short and disappointing ... It only lasted about 15 minutes.'' She described the crowd as ``pretty well-lubricated and rowdy.'' In Connecticut, a shell veered off into a crowd of thousands at Fuessenich Park during the grand finale of the fireworks display at Torrington's 250th anniversary party, said fire Lt. Nick Florio. ``People were crying. Everybody got blood on them. It was disgusting. It just misfired and hit people,'' said Jody Lothier, who was watching the display. Two women were listed in serious condition with burn injuries late Wednesday at a Torrington hospital. Three-year-old Robert Shopey, who suffered multiple burns, was in stable condition at a hospital in nearby Hartford. In Philadelphia, Carter received the second annual Philadelphia Liberty Medal and the $100,000 for his international peace and humanitarian activities. The former president, standing under a sizzling sun in front of a flag-draped Independence Hall, then helped city officials cut and serve ``America's Birthday Cake'' to a crowd of thousands. At Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's Virginia home, Gov. L. Dougls Wilder told 48 people taking the oath of citizenship that they have a social and moral obligation to help others become free. Wilder, the nation's first elected black governor, said Monticello was appropriate for the ceremony because freedom-loving people everywhere invoke the name of Jefferson. ``Today and for the rest of your lives you will know the joy and hope of freedom,'' Wilder said. ``This morning, your rights as an American citizen and a human being are being recognized.''

DOC.HEAD: Western Leaders Prepare to Discuss NATO's Future
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 5th graf, ``Bush arrived xxx to update with Bush arrival
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders began arriving Wednesday for a summit to overhaul NATO for a less militarized future as President Bush said Moscow could ease the flow of financial aid by curtailing defense spending. Faced with a rapidly diminishing threat from the Soviets, leaders of the 16 NATO countries will open two days of talks Thursday to discuss the political and military future of the alliance. There were stirrings of unease from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the host for the meeting, about U.S. proposals to make NATO appear less threatening to Moscow. ``The prime minister's consistent point has always been that you don't prevent war by going soft,'' a British government source said. ``You prevent war by keeping up your guard and by deterring anybody who might have belligerent ideas.'' Bush arrived in London shortly after dawn Thursday after an overnight flight from Kennebunkport, Maine. Wrapping up a seaside vacation, he told reporters he would look more favorably on Western aid for Moscow if the Kremlin spent less money on defense. ``I hope that given the changes in the world they'll be able to curtail that defense spending some,'' Bush said. ``If they do, I think it will be much easier for the West to give them certain kinds of economic assistance,'' he said. ``It will be a very good thing.'' Bush did not mention previous U.S. demands that the Soviet Union adopt Western-style economic reforms as a condition for receiving aid. While he did not spell out specific goals for reducing Moscow's military spending, Bush has said the Kremlin should drop its annual $5 billion subsidy for Cuba. Prodded by West Germany and France, Western countries are debating whether to come to the assistance of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his crumbling economy. Western aid is widely seen as a way of easing Soviet objections to a united Germany being a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. West Germany already has agreed to pump $3.1 billion in loans into the Soviet economy. West European leaders agreed late last month to consider assistance for Moscow but put aside a proposed $15 billion aid package. For his part, Gorbachev on Wednesday gave himself and the Soviet leadership two years to improve citizens' lives _ or resign. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' Gorbachev told a TV interviewer as he entered the Kremlin Palace of Congresses on the third day of the Communist Party's 28th congress. It was the first time the Soviet president and party leader, who is facing bitter criticism from both radical reformers and party traditionalists, has given himself and the leadership a deadline for turning around the country's political, economic and social problems. On the eve of the London summit, machine gun-toting police guarded Heathrow Airport's VIP lounge and sharpshooters watched from the rooftops as a string of prime ministers, foreign ministers and defense officials began arriving. The early arrivals included the prime ministers of Greece, Iceland, Denmark and Spain. Canadian Prime Minster Brian Mulroney and Secretary of State James A. Baker III were arriving late Wednesday. Security was expected to be even tighter on Thursday during almost simultaneous arrivals by Bush, French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. With the collapse of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, NATO is exploring ways to bring the now-outdated military alliance into line with a changing world. Western leaders hope the changes will ease Soviet concerns about East Germany leaving the Warsaw Pact to join with West Germany as a united nation in NATO. Bush has proposed that NATO leaders formally declare that nuclear weapons would be used only as a last resort _ a reversal of the 4-decade-old policy favoring a first-use nuclear option in the event of attack. He also has recommended the eventual withdrawal of 1,470 nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Europe and a reduction in NATO forces along what is now West Germany's eastern border. Western officials released some details of Bush's proposals in advance, perhaps to bolster Gorbachev against conservative critics at a Soviet party congress under way in Moscow. A senior British governnment source said Mrs. Thatcher was cool to the idea of declaring nuclear arms as weapons of last resort, and also was uneasy about the withdrawal of some 1,400 nuclear artillery shells from Europe. Referring to reduced East-West tensions, the source said, ``The important thing is to recognize the enormity of the changes that have occurred but not to assume at the same time that all threats have disappeared.'' In another step aimed at reassuring Moscow, West German defense ministry sources said in Bonn that the government was willing to consider a Soviet proposal that would limit the number of post-unification German troops to about 400,000. That figure would correspond to the combined strengths of Soviet and U.S. forces in the region under a formula expected to be approved in conventional force reduction talks in Vienna.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Winds Up Vacation, Heads to London
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 3rd graf ``The presidential xxx and 11th ``Bush plans xxx to update with Bush arrival in London
DOC.TEXT: President Bush departed Wednesday evening for the NATO summit in London after advising the Soviets anew to cut their military budget before looking to the West for economic help. Bush flew by Marine One helicopter directly from his oceanfront home in Kennebunkport to Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire, then stepped aboard Air Force One for the overnight flight across the Atlantic after a good-bye kiss from his wife, Barbara, who flew back to Washington. The presidential aircraft left just after 7:25 p.m. and arrived in London on schedule at 2 a.m., EDT. Before wrapping up a six-day respite along the rocky coast of Maine, Bush got in a final, full day of recreation, including boating and an early morning round of golf. He headed out on the links despite a bandaged right hand that he cut cleaning fish he caught Tuesday. He paused on the 18th green at the Cape Arundel Golf Club to comment on Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's remark at the Communist Party Congress in Moscow that the Soviets had ``ruined'' their country by ``squandering a quarter of our budget on military expenditures.'' Bush, who has resisted calls by French President Francois Mitterrand and others to proffer Western aid to the ailing Soviet economy, said he always maintained the Soviets are spending too much on their military. ``I hope that given the changes in the world, they'll be able to curtail that defense spending some,'' said the president. ``And if they do, I think it would be much easier for the West to give them certain kinds of economic assistance.'' Bush added that as a former chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, he was not surprised by Shevardnadze's statement. Cutting the Soviet military budget would ``free up funds to do more at home and it'll also free up Westerners' willingness to try to assist on the economic front,'' said Bush. It wasn't clear whether Shevardnadze meant to refer to the Soviet government budget or the Soviet economy as a whole. The United States spends about a quarter of its federal budget on defense but only about 6 percent of gross national product; a recent CIA estimate said the Soviet Union probably spends 18 percent of a far smaller GNP on defense and some Soviet economists have said the proportion could be a quarter or more. Bush plans 32-plus hours of talks and ceremony with the 15 NATO allies. He already has sent the NATO partners a proposal for far-reaching shifts in the alliance's military strategy in light of the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact. A centerpiece will be to declare that the alliance would only resort to nuclear weapons as a last resort _ a step back from the ``flexible response'' doctrine NATO has relied on since 1967. After the whirl of events in the British capital, Bush will hop back aboard Air Force One Friday for a 10-hour flight to Houston, where the annual economic summit of the world's seven wealthiest industrialized nations begins Monday. Bush conferred with top advisers earlier in the week at his Walker's Point summer home on both summits, and spoke by telephone Tuesday with the prime ministers of Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands. Bush spent much of his time in Maine golfing, fishing, boating or playing tennis. Since he had to depart before dark on this Independence Day holiday, the local fireworks were held a night early. Bush watched the Tuesday night display from the wooden deck of the U.S. Coast Guard Eagle, a three-masted tall ship. Bush readily lifted the bandage on his hand to display his fishing wound. ``Big fish yesterday ... A lot of them,'' he boasted, adding that he ``speared myself'' while filleting one of them.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,351.67, down 94.25 points, or 0.29 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Orders Most Cuban Diplomats To Leave Over Recognition Tiff
DOC.TEXT: Fed up with Cuba's refusal to recognize their government, Panama's leaders have ordered most of Havana's diplomats out of the country. Eleven of the 15 Cuban diplomats accredited in Panama must leave within 10 days, Assistant Foreign Minister Jose Raul Mulino said Wednesday. He said the embassy was advised of the expulsion orders on Tuesday. ``Due to the repeated and systematic hostile conduct by the government of Cuba against the legitimate elected government of the Republic of Panama,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a statement, only the charge d'affaires, the commercial and economic attaches and the consul will be allowed to remain. Cuba has repeatedly refused to recognize the legitimacy of the government of President Guillermo Endara, which was installed during the U.S. invasion that toppled strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on Dec. 20. Endara was on his way to victory in May 1989 presidential elections when Noriega had the voting annulled. Noriega's wife Felicidad and several of his associates took refuge at the Cuban Embassy after the U.S. invasion and former Noriega legislator Luis Gomez remains there. In March, the Panamanian government gave Mrs. Noriega, his daughters Sandra, Lorena and Thais, his son-in-law Jean Bauchamps and 10-month-old grandson safe conduct out of the country. It also expelled the Cuban ambassador, Lazaro Mora. The highest-level Panamanian diplomat in Cuba is a mission secretary. U.S. troops had surrounded the Cuban Embassy and residence after the invasion and Noriega opponents picketed the embassy several times. Cuban President Fidel Castro had supported Noriega, who shared Castro's contempt for Washington after U.S. officials accused the Panamanian leader of drug trafficking and pressured for his resignation. Noriega, who took refuge in the Vatican's embassy after the U.S. invasion, later surrendered and was flown to Florida, where he is awaiting trial on drug trafficking and money-laundering charges. Cuban officials refused to speak with an Associated Press reporter who went to the embassy. There was no unusual activity around the compound.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Shower Fujimori With Millions in Gifts For Stricken Nation
DOC.TEXT: Peru's president-elect ended a bittersweet visit to his parents' homeland today with private gifts for his stricken country, including $66,000 from an elderly woman who wanted to help Peru's hungry. Alberto Fujimori did somewhat better in eliciting private donations than in gaining promises of aid from the Japanese government. Japanese officials have denied that Peru's request for economic aid will be treated differently because of Fujimori's Japanese ancestry, which he emphasized during the five-day visit just as eagerly as he had while running for the presidency. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu resisted making specific promises of aid until Fujimori provides a concrete plan to cope with Peru's 2,000 percent annual inflation and $22 billion foreign debt, officials said.
