But citizens thrilled by the appearance of the first person of Japanese ancestry to win national leadership outside Japan showered the 51-year-old former agronomist with money. By mid-morning today, between $5 million and $10 million had been collected, according to Peruvian Embassy officials. Fujimori, who made a triumphant return to his parents' hometown of Kawachi on Wednesday, was to fly home later today. Among the private donors was 81-year-old Haruko Miike of Tokyo. Dressed in an elegant grey kimono, the former restaurant owner handed a check for 10 million yen, or about $66,400, to Fujimori at a downtown hotel as a gaggle of flashbulbs went off. ``I'm happy Mr. Fujimori will become president but I learned that there are a lot of people suffering from poverty in Peru. I wanted to do something while I'm alive,'' she told Kyodo News Service. ``Because of the drought, many children are starving,'' Fujimori told Ms. Miike. ``I'd like to use this to help the children.'' Another gift of 10 million yen in bills, wrapped in a blue-paper bundle, was given to Fujimori by 78-year-old Taiji Nagano, a real-estate company president. He exhorted the president-elect to ``do your best.'' Fujimori takes office July 28, Peru's independence day. Ivan Pinto, a Peruvian Embassy official, said Fujimori had received gifts from all over Japan during the last few days, mostly for the victims of a drought that has devastated the coastal areas of Peru. In his meetings with Japanese officials, Fujimori had sought medium- and long-term Japanese loans.

DOC.HEAD: Tearful Jurors Convict Christian Science Couple in Death of Son
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: A jury convicted a Christian Science couple of manslaughter in the death of their 2{-year-old son in a case that weighed religious faith against parental responsibilities to provide medical care. Some jurors cried after finding Ginger and David Twitchell, both 34, guilty Wednesday of involuntary manslaughter in the 1986 death of their 2{-year-old son, Robyn, who suffered a bowel obstruction. ``It has been hard on everyone and it was certainly hard on'' the jury, David Twitchell said minutes after the verdict was read. ``This has been a prosecution against our faith.'' But prosecutor John Kiernan said the case was about crime, not religion. ``What the case proved is the right to believe is absolute _ the right to practice is not,'' Kiernan said. A sentencing date is to be set Friday. The Twitchells remain free, but each faces up to 20 years in prison. Defense attorney Rikki Klieman said the Twitchells will appeal. She contends Judge Sandra Hamlin failed to instruct the jury properly on a religious exemption that applies to child abuse laws. The Suffolk County Superior Court jury deliberated more than 14 hours. Since 1980, there have been seven prosecutions of Christian Science parents. Five have been convicted, one acquitted and one case was thrown out, according to child rights activist Rita Swan, who said no cases were tried in the 1970s. Founded in 1879 by Mary Baker Eddy, the Church of Christ, Scientist, believes that physical disease, like sin, can be healed by spiritual means alone. Nathan Talbot, a spokesman for the Boston-based Christian Science Church, said he's confident the verdict will be overturned on appeal. ``We're deeply disappointed. It's still an unresolved issue,'' he said. ``It certainly isn't going to change spiritual healing.'' Robyn's sickness and death on April 8, 1986, were graphically detailed in two months of testimony that some experts said placed the Christian Science Church on trial. ``The important thing is to send a message to other Christian Scientists,'' said Swan, who with her husband founded Children's Healthcare Is A Legal Duty, Inc. in 1983, after their child died of meningitis when the Christian Scientist couple relied on faith healing. ``Their church has lied and lied and lied to them,'' Swan said in an interview from Sioux City, Iowa, where CHILD is based. The Twitchells were accused of recklessly and wantonly causing Robyn's death by denying him conventional medical treatment. Trial testimony began May 4 with a jury tour of the Twitchell's former home in Boston and deliberations began Monday. The Twitchells now live in Brentwood, N.Y., with their two other children. David Twitchell testified at the trial. His wife did not. Prosecution witnesses described what Robyn might have felt during his last day, from agonizing pain to frequent vomiting. Medical experts also testified the boy's life could have been saved by medical intervention, almost up until the end. Klieman argued that though the Twitchells made a mistake in not calling in a doctor, their son did not appear to have a life-threatening illness. She also said the Twitchells were being persecuted in violation of Fist Amendment rights to freedom of religion. But Kiernan said parents have an obligation to protect their children and that they sacrificed their child for the sake of their beliefs. The case was built on testimony from medical experts, emergency personnel, Christian Science practitioners and former neighbors of the Twitchells. Among key issues were the severity of Robyn's symptoms, his time of death, his parents' actions in calling in Christian Science practitioners and whether the Christian Science Church allows medical treatment when prayer fails.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Continue As Germanies Merge Economies
DOC.TEXT: East German workers who have mounted warning strikes to press for higher wages and job security are only increasing the chances that their jobs will be eliminated, West Germany's economics minister says. The minister, Helmut Haussmann, said in an interview published today by the newspaper Die Welt that East German industry must become more productive before its workers can afford to make demands. ``In the next few weeks it will become clear who gets the upper hand psychologically _ whether it's those who bring hope, new jobs and a new way of life, or the fearful and maybe even the malevolent,'' he was quoted as saying. Lack of self-control on the salary front ``will lead straight to unemployment,'' Haussmann said. Brief warning strikes involving up to 30,000 people began Monday, the first work day after East and West Germany formally merged their economies, currencies and social welfare systems. The East German news agency ADN said several thousand metal and shipyard workers continued work stoppages on Wednesday at plants in northern East Germany. The workers are demanding more pay, better on-the-job training and a guarantee that they will keep their jobs for at least two years, ADN said. But there are few guarantees in the free market into which East Germany is now entering and economists have predicted that up to one third of the former Communist state's 8,000 businesses could fail. The experts say as many as half of East Germany's 8 million workers could lose their jobs under the pressure of competition from West Germany's powerful and productive companies. Haussmann said some of this week's strikes appeared to have been staged under ``remote control'' _ presumably from West Germany, whose powerful IG Metall union has been helping its East German branch recruit thousands of members in recent weeks. Amid the labor unrest, the East German Cabinet set Dec. 2 as the date for electing members to an all-German parliament, and West Germany's governing coalition gave its assent. East Germany's Parliament still must approve it, but that is unlikely to be an obstacle, because Prime Minister Lother de Maiziere's government has a parliamentary majority. Government sources said de Maiziere would insist that elections for the all-German parliament be kept separate from West German elections, even if they occur on the same day. The separation of the elections is an important issue because West German law requires political parties to win at least 5 percent of the vote to obtain parliamentary representation. There is no such law in East Germany, and some East German parties fear they would fail to reach the threshold if forced to compete in a single election in both countries. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said that if the 5 percent rule were applied in both countries but the ballots were tallied separately a party in West Germany would need 2 million votes for representation, while in East Germany only 575,000 would be needed. There are about 40 million eligible voters in West Germany, and approximately 12 million in East Germany. Immediately after the election, East Germany is expected to declare itself unified with West Germany under the West German Constitution. On Friday, Schaeuble and East German Parliament State Secretary Guenther Krause will begin talks in East Berlin on a second state treaty to iron out the constitutional and legal aspects of final unification.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's U.S. Visit Gave Boost to Civil Rights Movement
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's U.S. tour gave the American civil rights movement a glimpse of a hero at a time when it could use one, associates of the late Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. said. ``The visit of Mr. Mandela came at a time when the American people, not just black America, are hungry and thirsty for somebody who can lift us to another level,'' said longtime civil rights activist John Lewis, now a congressman. But while the heirs to King's civil rights legacy in his hometown of Atlanta emotionally embraced the South African leader last week, movement leaders and scholars say it would be unfair to expect him to rekindle the civil rights movement in this country. ``It's hard to me to see it having that effect simply because the economic and social problems within urban black America are so serious now and so much more serious than 1968'' when King was slain, said David J. Garrow, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of King. Mandela, the 71-year-old leader of the African National Congress, was jailed 27 years in a South African prison for plotting sabotage to overthrow the nation's white minority government. He was released in February. The anti-apartheid leader raised more than $7 million for the ANC and was greeted by enthusiastic crowds nearly everywhere he went during his eight-city, 11-day U.S. tour that ended Saturday. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the King-founded Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said Mandela's recent visit will have a lasting effect. ``I think Mr. Mandela's inspiration will spill over into several just causes related to the struggle for justice,'' Lowery said. ``It puts new life into the movement. He has done what we keep saying we are going to do when we say, `We shall overcome.''' Lewis, D-Ga., said it will take grass-roots activism to reignite the civil rights movement, but he called Mandela's visit ``a shot in the arm,'' citing the African leader's charisma and moral message. ``Some people say you don't need heroes, don't need leaders. I disagree,'' said Lewis, who was jailed 40 times between 1960 and 1966 for his civil rights activities. ``Every generation needs some individual, some flesh and blood embodiment of a cause or an idea.'' Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, known in the 1960s as militant protester H. Rap Brown, said Mandela is a ``legitimate champion among the people,'' but charged mainstream civil rights leaders used Mandela for their own ends. ``They would love to lend themselves to the energy that surrounds him, the aura that surrounds him. They are obsessed with raising money and they welcome any person or figure who would allow them to generate income,'' he said. Others said it is dangerous to focus on one person. Most American blacks are not looking for a leader to replace King, said Joseph Windham, a professor of African history at Atlanta's Morehouse College. ``You always have a group of people looking for a messiah, a great leader, a great image,'' Windham said. ``But I think the majority of people understand they have to identify with the movement, the liberation struggle. ... It's dangerous to focus on one particular individual because if something happens to them, the movement is decapitated.''

DOC.HEAD: Olive Ann Burns, Author of `Cold Sassy Tree,' Dies At Age 65
DOC.TEXT: Olive Ann Burns, whose battle with lymphoma prompted her to write the 1984 novel ``Cold Sassy Tree,'' has died at age 65. Ms. Burns had been ill with lymphoma since 1975, and was hospitalized for several weeks before her death Wednesday at Piedmont Hospital. The name of a mythical town, ``Cold Sassy Tree'' is about small-town life in north Georgia in 1906. It became a Book-of-the-Month Club alternate selection in 1984, and was made into a cable television movie in 1989. Ms. Burns had worked for Atlanta Weekly, a former Sunday magazine of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Ms. Burns later worked as a free-lance writer and advice columnist for The Atlanta Constitution. A memorial service was scheduled for Sunday. She is survived by a son, John A. Sparks of Colorado Springs, Colo.; a daughter, Becky Sparks of Atlanta; a brother, William H. Burns of Atlanta; and two sisters, Margaret Turn of Bushkill, Pa., and Jean LeGrand of Conyers.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Wednesday's Session of Party Congress
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of Wednesday's session of the 28th Communist Party congress, in its third day:

GORBACHEV'S DEADLINE: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, speaking to reporters outside the session, gives himself and the rest of the Communist leadership two years to improve citizens' lives or resign. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' he says.

MORE CRITICISM: Regional party officials accuse Gorbachev's leadership of cowardice and indecision, but the speakers themselves offer no new ideas and no alternative to re-electing him as party leader.

ECONOMIC REFORM: Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin defends the transition to a market-based economy as necessary ``if we want to be done with the shame of lines, speculation and closed stores.'' He says the Communist Party has no choice but to embrace the change: ``Any party or social organization that tries to hinder this process, try to go against the logic of social progress, will inevitably be pushed aside from the historical battle and meet defeat.

SIGN OF THE TIMES: One delegate, fed up with trying to get his name on the list of speakers, strides to the front of the hall and unfurls a sign reading, ``I ask for the floor. I have something to say.'' It is signed ``Master Koltsov.'' Despite his efforts, however, Koltsov is not given the floor and the sign is quickly removed.

DOC.HEAD: New Gunfire But Doe In Control; Rebels Say U.S. Delaying Doe Departure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with more gunfire today, rebel leader saying U.S. delaying Doe exile. Picks up 6th pvs `The city...'; SUBS 18th graf `But Thomas...' with to CONFORM. ___
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool report by journalists in Monrovia, including Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul.

Rebels are slowly advancing from suburb to suburb of this capital, where an atmosphere of fear and lawlessness prevails along with expectations President Samuel Doe will soon take flight. But this morning, though gunfire was being heard in some outlying areas of the city, Doe's forces remained in control. Christian radio station ELWA, monitored in neighboring Abidjan, said the city streets remained empty. The besieged Liberian leader met Wednesday with the U.S. ambassador, whose government has offered Doe safe passage. Doe has agreed in principle to resign, seeking assurances of safety for himself and members of his minority Krahn tribe. Most of Doe's Cabinet ministers and senior administration officials have fled the country. Rebel spokesman Thomas Woewiyu, who is based in the United States, accused the U.S. government of delaying Doe's exit. He said Wednesday that Washington opposes rebel leader Charles Taylor taking power himself. The United States has publicly supported an effort by several West African countries to negotiate an end to the war. The capital would be the final conquest for the rebels, who mounted their insurgency six months ago in the West African nation of 2.4 million people. The city of a half million people has been without water or electricity for the past week and plagued by shootings and lootings by army soldiers. At least 17 bodies were found Wednesday at different locations, some of them shot, witnesses said. U.S. Ambassador Peter De Vos drove under heavy U.S. Marine guard through streets of shuttered and barred shops to Doe's fortress-like mansion for about an hour of talks Wednesday. Officials declined to give details of their discussion. Washington put its naval task force, which includes 2,100 Marines, on alert off the Liberian coast. It has offered to evacuate Doe, but he has not asked to leave, the U.S. State Department has said. The rebels, who accuse Doe of corruption and human rights abuses, renewed their offensive after peace talks broke down last month. Soldiers at a roadblock in Monrovia said 1,000 rebels were advancing on the eastern suburb of Congo Town from Paynesville suburb, which echoed with artillery and gunfire Wednesday. Firing also could be heard on the city's western outskirts. Rebel sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said only 800 men were involved in the assault on the capital. Soldiers went on a spree of shooting and looting shops during a dusk-to-dawn curfew in Monrovia on Wednesday. The troops, some of whom appeared to be intoxicated, fired into the air and harassed passers-by for money and cigarettes. Others roamed the city in stolen cars and pickup trucks bristling with M-16 rifles. Doe has asked for assurances for his own safety and those of fellow Krahns if he does capitulate. But Woewiyu, who participated in the peace talks, said: ``There will not be any mass retribution. He (Doe) need not make that a bargaining point.'' The civil war has pitted the Krahns and Mandingos against the Gios and Manos, the tribes to which many rebels belong. A close Doe adviser, Elvin Jones, minister for presidential affairs, was the latest Cabinet member to leave the country. Jones flew to neighboring Ivory Coast on an unscheduled flight Wednesday. Liberia's army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Henry S. Dubar, who fled last weekend, told a newspaper in neighboring Sierra Leone: ``A general should know when to retreat. After counting the casualities and assessing the supplies, arms and ammunitions, a general must be able to decide whether to continue fighting or not. I saw our people without light, and drinking unsafe water. At that point I decided to ground arms.'' Residents said Doe has armed Krahns who fear that rebels will slaughter them. Two months ago, he emptied the prisons of criminals and conscripted them into his rapidly depleting army. Many soldiers are Krahns. One Gio said several of his Krahn friends had been given U.S.-made, M-16 rifles and army uniforms in the last few days. A reporter said he had met a Finance Ministry official, with no military training, who had also been given a uniform and a gun. Doe seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that toppled descendants of former slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Mayor Tries To Show Arab Areas Safe for Jews, Tourists
DOC.TEXT: Near the garden where the Romans arrested Jesus, Jerusalem's Jewish mayor sat unguarded in an Arab cafe to show fellow Israelis and tourists they are safe in the city's Arab section. Mayor Teddy Kollek's effort Wednesday to demonstrate it was business-as-usual in Arab east Jerusalem came amid the worst wave of political violence to hit the city since the Palestinian uprising began in Dec. 1987. ``I am trying to take the edge off the apprehension,'' Kollek said as he drank Arabic coffee at a small outside table in the tourist cafe near the Garden of Gethsemane. The 78-year old Kollek, sitting with his back to the narrow street and making business calls on a portable telephone, said he was not worried extremists might attack him. ``I never have guards,'' he said. Other politicians rarely go to east Jerusalem without armed security men, and the main Arab shopping streets are heavily patrolled by police. The cafe Kollek visited was empty except for one Palestinian who stopped to see the mayor about a problem. Few Israelis go to east Jerusalem because of the violence of the uprising. Two weeks ago, police placed a curfew on a nearby Arab neighborhood after two Palestinians were killed by police during anti-Israeli rioting. Curfews are rare in Jerusalem, which has been calmer than the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Of the 721 Palestinians killed in clashes with Israelis during the uprising, seven died in Jerusalem. Six of the 45 Israeli victims were slain in the city. Kollek's well-publicized campaign to dispel fear began Monday in a cafe near the Old City's Damascus Gate, where more than a half-dozen Jews have been stabbed in the past two years. Lately, violence also has spread to Jewish sections of Jerusalem. One Israeli was killed and more than 14 wounded in three pipe bombings in the past month. Jews rioted in response to the stabbing of an 11-year-old boy and persistent Arab stoning of cars. Jerusalem is home to some 120,000 Palestinians and 354,000 Jews, 120,000 of whom live in neighborhoods built in the eastern sector after it was captured in the 1967 Middle East war and annexed by Israel. Kollek, mayor since 1965, enjoys considerable support from both communities. He is seen by many Arabs as a political moderate who does not discriminate against the city's Arab minority. ``We like Mr. Kollek,'' said Khaled Ansari, the Palestinian who runs the cafe where Kollek set up shop Wednesday.``He has done good things for us.'' Kollek, visibly uncomfortable in the hot Middle Eastern sun, said he would probably have to limit the hours spent in Arab neighborhoods in his confidence-building campaign. ``I get much more work done in my office,'' he explained.

DOC.HEAD: First Court Award for Women Over Discrimination in Promotions
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese court has ruled for the first time that female workers were denied promotions due to sex discrimination, awarding 18 women a total of $640,000 in lost wages. The lawsuit, which took 10 years to wend its way through the court system, was filed by women who worked for a semi-governmental medical insurance fund. ``This is an epoch-making ruling that will lead to making other corporations review their labor practices,'' said Eiko Shinotsuka, a labor economist at Tokyo's Ochanomizu Women's University. ``There are many other Japanese companies discriminating against females,'' she said after Wednesday's ruling. In addition to the $733,000 requested in the lawsuit, the plaintiffs asked that the women be given promotions allegedly denied on the basis of sex. The court refused, saying that it could not direct such personnel decisions. The women employees of the Social Insurance Medical Fee Payment Fund charged that fund agreements in 1978 to provide raises and promotions for only male employees violated Japanese law. Women comprised about half of the fund's total 6,300 workers. The Tokyo District Court said promoting the male employees while excluding their female colleagues constituted sex discrimination. It awarded $640,000 in lost wages that the women would have received if promoted, court officials said today. ``It was a long fight,'' said Yoko Tsuji, one of the 18 plaintiffs. ``I'm very happy if this ruling will help other women victimized by discrimination,'' she told the newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun. Japan's Constitution forbids discrimination based on sex, and its labor laws require equal treatment where salaries are concerned. In another development, female members of Parliament on Wednesday protested the appointment of a man as the new head of the Women's Bureau, a division of the Labor Ministry. Hyakutaro Takahashi will be the first man to occupy the post since the bureau was established in 1945. Although women's voices are increasingly being heard in government, Japan's women's movement is small. The nation's first sexual harassment case was filed only last year, but since then the number of such complaints has ballooned.

DOC.HEAD: Former National Poster Child Takes to Scuba Diving
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Rush walks underwater and can even jump and do a flip. That's not bad for the 1984-85 Muscular Dystrophy national poster child who's had to use a wheelchair for most of his 13 years. Christopher is taking scuba diving lessons along with his parents and 6-year-old sister, Julie, in suburban Detroit. ``It's the first time I've ever been able to walk or jump. I can walk underwater and jump and do a loop-the-loop,'' Christopher said in a recent interview. ``I think my legs have even stretched.'' It all began when Christopher and his dad, Richard, watched a scuba diving program on cable television. A friend of the family suggested lessons with Jerry Rowe at the Michigan Underwater School of Diving in Lincoln Park. ``Jerry Rowe is a great inspiration. He's very patient. I'll say, `I can't do it.' Then he'll say, `I don't want to hear that.' Then he's so good to me. If it's too uncomfortable, we'll stop,'' Christopher said. Rowe said he was a bit apprehensive at the start, partly because of concern that Christopher might have trouble holding the mouthpiece in place underwater. ``I remember when I first met Chris. I patted him on the head and his head dropped to the side. I felt terrible,'' Rowe said. But exercises in the pool and at home improved his bite after a few lessons. Local television anchorman Joe Glover, Christopher's pen pal and the Detroit host of the annual Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, said he's seen tremendous improvement in the teen-ager in the few weeks of scuba training. Christopher's scuba adventures with the anchorman will be filmed as a documentary for WJBK. Some of the scenes may be used for the national telethon. When the lessons end this summer, Christopher hopes to earn his certification in style on a diving trip to the Grand Cayman islands in the Caribbean. ``I just can't wait to see how excited Chris will be diving in salt water. It's just overwhelming,'' said Kim Shearouse, a seasoned scuba diver, who watched from poolside. ``He's just going to love it.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Abroad Send For Big Macs And California Bubbly
DOC.TEXT: Americans celebrating Independence Day abroad dined on Big Macs in Beijing, sipped California bubbly in Moscow or guzzled beer in Frankfurt. Even Britain's famed Harrod's department store honored the ``colonies'' with a festive sale. But in the Philippines, home to 40,000 U.S. soldiers and their dependents, anti-American protesters burned the Stars and Stripes on Wednesday. About 900 Americans showed up to a party at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, serenaded by country music. A crew from McDonald's in Hong Kong prepared the coveted burgers and fries in a tradition begun in 1983. Tickets this year were limited. In the past, the event was an elaborate daylong block party open to all, complete with children's parades, dragon dances, Chinese acrobatics and firecrackers. Last year, however, the embassy held only a small ceremony for its personnel. Nearly all Americans in Beijing had fled following the June 3-4 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. The event was a bit cheerier this year, with the addition of a barbershop quartet and a band called ``The Back Door'' _ a reference to the Chinese practice of using personal relationships to get special favors. The band is made up mostly of embassy personnel. In Moscow, curious Soviets gathered outside the gates of Spaso House, the residence of U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock, watching guests arrive at the annual Fourth of July reception. Guests mingled on the lawn in hazy sunshine, enjoying California champagne and hors d'oeuvres. Yevgeny Primakov, a member of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Presidential Council advisory group and non-voting member of the Politburo, arrived in his Zil limousine and chatted privately with Matlock on the balcony. Dignitaries included Yelena Bonner, widow of dissident Andrei D. Sakharov; members of the Supreme Soviet legislature; and dozens of ambassadors and military attaches in dress uniform. Several American musicians taking part in the Tchaikovsky competition also were present. A huge American flag was draped from the second story of Matlock's residence. The flag did not fare so well in the Philippines, where about 500 militants protesting U.S. bases in the country burned a flag in front of the embassy to mark July 4 _ which is also Philippines-American Friendship Day. About 100 riot police stood guard, but there were no clashes. ``What festivities should we celebrate?'' the militants said in a statement. ``In fact, we are the ones being feasted on ... by American imperialism.'' The United States ruled the Philippines for nearly 50 years before independence on July 4, 1946. In London, that very British of institutions, Harrods department store, kicked off its annual summer sale with an American bang. Actor John Forsythe _ Blake Carrington of TV's ``Dynasty'' show _ greeted shoppers outside the store accompanied by baton-twirling majorettes, a 100-piece Dixieland band and an Uncle Sam on stilts. In West Germany, where a quarter million U.S. military personnel live along with their families, celebrations were held at Frankfurt's East Park carnival grounds, and included amusement park rides, an old-fashioned rodeo, and traditional German beer and wurst. In Paris, groundbreaking ceremonies were held for a multimillion-dollar American Center on the eastern edge of the city. Designed by architect Frank O. Gehry of Santa Barbara, Calif., it will be the biggest cultural center in Paris, Mayor Jacques Chirac told guests. Despite cool, damp and windy weather, highwire artist Philip Petit inched across a cable above the crowd, attaching a giant paint brush and musical key to a red velvet theater curtain adorned with thespian masks. In Bahrain, the U.S. community highlighted its July 4 celebrations by inaugurating a $19 million fortress-like embassy compound. Ambassador Charles Hostler escorted the emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa Bin Salman Al Khalifa, to a brief ceremony. Five-year-old Joshua-Barney Burgess of Merritt Island, Fla., presented the emir with scissors to cut the ribbon.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Has A Job For You
DOC.TEXT: The government is recruiting workers to help clean up radioactive contamination at its nuclear weapons plants over the next 30 years. The Department of Energy said it will take 50 percent more money and twice as many people as previously estimated to carry out a five-year cleanup plan at the waste sites. ``We've got to convince the people in the colleges to go and look at this as the career of the future. ... It's an exciting career, an interesting career, one that is involved with new technology,'' Leo Duffy, head of DOE's cleanup office, said in a recent interview. He said there are at least 20,000 job openings over the next 30 years in the field and an annual budget in billions of dollars. As the department tries to lure workers into the field, Duffy said it will face the same image problems it faces every day. ``Technology does not always interest every man and woman,'' he said. ``Distrust in Department of Energy past practices is a problem. The fact you've got radioactivity is a major problem,'' Duffy said the lack of scientists and adequate technology are the biggest hurdles to cleaning up weapons plants that have dumped high-level radioactivity into the soil and water.
DOC.HEAD: President Declares Parts of Nebraska Disaster Area
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has declared parts of Nebraska a major disaster area because of the severe storms, tornadoes and flooding that struck the state last month. The declaration, issued Wednesday, makes federal funds available for the recovery effort in a 14-county area. The counties are: Buffalo, Colfax, Dodge, Douglas, Gage, Hitchcock, Madison, Platte, Red Willow, Sharpy, Sherman, Stanton, Thurston and Washington. The federal aid includes temporary housing, grants, low-cost loans and other help for both individuals and business owners. The government also normally pays up to 75 percent of the costs of repairing or replacing damaged public facilities. The severe weather struck the state beginning June 10. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is still surveying other areas of the state to determine whether the disaster declaration should be extended to other counties. Edward A. Thomas of FEMA's Boston regional office was named to coordinate federal recovery operations.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go.'' _ Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, giving himself a deadline for reversing the country's economic and political downslide during the third day of the Communist Party's 28th Congress.

``To say it's the hottest item we've had is an understatement. He's the hottest thing I've seen in 10 years.'' _ Chris Nilan, sales manager for Nilan's Alley Inc., which sells novelty items to stores throughout the Southeast.

``This has been a prosecution against our faith.'' _ Christian Scientist David Twitchell, after he and his wife were found guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the 1986 death of their 2{-year-old son, who suffered a bowel obstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Architect of Japan's Industrial Dynamo Says It's Time to Gear Down
DOC.TEXT: The government ministry that helped engineer Japan's export-fueled economic boom says the global powerhouse must now turn inward and set its own house in order. Funding priorities, once almost exclusively targeted to industrial growth, should shift to the nation's frayed infrastructure and frustrated consumers, says the an advisory report approved today by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. While short on specifics, the ministry's vision for the 1990s addresses many of the demands for economic reform made by the United States in talks that led to last month's agreement on ways to tackle the U.S. trade deficit with Japan. These include a push for more spending at home on public works such as roads, sewers and parks _ ``areas in which Japan lags behind other major developed nations,'' a summary of the report said. The report also repeatedly urges that Japan make life easier for its high-paying consumers, who should have ``the opportunity to choose what to purchase and the chance to decide what price to pay.'' It was an oblique admission that prices have been kept artificially high by government-protected home markets, where the staple food, rice, costs several times more than on world markets. The ministry's criticism seems to contradict its own annual white paper, issued two weeks ago, which concluded that the high trade surplus with the United States was caused by natural factors, not closed markets. The report also warns, however, that manufacturing is still vital to Japan's economy. It recommends that the government nearly double funding of research and development to about 1 percent of gross national product. Kunio Morikiyo, director of the ministry's Policy Planning Office, denied at a news briefing that the push for internal reform was a response to the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative talks with the United States. Nonetheless, the report echoes policy guidelines issued in May by a panel of bureaucrats and lawmakers from the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Those guidelines also were believed to reflect Japan's eagerness to resolve the unremitting trade dispute between the world's two most powerful economies. ``Internal reform is a must,'' Morikiyo said, if Japan is to avert a worsening of economic friction between Western countries, particularly in the vacuum left by the disintegration of the Communist East bloc. ``It is extremely urgent that Japan find solutions to these problems during the current decade, while it still has a strong investment capacity,'' the report says. Among other key recommendations of the report, MITI says Japan should: _Increase the housing supply by solving the ``the expanding bubble of land prices;'' Property tax reform and zoning changes have been proposed as solutions. _Take the lead in protecting the global environment, particularly by reducing the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere; _Reduce working hours to 1,800 a year from 2,076 in 1989, despite the difficulty caused by a tight labor market; _Advance the position of women by ``building a social framework that enables men and women to cooperate and share domestic tasks . .. that until now have fallen mostly on women.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Midwest; Violent Storms in New York State
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms moved across parts of the Midwest early today, and lightning storms knocked out power in upstate New York. Temperatures cooled overnight in the Plains and Midwest, where record highs were set on the Fourth of July. Northern Texas today was again likely to see temperatures soar past 100 degrees, the National Weather Service said. Temperatures over 100 degrees also were expected in western Tennessee. Thunderstorms crossed the Maine coastline early today, and rain fell in northern New Mexico and Portland, Ore. Showers and thunderstorms were likely today along the eastern flank of the Rockies. Storms also were expected to develop along a cool front stretching from the central Plains through the Mississippi Valley and lower Ohio Valley. Power outages were reported across a four-county region in upstate New York early today after a violent lightning storm. Storms dumped as much as 2 inches of rain in the Saranac Lake area Wednesday during a three-hour period. More than 2 inches of rain fell in two hours period and caused minor washouts at Cambridge and Jeffersonville, Vt. As much as 3{ inches of rain washed out dirt roads near Worcester, Va. The high temperature Wednesday in the Lower 48 states was 110 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., Lake Havasu City, Ariz., and Laughlin, Nev. DOC.HEAD: Congress, President Move in Two Directions on Family Legislation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 12th graf ``Bush has xxx to CORRECT million to billion
DOC.TEXT: Once again the White House and Congress are at odds over how to protect a revered American institution. First it was the American flag. Now, it's the American family. Congress passed legislation requiring employers to grant parents up to three months of unpaid leave for medical emergencies or the birth or adoption of a child. Bush vetoed the bill, saying the measure forces businesses to provide a benefit that they should be free to negotiate with employees. ``If our nation's employers are to succeed in an increasingly complex and competitive global marketplace, they must have the flexibility to meet both this challenge and the needs of their employees,'' he said. The dispute over family leave could lead to partisan bickering over an institution every bit as revered as the flag. Bush sought a constitutional amendment against burning the flag but Congress last month rejected it as an infringement on freedom of speech. In the case of the family leave bill, veto override prospects are uncertain at best. The House passed the family care legislation in May, just before Mother's Day, by a 237-187 vote. That's 46 votes shy of the two-thirds majority needed to override a presidential veto. The Senate passed the measure on a voice vote on June 14. But according to Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., a substantive test vote on the issue came out 55-45 in favor, or a dozen votes shy of the needed two-thirds majority. ``The President is going to have this bill on his desk every year. He's going to have to veto a family and medical leave bill one way or another,'' Dodd says, almost angrily. ``I'm going to serve this legislation up to him. He's going to have to explain and explain and explain as the situation gets worse out there.'' Meanwhile, a congressional turf fight, along with a possible veto threatens a landmark child care measure. Among the disagreements are whether Congress, as Dodd proposes, would review the child care aid program every year or whether, as the House favors, the aid should become an entitlement that would automatically roll over every year. Bush has said he will veto any child care measure that spends more than $15 billion over five years. Both House and Senate versions exceed Bush's limit. In some ways the strengths of the two bills are also their weaknesses, according to some observers and participants. They concern the needs of two-income families and single mothers forced by economics into the workforce. Only one American family in 10 consists of a working father and a stay-at-home mother. More than half of all mothers of infants work outside the home. And by 1995 two-thirds of all preschool children will have mothers working full time outside the home. Conservatives support family leave because it promotes the idea of a mother being home _ at least temporarily _ with her child. Yet some, including the president, say the bill intrudes on the right of businesses to set their own employee policies. Family leave has won some support from anti-abortion activists such as Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. ``He's consistent with his pro-family posture,'' said Donna Lenhoff of the Women's Legal Defense Fund, which supported the family leave bill. ``It's difficult to tell a woman to carry a child to term and then lose her job.'' Child care has run into opposition from fiscal conservatives who don't want to create another government entitlement program for the poor. Ideological conservatives object to the implication that the government favors working mothers over those who stay at home. That both bills are in Congress simultaneously also has been a disadvantage, according to some. Child care ``is stalled for good reason. It created two new entitlements at tremendous cost and it helps only a small fraction of the population,'' said Rep. Marge Roukema, R-N.J., a leading House backer of family leave. ``The family and medical leave bill is far more consistent with the family values that Republicans have talked about over the campaign period.'' Family leave, Dodd said, ``is a matter of human decency,'' much in the way the federally mandated 40-hour work week was deemed a matter of human decency decades ago. Child care, he said, addresses an obvious human need. Added Lenhoff: ``Child care is what you need when everything's normal _ you're going to work and you need help caring for your kids. Family and medical leave is what you need when you can't go back to work.''

DOC.HEAD: Harley ``Ace'' Tinkham Dead at 67
DOC.TEXT: Harley ``Ace'' Tinkham, a Los Angeles Times sports columnist known for his anecdotes and knowledge of statistics, has died at age 67. Tinkham died Wednesday morning at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank of complications from pneumonia. He had suffered respiratory problems for several years. He wrote the Morning Briefing column of offbeat observations and statistics, as well as sports trivia and colorful anecdotes. Tinkham's last Morning Briefing appeared June 8. In 1950, Tinkham joined the Los Angeles Mirror, which was absorbed by the Times in 1962. He then went to work at the Los Angeles Herald Examiner but returned to the Times in 1968, covering track and field. In memory of Tinkham, the Times did not run a Morning Briefing today. He is survived by his wife, Ena; a daughter, Michele; a son, Christopher, and a sister, Helen Argast.

DOC.HEAD: West Approves Aid to East European Countries
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs, recasting to present forward-looking angle and move up references to aid for Eastern European countries, except Romania.
DOC.TEXT: Western nations are pushing forward with financial help for economically-stricken Eastern European nations while stopping short of embracing similar relief for the Soviet Union. Foreign ministers of two-dozen Western nations agreed Wednesday to extend to Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and East Germany an assistance program initially set up to help Poland and Hungary. They refused to include Romania because of recent violent repression of protesters there. No specific dollar numbers were committed in the discussions here. The Western nations previously had pledged more than $12 billion in food, economic and environmental assistance to Poland and Hungary. ``This was not a pledging session,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The foreign ministers ducked the troublesome question of direct economic assistance to the Kremlin, however. In their final statement, they discussed the situation there and merely ``underlined their interest in positive developments'' toward a democracy and a free-market economy. The issue of aid to the Kremlin, which pits the United States for the most part against West Germany and France, was expected to surface at the summit of NATO leaders opening today in London. It also was likely to dominate next week's economic talks in Houston among President Bush and the chiefs of six other leading industrialized nations. In recent weeks, West Germany has urged its allies to quickly fashion a $15 billion to $20 billion aid package to support Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's beleaguered perestroika program of economic reforms. ``We cannot expect the Soviet Union to resolve problems regarding the transition to a market economy on their own,'' West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told reporters in Brussels. He said the Kremlin badly needs financial help and advice. ``It is in the common Western interest to give this support to the Soviet Union because a deterioration of the situation (there) will put Gorbachev off course and in danger,'' Genscher said. But Baker said the United States has ``some difficulties'' with the idea of giving economic aid to Moscow with no strings attached. ``We think that the absence of real progress toward a market economy in the Soviet Union argues against the provision of assistance at this time,'' Baker said at a news conference. He also said the Kremlin was spending as much as a quarter of its economic output on the military. ``We have to ask ourselves the question _ why not get some of that money from those sources,'' Baker said. Even so, he said, the United States wants to see Gorbachev's programs work. ``A reformed Soviet Union is a more open and more stable and therefore more secure Soviet Union and that's in the best interests of ... the West in general,'' Baker said. Gorbachev has not formally asked for Western help. But the issue of Western aid has become linked to efforts to win Gorbachev's backing for immediate and full membership of a united Germany in the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Western hope is that with a massive aid program, the Kremlin leader would drop his objections. West Germany belongs to the NATO military alliance, but East Germany is part of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Leaders of the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, recently agreed in principle to provide assistance to Gorbachev but rejected Franco-German calls for immediate help. The leaders asked aides to consult with the Kremlin about proposals for short-term loans and longer term assistance. The foreign ministers, at their meeting Wednesday on aid for Eastern Europe, asked to take a look at the community's work when it was completed. human rights. Speaking of the ministers' refusal to include Romania in aid plans, Baker said the actions of leaders there raise ``serious questions about (the government's) commitment to democratic reform and basic human rights.'' Frans Andriessen, the European Community's top foreign affairs official, said the nations would like to help Romania when conditions improve. ``This is not an attempt to isolate,'' he said. ``The door is (still) open.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Told Her Baby Was Dead But Finds Out He's Alive
DOC.TEXT: A woman was mistakenly told her newborn baby had died in a hospital and discovered three days later her son was still alive, hospital officials said. Juanita Ayala of Middletown gave birth by Caesarean section June 28 at Horton Memorial Hospital. Her baby was ill and was taken to Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla while Ayala recovered at Horton. On Sunday, Ayala was told her baby had died. On Tuesday, the day the child's obituary appeared in a local newspaper, a Westchester doctor called to tell her the baby was alive. ``When they told her the baby died, she was very shaken up,'' said Wanda Leon, Ayala's 13-year-old niece. ``Then, when they told her the baby was still alive, she was very angry, because they lied to her.'' Ayala, who has three other children, speaks only Spanish. The baby, Luis Miguel Ayala, was in critical condition at the Westchester hospital. Horton spokeswoman Candice Groudin said a Westchester doctor told the nurse in charge of Horton's obstetrical unit that the baby had died. Westchester spokesman Barry Bowman said it was unlikely the information came from Westchester.

DOC.HEAD: Dodger Stadium Exempt From Anti-Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: Dodger Stadium will be spared tonight's planned aerial pesticide spraying against the Medfly _ and that has activists angry. ``It's absolutely unreal,'' said former Monterey Park Mayor Patricia Reichenberger. ``Here are thousands of people complaining about spraying and out of the blue they exempt Dodger Stadium.'' Helicopters dropping malathion-laced syrup on a 14-square-mile area will avoid the ball park because it lacks the fruit trees that lure Mediterranean fruit flies, said County Agricultural Commissioner E. Leon Spaugy. ``There's nothing at the stadium but blacktop,'' Spaugy said. ``It's just a big area, with a big parking lot with no host trees.'' During the 11-month Medfly infestation, agriculture officials also have exempted the Crystal Cathedral in Orange County, areas of Riverside County that are home to the endangered kangaroo rat, and city reservoirs. The downtown area will be sprayed at least three times, agriculture officials said. The spraying was ordered after a Medfly was found recently in the area. The flies, which can turn fruit to mush, are disastrous in the state's multibillion-dollar agriculture industry. Opponents contend not enough is known about malathion's long-term health effects. State officials say the pesticide is safe.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Pays for Postmasters Letters Defending Rate Increase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead and grafs 10, The Postal Service, and 16, The same letter, to CORRECT BY deleting reference to taxpayers.
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service footed the cost when hundreds of postmasters mailed letters to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce defending a proposed increase in postal rates. For a week, the chamber's Washington office has been getting 100 letters a day from postmasters and other postal employees in the Midwest and Western states, the organization says. About half the letters are in envelopes marked ``Official Business,'' which carry a penalty for private use. A few dozen contain form letters. Chamber officials object. ``It's wrong for people on the government payroll to be using government time and resources to lobby,'' said Tracey Schreft of the chamber's Small Business Center. But the Postal Service says the letters were official business and were needed to combat a chamber-published brochure against the proposed new 30-cent stamp. Titled ``Cancel This Stamp,'' the brochure invites the chamber's member businesses to battle the rate increase and ``join the fight against waste in the Postal Service.'' The brochure contains ``inaccuracies and distortions intended to discredit the great job we're doing,'' said Jim Mruk, a Chicago-based Postal Service spokesman. ``We feel the use of the penalty envelope is warranted,'' Mruk said. ``This is part of the normal course of doing business. We have no apologies for it at all.'' The independent Postal Rate Commission has until early next year to review the agency's rate increase plan. A first-class stamp would go from 25 cents to 30 cents, post cards from 15 cents to 20 cents, and the cost of sending a seven-pound package would rise from $4 to $5.06. The Postal Service says it does not know how much the postmasters' letters cost because it is uncertain how many were sent. Mruk said there was no ``organized effort to lobby the chamber.'' Rather, he said, the Central Region's postmaster general wrote the chamber about the brochure and sent copies to medium-level managers ``who shared them with postmasters.'' All the letters are from the Postal Service's central region, which includes Colorado, Wyoming, the Dakotas, Minnesota, Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Missouri. ``As an employee who works closely with the community and the Chamber of Commerce, I must complain strongly and bitterly against the article being disseminated from your office entitled `Cancel This Stamp','' began a letter from postmaster Cecelia White of Ada, Kan. The letter criticizes the brochure for alleged inaccuracies, and for soliciting Postal Service ``horror stories'' from businesses. The same letter arrived from postmasters in Partridge, Redfield and other Kansas communities. All were in officials envelopes instead of bearing stamps. In an interview, White she did not think about paying for the letter herself. ``We're willing to put stamps on some things. I didn't think they told us to put a stamp on this,'' she said. A letter from postmaster Robert J. Herman said: ``I am going to tell the business community of Raymond, Ill., the truth about the requested postage rate increase by the United States Postal Service _ the best postal system in the world!'' Last month, the Postal Service withdrew a $21,000 advertisement from a chamber magazine following stories critical of the rate hike plan.

DOC.SECOND: PM-2 Live Crew-Review, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0416,0493
DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Waves the Flag: A Review of New Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `This is...' with 2 grafs to fix garble. Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: ``Banned in the U.S.A.,'' the new single from 2 Live Crew, sounds like a newsletter from the American Civil Liberties Union _ with a beat, of course. The rappers quote lyrics from ``The Star-Spangled Banner.'' They quote the Gettysburg Address. They even quote Bruce Springsteen. But there are no dirty words _ and no apologies _ on ``Banned in the U.S.A,'' which arrived in record stores Wednesday. ``We have the right to say what we want to say,'' chants group leader Luther Campbell. ``We have the right to do what we want to do. We have freedom of expression. We have the freedom of choice. You have the right to listen to whoever you want to.'' This is 2 Live Crew's first new record since last month's arrest in Hollywood, Fla., for performing songs from the million-selling ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which a federal judge ruled obscene. Since then, their lyrics have made rock critics out of everyone from district attorneys to undercover cops to Phil Donahue, and have received more scrutiny than President Bush's annual budget message. Musically, the record is a weak lift of Springsteen's ``Born in the U.S.A.'' _ borrowed with his permission. But lyrically, coming from a group arrested by more than a dozen sheriff's detectives, it offers a neat, PG-rated lesson about racism, politics and the First Amendment. In fact, a classroom might be the ideal place to hear it. On ``Banned in the U.S.A.,'' 2 Live Crew's four-letter words are ``land'' and ``free,'' and soundbites are heard from ``America the Beautiful'' and the evening news. ``Is this not America?'' Campbell asks. ``This is not China. This is not Russia. This is not the place where they brought down the wall.'' So on Independence Day, 2 Live Crew comes not to burn the flag, but to wave it, flashing the peace sign to right-wingers and left-wingers alike, and warning politicians to ``wise up 'cause on Election Day, you'll be banned in the U.S.A.'' The rappers produced the single on their own Luke Records, a Florida-based independent, but are being distributed by a major label, Atlantic Records, for the first time. ``Like many Americans, I was shocked to see in the news media those disturbing scenes of a black musical artist being arrested and placed in the back seat of a police car for the `crime' of performing before an adult audience,'' Doug Morris, president and chief operating officer of Atlantic Records, said in a recent statement. In the same statement, Campbell praises the agreement with Atlantic as ``a very positive message to send when a controversial independent label can join forces with a major such as Atlantic.''

DOC.HEAD: 400 Treated for Heat Exhaustion, Hyperventilation Before New Kids Concert
DOC.TEXT: About 400 children were treated for heat exhaustion and hyperventilation after waiting for hours in the sun to see the group the New Kids on the Block. An estimated 35,000 youngsters streamed onto Harriet Island for a concert Wednesday. Many waited more than eight hours with little food and drink in hopes of getting a good view of the popular performers. Police estimate that about 4,000 teen-agers entered the gates at 11 a.m., and about 20,000 had arrived by 3 p.m. Opening groups began playing for the crowd at 7 p.m., and the New Kids took the stage at 9:30 p.m. Although the temperature was only in the upper 70s, the crowded conditions apparently contributed to the problem. ``It was so hot out there, and the only time you could breathe fresh air was when a breeze blew over. It was so crowded,'' said Angela Frank, 15, of Cloquet, who was treated at a Red Cross tent. Terri Nelson, who worked as coordinator of the Red Cross tent, said there was a steady flow of visitors. Five people required hospitalization, authorities said. ``We've had no major incidents except heat exhaustion,'' said Lt. Richard Jardell during the concert. The city brought 10,000 pounds of ice to the concert and distributed it to the crowd, he said. The five New Kids are known for their tightly choreographed shows and their rabid teen-age following. Among the group's hits is the current No. 1 single and album, ``Step by Step.''

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Dissolves Regional Parliament in Kosovo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New Thruout to UPDATE with background; No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Yugoslavia's largest republic today dissolved the local legislature and government in its troubled southern province of Kosovo, the state news agency Tanjug reported. The move by the republic of Serbia is likely to cause more unrest by the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo, the nation's least developed region. The decision by all three chambers of the Serbian parliament came in the wake of Monday's declaration by 114 ethnic Albanian deputies in Kosovo's provincial assembly to secede from Serbia, Belgrade television said. The document proclaimed Kosovo equal in status to Yugoslavia's republics and declared that ethnic Albanians, the third-largest ethnic group in the country, would no longer be considered a minority. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two nominally autonomous provinces. Kosovo, a province of 1.9 million, 90 percent of whom are ethnic Albanian, has progressively lost control of its affairs to Serbia. The decision to dissolve Kosovo's 188-member legislature and the local government of Premier Jusuf Zeinulahu was read to deputies during Thursday's assembly session, according to journalists in the provincial capital, Pristina. Delegates were informed that all elected officials in the regional government were suspended. Ethnic Albanians seek restoration of the broader autonomy they enjoyed under a 1974 constitution that was amended in March 1989. Serbs, who consider Kosovo the cradle of their medieval kingdom, claimed that ethnic Albanians were pressuring the remaining Slavs to move out of the province. Since the constitution was amended, about 60 ethnic Albanians have been killed in clashes with security forces. Ethnic Albanians, who have been demanding free elections and a multiparty system, deny they discriminate against Slavs in their province. They say that claim has been used by Serbia's Communist leader, Slobodan Milosevic, to gain popular support for his hard-line policies. Serbia's Communist leadership is proposing a new state constitution that would effectively remove any vestige of self-government enjoyed by its southern province. The elimination of Kosovo's parliament under a new constitution would make ethnic Albanians a small minority in the Serbian parliament. ``The decision to dissolve the regional parliament is an illegal one and the Albanian people will not recognize it,'' said Ibrahim Rugova, leader of the Democratic Forum, an ethnic Albanian group that claims 500,000 members. ``Serbia currently does not have any constitutional right to do such a thing,'' he said, adding that the Forum would call on ethnic Albanians to remain calm ``in the face of this provocation.'' ``Both the parliament and the government should continue to function normally, because (ethnic Albanians) have the majority,'' he said. Serbian authorities also announced they were imposing unspecified ``extraordinary measures'' on Pristina's radio and television, as well as in the local telecommunications company, Tanjug reported. It said the measures, which appear designed to give Serbia full control over the media, will also extend to the Albanian-language Rilindia publishing house, Kosovo's largest. Meanwhile, results of a referendum held Sunday and Monday in Serbia on whether to hold multiparty elections before adopting a new constitution, showed 96.8 percent of the population voted for the government proposal to delay a free ballot. The results of the vote, in which some three-quarters of Serbia's 6.7 million registered voters took part, were released Thursday. Opposition parties, which demanded that elections be held before enactment of a new constitution, had called on supporters to boycott the referendum. Yugoslavia's northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia increasingly have sided with Kosovo in its drive for autonomy from Serbia. This spring, the republics held their first free elections in 45 years for local legislatures. Both votes were won by center-right parties, which trounced the Communist parties that called the elections. Yugoslavia's other three republics are scheduled to hold free elections later this year. And on Monday, Slovenia's Parliament proclaimed the state's full sovereignty. The declaration provides for an independent legal system that would take precedence over federal laws, and for Slovenian control of armed forces stationed in the republic. Slovenia, the most prosperous of Yugoslavia's republics, contains 2 million of the country's 23 million population. The republic's new authorities demand that Yugoslavia become a loose confederation of sovereign states. But the Communist government of Serbia vehemently opposes turning Yugoslavia into a confederation. Serbia also rejects Western-style democracy for Yugoslavia, created in 1918.

DOC.HEAD: Last Night for Homeless Outside S.F.'s City Hall
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Critics had ...' with four grafs to include protest in Santa Cruz, add Agnos party affiliation.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 100 homeless people early today spent what may be their last night sleeping in a plaza outside City Hall. Starting tonight, police are under Mayor Art Agnos' orders to arrest homeless who sleep in public places. ``It ain't going to work,'' said Butch, a two-and-a-half year resident of Civic Center Plaza, where the homeless were spread out in sleeping bags, tents or just a few blankets. ``They're just going to go somewhere else.'' Butch, who would not give his last name, moved out of the plaza four months ago. But he said he's thinking about moving right back. ``I pay rent now _ I pay $225 a month. For what? A roach-infested, rat-infested room,'' he said. Many homeless complain about the poor conditions of the shelters and other housing alternatives offered to them. City officials defend their plan as a new approach to serving the homeless by offering them a way to rejoin society. ``It's a start,'' Agnos said this week. ``The idea is to move these people out of the parks, out of being homeless and into transitional and permanent housing.'' In Santa Cruz, homeless activists from around the state squared off with angry residents on Independence Day over the issue of whether freedom extends to allowing people to sleep in public parks. About 200 homeless activists, rallying outside the Santa Cruz County Courthouse, demanded an end to the city's camping ban, saying people should be allowed to sleep where they can. The activists were outnumbered by about 600 counterdemonstrators who said they were tired of giving Santa Cruz's ``bums'' and ``squatters'' a free ride in the seaside town about 75 miles south of San Francisco. Critics in San Francisco had accused Agnos, a liberal Democrat, of waffling on the homelessness issue for years. He was torn for the last two years between a campaign promise to clean up the plaza and a vow to not break up the sprawling encampment until a viable alternative was available. This week, the city took over two comprehensive service shelters. More than 150 people have moved into them. But those still in the plaza and advocates of the homeless remain critical of the mayor's plan. ``This is unconscionable cruelty put on the victims of society for the sake of window dressing,'' said Tom Osher of Food Not Bombs, an organization that has been feeding the homeless in the plaza since last July. ``The net effect (of the eviction notice) is that it does absolutely nothing,'' Osher said. ``Everybody is just going to move.'' Many of the homeless who stayed at the plaza were not sure what they would do once the deadline arrives. Asked where they would go, many shrugged their shoulders and murmured ``somewhere else.'' On Monday, outreach workers began encouraging the Civic Center's homeless to report a municipal office that would give them an alternative to life on the streets. By Tuesday, 82 people had reported to the office, and 64 men were sent to a new shelter nine blocks from the Civic Center. But homeless advocates charge that the ``cleanup'' program will force 215 people already staying in a shelter out on the streets to make way for the displaced Civic Center homeless. The new policy also will break up couples and force many people into jails, doorways or alleys, they said. ``What's going to happen Friday night is San Francisco will start criminalizing homelessness,'' said Josh Brandon of the Coalition on Homelessness.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Acknowledges He Gave Party Officials Mixed Signals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev meeting with local officials, quotes and details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev acknowledged to local Communist leaders that the Kremlin had cast them adrift as it rapidly switched signals in a bid to quiet republics' demands for autonomy, a local official said today. Gorbachev met with more than 300 officials late Wednesday, after the Soviet president had given himself and his leadership a two-year deadline to improve citizens' lives in the Soviet Union. Filip Stroganov, a party leader from the Baltic republic of Latvia, said Gorbachev had converted him from an opponent to a supporter during the meeting, which lasted late into Wednesday night. ``I like people with character,'' Stroganov said. ``Yesterday I saw his character.'' The Latvian delegation met with reporters today as delegates to the 28th Communist Party Congress broke up into sections to debate economic, military, farm, regional and other issues. Reporters were allowed to attend the first three days of the congress, but were not permitted in today's section meetings. The official Tass news agency, in a brief statement, reported there were ``sharp polemics on social, economic and agricultural party policy'' in the sectional debates but did not provide any details. Stroganov said regional leaders complained that Gorbachev and the central leadership changed their minds too often on a new structure to bind the Soviet Union's republics. Latvia's neighbor, Lithuania, already has declared independence. The parliament of Latvia and the third Baltic republic, Estonia, have signaled their intention to follow. ``We don't have a clear position on this question,'' Stroganov said. ``In the course of a year, opinions in the center were changed three times. First we were talking about a renewed federation, then we were talking about a confederation, and today, just a little while before the congress, we started talking about a union of states.'' ``The lack of a precise position on this issue put us in an awkward situation,'' Stroganov said. Gorbachev ``agreed with this yesterday,'' he added. The regional leaders had been pressing for a meeting for more than two years, and Gorbachev also acknowledged it was a mistake to put it off for so long, he said. The Soviet leader's Council of the Federation recently has begun meeting to try to work out a new treaty among the republics. But the Baltic republics still want to be out altogether, and other republics as well are clamoring for more autonomy. The latest formulation of a union of states, not yet well-defined, is intended to take those strivings into account. Stroganov also said regional party leaders demanded more freedom from Moscow. ``We don't need centralism, we need democracy,'' he said. Earlier Wednesday, Gorbachev told journalists that the leadership should quit if its reform program does not show results in two years. It was the first time that Gorbachev had given a deadline for his reform program, which was launched when he took power in 1985. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' Gorbachev said. He did not specify who would be covered by his self-imposed deadline, but it seemed likely it was meant for both party and government leaders. Most important Soviet officials still hold key posts in both the Communist Party and the Soviet government. Speaking confidently in a videotaped segment shown on the nightly TV news program ``Vremya,'' he denied that the Kremlin leadership would do anything just to hold onto political power. ``I will tell you, before perestroika we had more power. I don't know who had more power than the general secretary of the Central Committee. If it had only been for my sake, there would have been no need for any reforms, renewal in either the party or in society.'' The leadership has made mistakes and errors, but it was courageous in starting his reform program, he said. In Wednesday's session, Gorbachev heard bitter criticism of his program from party officials who accused the leadership of cowardice and indecision in an ideological battle against growing anti-communist sentiments. ``Our position today reminds of an army that is retreating in haste without a plan,'' said Nursultan Nazarbaev, party chief in the Kazakhstan republic as he pleaded for clearer direction from the Kremlin. Despite a second day of sharp criticism, however, speakers displayed no new ideas and no alternative to re-electing Gorbachev to another five-year term as party chief.

DOC.HEAD: Two Continental Flights in Denver Abort Takeoffs
DOC.TEXT: Two Continental Airlines jets aborted takeoffs within an hour of each other because of engine trouble, an airline spokesman said. A Continental Airbus A300 en route to Houston aborted a takeoff from Stapleton International Airport after an engine caught fire, spokesman Flo Ternes said. All 207 passengers and 10 crew members escaped injury. An hour later Wednesday at the same Denver airport, a Continental flight to Los Angeles with 146 people on board aborted a takeoff because an engine overheated, the airline said. The fire in the left engine of the twin-engine Airbus forced the pilot to slam the brakes on Flight 1232 less than 100 yards before the end of the runway, the Houston bound passengers said. The passengers, who were evacuated after the aircraft blew all eight tires, praised the pilot, whose name was not released by Continental. ``The plane stayed true,'' said Calvin Garwood, a Houston lawyer. ``Another two or three seconds and we could have been in real trouble because we would have been airborne. The nose was just coming off the ground.'' The fire was smothered by the engine's internal extinguisher. The Federal Aviation Adminstration is investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Vaclav Havel Elected President For Another Two Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Dubcek comment, military parade. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The country's new Parliament today re-elected former dissident playwright Vaclav Havel as president, completing the political transition from Communist to democratic rule. He is to serve a two-year term. The immensely popular Havel, running unopposed, was elected with the necessary three-fifths majority in a nationally televised secret ballot. A total of 234 deputies voted for him, and 50 against. There were no abstentions. Sixteen deputies were absent. ``I think the fact that there were 50 deputies voting against me is a very good, significant and convincing evidence of the democratic character of my election ... I am quite rejoicing over that. I would not feel good if I had been elected by 100 percent as was my precedessor,'' Havel said. Havel was to deliver his inauguration speech later in the day. Havel, who on Dec. 29 became the country's first non-Communist president in 42 years, was nominated by Civic Forum and its Slovak counterpart, Public Against Violence. The two groups led the peaceful revolution that toppled the hard-line Communist regime in November. The parliamentary session, held in a medieval hall at the Hradcany castle, was opened by Parliament President Alexander Dubcek, whose ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968 were crushed by Soviet tanks. ``By the election of the president, the revolutionary transition, which we have been living through since November, will be ended,'' Dubcek said. He praised Havel as a man who ``has proved competent as a politician and statesman .... Vaclav Havel, playwright in the seat of president, has gained, by his work, the confidence of our people.'' ``He proved himself even in the times of repression of freedom and rights, when it was not easy or convenient to show a firm stand of a citizen and bravery,'' Dubcek said. The former Czechoslovak leader said Havel deserves ``great credit for the fact that our development, even in the most extreme situations, has not slid toward revenge, political intrigues, confrontation and intolerance.'' After the ballot, Havel was led by Dubcek and other officials up the red-carpeted aisle of the Vladislav Hall to sign the oath of office. As a military band played the national anthem inside the hall, the sound of a 20-gun salute reverberated throughout the city. After the parliamentary session, Havel, accompanied by Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek, attended a military parade at the castle's third courtyard. He was the only candidate for the office. Stefan Kvietik, who was nominated by the separatist Slovak National Party, refused the candidacy.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Says CIA Trained Guerrillas at Drug Lord's Mexican Ranch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, ``The CIA...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with additional CIA comment. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The report...'
DOC.TEXT: The CIA trained Guatemalan guerrillas at a Mexican ranch owned by a drug lord convicted in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena, a federal report says. But the Drug Enforcement Administration report does not detail why the guerrillas were being trained, nor whether the Central Intelligence Agency knew who owned the ranch. The CIA denied the report, details of which the Los Angeles Times published today. ``The whole story is nonsense,'' agency spokesman Mark Mansfield said today. ``We have not trained Guatemalan guerrillas on that ranch or anywhere else.'' ``The CIA does not engage in drug-running activities,'' he said Wednesday. The report, completed in February, said the Guatemalan guerrillas were trained during the early 1980s at a ranch near Veracruz owned by Rafael Caro Quintero, and that a guerrilla clash there left 19 Mexican police dead. Caro and two other men are serving prison terms in Mexico for their roles in the 1985 torture-murder of Camarena and his pilot in Guadalajara. Four other men are on trial in Los Angeles over their alleged involvement in the slaying. The DEA report became available in Los Angeles on Tuesday night after U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered prosecutors to turn the information over to the defense, the Times said. It was based on an interview two DEA agents conducted in September with government informant Laurence Victor Harrison. Harrison, according to court documents, ran a communications network for drug lords and their Mexican law enforcement allies in the early and mid-1980s, the Times said. Harrison told the DEA agents that CIA operations personnel once stayed at the home of drug trafficker Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo _ also convicted in the Camarena case. On Feb. 9, Harrison said the CIA used as a cover the Mexican Federal Security Directorate. At the same time, members of that directorate were working with ``major drug overlords'' to ship narcotics to the United States, Harrison said. Sometime between 1981 and 1984, members of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police who went to the ranch on a separate drug investigation were confronted by the guerrillas, Harrison said. ``As a result of the confrontation, 19 MFJP agents were killed. Many of the bodies showed signs of torture; the bodies had been drawn and quartered,'' he told the DEA agents.

DOC.HEAD: Fake Bombs Create Scare at JFK Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The decoys...' to CORRECT airline name.
DOC.TEXT: A cargo inspector at John F. Kennedy International Airport spotted a cache of bombs and guns before they were loaded onto a plane, but the weapons turned out to be fake, officials said. The decoys, supplied by the Federal Aviation Administration, are used by Pan American World Airways to train baggage inspectors to detect the real thing. The inspector was checking the cargo for Flight 403 to Florida on Wednesday when he spotted suspicious items in two boxes. Port Authority police evacuated the baggage room and notified the FBI and the police department bomb squad. Police cleared the baggage room at 6:45 a.m. and it was kept closed until 9:25 a.m., when Pan Am officials told police what had happened. ``As far as we knew, we had real explosive devices,'' said Port Authority Police Lt. Louis Echavarria. The airline delayed six flights for up to 20 minutes because of the scare, said Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon. It was a mistake not to notify the baggage inspector that the items were being shipped, she said, but ``it does show that the screening device and the screening procedure is working.'' The two dummy pipe bombs, fake hand grenades and fake guns were being shipped to Haiti and the Cayman Islands via Miami for security tests.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister To Shake Up Government; Minister Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with agriculture minister resigning in anticipation of shake-up, announcement by gov't spokeswoman. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The government...'
