DOC.TEXT: The agriculture minister resigned today in anticipation of a major Cabinet shake-up by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who is under pressure to dismiss holdover Communists from key posts. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told reporters that Mazowiecki intends Friday to bring to a close a ``certain stage'' of activity by the East bloc's first non-Communist government. But she declined at a news conference to reveal how many other ministers would be ousted, or what new programs Mazowiecki would propose. The pro-government Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said today that up to 10 of the 24 Cabinet members could be dismissed in the realignment. It said Mazowiecki would use the occasion to counter the campaign Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa has mounted against him, splintering the popular movement that rallied to oust the Communists. Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki of the Peasant Party handed in his resignation during an appearance before parliament this morning. He said he had failed to obtain special consideration for farmers to protect them from stringent economic reforms that have outraged them. ``A certain stage of our activity is coming to an end now. The prime minister will speak about it tomorrow,'' said Mrs. Niezabitowska. She added that the Polish people should be proud of the ``path of peace'' taken by the government in its attempt to transform Poland into a democracy, and urged Poles to adopt similar peaceful means in political conflicts to come. The current Cabinet was installed Sept. 12 after 45 years of Communist rule. The government has been under increasing pressure in the past two months, grappling with a major rail strike, two farm protests that required police intervention and steady criticism from Walesa and other elements of Solidarity. Walesa has been urging Mazowiecki to replace holdover Communists, hold early parliamentary and presidential elections and speed privatization of state enterprises. The interior minister, Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, a former Communist still in charge of the police, is considered a prime candidate for ouster. Diplomatic sources said his removal is ``definite.'' Kiszczak's department has been criticized for destroying evidence of its past activities, and new accusations surfaced this week that it continued to spy on Solidarity even after Mazowiecki was named prime minister. Widely lauded in the West for its determined effort to tackle Poland's economic problems, the government's popularity has dwindled at home. According to a survey by the state polling service released Tuesday, just 64 in 100 Poles expressed support for the government. That compares to approval ratings of 80 percent to 90 percent in the fall, before the government implemented its shock economic reform program. The program ended subsidies and has all but halted inflation. But Poles' buying power has suffered and the reaction has been sharp protests from hard-hit sectors. Among those protesting most loudly are Poland's 2.5 million private farmers. Walesa is widely believed to be gearing up to run for president to replace former Communist leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who Parliament elected to the post as part of a political deal that would make it easier for the Communists to surrender control. As part of the deal, Mazowiecki also agreed to leave the powerful police and army ministries in the hands of the Communists, and to give them two other ministerial slots _ transportation and foreign trade. However, with the subsequent collapse of Communist rule throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union's acquiescence to the changes, many Poles have argued that the Communist no longer pose a significant threat to the stability of the Solidarity government.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Ice on the Horizon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to $500 billion sted $500 million in 13th and 15th grafs. Also sent July 3 as PM-Business Mirror, b0219, for use today; on financial wire as PM-Business Mirror.
DOC.TEXT: Here is an icy thought that, oddly, might make a hot summer seem even hotter: The savings and loan bailout, which could cost taxpayers $300 billion, may be just the tip of the iceberg. If the tip is equal to a sum of that size, the single most expensive governmental cost in peacetime, then how massive must the bulk of the berg be? Conceivably, in the trillions of dollars, says economist Ronald Utt, who points out that financial obligations of agencies underwritten by the federal government now total $5.8 trillion. ``And much of that obligation is in bad shape,'' says Utt, vice president of the U.S. Chamber Foundation, a former employee of the White House Office of Management and Budget and a former Heritage Foundation fellow. Potentially, he says, these financial obligations represent a staggering breakdown of government. And, a growing number of critics are saying, the lack of public information on the matter represents a communications breakdown. Most people, it seems safe to say, cannot imagine that other financial breakdowns are threatened, reasoning that if that were so they would have heard of them. But that logic breaks as throroughly as the communications. The obligations Utt refers to are spread among deposit insurance programs, loan and pension guarantees, direct loan programs such as those administered by the Small Business Administration, and debts of five government enterprises. Utt's chilling observations are contained in a paper written for Heritage, a conservative think tank whose opinions sometimes have been influential in the Bush and Reagan administrations. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., says Utt, is by no means the only federal credit program confronted with huge losses. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Federal Housing Administration lost money in 1988 and 1989 and seemed destined to lose again in 1990. The FHA, he says, has seen the level of claims against its shrinking reserves rise nearly three times in three years. Further, he states, ``Half of the farm loans made by the Farmers Home Administration are in default, and half of these defaulted loans have been in that condition for more than three years.'' On and on it goes. The federal government, he notes, stands behind nearly $500 billion in guaranteed Veteran's Administration and FHA mortgages, $48 billion in guaranteed student loans ... ``... and a host of other guarantees ranging from rural electrification to shipbuilding loans, and from small business disaster loans to loans for building plants to convert grain to ethanol.'' All together, he estimates, the contingent liability associated with loan and deposit guarantees totaled $3.5 trillion at the end of fiscal 1988. And other insurance programs _ flood insurance, for instance _ add $500 billion more. How could such massive obligations not rise to the surface and break more forcefully into the media? How can such dangers lurk so near and not cause more concern? Utt doesn't have an answer to those questions, but he does suggest that both Congress and taxpayers played a role. Most lawmakers, he says, ``tried to convince Americans that the crisis was just an isolated incident, and that the vast bulk of the government credit programs are well-managed and pose little risk to the taxpayer.'' And for their part, many taxpayers have wished this to be so. It isn't, says Utt, who advocates passage of an Omnibus Credit Solvency Act ``to fundamentally restructure these many programs in order to reduce taxpayer exposure to costly program failures.'' Before it is too late, he adds.

DOC.HEAD: NATO: Where It's Been, Where It's Going
With PM-NATO Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The changes in Europe's political landscape the past year make this NATO summit one of the most significant in the alliance's 41-year history. Here, at a glance, is a look at where the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been and where it may go:
DOC.HEAD: ORIGIN
DOC.TEXT: The NATO treaty was signed April 4, 1949, in Washington. In it, the United States, Canada and 10 European nations _ Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal _ aligned themselves against any military threat from the Soviet Union. Greece, Turkey, West Germany and Spain later joined the alliance. The treaty says, ``The parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all.'' France, Spain and Iceland are not part of NATO's integrated military structure.
DOC.HEAD: OBJECTIVE
DOC.TEXT: NATO seeks to maintain enough military forces to deter an attack from the seven nations of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact while at the same time striving for disarmament and detente.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE
DOC.TEXT: The alliance is the military protector of 620 million people: 352.8 million in Western Europe, 242.2 million in the United States and 25.6 million Canadians.
DOC.HEAD: EASTERN COUNTERPART
DOC.TEXT: The Warsaw Pact is a military alliance created May 14, 1955. Its members are the Soviet Union, East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania.
DOC.HEAD: SUMMIT EXPECTATIONS
DOC.TEXT: The Berlin Wall has fallen. The German economy has merged. Free elections have replaced most of the totalitarian leaders of Eastern and Central Europe. And Red Army troops and tanks are preparing to go home. How can NATO, after four decades as a military alliance poised against the Warsaw Pact, transform itself into a mostly political organization following the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe? NATO leaders are expected to order a review to develop a negotiating position for reducing short-range nuclear weapons in talks with Moscow. The Kremlin suggests that those negotiations begin this fall, but NATO insists that they take place only after an agreement to reduce tanks, artillery and other conventional forces in Europe. The ministers are expected to nudge negotiators from the East and West to wrap up the slow-moving conventional arms talks and pledge to make even deeper cuts in a later round of discussions. They also will likely discuss the strategy of forward defense, brought into question by the prospect of a united Germany. Forward defense refers to the stationing of troops to defend the front line during an attack. The idea is to defend territory at its border and not give up any land to invading soldiers. The border between East and West Germany has historically been considered part of the front line, but it is soon to be erased.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Professor Demonstrates Hydrogen-Powered Car
LaserPhoto TOK4
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese professor who has built a car powered by highly volatile liquid hydrogen demonstrated the vehicle today and said it causes almost no air pollution. Industry officials said, however, it may take 10 years to produce a commercial version of the car, developed by Shoichi Furuhama, president of the Musashi Institute of Technology. The car's liquid hydrogen fuel is made from water and costs $22.80 a gallon in Japan, officials said. In a test drive today, the car, known as the Musashi 8, reached a speed of 82 mph. Test drivers at Nissan's Oppama factory, near Tokyo, said they believed the Musashi 8 could reach a speed of 94 mph. The car does not backfire before combustion, a defect that has slowed previous research on hydrogen-fueled cars, Furuhama said. I has computer-run pumps and valves that keep the liquid hydrogen at minus 453 degrees. Furuhama said the car creates almost no air pollution. The engine is in a Nissan Fairlady Z body. Nissan has provided financial support and technical assistance to Furuhama's research team. But the new vehicle still has many problems, its developers said. Liquid hydrogen is exremely volatile and engineers are concerned about the dangers of explosion in a crash. Furuhama said the difficulty of obtaining liquid hydrogen has prevented scientists from thoroughly studying its safety. A researcher working with Furuhama said on condition of anonymity the car also must carry a large volume of fuel. Hydrogen cars sometimes have been jokingly referred to as ``cars which carry fuel and not passengers,'' he said. Yasuhiko Nakagawa, a researcher at Nissan's Central Engineering Laboratories, said the fuel mileage is also not as high as for conventional vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman: Scientist Accused of War Crimes Deserves Hearing
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio congressman met with a former Nazi rocket scientist and sharply criticized the U.S. government for trying to keep him out of the country. Rep. James Traficant said Arthur L.H. Rudolph, a former Nazi Party member, passed a lie detector test Wednesday in which he denied having worked slave laborers to death during World War II. Traficant said Rudolph was the victim of an unfair investigation by the U.S. Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, which is responsible for hunting down former Nazis living in the United States. ``They have fared very poorly,'' Traficant, a Democrat, said of the Nazi hunters. ``They've looked for high profile cases to justify their existence.'' Rudolph, a close friend and co-worker of German rocket chief Wernher von Braun since 1934, was brought to the United States by the Army after World War II to develop the U.S. rocket program. Eventually, Rudolph supervised the design and production of the Saturn 5 rocket, which took U.S. astronauts to the moon. But in 1984, faced with what the OSI said was evidence of his involvement in war crimes, Rudolph voluntarily renounced the U.S. citizenship he had been granted, admitted his complicity in war crimes and left the country. He was allowed to keep his pension from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He has been living in Hamburg, West Germany, but came to Canada on Sunday for what he said was a vacation with his wife and daughter, and also to meet with Traficant about returning to the United States. Rudolph claims to have acted as an advocate for the slave laborers who built V-2 missiles for the Nazis during the war, and has said he helped them get extra rations whenever possible. The U.S. government estimates that as many as 20,000 workers died while building V-2 rockets at an underground plant in central Germany. With the 84-year-old Rudolph sitting beside him, Traficant said the scientist was coerced into renouncing his citizenship and now wants to return because he does not want to be remembered as a war criminal. ``Dr. Rudolph has decided that history and how they'll record his name may be more important than the hassles which he'll undertake,'' Traficant said. Rudolph, blinking constantly under the strain of camera flashes and television lights, refused to discuss the case. On Tuesday, Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said the department still considers the agreement Rudolph signed in 1984 valid. Traficant said if Rudolph is guilty of war crimes, he shouldn't be getting his NASA pension and benefits. ``He's getting almost $50,000 a year from the U.S. Treasury. If he's a Nazi war criminal, I don't want him to get a dime,'' Traficant said. ``If he is innocent, I want him to be returned to (the United States). America is his home. He helped put America on the moon.'' Rudolph, who was detained for 8{ hours upon his arrival in Canada Sunday, faces an immigration hearing in Toronto Friday to determine whether he can remain in that country. Canadian Jewish groups have called for Rudolph's immediate deportation. ``I think it's shameful that Canada has allowed Rudolph to come in and permit Canada to be a launching platform for a vile political attack against the U.S. Justice Department and its legal system,'' said Sol Littman, Canadian representative of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which tracks former Nazis. U.S. Rep. Bill Paxon, a Republican from Buffalo, N.Y., also criticized Traficant's efforts to return Rudolph to the U.S. ``Nazi war criminals should be hunted down, tried, convicted and jailed, not honored and extolled, as Congressman Traficant is doing for Rudolph,'' Paxon said in a statement. Traficant also has defended John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland auto worker who was convicted of Nazi atrocities and is on death row in Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, Rockefeller Foundation Exec Meet Again on Bank Idea
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela is following up on a Rockefeller Foundation idea for a bank that would channel international investment to South Africa once the apartheid system is abolished. Foundation head Peter C. Goldmark said Wednesday that Mandela wants to ``have it ready to go when a representative government in South Africa is chosen.'' Mandela, Goldmark and several officials of the African National Congress met in London on Tuesday to continue discussions and form a working group. Goldmark made the proposal at a June 22 meeting between the anti-apartheid leader and business leaders in New York. He likened it then to the Marshall Plan, which helped war-ravaged Europe 40 years ago, and efforts now being made to help Eastern European countries recover from communism. Other executives at the meeting said the idea appeared to generate strong interest and Mandela called the proposal ``constructive and imaginative.'' Goldmark said in a telephone interview from his Brooklyn home on Wednesday that the hour-long, follow-up meeting was held at Mandela's request. ``He didn't let any grass grow under his feet on this one,'' Goldmark said. Goldmark said he would work with two ANC officials _ Foreign Secretary Thabo Mbeki and Treasurer Thomas Nkobi _ ``to design a structure through which that business interest can be channeled.'' Other governments also will be approached as potential contributors, he said. ``They are going to lead the effort,'' he said, referring to the ANC. The Rockefeller Foundation would assist with the actual mechanics of setting up an organization. Goldmark said Mandela had not ruled out creating an agency ``under the roof of an existing institution,'' such as the World Bank. But he said he felt a separate bank would be an ``identifiable, focused mechanism for tapping the energy and interest that's out there.''

DOC.HEAD: 19 Injured By Errant Rocket
With PM-July Fourth Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 4 grafs, bgng, `Officials from ..., with 9 grafs to UPDATE with details on investigation, identity of fireworks operator, comment from company, new conditions of injured; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An errant rocket from the town's Independence Day fireworks display plowed into a crowd of spectators and injured 19 people, at least two of them seriously, authorities said. The shell veered off course during the grand finale of Wednesday night's fireworks display at Fuessenich Park, Fire Lt. Nick Florio said. The display, which drew a crowd of more than 10,000, also marked the town's 250th anniversary. Witnesses said the rocket exploded, showering the tightly packed crowd in the west end of the park with flaming debris. ``One lady was blown out of her seat,'' Scott Pro of Brookfield told radio station WSNG. ``It's one of the worst things I've ever witnessed.'' Jody Lothier, another witness, said a young child was struck in the face with the burning material and another youngster flew 15 feet in the air after being hit. ``It just lifted him off the ground,'' she said. Police Chief Mahlon Sabo said the rocket skidded across the ground from the launch site, injuring spectators 400 feet away. Fire Marshal Ron Corey said today that his office is working with the state fire marshal's office and Torrington police to determine the cause of the explosion. He said officials are investigating several possible causes, including whether there was too much gunpowder packed into the shell. Corey identified the operator of the fireworks display as Ken Lupoli of Hamden, a subcontractor who uses fireworks supplied by Vitale Fireworks Display Co. Inc. of New Castle, Pa. He said Lupoli has put on several fireworks displays. ``He's always done an excellent job. He even goes beyond the (fire) code,'' Corey said. A woman who answered the telephone at Lupoli's home today said he wasn't at home and wasn't available for comment. Frank Rondinelli, a spokesman for Vitale Fireworks, said the company is working with police and fire officials to determine the cause of the explosion. He said the company does not believe there were any safety problems with the fireworks. Among those injured was 3-year-old Robert Shopey, who suffered multiple burns. The child was flown by helicopter to a Hartford hospital where he was in serious condition in the intensive care unit today. Rebecca Shopey, 23, was in stable condition in Torrington's Charlotte Hungerford Hospital where she was being treated for burns to her eyes and face, a hospital spokesman said. One-year-old Ashley Shopey was treated there and released, the hospital said. Sixteen other people were treated at Charlotte Hungerford and two were admitted. Both were listed in stable condition today.

DOC.HEAD: Rioting After Germany Beats England In World Cup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to CLARIFY score. Pickup 3rd, `One man...'
DOC.TEXT: Soccer hooligans threatened German citizens and overturned foreign-registered cars after West Germany defeated England in the World Cup semifinals, and more than 500 people were arrested, police said. Police said 35 officers were injured in disturbances, which broke out Wednesday night, when in Turin, Italy, West Germany defeated England 4-3 in penalty kicks after tying 1-1 in regulation time. Police said heavy drinking by fans who watched the match in pubs contributed to the rowdiness. One man was killed while intervening in a disturbance in Totton, in southern England, but police were uncertain whether the incident was related to soccer frustrations. French police arrested five British soccer fans at a railroad station in Dijon Tuesday night after a brawl on a Turin-bound train. Police said the five were ringleaders of an attempt to oust other passengers and their baggage so 150 British fans could travel together. Seven police officers were injured. In the seaside town of Brighton, 50 miles south of the capital, police locked 300 German students in a nightclub to protect them from hundreds of angry English fans. The students later were escorted safely from the scene aboard five buses. Also in Brighton, police said 200 English youths chased young Germans through the streets. The town has a large population of Germans and other foreign students attending English language courses. Five hundred English fans roamed Brighton's streets, overturning cars with foreign license plates, smashing shop windows and looting. Police reported 15 arrests in the town. Police around the country anticipated the violence, for which British soccer fans are notorious. Extra officers were sent to trouble spots after violence in several English towns and cities Sunday night when England beat Cameroon in the quarterfinals. In Turin on Wednesday night, a 23-year-old German was stabbed in the back and seriously wounded when a fight broke out between rival English and German fans. Police used truncheons to disperse rowdy crowds near the city's main train station. London police dealt with 18 incidents, Scotland Yard said. Drunken fans hurled beer cans and other missiles at police. Hooligans in Grantham, 110 miles north of London, smashed windows at the Premier Restaurant, in the building where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher grew up. In nearby Worthing, police arrested 18 people after a crowd of up to 200 people smashed shop windows and looted the contents. In a pub in Blackburn 185 miles northwest of London, 20 youths armed with pool cues attacked two police officers, who were later treated in a hospital. In the port city of Southampton, 70 miles southwest of London, a group of up to 20 youths smashed up the Royal Oak pub. ``When England lost they went berserk, picking up anything they could find and smashing it,'' said pub manager Bernard Smedley. Lawmakers from both the opposition Labor Party and the governing Conservative Party denounced the violence. An estimated 30 million Britons watched the match on TV, leaving streets in London and elsewhere deserted. The Rolling Stones concert was temporarily drowned out at London's Wembley Stadium as thousands of fans there roared ``England, England'' when England drew level with West Germany at one stage in the match in Turin. Many in the concert audience had brought radios and portable TV sets so they could follow the match. The rock group struck up with ``You Can't Always Get What You Want'' when an England goal was disallowed. Mrs. Thatcher said in a statement Wednesday night: ``We are very proud of the England team, for despite losing by a penalty shoot-out, they played magnificently in the match. It was a great achievement to reach the semi-finals...

DOC.HEAD: Two More Flash Flood Victims Found
DOC.TEXT: Officials said today they recovered the 26th victim of flash floods that ripped through two communities here last month. The victim, found about 9 a.m., was not immediately identified, said Belmont County Coroner's Investigator Chuck Vogt. The body was about two miles south of the mouth of the Wegee Creek, washed up on the Ohio shore of the Ohio River, which divides the state from West Virginia. The 25th victim, identified today as Dorothy Moore of the Wegee Creek area, was spotted Wednesday in the Ohio River by a pleasure craft, Vogt said. The body was found five miles south of Shadyside in an area about 200 yards south of Wegee Creek where a crane had removed debris, he said. About 5{ inches of rain fell near this eastern Ohio village in three hours on June 14, sending walls of water down Wegee and Pipe creeks. Eight people remain missing, Vogt said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Disagree on Where Collision Occurred
DOC.TEXT: The pilots of two container ships that collided last weekend disagree over the exact spot of the accident and claim the other was on the wrong side of the channel. The pilot of the outbound Columbus America told a Coast Guard-National Transportation Safety Board investigating panel Wednesday that his ship was well within the outbound section of the 1,800-foot-wide channel into Hampton Roads. ``At the worst, I would have been 600 feet north of the buoy. That would have still given him 1,000 feet,'' said Capt. Richard L. Counselman Jr. On Tuesday, Capt. John A. Jones, pilot on board the inbound Neptune Jade, said the Columbus America was too far north in the east-west channel. ``How that happened, I do not know. He was well out of position,'' Jones said. The ships collided Sunday evening in a heavy rain squall that limited visibility. The Columbus America's fuel tank was ruptured, spilling 30,000 gallons of fuel oil. Most of the oil ended up in the Elizabeth River section of the harbor as the ship returned to port spewing oil. Each pilot was asked to draw their courses on separate maps. Jones' plot showed him almost on top of a buoy marking the northern boundary of the channel when the accident occurred. Counselman's plot showed him on top of the buoy marking the south boundary of the channel. Neither ship kept a series of fixed positions on their charts as is the case with military ships, which are required to keep exact records of their positions at all times, said Coast Guard officials. The panel was to try to sort out the discrepancies today during questioning of Counselman. Jones has been a pilot with the Virginia Pilots Association for 17 years. Counselman has piloted for the association since 1950, and was its president from 1969 until May. During his 21 years as president, Counselman said he only piloted about 10 ships a year. Coast Guard officials said the cleanup of spilled oil in the bay was completed Tuesday. The owner of the 635-foot Columbus America, Columbus America Inc. of Hamburg, West Germany, agreed to pay for cleanup costs, said Eugene K. Johnson, commander of the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Norfolk. He had no estimate on the cost. The 800-foot Neptune Jade, registered in Singapore, received only minor damage, the Coast Guard said.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Paris Museums Closed After Thefts
LaserPhoto PAR8,9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf pvs, `Portrait of...' with 1 graf to CORRECT year that Renoir was painted. Pickup 12th pvs, `The theft...' ADDS 6 grafs background, new quotes at bottom.
DOC.TEXT: Five Paris art museums closed their doors today to individual visitors after paintings were stolen from three museums, including a Renoir cut out of its frame at the Louvre, over a span of several hours. Jacques Sallois, director of national museums, said security would be tightened at the city's major museums, which remained open. He refused to say what measures would be taken. The museums closed to individuals are relatively small and focus on the works or the collections of a particular individual _ the Eugene Delacroix, Gustave Moreau, Jean-Jacques Henner, Hebert and Ennery museums. Sallois' unprecedented announcement came shortly after police revealed that a third museum had suffered a theft during the short time span Wednesday. Police said it was possible all three thefts were committed by the same person or group, moving across the city center from one museum to another. According to investigators, the theft revealed today apparently was the first to occur in the series. An 1816 work by French landscape painter Paul Huet was lifted off its hook Wednesday morning at the Carnavalet Museum, a historical museum in one of the oldest sections of Paris. The painting, ``Les Moulins de la Glaciere,'' was estimated to be worth about $14,500. The other two stolen paintings were cut from their frames _ Renoir's ``Portrait of a Seated Woman'' from the Louvre and Ernest Hebert's ``Portrait of Monaluccia'' from the museum named after the artist. Both were small format paintings, a type often chosen by thieves because they can be easily concealed. ``Portrait of a Seated Woman'' (1890-1895), measures 13.5 by 10.5 inches. Hebert's work, painted about 1870, measures 14 by 12 inches. The theft of the Renoir was discovered about 2:15 p.m., officials said. The Hebert was discovered missing from the Hebert Museum, across the Seine River on the Left Bank, about an hour later. All three victimized museums are run by the government. Officials gave no estimates of the value of the Renoir and Hebert. Independent experts suggested a possible value of $300,000 to $600,000 for the Renoir, but said it was impossible to give a precise valuation and noted that Renoir had done scores of portraits of women in his later years. The Louvre's director, Michel Laclotte, said the theft of ``Portrait of a Seated Woman'' appeared to be the work of an ``especially clever'' professional. ``The canvas was very thin, the cutting instrument was probably extremely sharp and caused so few vibrations that the electronic sensor did not pick them up,'' he said. Laclotte led reporters to the spot where the portrait had been hanging _ an isolated stairwell leading to the Denon Gallery, on the top floor of the Pavillon de Flore overlooking the Seine. Head painting curator Pierre Rosenberg said the Renior had been on display in the stairwell for several years, due to renovations in other sections of the museum, once a royal palace. It was donated to the Louvre in 1961 by French collector Victor Lion. Rosenberg said Renoir was a ``magic name'' among art lovers, which could explain the theft _ the first at the Louvre in more than 10 years. Sallois said there was no evidence of negligence on the part of museum guards, and expressed confidence in the staff.

DOC.HEAD: Army Kills 27 Rebels In Northern, Eastern Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Troops shot and killed 27 Tamil rebels in a new wave of violence in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, and the government said today it was planning to hold new elections in Tamil-dominated areas. At least 14 soldiers were also killed in rebel attacks. The proposed election, a major demand of the rebels, did not appear to be a peace overture but instead an effort to diminish the support of Tamil civilians for the guerrillas. Announcing the new elections, Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne charged that the rebels were blocking food distribution and causing civilian casualties in the north, the area under their control. Wijeratne said Parliament was likely to pass a law Friday dismissing the administrative council of the Tamil-dominated Northeastern Province. The dissolution of the council and new elections were key demands of Tamil Tiger rebels when they held talks with the government during a 13-month cease-fire. The insurgents broke the peace on June 11, causing a fresh round of fighting in which at least 1,930 combatants have been killed. Many civilians also have died, but the numbers are not known. The latest casualties included 13 soldiers killed in a rebel ambush today, military officials said on condition of anonymity. Also, 27 rebels and one soldier were killed in other skirmishes since Wednesday, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Ninth International Tchaikovsky Musical Competition Ends
DOC.TEXT: The prestigious Tchaikovsky competition drew to a close today with final performances by 48 musicians, including 10 Americans. Musicians were competing for the top prize in four categories: piano, violin, and _ for the first time since the event was initially held in 1958 _ voice and cello. Called the ``superbowl of musical competition,'' by one judge, the Tchaikovsky competition is held every four years. The competition, which began June 14, drew 335 competitors from 51 countries, organizers said. Winners were to be announced Friday. The top musicians in each category receive a $4,000 streo system, a gold medal and 5,000 rubles _ a non-convertible currency that cannot be taken from the Soviet Union. ``This is the most important competition in the world,'' said finalist Hans Choi, 31, a South Korean-born singer who lives in New York City. ``I must sing perfctly in six languanges because the judges come from so many countries.'' This year, for the first time, not only are the contestants and judges international, but the sponsorship as well. The hard-pressed Soviet hosts turned to a Japanese company to donate the stereo equipment offered as prizes. Deborah Voigt, 29, a singer who lives in New York City, said the Soviet audiences had been very supportive. ``I am a bit overwhelmed. The audience response has been unbelievable,'' she said. ``I used to think Italians were the best audiences, but now I think Russians make the best audience by far.'' The contest spokeswoman, Galina Tyurina, said the four halls where the competition has been held were filled to capacity for each performance. ``We have nothing but empty shelves in our shops,'' said Tyurina, ``but we love our music. There is no shortage of music in our country.'' Lucia Lin, a 28-year-old violinist from Boston, said she came to Moscow because of the competition's reputation. Lin plays with the Boston Symphony Orchestra. ``It's a lot of work _ stressful and grueling _ but I'm glad I came,'' she said. The Tchaikovsky competition is organized by the Ministry of Culture, the Union of Composers and the All-Union Music Society.

DOC.HEAD: Pamplona Prepares For Annual Running of the Bulls
DOC.TEXT: The hotels are booked, the bulls are ready and thousands of people were set Thursday to attend the annual San Fermin festival made famous by author Ernest Hemingway. The weeklong festival is to open at midday Friday in this northern city of 200,000 with the traditional firing of the ``chupinazo,'' a rocket blasted from the city hall balcony that sets off the celebrations with a bang. The festival of San Fermin, made famous by Hemingway in his 1926 novel ``The Sun Also Rises,'' is expected to double the city's population as thousands of revelers arrive for one of the world's wildest parties. The more daring _ or foolish _ will participate in the daily running of the bulls, which routinely results in gorings and tramplings and sometimes even death. The ritual occurs each morning of the festival when six bulls charge down city streets along a half-mile route to the city bull ring. Hundreds of people race ahead of the bulls, hoping not to trip or get caught in some of the tight turns along the route. Most escape unscathed, but not all are so lucky. Since the festival began, 52 people have been gored to death, according to city records. Last year seven people were seriously hurt and 198 suffered slight injuries. The annual festival honoring Pamplona's patron saint was inaugurated in 1394. Plagues and wars forced its cancellation several times, but it has run continuously since 1591. The first of the bull runnings is set for Saturday morning. Each evening, the six bulls that run the city streets will be killed during bullfights at the city bull ring.

DOC.HEAD: 200 Villagers Flee in Elephants' Rampage
DOC.TEXT: A herd of elephants went on a rampage in a northern village, trampling a man to death, smashing crops and forcing 200 people to flee their homes, a newspaper reported Thursday. Panggung village chief M. Nafi said the herd was believed to have come to the village for revenge after seeing four elephant carcasses at the rim of the forest, the daily Jakarta Post reported. The carcasses were of elephants killed by poachers for their ivory, it said. The newspaper said a 25-year-old villager was killed during the rampage over the weekend at the village in the regency of Krueng Aceh, about 1,000 miles northwest of Jakarta.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Arrested After Trying to Hijack Soviet Plane to Turkey
DOC.TEXT: A woman traveling with her 2-year-old daughter threatened to blow up a Soviet airplane unless it was diverted to Istanbul, Turkey, a newspaper reported Thursday. Crew members negotiated with the woman while the pilot landed the Tupolev 134 jet in the dark in the southern city of Rostov late Wednesday, the official Communist Party newspaper Pravda said. A parcel which she claimed contained a bomb was then found to be empty, it said. The woman, a shop assistant, was arrested by security forces at the airport. Pravda said the flight, carrying 24 passengers, originated in Sochi on the Black Sea, about 250 miles south of Rostov. It gave no other details. The hijacking bid followed a rash of successful hijackings in recent weeks in which domestic flights have been forced to fly to foreign countries.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Killed in Crash of Military Jet
DOC.TEXT: An Italian air force F-104 fighter plane crashed outside this Sicilian city while on a training flight Thursday, killing the pilot, the ANSA news agency reported. The pilot had radioed he planned an emergency landing on a highway, but the jet crashed in the countryside, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Navigator For Pioneering French Pilot Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jean Dabry, navigator for French pilot Jean Mermoz on several pioneering flights in the 1930s, died at his home north of Paris, the French media reported Thursday. He was 89. Dabry died Wednesday night, but no cause of death was given. There also was no word on any survivors. His funeral was planned Thursday. On May 12, 1930, Dabry and Mermoz completed the first non-stop flight between Africa and South America, crossing the South Atlantic from Senegal to Brazil in 21 hours, 14 minutes. Four years later, they completed the first commercial flight between Paris and Buenos Aires, Argentina. Mermoz disappeared in his plane ``The Southern Cross'' off the coast of Senegal in 1936. Dabry had served as secretary-general of an association called ``The Old Tigers,'' comprised of pioneers of the early days of international aviation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Farmers Fewer, But in Better Financial Shape
DOC.TEXT: The nation's farmers are moving toward the 21st century in a financial condition much improved from a few years ago, an Agriculture Department report said Thursday. ``The proportion of farms that are financially vulnerable today is half that of 1985,'' the report said. ``Farmland prices have stabilized and are beginning to rise.'' But the number of farms in the United States ``continued to decline throughout the 1980s as they have, almost unabated, since 1935,'' the report said. According to the 1987 census of agriculture, there were just more than 2 million farms, down 7 percent from 1982, when the previous census was taken. Small farms, although fewer in number, increased as a proportion of total farms. Mid-sized farms declined both in number and their share of the total. ``The number of large farms continued to increase,'' the report said. ``This trend shows little prospect of reversing in the near future.'' The analysis by the department's Economic Research Service was based on an annual report to Congress on the status of family farms. ``Virtually all farms in the United States are family-owned businesses,'' the report said. ``Fewer than 3 percent of all farms are organized as corporations, most of which are family held.'' Only 0.3 percent are corporations owned and operated by people other than a family. Single families own 87 percent of all farms, and multifamily partnerships operate the remainder. ``Because almost all farms are owned and operated by one or more families, we did not define family farm for this report,'' the agency said. Thomas A. Carlin, one of the authors, said ``a snapshot of the farm sector'' shows that most U.S. farms are small, non-commercial, and usually family owned and operated. Non-commercial units were defined as those having gross farm sales of less than $40,000 a year. ``Small, non-commercial farms produce a minor share of total U.S. food and fiber,'' he said. ``They are typically located near more densely settle urban areas where non-farm employment opportunities abound.'' The small farms often operate at a loss, with farm expenditures exceeding commodity sales, government payments and other farm-related income. ``Family well-being for these small farms depends primarily on off-farm income, and their average total income in most years is commensurate with that of all U.S. families,'' he said. Most of the nation's food and fiber is produced by ``very large commercial farms'' that are highly capitalized, Carlin said. Owners of such large farms typically control several million dollars of land, machinery and other assets. ``Many of the largest farms produce fruits, vegetables and horticultural specialty crops, crops not covered by federal price and income support programs,'' he said. Farming is the dominant occupation for families operating large holdings, and annual income in most years is above that of the U.S. average. Families with large operations do report off-farm income, but that is typically interest, rent or dividends rather than from a job paycheck. With some exceptions, most large farms are located away from major urban centers, in areas conducive to large-scale operations. ``The number of mid-sized commercial farms, those in between the extremes, continues to shrink,'' Carlin said. ``Most of these farms produce food and feed grains that are included in federal commodity programs.'' Thus, he said, mid-sized farms get more than half of all direct government payments. Operators are usually employed full-time on the farm, but often someone else in the household works off the farm.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Likely to Require Double Hulls For Larger Vessels
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving slowly toward an agreement to require double-hulled oil tankers and barges, but environmentalists already are complaining about a possible exemption for smaller vessels that ply inland waterways. House and Senate conferees next week begin working out differences in their versions of a long-awaited oil spill bill, which would increase penalties for spills and hold shippers liable for environmental damage. Conferees are expected to agree that two layers of steel are the best barrier between crude oil and the environment. But environmentalists say they worry that smaller barges will be exempt, which could imperil rivers and ocean harbors _ particularly in New England, where traffic is heavy and sea beds are rocky. ``We're concerned because ... the smaller barges get into semi-enclosed bodies of water, ecosystems they could destroy with just a small spill,'' said Clifton Curtis of the environmental group Friends of the Earth. Congressional staffers, environmentalists and shipping industry lobbyists say it is clear what the final version of the legislation will look like. They expect a requirement that new tankers and oceangoing barges weighing over 5,000 gross tons have double hulls, which consist of a second layer of steel and an airspace between the sea and the cargo. Older vessels would have to be either phased out of operation or refitted with second hulls. ``At this point the double hull requirement is a foregone conclusion,'' said a House staffer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But Curtis and other environmentalists cite Coast Guard statistics that indicate a majority of spills involve barges under 5,000 gross tons. In 1988, for example, 68 percent of the tanker or barge ``oil pollution incidents'' investigated by the Coast Guard involved the smaller vessels. Statistics compiled by the Lexington, Mass., consulting firm Temple, Barker & Sloane Inc. show that of 310 oil-carrying barges, only 72 are in the heavier weight group that, under the House bill, would be required to have double hulls by the year 2015. Ernie Corrado, president of the American Institute of Merchant Marine Shipping, said the tanker operators represented by his group realize that new barges, either foreign or domestic, will be required to have double hulls. ``We've accepted that,'' he said. Corrado said owners already have begun ordering new vessels with double hulls. But Corrado's group and others argue that double hulls also carry risks. Gases trapped between the hull walls could cause an explosion and a breach in the outer wall could allow water in the cavity between the hulls, capsizing the vessel. The National Academy of Sciences is working on a study expected to detail some of the weaknesses of double hulls. The Senate wants to give the secretary of transportation authority to review that study along with other data to see if alternatives to double hulls would work as well or better. ``It's not simply a question of economics, it's a question of safety,'' said Joe Farrell, president of the American Waterways Operators, a trade association representing coastal shippers, including oil barge haulers. The oil spill legislation has been debated in Congress for 15 years, but efforts to pass it out were stepped up after the Exxon Valdez spill of March 24, 1989. The super tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef in Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. Less sensational but still damaging to the environment have been barge spills in New York Harbor and Buzzards Bay, Mass. Among other provisions, the bill would create a $1 billion cleanup fund through a 5-cent tax on each barrel of oil created in or imported to the United States. It also would establish Coast Guard oil spill response centers along U.S. coasts. The double-hull provision is among the few remaining issues in dispute between the House and Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Reggae Among Anti-Protest Methods
DOC.TEXT: An abortion clinic says it may use reggae music's positive vibrations to drown out the chants of protesters at its door. Mary Litman, a spokeswoman for Women's Health Services Inc. of Pittsburgh, said the clinic may hire a reggae band to play during the next large protest by Project Multitude, a Pittsburgh anti-abortion group. The band would play louder than singing protesters and, possibly, drive away those who dislike reggae music, Ms. Litman said. The blend of rock 'n' roll and calypso is performed by such Jamaican artists as Yellowman and the late Bob Marley. ``We are going to take the initiative and try to have some control over what goes on,'' Ms. Litman said. In June, Women's Health Services solicited pledges from supporters based on the number of people who attended an anti-abortion demonstration. The clinic collected $2,800 after 350 people attended the protest, or about $8 per picket, Ms. Litman said. ``I would rather that our patients and their husbands and mothers and friends be able to walk into our clinic in total privacy,'' Ms. Litman said. ``But we cannot keep the pickets away, so we will use this to thumb our noses at them.'' The pledge drives and other tactics will not deter the protests, including one planned for September, said Mary Irwin, director of Project Multitude. ``If the Ku Klux Klan tried to make money off the number of blacks protesting in Alabama, I hope that would not discourage them for standing up for what is right in Selma,'' Ms. Irwin said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-July Fourth Rdp, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0473,0818
DOC.HEAD: Americans Celebrate Fourth With Fireworks, Parades and Picnics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 12th graf, `In Torrington...' to UPDATE with fireworks death in New York.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY25,NY26,WX6,BX3, LaserColor NY28
DOC.TEXT: Americans celebrated Independence Day by exercising their freedom of speech with protests in California and Florida, cutting a birthday cake for 25,000 in Philadelphia and building a world-record sandcastle in South Carolina. The traditional fireworks, parades and picnics also marked the Fourth of July festivities on Wednesday. The holiday was a record hot one in many parts of the nation, sending millions to beaches. Among high temperatures were 105 in Enid, Okla., 104 in East St. Louis, Ill., and 100 in Baltimore. ``You can't see the grass, the sand or the water, it's so crowded out there,'' said Chicago police Sgt. Mike O'Brien, stationed on the city's lakefront. In New York, some people cooled off by ice skating to patriotic music at Manhattan's indoor Sky Rink, where it was 50 degrees. Some Americans celebrated Independence Day with protests. Demonstrators marched for and against the homeless in Santa Cruz, Calif. Veterans took to the streets of St. Petersburg, Fla., urging better health benefits. In Little Rock, Ark., black activist Robert ``Say'' McIntosh traded barbs with 30 to 40 Ku Klux Klansmen from behind a line of 60 state troopers at the state Capitol, but he never carried out his threat to burn the American flag. ``I just wanted to prove that flag belongs to all of us,'' McIntosh said. A group in Adelanto, Calif., did burn a flag _ but it wasn't a protest. The torching of a 67-foot by 102-foot version of Old Glory was a flag retirement ceremony by the local American Legion. Among the larger crowds for fireworks displays Wednesday were the 1.3 million people who turned out for a blast over New York's East River and the 400,000 people who watched a show over the Washington Monument in Washington, D.C. Fireworks _ legal and illegal _ also caused injury and destruction. In Torrington, Conn., an errant rocket from the town's Independence Day display shot into a crowd of at least 10,000 spectators, injuring 19 people, several seriously. In Hickman, Neb., illegal fireworks started a fire that destroyed a home. Someone threw a firecracker into a burning garbage can outside a party at the Hell's Angels' Manhattan clubhouse, New York police said. Shrapnel from the resulting explosion injured four people, including a 14-year-old boy who died at a hospital today. Fireworks shows didn't go on at all in some Northeast communities, where budget cuts curtailed holiday celebrations. ``There's just no money,'' said John Craven, a police officer in Holyoke, Mass. ``The city is in tough shape so nobody put on a Fourth of July celebration this year.'' Fireworks displays also were canceled in Aspen and Vail, Colo., because extremely dry conditions posed a fire danger. Celebrations turned violent in some places. Two people were wounded, one critically, and three people were arrested early Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif., in shootings police blamed on gangs at the ``Dawn's Early Light'' sunrise fireworks display. The display was moved from night to early morning three years ago to cut down on gang violence. Three people were wounded by gunfire and nine people were arrested in Fort Worth, Texas, when the annual holiday celebration in the Como neighborhood turned violent Tuesday. In more peaceful celebrations, the Boston Pops concert on the Esplanade in Boston drew more than 150,000 people, while in Boston harbor ``Old Ironsides'' _ the USS Constitution _ made its yearly turnaround. With the Chicago suburbs being bugged lately by cicadas, a group of men dressed up to look like the insects and participated in Lake Bluff's Independence Day parade. July Fourth also was a day for awards. In Philadelphia, birthplace of the Declaration of Independence, former President Carter accepted the $100,000 Liberty Medal and helped Mayor W. Wilson Goode cut ``America's Birthday Cake'' _ a giant pastry big enough to serve 25,000 people. In Decatur, Ala., former hostage Frank Reed accepted the Audie Murphy Patriotism Award. In return, he gave the people of Decatur a piece of the Berlin Wall and called on Americans not to forget those who remain captive in Lebanon. Glenn and Leslie Loy of Traverse City, Mich., earned a less weighty prize at Windermere Beach on Mackinac Island, Mich _ $200 for winning the annual International Mixed Doubles Stone-skipping contest. The Loys combined for 27 skips. In Myrtle Beach, S.C., as many as 10,000 people built 10.5 miles of what promoters called the world's longest sandcastle. The city lost the title it had earned with a 5-mile castle when Long Beach, Wash. built a record 6.5 mile-long structure in June.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say Ocean May Confuse Global Warming Record
DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Weather changes caused by unusual Pacific ocean currents may have led scientists to overestimate how much the Earth has warmed up in recent decades, according to a new study. But, says the author, it may be that global warming helped cause those changes in the ocean. Jim Angell of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has calculated the amount of global warming associated with the El Nino events over the last couple of decades. Subtracting the ocean effects reduces the global warming by one-fourth between the 1960s and the 1980s, according to Angell's report, being published Friday in Geophysical Research Letters, a journal published by the American Geophysical Union. But he cautions against quick assumptions about which is cause and which effect. It may be that part of the increase in global warming is a result of the strength of the El Nino events in the 1980s, but it may also be that the global warming led to more and stronger El Ninos, Angell said in a telephone interview. Concern about global warming has grown in recent years, with many scientists worried that increasing carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere will act like a greenhouse, overheating the planet. Scientists have estimated that the layer of air closest to the Earth warmed by 0.33 degrees Celsius (0.59 degrees Fahrenheit) between the 1960s and the 1980s. Several of the warmest years recorded occurred in the 1980s, a time when at least two of the so-called El Nino events also took place. Angell, of NOAA's Air Resources Lab in Silver Spring, Md., noted that ocean warming in El Ninos can contribute to changes in global temperature. El Nino events involve unusually warm water moving eastward in the Pacific Ocean. They can affect weather events worldwide during their lifetime of a year or so. The strongest El Nino in at least a century occurred in 1982-83 and a milder one took place in 1987-88. Angell found that after subtracting the effect of the El Nino warming from the record, the air had warmed by 0.24 degrees Celsius (0.43 degrees Fahrenheit), 27 percent less than the original calculations. In addition, 1988 is no longer the warmest year on record, being only slightly hotter than the overall average, Angell concluded in the journal article. Subtracting the effects of the El Nino also cuts in half the annual variations in global temperature, Angell explained, and makes it easier to see the cooling that results from volcanic eruptions. Scientists had expected the eruptions of the Indonesian volcano Agung in 1963 and Mexico's El Chichon in 1982 to cool the globe because of their smoke and ash blocking sunlight. No cooling was apparent, however, which prompted Angell's study. He found that the warming effect of El Nino swamped the cooling from the volcanoes in the original record. When the El Nino warming is deleted the volcanic effects become much more obvious, he explained. The El Nino is named with the Spanish word for the Christ Child because it was first noticed by South American fishermen and generally occurs around Christmas time.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Public Schools Must Provide Early Childhood Services
With AM-Teachers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fore relesae at 2 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Public schools should offer day care, meals and health screening for preschool, kindergarten and elementary school children, the nation's largest teachers' union said Thursday. The board of directors of the National Education Association approved a committee report that said public schools should be the primary provider of such early childhood services. It said they should be universal, with low or no cost to the child, and all children would have equal access. With the exception of Head Start, most day care or preschool programs are offered by private or non-profit organizations. Head Start provides education, meals and health screening for needy youngsters ages 3 to 5 but officials said only a small percentage of eligible children are served by the program. Public schools also are ``an acknowledged socializing agent,'' with established systems that allow for easy handling of money, the report said. The committee said its recommendations were prompted in part by changes in American families and the labor force. It also cited changes in the demographics of poverty, increases in the preschool population and its changing ethnic composition. ``The need for education and care programs for young children is not being met,'' the report said. ``NEA believes that early childhood programs must be available for all 3- and 4-year-olds.'' NEA statistics showed that between 1960 and 1985, the percentage of traditional households _ mother, father, two school-age children _ decreased from 60 percent to 7 percent. It also said that more than 3.2 million mothers work outside the home, and 200,000 more mothers join the labor force yearly. By 1995, it is estimated that 80 percent of children under age 6 will have mothers working outside the home. The number of such children is expected to increase by 9 million this year, from 14 million in 1980 to 23 million. Of this increase, 55 percent will likely live in poverty _ and poverty is the most valid predictor of educational failure.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Believe Convict Plotted Escape for Lehder
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted on weapons charges may have been plotting to help Colombian drug kingpin Carlos Lehder escape from federal prison, a prosecutor said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Anthony Bruce said investigators believe Dominic Taddeo was involved in planning a jailbreak attempt for Lehder, a key figure in the Medellin drug cartel in the early 1980s. Investigators reached that conclusion after searching a storage locker rented by Taddeo in Allentown, Pa., Bruce said. ``We found stuff in the Pennsylvania locker that led us to put two and two together and determine there might be an attempt being planned to get Carlos Lehder out of Marion,'' he said. Lehder is serving a 140-year sentence at the federal prison in Marion, Ill., for drug trafficking and conspiracy. Bruce would not be more specific about what was found in the locker. Taddeo was sentenced last week to 17 years in prison for illegal possession of weapons and for jumping bail on those weapons charges two years ago. A federal grand jury in Rochester is hearing allegations that Taddeo was involved in three mob-related killings in the early 1980s. Taddeo, 33, has never been charged in those killings. Bruce said he will recommend that Taddeo serve his sentence at Marion, considered the nation's highest-security prison. ``As I understand Marion, you do not leave your cell unless you're in the company of two guards,'' Bruce said. ``You might get somebody out of Marion with the Russian army, but short of that, you're hurting.''

DOC.HEAD: Moore's Friend Testifies She Saw Barry Use Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with developments on admitting Farrakhan and Stallings.
DOC.TEXT: A former business partner of the ex-model who participated in a sting operation against Marion Barry testified today that she saw the mayor snort cocaine from a straw during a 1986 party. In another development, a federal appeals court refused to order the admission of two black leaders as spectators at the trial. Carole Bland Jackson said the drug use occurred in the bathroom of a Washington apartment after a 1986 city-sponsored cruise on the Potomac River to which Barry had invited Rasheeda Moore. Moore and Jackson worked together on Project Me, a self-esteem modeling program for teen-age girls that Barry asked Moore to set up. ``The mayor and Rasheeda were sitting on the side of the bathtub and ... cocaine was visible,'' Jackson testified. ``I snorted first, then Rasheeda took it, then the other gentleman and Mayor Barry.'' She did not identify the other man. Jackson was the third witness in Barry's drug and perjury trial to testify that she actually saw him use drugs. Moore testified last week that she and Barry used drugs together on more than 100 occasions. Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis also testified that he and Barry used drugs together. When asked by assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin if she was sure that Barry had used drugs, Jackson responded, ``absolutely positive.'' Jackson said she left the apartment a short time later, after ``the mayor came out and made sexual advances towards me, which I declined.'' Jackson also described using drugs in Barry's presence on another occasion in 1986. She testified that while she did not see the mayor use cocaine then, the mayor was in a bathroom where cocaine was present, holding his nose and ``sitting there sniffing.'' Prosecutors introduced into evidence a videotape of a September 1986 press conference in which Barry dismissed criticism of a city anti-drug plan that targeted drug buyers by using undercover officers as drug pushers. ``I have no sympathy for those who are crybabies about the fact that we have police officers selling to those who want to buy drugs,'' the tape showed Barry saying. ``We want everybody to know that the next drug buy may be from a police officer.'' Retchin said that since the tape showed Barry was aware such undercover tactics were being used, Barry could not complain he had been improperly tricked into buying crack cocaine from an undercover FBI agent when he was arrested in a sting operation Jan. 18. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. One of the possession charges stems from the sting operation, in which Barry was videotaped smoking crack cocaine in Moore's hotel room. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is presiding over Barry's trial, had refused to allow Nation of Islam Minister Louis Farrakhan and Bishop George Stallings to attend the mayor's trial on Barry's courtroom passes. Barry appealed the decision. The appeals court said today Barry's arguments for admitting the two are premature and returned the case to Jackson for further consideration. The appeals court said Jackson should rule on the matter based on arguments that would be filed by the two excluded black leaders, Barry's arguments for admitting Farrakhan and Stallings can only be made on appeal from his conviction, if there is one, the appeals court said. The two were refused admission to attend the trial last week because, Jackson said, their presence would be ``potentially disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' Barry said his constitutional right to a public trial was being violated. ``The court lacks jurisdiction to entertain Marion Barry Jr.'s Sixth Amendment claim at this time,'' said the appeals panel. ``We believe that the most appropriate course ... is to require'' Farrakhan and Stallings ``to present their First and Fifth Amendment claims to the district court,'' said the three-member panel of appeals judges. ``Only Barry's counsel addressed the court concerning the admission of Farrakhan and Stallings; no one representing Farrakhan and Stallings presented their separate claims,'' the panel said. The National Bar Association and the National Conference of Black Lawyers objected to Jackson's decision to bar Farrakhan and Stallings, a former Roman Catholic priest who broke from the church to lead his own congregation. The two black lawyers' organizations complained Wednesday that the decision to bar Farrakhan and Stallings was ``unconstitutional and highly outrageous.'' The National Bar Association filed a friend of the court brief supporting the American Civil Liberties Union in appealing the ruling to the appeals court. The ACLU argued that Farrakhan and Stallings are entitled to view the proceedings. Jackson's lawyers argued that judges have wide discretion to protect order and that he is ``doing his best to run a fair and orderly trial under the most difficult circumstances.''

With PM-Barry Trial

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0503, AM-Peeved Postmasters, transmitted July 4 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press story on July 4 erroneously reported that postmasters used taxpayers' money to mail hundreds of letters to Washington defending the proposed postage rate hike against a business group's attack. The mailings in fact were paid for by postal customers, through their purchase of stamps and services. The Postal Service no longer receives a taxpayer subsidy for operations.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Losing Sight Gets Wish: Piano
DOC.TEXT: A musically inclined 3-year-old boy who is losing his eyesight to cancer had his dream come true when the West Virginia Make-a-Wish Foundation gave him a piano. Jeremy Sirbaugh received the piano Tuesday at his home in a ceremony attended by 30 friends and family members. The foundation grants the wishes of seriously ill children. Since birth, the Weston boy has suffered from retinal blastoma, and the disease already has claimed one of his eyes, said his pediatrician, Dr. Jeanie West. West said Jeremy has undergone radiation treatments and other medical care since he was 7 months old. The boy's disease is not fatal, but West predicts he will be totally blind within two months. Jeremy's teachers have found him to be musically inclined. His mother, Louise Sirbaugh, said she will find Jeremy a music teacher.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Workers, Muscovites Disappointed by Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: Workers at a major car factory don't like what they have seen so far of the Soviet Communist Party congress, and other city residents said Thursday they doubted the party could improve their lives. ``I am not satisfied. Things are happening the same old way. The way we elected delegates was new, but the same old people were elected,'' said Viktor Gushchin, a worker in the eastern Moscow machine shop of the ZIL car factory, famous for the hulking black limousines favored by the party elite. The 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party convened Monday amid growing friction among members over the party's course, and increasing despair among citizens that perestroika will make a difference in their lives. Party leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has come under heavy fire from orthodox Communists during debates, but they have displayed no new ideas of their own on how to alleviate the chronic economic and political crisis. ``After the first few days, I am not sure this party has a future. These leaders must get advice. If these old people stay then I don't know what is going to happen,'' said Sergei Tkachenko. ``The party leaders must change radically because if it doesn't then the people won't support them.'' Of the factory's 60,000 workers, 11,000 belong to the Communist Party, but their numbers are starting to drop as confidence in the party dwindles. ``We have got to be able to live better. We don't get paid enough, so people are leaving the party because they are not satisfied,'' said Sergei Grigoryevich, an 18-year veteran at the factory. All of the workers interviewed in the machine shop during their break said they were disappointed that so few workers were delegates to the congress, although the factory itself has three delegates to the congress. Workers make up just 12 percent of the delegates and farmers 5 percent. ``The leaders don't really know workers problems and it doesn't bother them so that is why they just utter empty words,'' Tkachenko said. Throughout the city, residents appeared doubtful and depressed by the party's failure to improve their lives. ``I don't care about this congress. I'm sick of hearing about it. They talk, talk and there are no changes. They should take decisions to make things better so people can see it,'' said Igor Smirnov, a driver for a local cooperative. ``The delegates say they are working. Well, they should have something to show for their work and they don't,'' said Smirnov, who worked as an ambulance driver before joining the budding cooperative movement two years ago. The party did not win high ratings either at the Cheremyushki market, an open-air bazaar of fruits, vegetables and milk products grown on private plots. ``I think the party is going to break apart. Who knows what will happen then. But to tell you the truth I am not paying much attention to the congress,'' said Yelena Lissovskaya as she ladled up bottles of sour cream. The mood was sullen at a nearby state grocery story on Leninsky Prospekt, a wide avenue in the southern part of the city. ``Nothing is going to happen. They've been at this perestroika for five years and look at this store _ some milk, a bit of cheese, nothing else. Nothing good is going to come out of this,'' said Lydia Lyanova, one of the cashiers in the dimly lighted shop. ``I'm not going to talk politics with you. If you want to talk salami or cheese, OK, but otherwise please get out,'' the store director told a reporter. He would not give his name. ``I'm not a Communist. How should I know what they're doing downtown? Anyway, other parties and groups will soon be registered and the Communist Party wont't count for much anymore,'' said Sasha Anykin, as he swept a dusty boulevard with a handmade broom.

DOC.HEAD: City to Rebuild Cobble Stone Streets
DOC.TEXT: Contractors will be laying cobble stone streets again as part of a reconstruction project in Manhattan's SoHo Cast Iron Historic District, the city announced Thursday. The city will spend $11 million during the next two years to rebuild Greene and Mercer streets. The work will include new sewers, water mains, catch basins, street signs and traffic lights, the Transportation Department said. Because the district was designated a landmark area in 1973, the project will include distinctive street lights and fire hydrants and the existing cobble stone roadways will be restored by hand. ``It's worth a few extra dollars to maintain the quality of the neighborhood,'' said department spokesman Joseph DePlasco. About 85 percent of the funding is coming from the federal government, he said. Mercer Street will be rebuilt from Canal Street to Eighth Street. Greene Street will be rebuilt from Canal Street to Houston Street. The landmarked area contains the largest collection of full and partial cast-iron facades in the world and retains much of the character of a 19th century commercial district.

DOC.HEAD: Housemate Charged in Scalding Death
DOC.TEXT: A man has been charged with murder in the death of his housemate, who was scalded with boiling water after an argument over a pack of cigarettes, authorities said. Thomas Wright, 47, was scalded May 22 after he fell asleep following the argument, investigators said. Odell Butler, 57, originally was charged with aggravated assault but the charge was changed to second-degree murder after Wright died Monday at a Memphis hospital, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Will Run for D.C. `Shadow Senator' Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds last graf background.
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson said today he will run for one of the district's two ``shadow senator'' posts in the September primary election. The shadow senators will be unpaid lobbyists for D.C. statehood, with no official duties. Jackson, a two-time contender for the Democratic presidential nomination, said on Fox Television's Morning News that holding the post would allow him to help ``expand democracy'' in the District of Columbia. ``That's what statehood is all about,'' Jackson said. ``More people live here than five states, we pay more taxes than 10 states, we pay more taxes per capita than 49 states, and yet no vote on Capitol Hill. It's taxation without representation. It's not fair. We deserve statehood.'' City voters approved the ``shadow'' plan in a 1980 referendum. The city's only representative in Congress is a non-voting delegate in the House. Jackson said election to the post would have no bearing on whether he decides to run for president in 1992. ``The two are not connected whatsoever,'' he said. Jackson told reporters before attending a luncheon today at Howard University that statehood would improve the lives of district residents. ``The premise is statehood means less taxes and better hope,'' he said. Jackson's political plans have been the subject of speculation since he moved to the nation's capital last year. In February, he announced he would not run for mayor, but he refused to rule out some other political race. Some supporters had encouraged Jackson to run for the city's non-voting House seat, but candidates must live in the District of Columbia for more than three years to be eligible to enter that race. Other candidates for the ``shadow'' posts include James Foreman, a longtime civil rights activist, and Harry Thomas Jr., the son of city councilman Harry Thomas. Although voters approved the ``shadow'' plan in 1980, the city council twice canceled scheduled votes to fill the posts. Under a plan approved by the city council this spring, district voters will select two ``shadow'' senators and one ``shadow'' representative to lobby full-time for statehood on Capitol Hill.

DOC.HEAD: All That Glitters Could Be Sold
DOC.TEXT: All that glitters could be sold by IRS agents who seized the store where country music stars have for years bought their rhinestones. The Alamo, stocked with shark-skin boots, leopard-skin jackets and sequin gowns, was seized June 11 by the Internal Revenue Service in a tax judgment against Tony Alamo, a fugitive preacher who blames a government conspiracy for his troubles. An auction hasn't been scheduled, but the government on Tuesday released an inch-thick stack of papers listing the goods _ 946 lots from the Alamo store and 183 lots from Alamo's house. Alamo says the items are worth $50 million. Any auction could be delayed for months by appeals, or the merchandise would be returned if Alamo decides to pay $7.9 million in taxes which the IRS claims he owes. Such an auction would draw great interest and the agency would publicize the time and location well in advance, said Dan Boone, an IRS spokesman. ``I can say that we have had a lot of calls from people from out of state inquiring whether there'll be an auction,'' he said. ``We'll make available to bidders on the day of the auction a complete list of items.'' It took three semi-trailers to haul the goods away, Boone said. ``We'd prefer not to say where it is,'' Boone said. ``It's just in safekeeping.'' Inventory of the store, now serving as the church, shows hundreds of skirts, shirts, boots, hats, and trademark Alamo denim jackets. The list is studded with such adjectives as sequined, fringed, feathered, beaded, braided, jeweled, iridescent, electric, embroidered, elephant-print and lame. ``We've done clothing for all the elite people in the world,'' Alamo told The Tennessean newspaper by telephone from a location he would not disclose. ``Anything that the general public could wear, right up to the king of England or the Prince of Wales. ``If anyone had any right to have anything, it would be us, not (the IRS), because we're the strongest Christian work. God didn't want us to be poor.'' The IRS list includes a leopard-skin jacket, sequin pants, a black sequin evening gown, 30 fur-lined women's slippers. Furs come in mink, raccoon, otter and fox (fox varieties include red, indigo, blush, impala and Scandinavian). Boots come in lizard, gator, ostrich, shark, python, crocodile, cobra and rattlesnake. Alamo is an Arkansas evangelist whose church following has been called a cult and widely dismissed for its virulent attacks on Catholics and requiring church members work for little or no pay. Alamo gained notoriety when he said that his wife, Susan, who died of cancer in 1982, would be resurrected. He kept her embalmed body on display for six months while followers prayed. In 1988, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled against his foundation, which sought to avoid paying taxes on the meals, clothing and other goods it supplied its workers.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman, Woman Shot in Church Parking Lot
DOC.TEXT: A man shot an off-duty police officer this morning and then fired into a group of teen-age girls and chaperones boarding buses for a Mormon church camp, hitting at least one, police said. After firing several shots, the gunman fled to a nearby residence, where he stood off police for about two hours before surrendering, Officer Leo Speliopoulos said. The arrested man's name was not immediately available. Speliopoulos said the gunfire broke out about 6:50 a.m. behind a Glendale Stake center of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. More than 100 girls and adults were in the parking lot, either boarding buses for a camp on the Mogollon Rim or seeing off the campers, he said. Police said the man opened fire without provocation, hitting off-duty Officer Steve Checketts, 43, in the arm and chest. ``Then he began indiscriminately firing at several individuals there,'' Speliopoulos said. One bullet hit Elaine Beech, 47, in the ankle. The wound was treated at Thunderbird Samaritan Hospital, and she was sent home. Checketts was listed in serious condition at John C. Lincoln Hospital. A parent at the scene said he saw the gunman before the incident. He said the man was lurking in the back of the parking lot near a large garbage bin. The parent said Checketts began walking toward the gunman, and the man opened fire. The witness said two other people suffered leg wounds before the gunman fled on foot. Authorities could not confirm that a third person was hit.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Day Trash Hauled Away Before Dawn's Early Light
DOC.TEXT: In the rocket's red glare, National Park Service squadrons stood ready for battle. And by dawn's early light Thursday, they had vanquished an Independence Day layer of discarded pop cans, tissue paper and orange peels on the National Mall.
