Hardy tourists who braved Thursday's 100-degree heat and humidity to visit the Washington Monument, tour Mall-side museums or attend a folk festival found only acres of trampled grass, some strewn pretzels and lines of portable toilets as reminders of the previous day's huge crowd. About 400,000 people celebrated July 4th on the Mall with music, food and fireworks, leaving behind tons of debris on the wide expanse of grass that stretches from the Lincoln Memorial to the Capitol Dome. But before the post-fireworks parties had finished, at least 200 Park Service maintenance staff were picking up the trash and hauling it away, spokesman Earl Kittleman said. ``They really swept in and scoured the site,'' said Mary Combs, press officer of the Festival of American Folklife, who arrived early Thursday to prepare the Mall for singing, corn-roasting and basket-weaving. ``By the time we got in, it was pretty well cleaned up,'' she said, waving at the empty expanses of grass on the Mall at 12th Street. ``It started about two hours after the fireworks,'' said Greg Carey, health services representative for the Red Cross, who manned a first-aid station late into the night and watched the operation begin. ``They do an excellent job of cleaning up,'' Carey said, taking a break from his inventory of bug sprays, sun creams and bandages left over from the previous night's work. The overnight pickup produced about 30 to 40 cubic yards of trash, Kittleman said. He did not have a cost estimate for the operation. In an innovation this year, the waste management company Browning-Ferris Industries set out bins for recyclable glass and aluminum, while another private firm, Science Applications International Corp., organized about 200 volunteers to encourage picnickers to separate their cans and bottles for recycling. The effort produced about 1,000 pounds of glass and 3,000 pounds of aluminum for recycling, Kittleman said. Profits from the operation are to be turned over to the Park Service. Park police reported 20 arrests from the celebration, including 11 for minor drug violations, five for vending without a permit and two for fighting, Maj. William Spruill said. About 500 people were treated for heat exhaustion, cuts, bruises or other medical problems, including 80 sent by ambulance to hospitals and two emergency cases lifted out by helicopter, Spruill said. ``It was a pretty normal Fourth of July,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Convoy Rumbles Through Reunion Village
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet armor rumbled through an Estonian hamlet in a show of military force Thursday, causing postponement of a veterans' reunion that included soldiers who fought in Nazi brigades, Estonian media reported. Organizers postponed plans for a reunion in the central village of Tori on Saturday and Sunday after a convoy of 28 Soviet armored vehicles and 15 loaded troop trucks passed through, the Estonian News Service said. ``Today they arrived in Tori and drove through the town fully armed,'' the Baltic republic's official news agency said. ``The Estonian government and the Ministry of Internal Affairs were not informed about the movement of the troops.'' ``The Estonian government strongly protests the actions taken by the army, which can do nothing but exacerbate the already tense situation, especially in situations such as this where the actions are connected to political ambitions,'' it said. An official of the news service said that soldiers apparently were in the town only briefly, and then left. The reunion planned by the Heritage Society, a group seeking to promtoe awareness of Estonian history, was indefinitely postponed, it added. Calls to the Heritage Society's chapter in Tori went unanswered. The dispute highlighted the sensitivity of World War II allegiances among the Baltic republic's citizens, an issue underlying Estonia's independence drive. Soviet soldiers entered independent Estonia in 1940 under Adolf Hitler's pact with Josef Stalin dividing Eastern Europe into spheres of influence. Estonia and its Baltic neighbors Lithuania and Latvia were absorbed into the Soviet Union. Heritage Society members issued an open invitation to soldiers who fought for Estonian independence, and included those who served in the German army in World War II, Estonian news reports and Heritage Society officials said. The invitation also was extended to the handful of soldiers still alive who fought both Germans and Russians to establish Estonian independence in 1918, and partisans who fought a guerrilla war against Soviet power. A leader of the Heritage Society, Argakas Kullo, said by telephone from the Estonian capital of Tallinn that about 65,000 to 70,000 Estonians served in German military units during World War II. He said most fled west with the German army when it retreated in 1944. He said the society does not know how many former German army soldiers might still be in the republic, or how many would have attended the gathering. The Soviet news agency Tass said the reunion was to have included Estonians who served in Nazi Germany's 20th SS Division and the Omakaitse punitive squad. It called plans for the gathering an ``outrage.'' The Estonian News Service quoted Col. Gen. Fyodor Kuzmin, the Soviet military commander in the Baltics, as characterizing the gathering as that of ``fascists'' and members of former SS divisions. He called the meeting ``inadmissible.'' The report quoted Estonian State Minister Raivo Vare as responding that the government had taken steps to prevent trouble. He also urged the military commanders to avoid interference that would ``bring a senseless and dangerous aggravation of the situation,'' the news service said. Kullo called the military move through the village of Tori a ``pure provocation'' by the Soviet military. The chapter in Tori, a village of about 500 people 75 miles from Tallinn, organized the reunion months ago with the approval of the Heritage Society's leaders, Kullo said in a telephone interview. Soviet media previously have criticized the Estonian Heritage Society for what they claim are its fascist leanings. But Kullo said Soviet officials have it in for the Heritage Society because it was one of the first Estonian organizations to raise nationalist issues in the republic's drive for sovereignty. It predated the Estonian People's Front, which has led the drive to restore the republic's independence, and first raised the issue of restoring the flag of the independent Estonian republic, Kullo said. Since Estonia restored its blue, black and white flag, many other Soviet republics have resorted to flags they used before they became part of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Descendant of Humble Oil, Texaco Founders Dies
DOC.TEXT: Robert Lee ``R.L.'' Blaffer II, grandson of a Humble Oil founder and great-grandson of a Texaco founder, has died of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, authorities said. Blaffer, 30, was found dead early Wednesday in his bedroom in his condominium. Police were investigating the death as a suicide, Sgt. D.D. Shirley said. Police said no note was found. Friends and neighbors said Blaffer was not employed. They described him as friendly but a recluse, although last weekend he took his mother, Camilla, to a family friend's anniversary party. His grandfather, Robert Lee Blaffer, was a pioneer in the early days of the Texas Spindletop oil field discovery in 1902. Fifteen years later, the elder Blaffer and three partners helped found Humble Oil & Refining Co., which became Exxon. Robert Blaffer married Sarah Campbell, daughter of Texaco founder William T. Campbell. He is survived by his mother. Funeral arrangements are pending.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Killed Trying to Protect Puppies From gasoline ignited and
DOC.TEXT: killed the youngster and his dogs, authorities said. Roger Dale Langston, 7, had seen his grandfather use gasoline outside the house earlier Wednesday to keep ants out. He apparently decided to try the same thing to keep ants away from five puppies and their mother on a screened porch, said Fire Department Lt. Doug Conner. ``He just did it on his own,'' Conner said. The gasoline vapor was ignited by a pilot light on a dryer or water heater, which were on the porch, and the boy became trapped by flames, Conner said. A brother and the boys' grandfather tried to rescue him but were driven back by the heat.

DOC.HEAD: Police Detain Three More Kenyans in Crackdown on Opposition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with one opposition member saying he escaped security forces who came to arrest him. Pickup 9th, `Another lawyer...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities today detained three more prominent Kenyans linked to recent calls for a legalized opposition in this one-party state, including the son of a former vice president and two lawyers. The detentions of lawyer John Khaminwa, lawyer Mohamed Ibrahim, and Raila Odinga, son of former Vice President Odinga, brought to 10 the number of people who have been seized in a two-day sweep. An earlier report said that lawyer-editor Gitobu Imanyara, another opposition member, also was detained today, but an associate said Imanyara called him to say that he escaped security forces who came to his home. The associate, who requested anonymity, said Imanyara had gone into hiding. On Wednesday, police arrested Kenya's two top opposition leaders, who had urged the government to let them hold a public rally this weekend to push for multiparty democracy in Kenya. The two men, Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, are former Cabinet ministers who have been leading a campaign to legalize opposition parties this African nation of 23 million people. The detentions follow government promises of stern action aimed at halting the proposed rally on Saturday. A Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: ``The government has talked tough. Now it apparently has decided to act tough.'' The American Embassy in Nairobi said it was ``following the situation with interest and concern.'' Khaminwa was detained at about noon at police headquarters while trying to ascertain the whereabouts of the two opposition leaders picked up Wednesday. Another lawyer, Japheth Shamalla, who accompanied Khaminwa on his search, said he last saw Khaminwa as he was being led into the office of area police chief G.K. Kinoti. Later today, Odinga, a two-time former detainee and Kenya's longest-serving political prisoner, was seized at his office by plainclothes police, said his lawyer, Gibson Kamau Kuria. Kuria, also a former detainee and a prominent human rights activist, said he did not know where Odinga was taken. Ibrahim was seized this morning from his office at a prominent local law firm, according to the Daily Nation newspaper. It did not have further details. The government tonight announced the detentions of Matiba and Rubia, but it did not say where they were being held or whether they would be charged. The government did not mention the other detentions. A constitutional amendment in 1988 empowers authorities to hold people up to 14 days without charge. President Daniel arap Moi has described those seeking to legalize opposition parties as traitors and subversives, and has vowed to hunt them down ``like rats.'' He claims the existence of about 40 tribes in Kenya would invite tribal-based parties, leading to ethnic divisions and even tribal warfare. Matiba and Rubia say the one-party system has led to widespread corruption and election rigging. They have led a loose alliance of lawyers, politicians and churchmen seeking change in Kenya, which has been a de facto one-party state since the last opposition party was banned in 1969. On Tuesday night, Moi issued a warning to people planning to attend the weekend rally. ``Any blatant attempt to flout the law in respect of an illegal public meeting will be dealt with ... with the full resources for the protection of law and order which are at the disposal of the state,'' Moi said. Matiba and Rubia sought to hold the meeting at an historic field a few blocks from downtown Nairobi. The area, called Kamukunji, was used frequently before independence in 1963 by Jomo Kenyatta, who led the movement against British rule and went on to become the east African nation's first president. Although Matiba and Rubia have said they would not attend Saturday's rally if they were not granted a permit, there have been widespread rumors that many may others would gather at Kamukunji anyway.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Allies Agree to Bush Suggestion of Gorbachev Invitation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 8-10 with late developments. Should stand
DOC.TEXT: President Bush won approval from other Western leaders today to invite Mikhail S. Gorbachev to NATO in a dramatic goodwill gesture toward the Soviet Union. Bush also urged them to declare that nuclear weapons would be used in Europe only as a last resort but that proposal was questioned by Britain. Bush said leaders of the other Warsaw Pact nations of Eastern Europe also should be invited to NATO. All of the invitations are for some future date, not the two-day NATO summit that began today. The president made his surprise proposal to invite Gorbachev as NATO began debating steps to reshape the Western alliance as a result of the rapidly diminishing military threat from the East. French presidential spokesman Hubert Vedrine reported later that the allies had endorsed Bush's idea. However, a British spokesman said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was cool toward the idea of declaring nuclear weapons as arms of last resort. ``I think the trouble is we are concerned about the implications of last resort,'' the official said. Britain is wary that the U.S. declaration would remove the useful uncertainty about how the West would respond if the Soviets staged an attack. Diplomatic sources said the proposal was intended to demonstrate that NATO is changing to keep pace with rapid developments in East Europe and the Soviet Union. The Warsaw Pact has virtually collapsed since the Soviets' former military allies began ousting their long-dominant Communist governments last year. Vedrine said NATO would invite Gorbachev ``to come and speak in the name of the Soviet Union'' before the North Atlantic Council in Brussels. The council is the principal body of NATO and meets at various levels: ambassadors, foreign ministers, or on occasion, heads of state or government. It was not clear who would be Gorbachev's audience. Diplomatic sources said the invitation probably would be aimed at early December when a meeting of Western foreign ministers already is scheduled. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's proposal amounted to the allies ``reaching out to old adversaries.'' NATO foreign ministers met for four hours late today working on the language of the joint statement that will be issued at the conclusion of talks Friday. They were to get together again after a black-tie dinner with the leaders. Not long ago, it would have been unthinkable for a Soviet leader to be invited to address the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which was forged in 1949 to counter potential military aggression from the East. Now, however, Western leaders speak of the Soviet Union and East European nations more as friends than foes. Along with a series of Bush proposals to revamp NATO for a less militaristic future, the summiteers were expected to debate whether Western nations should rush cash assistance to Moscow to help bail out the Soviet Union's crumbling economy. On Wednesday, Bush seemed to ease his conditions for Western aid. The summit, however, was far from harmonious. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl told NATO leaders they should make a joint declaration with Warsaw Pact countries ``that we no longer regard one another as adversaries.'' Said Kohl: ``Confrontation and the Cold War belong to the past.'' But French President Francois Mitterrand said he opposed Kohl's call for a joint non-aggression declaration, as does the United States. One Canadian official said the idea was ``losing speed.'' Acknowledging that she was in danger of being called ``Cold War warrior,'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher cited detailed statistics about Soviet arms production and urged NATO to keep up its guard while reaching out to Moscow and East Europe. She also expressed qualms about Bush's proposal that NATO declare it would use nuclear arms in Europe only as a ``last resort.'' Mrs. Thatcher urged the Western allies to be avoid any misunderstanding about their support of European security ``lest the deterrence of our weaponry is impaired.'' Besides recommending a ``last resort'' nuclear policy for NATO, Bush has proposed the eventual scrapping of 1,470 nuclear artillery shells and 1,560 U.S. tactical nuclear bombs deployed in West Germany, Turkey and Italy. The diplomatic sources, who spoke only on condition they not be identified, said Bush did not envision that Gorbachev would rush to London to address the current 16-nation NATO summit, which ends Friday. West German spokesman Hans Klein said ``it is possible'' that a high-level NATO message to Soviet leaders. Separately, NATO spokesman Robin Stafford said NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner had accepted an invitation from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze to fly to Moscow, but that no date had been decided. ``We are at a turning point in Europe's history,'' said Mrs. Thatcher as the summit got under way. ``Our signal from this meeting must continue to be one of resolve in defense, resolve and unity and defense, coupled with willingness to extend the hand of friendship to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union,'' she said. Bush, looking tired after an overnight flight to London, sat next to Mrs. Thatcher and Secretary of State James A. Baker III as the leaders gathered around a long oval table in a chandeliered room of a government mansion. Mrs. Thatcher said she had received messages from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel within the last 24 hours. She did not disclose the contents but said the two leaders were ``as interested in the results of this summit as we are.'' Kohl insisted on full NATO membership for a united Germany, and said there was no reason for Soviet concern. Such a development would ``enhance their own stability and offer them a new opportunity for partnership,'' Kohl said. Offering words of caution, Mrs. Thatcher said, ``NATO has defended peace with freedom and justice but it's never threatened anyone. The cornerstones of that sure defense must remain, for we don't know what the future holds. But its architecture may change in the new situation.'' Machine gun-toting police patrolled Heathrow Airport's VIP lounge and sharpshooters watched from rooftops as the NATO leaders converged for their critical meetings in Lancaster House, a 19th century mansion in central London. The primary purpose of the meeting is to transform NATO from a now-outdated military machine into what essentially would be a political alliance. On Wednesday, Gorbachev oviet citizens' lives in two years or would resign.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says He Treated Hackman's Heart Problem Just in Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with doctor's news conference; adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gene Hackman narrowly avoided a heart attack when he checked into a hospital complaining of chest pain, his doctor said today. ``We think we got him just in the nick of time,'' Dr. Herbert Semler said at a news conference after he treated the actor for partial blockage of a coronary blood vessel. Hackman, 60, was vacationing on the Oregon Coast when he began suffering the pain. He was admitted Tuesday to St. Vincent Hospital & Medical Center. Semler said Hackman suffered from a narrowing of an artery leading to the heart. The doctor said he inserted a balloon catheter into the artery. Semler said he was recommending an exercise and diet plan for Hackman, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif. ``He's feeling fine and he's ready to make another movie,'' Semler said. He said his patient would be released late today or Friday. Hackman finished filming a new movie in Europe just before his Oregon vacation. The son of a journeyman pressman, Hackman is a former truck driver and soda jerk. His most acclaimed role to date was as the rough-and-tumble narcotics cop Popeye Doyle in 1971's ``The French Connection.'' His performance won him an Academy Award. He didn't pursue acting until he was in his 30s, attending the Pasadena Playhouse with Dustin Hoffman to study. His first break came in 1964, when he played opposite Sandy Dennis in the Broadway comedy ``Any Wednesday.'' He followed that a few years later with 1967's ``Bonnie and Clyde,'' in which he played Clyde's brother Buck and was nominated for an Oscar. His work in 1970's ``I Never Sang for My Father'' brought him another Academy Award nomination. In 1974's ``The Conversation,'' directed by Francis Ford Coppola, he played an obsessive surveillance agent. Other credits include ``Lilith,'' ``Hawaii,'' ``A Covenant With Death,'' ``Downhill Racer,'' ``Bite the Bullet,'' ``Scarecrow,'' ``Night Moves,'' ``Lucky Lady,'' ``The Domino Principle,'' ``A Bridge Too Far,'' ``Superman,'' ``The Package,'' ``Reds,'' ``No Way Out,'' ``Target,'' ``Hoosiers,'' ``Mississippi Burning, ``B.A.T. 21,'' and ``Loose Cannons.'' Hackman's upcoming releases are ``Postcards from the Edge'' and ``Narrow Margin.''

DOC.HEAD: Navy Announces New Ship Names
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has decided to name its last Los Angeles-class attack submarine the USS Cheyenne in honor of the capital of Wyoming, the Pentagon announced Thursday. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney hails from Casper, Wyo., and served the state as a member of the House of Representatives from 1979 until he was chosen to lead the Pentagon in 1989. The Navy also announced the names of other new ships authorized for construction in the current building program, including two Ohio class ballistic missile submarines. Named for states of the Union, they are the USS Rhode Island and the USS Maine. Two Arleigh Burke class destroyers were named after naval heroes and leaders in the naval service. The USS Russell honors Rear Adm. John Henry Russell, a distinguished commander in the Civil War, and his son, Maj. Gen. John Henry Russell, a former Marine Corps commandant. The USS Paul Hamilton honors Paul Hamilton, who served as the Secretary of the Navy from 1809 to 1813, the Navy said. Two names were assigned to Supply class fast combat support ships, the USS Rainier, and the USS Arctic. Three Avenger class minesweepers were given the names USS Ardent, USS Rockford and USS Dextrous. Three Osprey class coastal minehunters were given the names USS Pelican, USS Robin, and USS Oriole, while one Stalwart class ocean surveillance ship was named the USS Impeccable. Three ocean survey ships were named the USS Waters, the USS Pathfinder and the USS Sumner, the Navy said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Stage Warning Strikes
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 East Germans demanding better pay staged brief warning strikes Thursday, and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere complained about unreasonably high food prices. Despite the gloom pervading much of East Germany's rickety economy, Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl said that 63,490 private companies set up business, creating 150,000 jobs. But unemployment is expected to surge over the next months as East Germany faces competition from the West. Pohl also said at a news conference that 6,777 of East Germany's 8,000 state companies were being privatized. East and West Germany merged their economies and social welfare systems on Sunday in a prelude to full German unification, expected after all-German elections, proposed for Dec. 2. Several thousand metalworkers struck seven plants near Leipzig after pay talks deadlocked two days ago, according to the state ADN news agency. The half-hour stoppages were organized by West Germany's powerful IG Metall labor union, which threatened to stage ``more than just warning strikes'' unless negotiations resumed, ADN said. The agency gave no specifics on the workers' demands. It also did not say why the negotiations collapsed. In southwestern Erfurt, 9,000 workers in metalworking and electric equipment industries rallied outside their labor union's headquarters as contract talks began, ADN said. They demanded job security and more say in how their companies are run. IG Metall wants East Germany to adopt the West German system of stipulating salary scales and job descriptions in huge collective contracts that bind all workers in a specific industry. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said in Thursday's Die Welt newspaper that lack of self-control on the salary front ``will lead straight to unemployment.'' De Maiziere, in an address to parliament Thursday, said the prices of some foodstuffs varied 100 percent from one East German region to another. ``There's no way that can be justified merely by higher transportation costs or overheads,'' he said. ADN reported price rises of 400 percent to 600 percent in the northern Mecklenburg and Pomerania regions and said there were long shopping lines in southeastern Dresden. ``There are cities in East Germany where the average price levels are way above those in West Germany,'' Pohl said. ``We need certain guarantees that citizens ... won't be exploited.'' In his parliamentary address, de Maiziere also urged NATO reform. Leaders of the Western alliance began meeting in London Thursday to discuss the pact's future amid a changing Europe. ``NATO must regard itself as an alliance of free and democratic nations in the most comprehensive sense, and reform its structure and strategy,'' the East German leader said. ``That means saying goodbye to the current `flexible response' strategy, which relies on forward defense and using nuclear weapons as the first party in a conflict.''

DOC.HEAD: Albania Reportedly Reimposes Some Travel Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to CORRECT that government changed visa requirement, not passport requirement. Pickup 5th pvs, `The Austrian...'
DOC.TEXT: Albania today reimposed some travel restrictions, the Austria Press Agency reported, after hundreds of its citizens stormed foreign embassies or gathered outside them in an effort to flee their homeland. The reported government move, only two days after the restrictions were lifted, came as diplomats were deadlocked over the fate of more than 200 Albanians who have taken refuge in the embassies. The Austrian report, apparently based on official sources in Tirana, the Albanian capital, said the measure was necessary because of the ``alarming situation'' in front of the foreign missions. On Tuesday, a new Albanian law went into effect allowing any adult to apply for a passport. The law also said that Albanians holding passports could apply directly to foreign embassies for visas. The Austria Press Agency said the government announced today that Austrians could no longer apply to the embassies for visas. The report mentioned nothing about any change in the new passport law. The Austrian news agency, which has had a reporter in Tirana for the last few weeks, said another 15 people had asked for asylum at the West German Embassy, and at least 20 refugees were said to have climbed the fence of the Czechoslovak Embassy, already sheltering 25 people. If the figures are correct, the total of refugees now holed up inside foreign missions would be between 270 and 290. Witnesses in front of the West German Embassy claimed a man was brutally beaten and dragged away by security forces, but a German government spokesman in Bonn said there were no reports of new disturbances outside the mission. The asylum-seekers, many of whom crashed through gates or scaled walls to enter embassies earlier this week, present one of the biggest challenges in 45 years to the rulers of Europe's poorest, most isolated country. Albania, the last hard-line Communist country left in Eastern Europe, in recent months has expressed interest shedding its isolationist ways and broadening ties with other nations. But the Communist monopoly on power continues. Communist Party chief Ramiz Alia, who succeeded Stalinist strongman Enver Hoxha, has firmly rejected a the type of multiparty system that has taken hold in the rest of Eastern Europe. The lifting of the travel restrictions on Tuesday was part of a reform package adopted in May. Under it, Albanians who previously were not allowed to travel freely were entitled to passports; a ban on religion was lifted; and the death penalty for defectors was abolished. Earlier today, a diplomat said by telephone that as many as 500 Albanians assembled in front of the Yugoslav Embassy, waiting for travel visas. Another crowd of several hundred people was waiting outside the West German mission and a smaller group in front of the French Embassy, the diplomat said. In Geneva, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar today urged authorities in Tirana to be ``consistent'' in allowing the Albanians seeking refuge to leave the country. Perez de Cuellar visited Albania in May, the first visit by a U.N. secretary-general. He helped persuade the government to allow six brothers and sisters to leave Albania for Italy. In Brussels, the 12 European Community nations also urged the Albanian government to allow its citizens to leave. They also urged Albanian authorities not to remove any of the Albanians from the embassies but to respect ``the inviolability of diplomatic missions.'' The United States has no embassy in Albania since the two countries do not have diplomatic relations. A Hungarian diplomat who was reached from Budapest today said a man and a woman walked into the embassy compound this morning as ``we were opening the gate to let a car out.'' The two brought the number of refugees inside to six. ``There is a strong police presence around the embassy, but no incidents,'' said the Hungarian diplomat who, like all others, refused to be identified. The Austrian news agency said no agreement was reached in a meeting between Yugoslav Ambassador Novak Pribicevic and Bashki Dino, a director at the Albanian Foreign Ministry. Pribicevic was chosen to represent other foreign diplomats in the talks. Last week, a few Albanians hoping to flee their country of 3.2 million sought political asylum at embassies. Word of their success apparently spread and on Monday their numbers swelled. Dozens of refugees were shot at by security forces as they clambered over walls or crashed trucks through embassy gates in a desperate bid for freedom, diplomatic sources said. It was not immediately known how many people were injured or arrested. At least three people were wounded by gunfire from secret police agents, said diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. Between 30 and 40 refugees suffered minor injuries when their truck crashed through the iron gates of the West German Embassy, a spokesman in Bonn said. The embassies were scrambling to find ways to feed the refugees. Albania refused on Wednesday to grant landing permission for a cargo plane carrying relief supplies for the West German Embassy, where 86 Albanians had sought refuge, said Hanns Schumacher, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Welcomes Bush's `Last Resort' Proposal
DOC.TEXT: West Germany on Thursday welcomed President Bush's proposal to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort and called on NATO to remove all nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Europe. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is under enormous domestic pressure to get rid of nuclear weapons on German soil, also said NATO and the Warsaw Pact should declare a formal end to more than four decades of the Cold War in the summit's final communique. ``The hallmark of the alliance's traditional political role is that it extends the hand of friendship and cooperation to former enemies who renounce confrontation and show tangible proof,'' Kohl said. ``We are prepared to solemnly state in a joint declaration with the Warsaw Pact countries that we no longer regard one another as adversaries,'' Kohl told the 15 other alliance leaders. The United States opposes such a joint declaration between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The West Germans were pleased with Bush's ``last resort'' proposal, made at the opening of the two-day summit, to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. If adopted, the Bush proposal would represent a fundamental shift in NATO's current ``flexible response'' doctrine, which is designed to create uncertainty about when the alliance uses nuclear armaments. Hans Klein, the West German government's spokesman, agreed with Bush's proposal. ``The nuclear weapons were almost exclusively seen as a means to prevent war,'' he said. ``When you speak of them as a last resort, that is a formulation that is accepted by us.'' Kohl also proposed eliminating nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Europe. Bush has indicated his willingness to withdraw the 1,470 American shells, most of them located in West Germany. In general West Germany, along with Italy, have sought to lessen the focus on nuclear weapons without abandoning them; Britain and France, which have their own nuclear arsenals, have been less willing to relax the nuclear deterrent. Since 1983, there have been massive protests in Europe, especially West Germany, over the installation of medium-range nuclear missiles. But the United States has withdrawn 54 of its 108 Pershing 2 missiles, and 16 of its 96 cruise missiles from West Germany. The pullout is continuing. Kohl has been at the forefront of extending a helping hand to the Soviets, as West Germany seeks to remove the Kremlin's objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. Klein underscored that view Thursday, again stressing the need to support the reform processes in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The spokesman said a discussion about Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's mounting domestic difficulties ``came up again and again'' during the summit's first day. But he declined to say what assessment the NATO leaders had made of Gorbachev's chances for political survival. The Soviet president the day before had said his government should step down if it can't turn the country around within two years.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Plans To Consolidate Accounting Operations
DOC.TEXT: Top Pentagon officials will develop plans to streamline the varied financial and accounting operations for the armed services and defense agencies, it was announced on Thursday. At present, Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and defense agency operations function independently. Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood has instructed senior Pentagon officials to develop organizational plans to consolidate the operations under the direction of the department's comptroller, a Pentagon statement said. Those officials, who are scheduled to begin their work next week, will submit plans to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for approval within the next six months. The consolidation comes as part of Cheney's much-touted Defense Management Review, an attempt to make the department more efficient amid the nation's budget constraints. The statement said the services and agencies have their own operations, policies, management and overhead structures, develop and use their own accounting and finance systems, and set many of their own priorities. ``There is a great need within the department for standardization of financial and accounting information. The integrated ... organization will enable us to use our limited resources with greater efficiency,'' the statement quoted Atwood as saying. The new organization will encompass centers that employ 7,000 civilians and 500 military personnel. They include: _Army Finance and Accounting Center, Indianapolis, Ind. _Navy Accounting and Finance Center, Crystal City, Va. _Navy Finance Center, Cleveland, Ohio. _Marine Crops Finance Center, Kansas City, Mo. _Air Force Accounting and Finance Center, Denver, Colo. _Defense Logistics Agency Finance Center, Columbus, Ohio. _Washington Headquarters Services Finance and Accounting Operations, Pentagon. Those are the centers that oversee the pay going to the nation's active, reserve and retired military officers. They also supervise the civilians who work for the department and administer payments to defense contractors, transportation and travel payments, accounting, and reporting to the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget. The changes will not immediately affect positions at the various centers, ``but one of the objectives is to reduce cost. We expect the work force to be smaller in the long run,'' Defense Department spokesman Bill Caldwell said. Streamlining the centers into one organization will mean fewer jobs, but positions will be pared ``in increments, primarily through attrition and retraining personnel to fill positions in other areas where ever feasible,'' Caldwell said. He said a savings of $150 million annually is anticipated when the operation is fully implemented, an estimate that amounts to slightly less than 10 per cent of the current operational costs. The savings estimate was derived from a study of the major functions that will be consolidated, the official said. Although up-front costs for the consolidation could run over $100 million, they are expected to be offset in the long run, the official said. No decision has been made on where the new organization will be located.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Bodies Found From Deadly Ohio Flood
DOC.TEXT: Two more bodies have been recovered of victims of flash floods that ravaged eastern Ohio last month, bringing the toll to 26 known dead and seven missing, officials said Thursday. About 5{ inches of rain fell near this eastern Ohio village in three hours on June 14, sending walls of water down Wegee and Pipe creeks. A woman's body was spotted Wednesday night in the Ohio River by boaters. The body was recovered five miles south of Shadyside by West Virginia authorities, said Belmont County Coroner's Investigator Chuck Vogt. The 26th body was found Thursday about two miles south of the mouth of the Wegee, washed up on the Ohio shore of the Ohio River, which divides Ohio and West Virginia, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Name Change Proposed for Soviet Communist Party
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party leaders will consider a proposal to change their party's name in order to regain the people's trust, a spokesman said Thursday. Col. Gen. Dmitri Volkogonov, a prominent historian, proposed that the party change its name to something like ``The Party of Democratic Socialism,'' spokesman Alexander Lebedev said. However, the idea was unlikely to win support at the 4,657-member party congress, a poll by the congress' sociological service found. It reported that 80 percent of delegates favored keeping the name as it is, and only 14 percent backed changing it, according to the nightly news program ``Vremya.'' But Volkogonov, a three-star general who has written ground-breaking biographies of Josef Stalin and Leon Trotsky, told the congress' section on party renewal that the name change was inevitable. ``In his (Volkogonov's) words, even if the proposal doesn't find support now, in two or three years it will nonetheless be necessary to take this step,'' Lebedev reported. The proposal came at a section meeting that was closed to journalists. Lebedev said Volkogonov also argued that the current party name was a legacy from Stalin. The historian said Communist ideals have turned out to be ``a lovely utopia'' whereas socialism deals with more immediate, attainable goals. ``The renaming is not a goal in itself, but it's needed to restore people's trust,'' Lebedev quoted Volkogonov as saying. He spoke at a briefing Thursday evening. The section decided the proposal should be brought to the floor of the congress, Lebedev said, without specifying when it will be addressed. Several Eastern European Communist parties have changed their names or even disbanded in the past year in a struggle to retain vestiges of their former power amid political upheaval. The congress, which began Monday and is scheduled to run for 10 days, comes at a time of crisis for the Soviet party. It is not in immediate danger of losing its dominance of the political scene, but its authority is at an extreme low, members are reported quitting by the thousands and radical Communists have talked of splitting off and forming a new party. The congress, meeting in the Kremlin's massive Palace of Congresses, is technically the highest organ of the Communist Party, empowered to set the party line, change the leadership and revamp the party's entire structure. It broke into several sections Thursday after three days of plenary meetings at which Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the party leader and president, underwent a barrage of criticism for flaws in his reforms but also received repeated votes of personal support. Lebedev reported that in other action: _ Many delegates urged a sweeping turnover in the party's top leadership, perhaps by as much as 90 percent. _ Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin received heavy criticism for his speech Wednesday, in which he maintained that if the Communist Party does not support the country's switch from a planned to a market economy it will be left on the sidelines of history. _ Gorbachev, who sat in on the section on agriculture, urged the party to talk less and do more. The party ``has to understand that its monopoly is over, and it has to prove its right to an avant-garde role with deeds,'' he reportedly said. _ Several high-ranking officers accused the party of propagating a foreign policy that led to the loss of Eastern Europe and the weakening of the nation's defenses. Others defended the country's foreign policy as ``victorious.'' Earlier Thursday, a local Communist official said Gorbachev had acknowledged to a meeting of his colleagues that the Kremlin cast them adrift as it rapidly switched signals in a bid to quiet republics' demands for autonomy. Filip Stroganov, a party leader from the Baltic republic of Latvia, said Gorbachev had converted him from an opponent to a supporter during a meeting with more than 300 district and regional officials late Wednesday. ``I like people with character,'' Stroganov told reporters. ``Yesterday I saw his character.'' Stroganov said that regional leaders complained that Gorbachev and the central leadership changed their minds too often on a new structure to bind the Soviet Union's republics together. Latvia's neighbor, Lithuania, already has declared independence. The parliament of Latvia and the third Baltic republic, Estonia, have signaled their intention to follow. ``We don't have a clear position on this question,'' Stroganov said. ``The lack of a precise position on this issue put us in an awkward situation.'' Gorbachev ``agreed with this yesterday,'' he said. The regional leaders had been pressing for a meeting for more than two years, and Gorbachev also acknowledged it had been a mistake to put it off for so long, he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to RECAST grafs 1-2 to note that Detroit News also reported.
DOC.TEXT: When a speechwriter for Nelson Mandela struggled for a reference to ``Motortown'' music for the anti-apartheid leader's speech here, a flight attendant came to the rescue, local newspapers reported Thursday. The writer wanted to use an Aretha Franklin song that would relate to the struggle of the people, and he asked flight attendant Germaine Smith for help, according to the Detroit Free Press. The Detroit News carried a similar report. Smith, of Hyattsville, Md., suggested the Marvin Gaye song ``What's Going On,'' which Mandela quoted in his June 28 speech at Tiger Stadium. The lyrics, ``Brother, brother, there's far too many of you dying. Mother, mother, there's far too many of you crying,'' were quoted by Mandela in reference to the violence and squalid conditions endured by many blacks in racially segregated South Africa. Before quoting from the late Gaye's 1971 hit, Mandela told the sold-out crowd that he listened to ``Motortown'' music during his 27{ years in prison on a sabotage conviction. Gaye recorded on the Detroit-founded Motown record label.

DOC.HEAD: US Wants to Send Experts on MIA Mission to Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are hoping for a quick response to their request to send experts to Cambodia to return the remains of Americans believed killed during the Vietnam war. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon has told Congress the Cambodians have remains they believe are those of U.S. servicemen. Cambodian officials have agreed in principle to allow U.S. experts to examine the remains and to allow repatriation of those that prove to be American. Solomon has said in congressional testimony that the administration wants to send experts to Phnom Penh as soon as possible. About 80 Americans are still unaccounted for in Cambodia. U.S. experts have been to Vietnam and Laos on missions related to missing Americans but never to Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING
With AM-NATO-Summit Rdp,Bjt
West Germany Welcomes Bush's `Last Resort' Proposal
DOC.TEXT: West Germany on Thursday welcomed President Bush's proposal to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort and called on NATO to remove all nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Europe. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is under enormous domestic pressure to get rid of nuclear weapons on German soil, also said NATO and the Warsaw Pact should declare a formal end to more than four decades of the Cold War in the summit's final communique. ``The hallmark of the alliance's traditional political role is that it extends the hand of friendship and cooperation to former enemies who renounce confrontation and show tangible proof,'' Kohl said. ``We are prepared to solemnly state in a joint declaration with the Warsaw Pact countries that we no longer regard one another as adversaries,'' Kohl told the 15 other alliance leaders. The United States opposes such a joint declaration between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The West Germans were pleased with Bush's ``last resort'' proposal, made at the opening of the two-day summit, to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. If adopted, the Bush proposal would represent a fundamental shift in NATO's current ``flexible response'' doctrine, which is designed to create uncertainty about when the alliance uses nuclear armaments. Hans Klein, the West German government's spokesman, agreed with Bush's proposal. ``The nuclear weapons were almost exclusively seen as a means to prevent war,'' he said. ``When you speak of them as a last resort, that is a formulation that is accepted by us.'' Kohl also proposed eliminating nuclear-tipped artillery shells from Europe. Bush has indicated his willingness to withdraw the 1,470 American shells, most of them located in West Germany. In general West Germany, along with Italy, have sought to lessen the focus on nuclear weapons without abandoning them; Britain and France, which have their own nuclear arsenals, have been less willing to relax the nuclear deterrent. Since 1983, there have been massive protests in Europe, especially West Germany, over the installation of medium-range nuclear missiles. But the United States has withdrawn 54 of its 108 Pershing 2 missiles, and 16 of its 96 cruise missiles from West Germany. The pullout is continuing. Kohl has been at the forefront of extending a helping hand to the Soviets, as West Germany seeks to remove the Kremlin's objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. Klein underscored that view Thursday, again stressing the need to support the reform processes in the Soviet Union and elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The spokesman said a discussion about Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's mounting domestic difficulties ``came up again and again'' during the summit's first day. But he declined to say what assessment the NATO leaders had made of Gorbachev's chances for political survival. The Soviet president the day before had said his government should step down if it can't turn the country around within two years.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Reach Monrovian Suburbs; Government Soliders Loot
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following includes a pool report filed by journalists in the Liberian capital. Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul was among them.

About 5,300 rebels fought government troops in Monrovia's suburbs Thursday, according to an insurgent source in neighboring Ivory Coast, while soldiers ransacked stores and restaurants. President Samuel Doe's advisers continued to desert as the rebels tightened their grip on the capital. On Wednesday, Doe's most trusted commander, Lt. Gen. Charles Julu, left Liberia, weakening the president's already fragile position, U.S. officials in Washington said. Meanwhile, a senior rebel leader in the United States accused the U.S. administration of trying to prevent rebel leader Charles Taylor from taking power and said the rebels would not halt their advance to permit peace talks. In the city's eastern and western suburbs, growing numbers of rebels battled soldiers for a fourth consecutive day. The rebels now control all roads into Monrovia. Rebel sources in Ivory Coast said the 800-man contingent that attacked the capital's suburbs was reinforced by 4,500 others. The reinforcments brought up heavy armaments captured from army bases outside Monrovia. The rebel source said the insurgents took Schiefflin, the military camp 12 miles east of Monrovia. The rebels estimated Doe still had 2,000 fighting men in the capital. For the first time since the fighting began, the Christian missionary station ELWA did not broadcast Thursday evening. It broadcasts several times a day for several hours. The station is on the outskirts of Monrovia. In Monrovia, government troops shot their way into stores, warehouses and restaurants under cover of curfew and emptied the shelves in the early hours of thursday. Soldiers roamed the streets in stolen cars, firing in the air to frighten people and keep them back while they looted. The only vehicles on the streets were driven by soldiers who left dead and wounded civilians by the roadside. As morning broke, frightened Monrovians ventured out into deserted streets and discovered at least 16 bodies. A man with three bullet wounds bled for four hours in the city's main waterfront market despite pleas to soldiers to carry him to the hospital. Monrovia's main John F. Kennedy hospital, which like the rest of the city has been without water and power for more than a week, has been abandoned by doctors and nurses and most of its patients. A serious food shortage in Monrovia has forced people to beg for rice. ``Give us food, we are dying,'' one man said. Rebel leader Tom Woewiyu, based in the United States, said the Bush administration failed to keep a promise to force Doe out if the rebels held off from attacking the capital. ``The U.S. has had ample opportunity to take this man out ... But for some reason they don't want to do that. ... Maybe they want to see a government evolve that does not have Taylor involved in it. I don't know why. He's an unknown factor, I suppose.'' Woewiyu said senior State Department officials who had supported Doe during his 10-year rule were trying to intervene to help him again now. The State Department has said it questions Taylor's commitment to democracy. Doe, in his heavily guarded executive mansion, said Tuesday he would resign if his safety and that of his Krahn tribe were guaranteed, but so far he has shown no sign of leaving. In Monrovia, soldiers fired on fishermen in canoes off the coast, claiming they were transporting rebels. Shipping sources said 250,000 tons of rice bound for the stricken city is on board a ship, the Sea Star, steaming among U.S. navy ships off Monrovia. The captain reportedly feared the ship would be ransacked if it docked. The sources also said a ship carrying 5,000 tons of rice put in at the rebel-held port of Buchanan. The British-owned Rizcup Enterprise was hijacked by rebels off Monrovia last week. Health workers said young children and old people in Buchanan were falling sick and risked dying of starvation last week. Workers at a nearby rubber plantation were eating pig feed after food had run out. In Monrovia, the food shortage has forced people to forage for leaves and roots on patches of wasteland throughout the city. Meanwhile, Julu, head of the security unit assigned to protect Doe, fled to neighboring Sierra Leone. He had been chief of staff only since the weekend resignation of Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar, who also fled Liberia. Julu led army troops who killed more than 2,000 civilians in northern Liberia after an unsuccessful coup attempt against Doe. Liberia was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves and their descendents who ruled the county until Doe seized power in April 1980 in a violent coup. Liberia was black Africa's first independent nation.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Cautiously Wants to Draw East European Countries Closer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Fitzwater on Bush suggestion, subbing 3 grafs for grafs 2-3 pvs, and subbing 3 grafs for grafs 21-11, U.S. officials
DOC.TEXT: The NATO allies on Thursday searched for a way to draw East European countries, including the Soviet Union, closer to the Western alliance without giving away military secrets. President Bush suggested at the opening session of the two- day summit of NATO leaders the establishment of liaison offices between nations in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and the alliance, according to White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``The general purpose is to find some way to give them access to NATO in a learning capacity and hopefully one in which they would appreciate where we're coming from,'' he said. A diplomatic source, who demanded anonymity, said Bush emphasized that the Warsaw Pact officials would ``not sit at the table with us.'' The novel idea is one of a number of proposals being floated by the United States and other countries to revamp the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to respond to diminished East-West tensions. The allies want to make NATO, created in 1949 in an era of hostility and suspicion, appear less threatening to the Kremlin. In doing so, they hope to encourage Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to drop his objections to membership in the alliance for a united Germany. West Germany is an influential member of NATO, but East Germany belongs to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The idea of creating a special diplomatic status for the East European countries reflects the West's uncertainty about how to deal with its former adversaries. The European Community, the trading bloc of a dozen West European nations, also is struggling to give the emerging democracies as much economic help as possible _ short of full membership. It has come up with the idea of associate memberships. NATO, too, doesn't see its one-time enemies becoming new recruits. ``We're going to have to investigate ways of helping these countries be part of a bigger whole _ without necessarily having them become parts of the organization,'' said a senior NATO diplomat, demanding anonymity. ``We don't in any way want to give Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia (for example) the sense that they're being left out,'' he said. ``But at the same time, we can't officially bring them in.'' Officials don't want to upset the balance of power in Europe and leave the Soviet Union, still a formidable military power, without allies. ``For the Soviet Union not only having a united Germany in NATO but having some Eastern European countries in NATO would be perhaps a bit much to swallow,'' said the NATO diplomat. Jane Sharp, senior researcher at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute in Sweden, said, ``The big problem now is not to exclude and isolate the Russians. Taking East European countries into NATO probably is not a good idea.'' Even Hungary, which intends to withdraw from the Warsaw Pact by late next year, isn't rushing to join. ``Hungary does not want to make the European security situation less stable than it is today,'' Hungarian Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky said after a recent visit to NATO. ``Even if it were possible politically for us to think about applying for membership in NATO, that would be not conducive to security right now,'' he said. But there are ways to create closer links. ``I would expect NATO to strengthen and thicken its ties with like-minded states and reforming states,'' said a NATO official, demanding anonymity. U.S. officials have said Hungary has quietly proposed to NATO participating as an ``observer'' in political or non-military committees. Fitzwater said details of Bush's proposal have yet to be fleshed out. But he said it could mean inviting the Warsaw Pact countries to have an observer status at NATO, let them set up temporary or permanent liaison offices or attend meetings. No nations outside of the alliance currently have such a status, NATO officials said. Many countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, have separate missions to the European Community, even though they are not members. Moscow opened its liaison office last year. By doing so, they can keep closer tabs on the community's business and increase contacts with trading bloc officials. The United States also uses its mission to voice complaints over trade policies. At NATO, East European diplomats might be able to sit on some of the many conferences it holds yearly on a range of topics. The alliance has panels on science and technology, economics and one on the challenges of modern society. There has been a greater trend toward openness with the East. Since 1986, military observers from Warsaw Pact nations have attended Western war games. Last December, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze made an unprecedented visit to NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium. Since then, the foreign ministers of Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have stopped by. East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel will do so next week.

DOC.HEAD: One-Party Gov't Broadens Crackdown on Opposition, Torture Feared
DOC.TEXT: The one-party government on Thursday broadened its crackdown on proponents of multiparty democracy, arresting four more prominent Kenyans, including the son of a former vice president. The wives of two detained opposition leaders pleaded with President Daniel arap Moi's government to refrain from torture in what appeared to be the harshest crackdown since 1982. Thursday's arrests, of three lawyers and of the son of a former vice president, brought to at least 11 the number of people detained since Wednesday by the single-party government, according to detainees' families and other sources close to opposition figures. Several other prominent Kenyans went into hiding Thursday night. The arrests follow months of official criticism of those calling for reform, and come in advance of a rumored rally for multiparty democracy that the government has vowed to prevent. Two of those detained, former Cabinet ministers Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, had asked the government for permission to hold a meeting Saturday in support of legalizing political opposition, which has been outlawed since 1982. Their request was not granted, but rumor has been widespread in this East African capital that crowds might nonetheless appear, and Moi has warned people against attending any meeting. Matiba and Rubia were seized Wednesday by plainclothes security agents. In a press release Thursday, their wives, Edith Matiba and Hannah Rubia, said that ``our husbands' arrest is intended to force curtailment of the multiparty debate (and) stop lawful and peaceful changes which are crucial if Kenya is to avoid the well trodden path of so many other African states.'' The women, noting the unexplained slaying in February of Kenya's foreign minister, said they were ``extremely worried'' about their husband's lives, and about ill treatment the men might receive. ``We appeal to the Kenyan government not to torture our husbands,'' they said. Their statement reflected the heightening tensions that calls for political pluralism have brought to Kenya, a country best known for stability and democracy on a troubled continent. Since the beginning of the year a loose coalition emboldened by the changes in Eastern Europe has repeatedly accused the ruling Kenya African National Union party of intolerance, corruption and election-rigging. The government has flatly rejected any move toward multiple parties, and Cabinet ministers have called those backing such moves subversives. Moi, who has ruled Kenya since 1978, has repeatedly threatened arrests, vowing to hunt down political pluralists ``like rats.'' In a statement Tuesday, he said the government would use force if necessary to halt activities it deems subversive. ``The government has talked tough. Now it apparently has decided to act tough,'' said a Western diplomat, speaking on condition he not be identified further, when asked about the recent arrests. The American Embassy in Nairobi said Thursday it was ``following the situation with interest and concern.'' Later Thursday, lawyer John Khaminwa was detained at the provincial police headquarters, Mrs. Matiba and Mrs. Rubia said. Mohamed Ibrahim, who is with a law firm whose members have been critical of the government, also was detained Thursday, according to the English-language newspaper Daily Nation. Raila Odinga, son of former Vice President Oginga Odinga, was arrested at his office, said Gibson Kamau Kuria, a human rights lawyer. The younger Odinga, whose father is still seen as a potential rival to the government despite being removed from the vice presidency in the 1960s, has already twice been held for lengthy periods by Moi's government. Late Thursday, about 10 police seized Gitobu Iminyara, a lawyer who edits a monthly magazine that often criticizes the government on human rights issues, Kuria, the human rights lawyer, was one of several prominant Kenyans who went into hiding late Thrusday. Five associates of Matiba, including his driver, two bodyguards and two personal assistants, also were detained late Wednesday, according to Matiba's office. Kenyan law permits police to hold people without charge for up to 14 days. Late Thursday the government said it was holding Matiba and Rubia under public security statutes, but made no mention of the other detainees. Matiba's daughter, Julie, said the family had no word on where he was being held. Kenya has been a de facto one-party state since the last opposition party, led by the elder Odinga, was banned in 1969. A 1982 constitutional amendment declared it a one-party state. Later that year, the government arrested scores of people following a failed coup.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-agers Visit Israel, Africa to Promote Racial Harmony
DOC.TEXT: A black student took the podium recently at a party to promote racial harmony and helped lead the audience of blacks and Jews through a Hebrew song. Last year, Jermaine Cheeseborough was one of a dozen Philadelphia high school students who traveled together for a month to Africa and Israel. The message he brought back is that racial intolerance is encouraged when people from different ethnic groups don't come into contact with each other. Wednesday, six black and six Jewish high school students left Philadelphia on for a similar trip intended to break down racial stereotypes. The program, known as ``Operation Understanding,'' was set up six years ago by Philadelphia's U.S. Rep. William H. Gray III, who is black, and George H. Ross, former chairman of the board of the American Jewish Committee. The 12 students and two chaperones will spend 12 days in the West African nations of Senegal and Gambia and 12 days in Israel. They will then visit New York's Harlem and Lower East Side, and Mississippi before returning home. After returning, they'll give talks at high schools, synagogues and churches. ``What you are about to experience is one of the most breathtaking and awe-inspiring experiences of your life,'' Cheeseborough told the youngsters Tuesday night. Cheeseborough said he attended a predominantly black high school and until the 1989 trip had little interaction with Jewish people. ``Now,'' he said, ``I'm awakened.'' In addition to the travel, there was ``another trip going on between the students. I gained 11 brothers and sisters. I'm sure we'll remain friends for the rest of our lives,'' he said. Keith Peltzman, 17, one of the Jewish students who left on Wednesday's trip, said there is a ``silent separation'' between different races at schools across the United States. Even though many schools are demographically integrated, he said, they are not socially integrated. He said many white students let high school programs on African-American history ``go through one ear and out the other.'' ``What I hope to gain is an understanding of black culture,'' he said. ``And I hope to be able to come back to my friends and tell them about it.'' The $85,000 needed to fund the program for one year was raised from private and public sources. Public and private high schools in Philadelphia were invited to participate. The schools selected 100 applicants initially and that number was narrowed to 12. As part of the process, applicants had to write essays on their own and other ethnic groups. ``They wanted to see how aware we were,'' said Lockie Andrews, 16, of Central High School. Ms. Andrews, who is black, was among those chosen for the trip this year. Murray Friedman, the Middle Atlantic States director of the American Jewish Committee, said a similar program is under way in Baltimore. Other cities have also expressed an interest. At the send-off for the students, Philadelphia Councilman George Burrell said that as a politician he often faces the problem of ``grown adults not communicating with each other.'' ``High school is one of the toughest environments for race relations in America today,'' he said. ``Take your understanding and try to find a solution to this complex problem.'' Eighteen-year-old Jolie Davis, a 1988 alumna, said the trip had taught her to deal with prejudice. Davis, who is Jewish and just completed her freshman year at Brandeis University, said whenever she hears about prejudice against any racial or ethnic group ``it hurts me.'' ``One of the important things I learned is that everyone has stereotypes,'' she said, ``and it's important to break them down.''

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Wall To Be Gone By December
DOC.TEXT: The remnants of the Berlin Wall will be demolished by the end of this year, the East German defense minister was quoted as saying Thursday. A West German firm has been contracted to tear down what is left of the 61-mile barrier, Rainer Eppelmann told the state ADN news agency. The rubble will be used to build a new express railway line from Berlin to Hanover, West Germany, Eppelmann said. The barriers separating West Berlin from rural East Germany to the north, west and south will probably take another year to be demolished, he said. The Berlin Wall effectively fell on Nov. 9, when Communists who had ousted hard-line leader Erich Honecker lifted all travel restrictions for East Germans in an effort to retain power. Since then, the graffiti-covered wall, the most visible symbol of the Cold War, has been torn down in dozens of places. All controls on the East-West border ended when the two Germanys merged their economies on July 1. Berlin's most famous border crossing, Checkpoint Charlie, was hoisted into history late last month. The wall was built on Aug. 13, 1961, to stem the flow of East Germans trying to escape to the West during repressive Communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Thursday's Highlights of the Communist Party Congress ^With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Highlights of Thursday's session of the 28th Communist Party Congress, its fourth day:

NAME CHANGE: The congress will consider a proposal by prominent historian Col. Gen. Dmitri Volkogonov that the Communist Party change its name in order to regain people's trust. Although a poll found that the idea may not have the full support of the congress, Volkogonov said a name change is inevitable.

LAST WOMAN: Alexandra Biryukova, the only woman in the ruling Politburo, told the economic section she was retiring because she had been in the party leadership for 20 years, and she thought leaders should only be allowed two five-year terms anyway. Biryukova, who oversees consumer goods, was barraged with 120 questions from delegates.
LOW TIDE: Marshal Nikolai Ogarkov, former Soviet chief of staff, complained that ``the party's authority and power has never been lower,'' and blamed the media for many of the party's image problems.

ETHNIC CONFLICTS: The section on ethnic relations called the party's work in its field ``unsatisfactory'' and especially criticized the leadership for not stemming Baltic secessionism in time. One delegate dubbed liberal Politburo member Alexander Yakovlev ``the godfather of Baltic separatism.''

ARMY HARD-LINER: Maj. Gen. Ivan Nikulin complained Soviet foreign policy had led to the loss of allies in Eastern Europe and said Gorbachev's idea of a ``common European home'' was ``a myth'' that would lead to a greater gap between the Soviet Union and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Army Seizes 800 Pounds of Cocaine, Drug Terrorism Intensifies
DOC.TEXT: Security forces seized about 800 pounds of pure cocaine at an airport in northwest Colombia as a wave of drug-related terrorism intensified in major cities, officials said Thursday. The cocaine was found Wednesday aboard an airplane that was about to take off for the United States, an army statement said. It said two pilots at the scene were arrested. Police, meanwhile, on Wednesday destroyed a jungle laboratory in southern Colombia used to process cocaine, a national police spokeswoman said. She spoke on condition of anonymity. During the operation, police seized around 900 pounds of coca paste, the raw material used to produce cocaine, she said. She added that two suspected drug traffickers were arrested in houses near the laboratory. In other drug-related developments, six police posts in Medellin, where the world's most powerful cocaine cartel has its headquarters, have been bombed since Tuesday night, a Medellin police communique said. The blasts caused no casualties since policemen who had been stationed at the posts had recently been transferred to other parts of the city. Drug traffickers have been engaged in a campaign to kill policemen in Medellin in retaliation for a massive anti-drug crackdown. An off-duty police officer was shot dead Wednesday night, bringing to 160 the number of policemen murdered in or around the city so far this year, police said. Authorities say the Medellin cartel is paying $4,300 to each young motorcycle-riding assassin who kills a policeman. A small car bomb exploded Wednesday night in Bogota, the capital, destroying three cars, shattering glass in nearby buildings, and slightly wounding one person, a police official said. Bogota Police Chief Yazim Yanine Diaz told reporters that the bomb, carrying about 70 pounds of dynamite, was part of a terror wave being carried out by the Medellin drug gang. Last week the commander of the army's fourth brigade, Gen. Harold Bedoya, blamed Medellin cocaine boss Pablo Escobar for ordering a series of bombings and assassinations in recent months. In Medellin alone, five car bombs have exploded so far this year, killing at least 60 people. Officials are offering a $400,000 reward for information leading to Escobar's capture, dead or alive. He remains at large despite a massive manhunt. Colombia's Medellin and Cali drug cartels supply an estimated 80 percent of all the cocaine consumed in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos: Require New Teachers to Learn Second Language
With AM-Teachers
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos called on the nation's teacher colleges Thursday to require all prospective teachers to learn a foreign language, given the growing ethnic diversity of U.S. students. Addressing 3,051 delegates at the concluding session of the American Federation of Teachers' annual convention, Cavazos said teachers had to adjust to the increased linguistic and cultural diversity of the student body. ``Colleges of education should make proficiency in a second language mandatory,'' he said. Cavazos decried the fact that only 10 percent of all college graduates can speak a second language. In a statement from Washington, D.C., David Imig, executive director of the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education, called the proposed requirement a good idea. ``It would stretch the capacity of many students in education,'' he said. The State University of New York-Albany is one of only a very small number of teacher colleges that have such a language requirement, Imig said. At a news conference, Cavazos also added his support to those pressing for changes in curricula to reflect cultural diversity. ``We have had standardized curricula that have not recognized the diversity of this nation,'' he said. AFT delegates passed two resolutions dealing with cultural diversity. One called upon the federal government and states to increase funding for bilingual education and support research and training in that field. It also said districts should be free to experiment with different approaches to teaching foreign language students. A second proposal called for development of new history and literature curricula that reflects the contributions of blacks, Hispanics, American-Indians and other groups. ``We are not talking here of creating a segregated curricula, one for minorities that features just minority heroes and another for whites that focuses on just white heroes,'' said the resolution, which was supported by AFT's leadership. Too often, the resolution said, texts have squeezed in minority contributions as ``sidebars, peripheral to the main story. This is not good enough.'' ``Our children need the full picture, the whole truth, as best it is understood,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Levies Record Fine In Fatal Mining Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The operator of a Kentucky mine where 10 workers died in an explosion last year was fined more than $500,000 on Thursday, the largest penalty ever assessed by the government in a mine disaster. Pyro Mining Co. said it would appeal the fine, which was levied by the Labor Department's Mine Safety and Health Administration. The penalty stemmed from 121 alleged violations of federal safety laws. ``We're just not making any comment at all beyond the fact that we're surprised by the size of the penalty. The appeal is in process and we will continue that,'' said James Greenlee, executive vice president of Evansville, Ind.-based Costain Coal Inc., which owns Pyro Mining. The Labor Department contends Pyro managers knew explosive methane gas was accumulating in the mine four days before the explosion but failed to take action. ``We consider the violations in this case so flagrant and indicative of the company's negligence that this fine is warranted,'' William J. Tattersall, assistant labor secretary for mine safety, said of the record fine. Before Thursday, the largest penalty ever assessed for a mine accident stemmed from a 1976 blast that killed 26 workers at the Scotia mine near Oven Fork, Ky. In that investigation, the Blue Diamond Coal Co. was assessed $266,000. A May report by the agency said 10 specific violations contributed to the Sept. 13 explosion in Wheatcroft, Ky., which was the nation's worst mine disaster in five years. The agency charged that managers failed to make required checks for the deadly gas in the hours before the explosion, failed to keep enough clean air in the mine to clear out the methane and made a series of changes in air pathways that caused a methane buildup the day of the disaster. Federal investigators were unable to determine exactly what triggered the explosion. Thursday's announcement said that the company was fined $10,000 _ the maximum per violation _ for each of the 10 alleged violations investigators said directly contributed to the blast. The agency also fined the company $8,000 for 26 other violations _ 19 involving failure to make required pre-shift safety examinations and seven that involved electrical violations. An additional 13 violations involving electrical safety carried fines of $6,500 each while the remaining 72 violations received lesser penalties, the agency said. Joe Holland, president of United Mine Workers District 23, called the fines ``certainly a step in the right direction.'' ``I would like to see what they actually pay,'' Holland said, adding that the agency frequently reduces fines after negotiations with companies. The UMW is trying to organize Pyro workers and has strongly criticized Pyro's safety practices. Under federal law, a company can contest allegations of safety violations and fines by requesting a hearing before an administrative law judge of the Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, an independent agency. Greenlee said the company already has begun the process of challenging some of the alleged safety violations and also will contest certain fines. He declined to say which.

DOC.HEAD: Drizzle and Demonstrators, and the French President Was Late
With AM-NATO Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In many ways it was a typical NATO summit: The anti-nuclear demonstrators in drizzling rain, the tight security and the leader who arrived late, France's Francois Mitterrand. Mitterrand lived up to his reputation for tardiness, missing a coffee reception at Lancaster House and delaying the start of the first meeting. Under threatening skies and with a brisk wind blowing, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner spent about 10 minutes waiting on the steps before Mitterrand's limousine pulled up. The French president also lagged near the end just before lunch when the 16 NATO leaders gathered to pose for their ``family portrait.'' Because of the weather, the picture-taking session was moved inside to the main hall of 19th century Lancaster House, site of the 1979 conference that paved the way for Rhodesian independence. There was confusion over the toe marks where each leader was supposed to stand. Mrs. Thatcher helped get the front row lined up. Mitterrand arrived second last, just before Danish Prime Minister Poul Schluter. President Bush and Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney clapped when everyone was finally assembled.

At the end of the day, the delays didn't really matter. The summiteers finished their afternoon session one hour and 40 minutes early, catching motorcades and reporters by surprise. Bush stood briefly outside the door which was blocked by someone else's limousine. ``They can't get by with that car here,'' he said with some exasperation before his motorcade pulled off for the U.S. ambassador's residence where he relaxed before dinner.
Bush's relations with his French counterpart seemed cordial, according to French officials. They said the president addressed Mitterrand as ``old chap.''

One man whose name was on many minds at the summit was no Westerner. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a prime topic even before Bush's call for him to be invited to address a future NATO meeting, was 1,600 miles away in Moscow. Several observers quipped that Gorbachev probably wished he was at the NATO summit, where Western allies were trying to find ways to help him, rather than under attack at the Communist Party congress.
