Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip hosted the NATO leaders at a sumptuous dinner of poached sole with truffles, duck garnished with peaches and cherries, and raspberry ice cream in the crimson Throne Room of Buckingham Palace. There were five glasses _ for German white wine, French red, champagne, the queen's own private stock of port, and water. Seven cut-glass chandeliers and two-foot candles lit the room, where the crimson throne used by the queen at her 1953 coronation stands on a dais. The 52 guests dined at five tables, the queen in a green chiffon and gold lame gown flanked by Bush and Mitterrand, the prince by Woerner and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
Early in the morning, police with dogs combed Green Park, adjoining Lancaster House and site of the tented press camp. Officers stood on rooftops scanning the area with binoculars.

The NATO leaders missed about 100 anti-nuclear demonstrators from Britain and France at the edge of the park carrying signs saying ``No Need for NATO'' and ``Warsaw Pact Goodbye. NATO Why?'' Six Buddhist monks in saffron robes chanted prayers for peace as they beat on drums. Scotland Yard said four demonstrators were arrested for public order offenses.

But it wasn't all war, peace and weapons. Some NATO officials were caught watching the Wimbledon tennis semifinal on the TV monitors. And Kohl said he was confident of a West German victory over Argentina in the World Cup soccer final on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Coal Miners Favoring Strike Next Week
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some disgruntled Soviet coal miners apparently will go ahead with a one-day political strike next week, ignoring an appeal by the Communist Party Congress, state media reported Thursday. How many miners will join the strike is still uncertain, but a labor union official told the Tass news agency that miners in the Kuznetsk basin in western Siberia will stop work on Wednesday to protest the Communist Party's slow pace of reform. A widespread strike by the stridently anti-communist miners during the party congress would embarrass the Kremlin leadership and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, especially since the Communist delegates asked them to stay on the job. Vyacheslav Golikov, chairman of the Council of Workers' Committees of the Kuznetsk coal basin, said at a news conference in the western Siberia city of Kemerovo that the miners do not want to damage Russia, but working people must be protected, Tass reported. In some areas of the Kuznetsk basin, miners have decided to concentrate on repair or maintenance jobs rather than working in the pits, Tass said. In the Donetsk coal basin of the Ukraine, members of the Council of Strike Committees also have decided to strike for one day, although some of the rank-and-file miners still are discussing it, and a final decision will be made by the regional council on Sunday, the news agency said. The largest strike committee in the Donetsk basin, Donetskugol Amalgamation, is against the stoppage, Tass added. A correspondent for the national evening news program ``Vremya,'' in a spot survey at the Mushketovskaya pit, said two-thirds of the 75 workers on the day shift Thursday supported the strike. A national miners' congress last month voted to strike if Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and his cabinet do not resign. The miners blame Ryzhkov for an unpopular economic reform plan, now being revised, that called for drastic price increases but only minor steps toward a market economy. They also condemned the Communist Party for hindering reforms. They also demand that the party cells be removed from the workplace, as well as the armed forces and the KGB secret police. Golikov told Tass that the crisis can be averted by the development of democracy and a market economy and better social protection of the working people. Delegates to the party congress in Moscow urged miners ``to show restraint during this difficult period of time, to consider seriously contemporary problems and to realize that the policy of pressure and of ultimatums can lead to disarray in the economy, have a negative effect on perestroika and erode living standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Top British Official Says Obstacles Remain to Political Talks
DOC.TEXT: The top British official in Northern Ireland said Thursday that efforts had failed so far to begin negotiations on the restoration of local government in the province. Protestant leaders in Northern Ireland and the Irish government indicated that they have failed to agree on a formula for the talks on ending the 18-year direct British rule in the province. Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, the British government minister responsible for the province, told the House of Commons in London that contacts were continuing between the parties, but he could not announce a date for negotiations. Press reports had raised expectations of a breakthrough in the so-called ``talks about talks'' that have been going on for six months between Catholic and Protestant leaders in Northern Ireland. But Brooke said, ``I had hoped to be in a position by now to give some indication of when it might be possible to move to formal talks. I am in fact not yet in a position to do so. ``The important thing is that we have been making progress and will continue to seek to do so,'' he said. He added that ``in the end it is a matter for the potential participants, and in particular for the political parties within Northern Ireland, to decide if and when the conditions for carrying matters forward exist.'' Brooke did not say what issues remain to be resolved, but others made it clear that the sticking point was when the Irish government should become involved in the negotiations. The Irish government wants to be involved at all stages, while the Protestant parties in the North envision only a late role in the negotiations for Dublin. ``While substantial progress has been made on a number of important aspects, a satisfactory basis which would avoid problems later has not been established,'' Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said in Dublin. Protestant leaders blamed Dublin for blocking progress toward an agreement on restoring local rule. But John Hume, leader of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the largest Catholic party in Northern Ireland, said all the parties, including Ireland, wanted Brooke's initiative to succeed. The projected negotiations would be aimed at returning some power to local government, on a basis acceptable to the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority. Self-government was among the casualties of the violence that erupted in Northern Ireland in the late 1960s. What began as a civil rights campaign by the Catholic minority against economic and political discrimination escalated into sectarian conflict. The British army was sent into the province in 1969, and the British government suspended the Ulster parliament in 1972, assuming direct rule of the province. The Anglo-Irish Agreement, signed in 1985, guaranteed the Irish government a say in Northern Ireland's affairs as part of a process designed to promote peace in the province. The agreement provoked an angry reaction from the Protestant unionist parties, which want Northern Ireland to remain linked with Britain. They broke off all contacts with the British government in protest. It is a measure of Brooke's success that the unionist leaders are participating in talks which inevitably will involve some participation by Dublin. Brooke has been talking with Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders in Northern Ireland in an effort to reach an agreement on opening formal negotiations. These contacts have not included Sinn Fein, the legal political arm of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. The IRA has been fighting to push the British out of Northern Ireland, unite the province with the Republic of Ireland, and set up an all-Ireland socialist state. Since the British Army was sent to Northern Ireland in 1969, about 2,800 people have been killed in the violence. About 60 percent of Northern Ireland's 1.5 million are Protestant. Most of the remaining 40 percent are Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Chief Says Timing Not Right for New Aid to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will not likely support any proposals for Western financial aid to the Soviet Union at next week's seven-nation economic summit, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Thursday. ``I'm not clear that a new set of particulars is called for'' from the Western economic powers, Brady told reporters during a meeting in his Treasury Department conference room. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is expected to call for coordinated Western financial assistance for the Soviet Union when the economic summit begins Monday in Houston. Bush and Kohl will be meeting with the leaders of Britain, Italy, France, Canada and Japan to discuss trade, aid and other economic issues. Moscow has not officially asked for Western aid, but its economy is in a shambles. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday told the 28th Communist Party Congress he will resign within two years if his perestroika program for modernizing the Soviet economy is not showing positive results by then. Brady noted that senior Bush administration officials, including Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, traveled to Moscow recently to provide technical economic assistance. He said also that Soviet government banking and finance officials had visited Washington on technical matters. ``Aside from that tangible evidence of help and other gestures of good will by the president, he has said that at this particular time aid to the Soviet Union is a very difficult subject in this country,'' Brady told reporters. He suggested Bush would be more willing to assist Moscow if the Soviets stopped supporting Fidel Castro's Marxist regime in Cuba, and if more progress were achieved in U.S.-Soviet arms control negotiations. On another subject, Brady said he did not expect the Houston meeting to remove key obstacles to agreement on reforming international rules covering farm trade. That issue is a major source of friction between the United States and the European Economic Community, which represents 12 West European countries, although the negotiations on trade reforms involve nearly 90 other countries, too. An EEC official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday that his group was not bringing any new farm trade proposals to the Houston meeting. Brady said that Bush is eager for an eventual agreement on reforms for agricultural and other categories of world trade, but the president does not expect a major breakthrough in Houston. ``Although it's important to get a healthy discussion to take place in Houston, it's not necessarily the case that anything determinative will take place there,'' he said. ``To portray Houston as a turning point ... is mistaking the case.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Plane Refused Landing at Heathrow; Strike Congestion Cited
With AM-NATO Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A plane carrying Secretary of State James Baker was refused permission to land at London's Heathrow Airport because of congestion caused by a French air controllers' strike, authorities said Thursday. Instead, the military aircraft landed at a U.S. Air Force base at Mildenhall in eastern England, the Civil Aviation Authority said. As Baker was leaving Brussels Wednesday to attend the NATO summit in London, his pilot was told of a two-hour delay in British-controlled air space due to the French strike, said a spokeswoman. The 3-day-old strike, which began Tuesday, meant the flight sector to Britain ``was extremely busy,'' and there was ``tremendous strain on the system,'' she said, speaking on condition of anonymity. So the plane flew to Heathrow avoiding the British flight lanes, but was refused permission to land and had to go to Mildenhall instead, she said. U.S. State Department officials called it ``nothing more than a minor inconvenience.''

DOC.HEAD: Paramedic Testifies About Finding Battered Jogger in Central Park
DOC.TEXT: A paramedic testified Thursday that she found the Central Park jogger naked and bloodied, kicking and moaning in a puddle of mud, with a spot in the back of her skull that felt ``mushy.'' ``There was blood and mud all over her,'' said Estelle D. Paris, an Emergency Medical Service technician. ``She was cold, cold to the touch.'' Paris, 36, was the first medical professional to testify about the jogger's condition after she was gang-raped and left for dead April 19, 1989. She described how she and partner Rodney Mullins found the woman: ``We approached the victim lying in something of a spastic state ... Her arms would go rigid, then her legs would go up. There were moments when she would go limp.'' In grisly detail, Paris told the jury about the woman's medical condition. ``Both eyes were swollen shut,'' Paris said. ``There were bruises on both cheeks. Her lips were bloody, and there were scratch marks where skin was torn off.'' Paris said she removed a T-shirt that was tied tightly around the woman's neck and hands and stuffed into her mouth. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer showed Paris the once-white T-shirt, now brown with mud and blood stains. The witness identified it and said, ``It was wet and bloody at the time.'' The jury listened raptly as Paris recounted how she knelt under moonlight and the high beams of a police car to work on the woman. ``She had an occipital depression; it felt mushy,'' Paris said. Paris was testifying in Manhattan's state Supreme Court at the trial of Antron McCray, 15, Raymond Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16. They are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers. The female jogger, an investment banker now 29, was gang-raped, savagely beaten, and left naked and near death. She survived, but suffered brain damage and has no recollection of what happened that night, Lederer said. The prosecutor has refused to say whether the woman will testify. The three defendants are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders and face up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths are charged in the attacks and will stand trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Zoning Board Rejects Church Services in Industrial Park
DOC.TEXT: Zoning officials on Thursday unanimously rejected an appeal by Tammy Faye Bakker, wife of imprisoned PTL ministry founder Jim Bakker, to hold church services at a building in a busy industrial park. The Orange County Zoning Board cited public safety concerns in upholding a staff decision to shut down services at the newest site of Mrs. Bakker's New Covenant Ministries _ next door to a welding shop. Mrs. Bakker, who did not attend the hearing, has authority to operate a radio-television production studio at the location. The ministry, set up in Orlando last year, previously was housed in a shopping mall, a hotel and a piano store. Attorneys for the American Civil Liberties Union accused the zoning panel of ``trampling on the First Amendment rights of Mrs. Bakker'' because of her husband's conviction and imprisonment in the wake of PTL's collapse. ``It's a case of guilt by association,'' said Warren Keiner, the ACLU's central Florida chairman, referring to Bakker's 45-year federal prison term for fraud. Zoning officials acted after several Sunday services were held in the building in March. ACLU Attorney Jerry Bornstein argued that the board ``would be prohibiting the free exercise of religion'' by ruling against a church in an industrial area because there was no law against it. There has to be ``some overriding government interest against a house of worship,'' he said. Board Chairman Gary Russell agreed, but said there were sufficient reasons against it. ``That site is very intense, at the throat of a heavy industrial park,'' Russell said, adding that churchgoers could be endangered by truck traffic and activities such as the welding next door. William Parke, a real estate broker representing property owner Phillip Jordan, said he didn't think churchgoers would be in any danger, and that services would be ``an adjunct to a radio and TV studio.'' Parke later told reporters that even the studio was not operating now because the building is being modified slightly to comply with fire-safety regulations. Mrs. Bakker has just signed a new contract for a 12-month lease and a 12-month option to buy the site, he said. ``Mrs. Bakker is very interested in the property because the owners have agreed to carry the mortgage and the Bakkers would have a tough time getting a conventional mortgage,'' Parke said. Keiner and Howard Marks of the ACLU's legal division said the board's decision would be appealed to the Orange County Commission. ``We'll file a lawsuit if we're unsuccessful there,'' Marks said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead, Dozens Injured, 600 Arrested as Soccer Fans Riot
DOC.TEXT: Fans enraged by England's loss to West Germany in World Cup soccer rioted in 30 English towns in a night of violence that left three dead, dozens injured and 600 under arrest, police said Thursday. The rioting, mostly in southern England, broke out Wednesday night after fans watching live broadcasts from the semifinal in Italy poured into the streets when West Germany defeated England 4-3. More than 35 police officers were injured in clashes with the rioters. In the southern resort town of Brighton, 500 fans roamed the streets, overturning cars with foreign license plates, smashing shop windows and looting. The mob also chased German and French students through the streets. Police locked more than 300 students in a nightclub for their own safety before ferrying them away in buses. Also in Brighton, a 63-year-old woman suffered a fatal heart attack after rioters smashed the windows of her tavern. The town has a large population of Germans and other foreign students attending English language courses. Charges of criminal damage, burglary and assaulting the police were brought against 30 people in Brighton. In Hounslow, west London, a 30-year-old man was hit and killed by a police car answering a riot call. In Totton, near Southampton, a 33-year-old man was knocked to the ground when he tried to stop a group of rioters. He died in an ambulance and police said they were treating his death as murder. Before the crucial soccer game, police had publicized contingency plans for stop rioting, but the warning failed to deter violence in more than 30 towns. Reports of violence and arrests were reported in normally quiet towns such as Melton Mowbray, Uttoxeter and Yeovil, Leamington Spa, Peterborough, Newmarket, Shrewsbury and the seaside towns of Bournemouth, Weymouth and Worthing. In the port city of Southampton, 70 miles southwest of London, a group of up to 20 youths smashed up the Royal Oak pub. ``When England lost they went berserk, picking up anything they could find and smashing it,'' said pub manager Bernard Smedley. A spokesman for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she was appalled by the violence and the ``mindless vandalism and hooliganism.'' In the rioting, two youths were arrested for smashing the windows of Mrs. Thatcher's childhood home in Grantham, eastern England. In the House of Commons, Sir Geoffrey Howe, standing in as deputy prime minister while Mrs. Thatcher attended a NATO summit in London, said all lawmakers could be proud of the England team, which had never before reached a World Cup semifinal on foreign soil. Disappointment at the match's result could in no way justify the violence, Howe said.

DOC.HEAD: White Extremists Threaten More Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A white extremist group that has claimed responsibility for five recent bombings promised more attacks if President F.W. de Klerk continues with his apartheid reforms, a newspaper reported Thursday. Also Thursday, the African National Congress accused the government of failing to clamp down on white extremists, whose actions could threaten black-white negotiations on sharing power. In other developments, a bomb was discovered Thursday at the offices of a black mineworkers' union, but it failed to detonate, police said. The independent South African Press Association said police believed the bomb at the union office in the central town of Oberholtzer was planted by right-wingers. The pro-government Citizen newspaper said a group calling itself the White Wolves claimed responsibility for five bombings in Johannesburg since Friday night and promised to step up its ``freedom struggle.'' Right-wingers are outraged at de Klerk's stated intention of ending apartheid and sharing power with the black majority. They are demanding de Klerk hold a whites-only election and claim the president would lose to those who favor strict apartheid. Police Brig. Gen. Vic Haynes said there were more than 30 terrorist attacks in June, with extreme right-wing groups responsible for many incidents. However, no right-wing whites have been charged with any of the attacks. The White Wolves have claimed responsibilty for several attacks in the past two years. Police say they have not been able to determine if such an organization actually exists, or if white extremists acting independently have simply adopted the name. ``We are concerned that the government is not taking tough measures against the right-wing,'' ANC leader Walter Sisulu told a news conference. Sisulu said he ``would not be surprised'' if policemen, acting on their own, were assisting right-wing whites. He also accused the government of failing to stop police violence against black activists. Sisulu said he expected a decline in such actions following talks in May between the government and the ANC, the country's largest opposition group. ``But we don't see any decline, rather we see an increase,'' Sisulu said. He cited an ANC rally over the weekend where a black man was fatally shot in a confrontation with a policeman. The ANC said it would hold 20 rallies nationwide on Saturday to call for peace in the eastern province of Natal. ANC supporters and members of Inkatha, a conservative Zulu organization, have been locked in vicious faction fighting that has claimed more than 4,000 lives in four years. In the Soweto township outside Johannesburg, Sam Mabe, the assistant editor of the black-oriented Sowetan newspaper, was killed late Wednesday by two black gunmen in the Soweto township outside Johannesburg, police said. There was no evidence the attack was related to the recent bombings, police said. Aggrey Klaaste, editor of The Sowetan, the country's leading black daily, said, ``I am personally shattered, especially for his young family. It is a great loss to black journalism, and further indicates how cheap life is in Soweto.''

DOC.HEAD: Trial Provokes Debate on Religious, Legal Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, `Lawrence Tribe ...,' to CORRECT first name to `Laurence.'
DOC.TEXT: Although two Christian Scientists were found guilty of manslaughter for withholding medical treatment from their son, the debate continues over a key aspect of the case: When should the government overrule religious beliefs that affect children? Medical experts on Thursday applauded the verdict against David and Ginger Twitchell, saying it would help protect children. But a constitutional scholar said the decision reflects a ``fundamental unfairness'' because the Twitchells thought they were protected by a 1971 state law that exempted spiritual healing from child abuse statutes. The prosecution argued that the statute _ which states that children will not be considered neglected or abused when ``treated by spiritual means alone'' by an ``accredited practitioner'' _ did not exempt the Twitchells from manslaughter laws. After a two-month trial, the jury Wednesday found the Twitchells, former Boston residents now living in New York, guilty of involuntary manslaughter for not seeking medical treatment for their son, Robyn. They were found to have recklessly and wantonly caused their 2{-year-old son's death by relying solely on Christian Science spiritual healing to treat his five-day illness. The boy died April 8, 1986. An autopsy showed he suffered from a bowel obstruction. Special Prosecutor John Kiernan said the case was not an attack on religion, but sent the message that parents must protect their children. Steve Lyons, a defense attorney, contends $2 million was spent by the Suffolk County district attorney's office to prosecute the Twitchells so that ``the DA could put on a morality play.'' The case does not end here. Defense attorneys Thursday filed an appeal in Suffolk Superior Court on behalf of the Twitchells, who were not present. Kiernan recommended probation for the couple _ who could have received up to 20 years in prison _ and that their other children's health be monitored, according to Peter O'Toole, a spokesman for the prosecutor. According to Lyons, Judge Sandra Hamlin said she would not exceed the recommendation. She scheduled sentencing for Friday. Lyons said the appeal was based on Hamlin's failure to consider or instruct the jury on the spiritual healing exemption and her allowing a ``mocking and sarcastic trial of Christian Science doctrine to occur.'' The Christian Science Church, which has its world headquarters in Boston, has long taught that sickness and disease can be healed by prayer alone, just as sin can be washed away by spirituality. Since 1980, there have been seven prosecutions of Christian Science parents. Five have been convicted, one acquitted and one case was thrown out, according to child rights activist Rita Swan, a former Christian Scientist who actively seeks such prosecutions. Harvard law professor John Mansfield, a expert on church and state issues, says recent U.S. Supreme Court cases reflect a trend away from protecting religious beliefs as the nation moves toward a more secular society. The Twitchell case, along with a recent Supreme Court case involving peyote use by a Native American church, retreats from former ``special treatment'' accorded a person's religious belief, Mansfield said. ``They believe what they believe. That's their faith; they're helpless in the grip of their faith,'' he said. But the recent cases ask: ``Why should they have preferential treatment?' Physicians, such as Dr. Michael Grodin, a pediatrician and medical ethicist for Boston University, applauded the guilty verdict. He said it sends a message that religious convictions do not exempt parents from calling a doctor when a child faces a serious or life-threatening illness. ``No religion is going to be allowed to be a defense against abuse and neglect,'' he said. ``The bottom line is we have to have standards for protecting children.'' Laurence Tribe, a constitutional law expert at Harvard, said the verdict reflects a ``fundamental unfairness'' because the Twitchells relied on the state's spiritual healing exemption when they made their decisions about Robyn's health, but the jury was not so instructed. The state invited the Twitchells to rely on spiritual healing ``then turned around and prosecuted them without giving them the opportunity to put their reliance on state law before the jury,'' Tribe said. Tribe said he believed the state's highest court would reverse the decision. However, he said, the exemption should be revoked. ``There should be a very clear duty on the part of all parents to take children to the doctor when a certain threshold'' is reached.

DOC.HEAD: Union Square Bracing For 8,000 Barbershop Songsters
DOC.TEXT: Some 8,000 voices will try to create a global four-part harmony Friday to sing the praises of a barbershop quartet convention. The singers plans to offer visitors to Union Square their renditions of barbershop standards ``Sweet Adeline,'' and ``Toot Toot Tootsie'' and other variations in baritone, bass, tenor and soprano. The convention is held by the 52-year-old Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America, which is pledged to vocal precision uncluttered by the need to read music. Women have their own barbershop singing groups, under the name Harmony International. They sing the same parts as the men, only in a different key. This year, the sellout convention attracted a quartet from the Soviet Union, as well as Austria, England, Canada and New Zealand. Although purely an American singing form, barbershop singing is spreading over the globe. The Soviet quartet is a first for the convention. Members call themselves ``The Quiet Don,' after the River Don. Also for the first time, the special international competition, involving 17 choruses of 50 to 130 men each, will include the best harmonizing teams of the United States, Canada and England. Even before the formal proceedings began, the barbershop singer let the world know they were ready. On Monday, while checking in at their convention hotel, one or more of the groups would break into an impromptu song in the hotel lobby. ``It is a highly formalized form of music,'' said convention spokesman Al Zemsky, touching on crucial questions including ``tightened chords,'' ``extended sound,'' ``melody lines'' and ``overtones.'' The competition to produce the 1990 international quartet champion began Thursday with 51 quartets from the United States, England and Sweden participating. The finals are scheduled for Saturday night. The society, based on the modest American harmonizing of the latter 19th century, was formed in 1938 in Tulsa, Okla., by two businessmen. They worried that their favorite kind of music would be overwhelmed by movies and the phonograph. Today, the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America today about 36,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Vaclav Havel Elected President For Another Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Thursday re-elected Vaclav Havel as president, and the former dissident playright promised to do everything possible to create ``a happier future'' for his homeland. Thousands of people chanted ``Long live Havel!'' as they celebrated the inauguration in a carnival-like atmosphere outside Hradcany Castle. The election of Havel to a two-year presidential term culminated the political transition from Communist to democratic rule that has reshaped the country in just seven months. ``The two-year term for which I was elected will roughly coincide with the demanding time of the new building of our state, with a time which will culminate in the adoption of our new constitution,'' said the 53-year-old Havel, speaking to the crowd from a castle balcony. ``I promise you, that to the extent of my powers and abilities I will do everything so that we can pass through this time sucessfully and a happier future opens up for our country.'' Earlier, Havel, running unopposed, was elected president by the Parliament with the necessary three-fifths majority in a nationally televised secret ballot. A total of 234 deputies voted for him, and 50 against. There were no abstentions. Sixteen deputies were absent. ``I think the fact that there were 50 deputies voting against me is a very good, significant and convincing evidence of the democratic character of my election ... I am quite rejoicing over that. I would not feel good if I had been elected by 100 percent as was my predecessor,'' Havel said, shortly after the voting. Stefan Kvietik, who was nominated for president earlier this week by the separatist Slovak National Party, refused the candidacy. Havel, who on Dec. 29 became the country's first non-Communist president in 42 years, was nominated by Civic Forum and its Slovak counterpart, Public Against Violence. The two groups led the peaceful revolution that toppled the hard-line Communist regime in November and won a convincing victory in multi-party elections held last month. The parliamentary session, held in a medieval hall at the Hradcany Castle, was opened by Parliament President Alexander Dubcek, whose ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968 were crushed by Soviet tanks. ``By the election of the president, the revolutionary transition, which we have been living through since November ... will be ended,'' Dubcek said. He praised Havel as a man who ``has proved competent as a politician (and) statesman .... Vaclav Havel, a playwright in the seat of president, has gained, by his work, the confidence of our people. ``He proved himself even in the times of repression of freedom and rights, when it was not easy or convenient to show a firm stand of a citizen and bravery,'' Dubcek said. After the ballot, Havel was led by Dubcek and other officials up the red-carpeted aisle of the Vladislav Hall to sign the oath of office. As a military band played the national anthem inside the hall, the sound of a 20-gun salute reverberated throughout the city. After the parliamentary session, Havel, accompanied by Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek, attended a military parade in a castle courtyard. In the courtyard, an old Tatra 80, the car used by Czechoslovakia's first president, Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, was waiting. Havel will use the classic car for ceremonial occasions, Czechoslovak television said. The streets and open spaces around the castle were filled with people enjoying performances by rock and folk bands and theater ensembles.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Lab Says Its Has Found Nearly All Of $45 Million In Missing Items
DOC.TEXT: The Lawrence Livermore Laboratory said Thursday that it has accounted for all but a fraction of the more $45 million in equipment that had been reported missing. In a statement released by the Department of Energy's San Francisco office, officials said that as of Tuesday the lab could account for all but two percent of the items a report by the General Accounting Office said were missing. ``We have located about 98 percent of all the missing property,'' said Carol Powell of the DOE in San Francisco. ``We don't expect we'll ever achieve 100 percent.'' A statement by the nuclear weapons research and development facility laboratory in Livermore, Calif. said that only the only equipment still missing had an acquisition value of about $4.5 million and a current value of about $2 million. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, released a report Tuesday saying that as of mid-January, the Livermore laboratory was missing more than $45 million worth of equipment. The study said there were 27,538 missing items, ranging from typewriters to computers, and that the missing equipment represented 16 percent of the Livermore inventory. Livermore said the laboratory continued its inventory efforts after the GAO study ended in January and that all but a fraction of the missing items have been accounted for. Carl J. Bannerman, an assistant director of GAO and the leader in the Livermore study, said the laboratory claim about finding its missing equipment ``has not been verified.'' He said laboratory and DOE officials were aware of concern about the Livermore inventory as early as 1988 and that the GAO started looking into the property management controls at the laboratory in May 1989. ``The property controls are so inadequate that it took them a year to find that many'' of the missing items, said Bannerman. Powell said the Livermore's new inventory claims were investigated and proven by the DOE. The San Francisco office, she said, ``conducted a random sample survey which statistically validated the findings.'' Lawrence Livermore Laboratory is owned by the Department of Energy and operated by the University of California at Livermore. In hearings two years ago before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, there were allegations that government-owned equipment was being stolen from Livermore to finance purchase of illegal drugs. In its report, the GAO said that among capital equipment with an acquisition value of more than $5,000, there were 1,605 items missing, valued at about $20.6 million. Capital equipment would include large items such as X-ray generators and oscilloscopes. The laboratory statement said that 99.65 percent of this equipment has now been accounted for. The GAO report said that non-capital equipment valued at more than $500 included 25,516 missing items valued at $24 million. Livermore's continuing inventory has now found 97.39 percent of this equipment, the laboratory said Thursday. In a third category, which the GAO described as made up of items attractive to theft, there 407 missing items with a value of $800,000. Livermore said that it has now accounted for 98.96 percent of this equipment. In the report, the GAO said property controls at the laboratory ``are not adequate to ensure against theft, unauthorized use or loss.'' Livermore director John Nuckolls said in a statement that the laboratory is committed to full protection of government property and to the improvement of its accounting and inventory systems.

DOC.HEAD: Upset Win Puts Garrison in Path of Navratilova's Quest
DOC.TEXT: Zina Garrison's upset win Thursday over top-seeded Steffi Graf at Wimbledon puts her in the path of Martina Navratilova's single-minded quest for a ninth singles title and tennis immortality. In a daring, acrobatic attack, Garrison, 26, put away Graf, two-time Wimbledon champ, in a 6-3, 3-6, 6-4 semifinal victory Thursday. Navratilova, still formidable at 33, moved within one victory of Wimbledon history Thursday. With a sweeping left-handed serve followed by a backhand volley into the open court, she dispatched Gabriela Sabatini. No. 2-seeded Navratilova beat fourth-seeded Sabatini 6-3, 6-4. Navratilova said she couldn't wait to face fifth-seeded Garrison on Centre Court. ``I'll have to try not to hyperventilate when I get out there,'' she said. ``I'm sweating already just thinking about it. I'd like to play the final right now rather than wait two more days.'' On the men's side, Ivan Lendl continues his quest for the one top title that has eluded him with a semifinal match Friday against Stefan Edberg. Boris Becker and unseeded Goran Ivanisevic face off in the other semifinal. Lendl, Becker and Edberg are the top three seeds, respectively. Navratilova has beaten Garrison 27 times in 28 matches. Her only loss was in the quarterfinals of the 1988 U.S. Open. Before the two go on court, they must settle the matter of attire. Garrison, who lacks an endorsement contract, has been wearing tennis togs from Navratilova's personal line. ``We'll be twins if we wear the same outfits,'' Navratilova said. ``Maybe we'll flip a coin to see who wears what.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Announce Campaign for D.C. `Shadow Senator' Post
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson announced on Thursday that he will run for one of the District of Columbia's two ``shadow senator'' posts to lobby Congress to grant the city statehood. ``Statehood for the District of Columbia is the most important civil rights issue in America today,'' Jackson said. ``More people live here than five states, w than 10 states, we pay more taxes per capita than 49 states, and yet no vote on Capitol Hill.'' The shadow senators will be unpaid lobbyists for D.C. statehood, with no official duties. The city has one delegate to Congress who may vote in coe pay more taxesmmittees but not on the floor of the full House. Jackson, a two-time contender for the Democratic presidential nomination, said that the post would allow him to help ``expand democracy'' to the district. Jackson's political plans have been the subject of great speculation since he moved to the nation's capital last year. He said election to the shadow post would have no bearing on whether he decides to run for president in 1992. ``The two are not connectedation for all Americans and safe and affordable housing. ``If the American revolutionaries were right, that `taxation without representation is tyranny,' D.C. residents must take the initiative to demand statehood if it is ever to be achieved,'' he said. Initial drafts of the city bill called for $1.3 million to be spent on the two shadow senators. But city councilmembers this year said the positions shouldn't be funded in light of the city's current budget deficit. There are three other candidates for the two positions.

DOC.HEAD: The Heat Goes On
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms chased the heat across the Midwest to the East Coast on Thursday, bringing some relief from the sauna-like conditions of the Fourth. Record temperatures for July 5 included Baltimore at 103 degrees, breaking the record of 102 that had stood since 1919; and Greensboro, N.C., at 98. Records were tied in Charleston, S.C., (95) and Norfolk, Va., (98). Early-morning thunderstorms damaged trees in Coeymans and St. Johnsonville, N.Y., and thunderstorm winds gusted to 60 mph in Adams, Mass. Mid-morning thunderstorms damaged trees in Washington, Pa., and Lancaster, Ohio. By early afternoon, rain showers and thunderstorms extended across central and western New York state, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Virginia, Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio, Michigan, Indiana and illinois. Showers and thunderstorms also reached from northern Florida to the Gulf Coast and across Louisiana and southeast Texas. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from Missouri to Nebraska, South Dakota, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, the northern Pacific Coast and Washington state. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 2 inches at Houston, an inch and two thirds at Zanesville, Ohio, and an inch and a quarter at Galveston, Texas. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 57 degrees at Marquette, Mich., to 106 at both Needles and Palm Springs, Calif. The low for the Lower 48 states was 34 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Scappy Activist Known For Hunger Strikes For Homeless
With AM-Mitch Snyder
DOC.TEXT: The Mitch Snyder who forced a president to provide shelter for Washington's street people was a single-minded, often-abrasive advocate for the homeless. The Mitch Snyder who apparently ended his life Thursday in his room at a homeless shelter was a man who struggled with religious beliefs and was tormented by his abandonment of his young sons two decades ago. Snyder once described himself as dedicated to ``liberating people who are destitute.'' But his confrontational style drew criticism, sometimes from other homeless activists. When Snyder was on a hunger strike to force the White House to pay for shelter improvements, Rep. E. Clay Shaw, R.-Fla., called him ``a masochist who influences government by threatening to starve himself.'' Raised in New York City, Snyder married young and had two sons. But after a series of unsuccessful jobs, he walked out on his family in 1969 and wound up in the federal prison in Danbury, Conn., for auto theft. There he met the radical priests Daniel and Philip Berrigan and joined their anti-war group. Out of prison in 1972, he moved to Washington the following year, launching his career as an activist with the Community for Creative Non-Violence but cutting off all contact with his family. Snyder, who was himself abandoned by his father when he was 9, was apparently haunted the rest of his life by the family he failed to support. His ex-wife Ellen Daly, who remarried, only got in touch with Snyder again by telephone after he became famous. ``I said to him on the phone, `Mitchell, forgive yourself. I forgave you a long time ago,' '' she recalled in an interview in The Washington Post. ``He said no _ that's his punishment to himself. He said, `Till the day I die, I'll never forgive myself.' '' He later visited his ex-wife, and his sons Ricky and Dean both visited Snyder at the shelter, on one occasion helping serve Thanksgiving dinner to the homeless. Snyder's longtime companion, Carol Fennelly, told the Post he ``would wake up at night having dreams about his deserted kids. ... It would just prey on him.'' Two months ago, Fennelly was quoted as saying that she and Snyder were planning to be married in September, in a ceremony to be held in front of the community's 1,400-bed shelter. Snyder and the Community for Creative Non-Violence jumped to national prominence with his 1984 hunger strike that forced President Reagan, at the peak of his re-election campaign, to promise a run-down federal building for a homeless shelter in downtown Washington, along with funds for renovation. The episode was the focus of the made-for-TV movie ``Samaritan: The Mitch Snyder Story,'' starring Martin Sheen, who referred to Snyder as a ``saint.'' The film scarcely mentioned Snyder's previous life in New York. Snyder drew increasingly harsh criticism in recent years for his abrasive style, especially when he opposed the Census Bureau's effort this spring to count homeless people for the first time. He refused to let Census enumerators into his Capitol Hill shelter, saying, ``These people should be allowed to have their dignity and not be disturbed in the middle of the night to accommodate government grandstanding.'' Snyder recognized that he would win no popularity contests _ even among his friends. ``I don't consider myself a good person,'' he told the Post. ``I tend to be impatient, I tend to be very short, I tend to make heavy demands on people. I don't have time or energy to give much one-on-one, and so I'm very hard on people around me. I take much more than I give.'' In March, Snyder announced that he was taking some time off to live in a Trappist monastery in Virginia. ``I'm a religious person, and from time to time it's important to renew our relationship with God,'' Snyder told colleagues. He said he wanted to take time for reflection, ``to do simple work like baking bread.'' After President Bush's election in 1988, Snyder proclaimed himself optimistic about the years to come. ``I honestly believe George Bush is a nicer person. I believe Ronald Reagan was nice personally, but his politics were mean-spirited,'' Snyder said in a 1989 interview with The Associated Press. ``Listen to the music of Tracy Chapman, of U2. They are harbingers of a shift in mood. There's a 30-year cycle: the '30s, the '60s, the '90s. We've just come through the `Me Decade.' I think people have gotten sick of living only for themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airliner Hijacked to Sweden, Second Attempt Foiled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Incorporates AM-BRF-Soviet-Hijack, a0550
DOC.TEXT: A lone male forced a Soviet airliner carrying 178 people to land in Stockholm on Thursday and surrendered, airport police said. A woman threatened to blow up another Soviet plane unless it was diverted to Turkey. The incidents were among a rash of hijackings or attempted takeovers of Soviet passenger planes in the past month. The 19-year-old man, whose identity could not yet be disclosed, hijacked the plane to Sweden because he was unwilling to serve in the Soviet army, police spokesman Henry Hedenstrom said. The hijacker told crew members he had an ``explosive'' in his luggage, police said. The hijacker, who gave himself up within an hour after the aircraft landed, handed police a brown briefcase. It contained no explosive charge or weapon, airport spokeswoman Malin Engstedt said. Also Thursday, a Soviet newspaper reported that a woman traveling with her 2-year-old daughter threatened to blow up a Soviet airplane unless it was diverted to Istanbul, Turkey. Crew members negotiated with the woman while the pilot landed the Tupolev-134 jet in the southern city of Rostov late Wednesday, the official Communist Party newspaper Pravda said. The parcel which the woman claimed contained a bomb was found to be empty, it said. The woman, a shop assistant, was arrested by security forces at the airport. Pravda said the flight, carrying 24 passengers, originated in Sochi on the Black Sea, about 250 miles south of Rostov. Authorities said no one was injured. The flight diverted to Stockholm was a domestic Aeroflot Tupolev-154. It originated in Leningrad and was destined for Lvov in the Ukraine, according to airport authorities. Passengers and the seven-member crew were permitted to leave the aircraft three hours after landing, Hedenstrom said. It was the fifth hijacking of a Soviet airliner to Sweden or Finland since June 9. All four previous hijackings were carried out single-handedly by young men who threatened to blow up the aircraft, but later surrendered peacefully. None of the hijackers were armed. ``This is becoming fairly routine, although it's always a disturbance to regular traffic,'' Engstedt said. In the two previous hijackings to Finland, the two hijackers requested political asylum. Finland is considering one of the requests but has rejected the request made by hijacker Oleg Kozlov, 20. Kozlov went on a hunger strike and barricaded himself in his cell Tuesday in a central Helsinki prison. Finnish prison officials said they were attempting to negotiate with Kozlov, who has threatened to kill himself if guards break into the cell. Swedish police are holding two other hijack suspects. One said he hijacked an aircraft to avoid Soviet military service. The other said he acted after a family dispute. The Soviet Union has asked Sweden to extradite the hijackers, something the Swedish pilots federation also advocates. No decision has yet been taken by the Swedish government.

DOC.HEAD: Air France Ground Personnel Strike as Controllers Return to Tower
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic controllers ended a three-day strike late Thursday, but Air France ground personnel announced they would stage a 36-hour work stoppage this weekend. The strike beginning Friday by ground personnel was expected to slow recovery from the controllers' stoppage, which drastically cut the number of flights in and out of Paris. Many people had delayed their travel until the weekend. The controllers returned to work at midnight Thursday. However, as a result of the new strike, Air France said it was canceling half its flights Friday and Saturday morning from Charles de Gaulle Airport's second terminal, reserved for the national carrier. Ground personnel there said they were striking to protest staff shortages and press demands for higher salaries and revisions in job qualifications. The strike was also expected to affect other airlines which use Air France services at the second terminal, including Alitalia Airlines, Austrian Airlines and several Eastern European carriers. Air traffic controllers at Athis-Moni, France's largest flight control center, walked off the job Tuesday, complaining they were overworked and underpaid. That strike cut domestic and medium-haul flights by about 60 percent and forced cancellation of most charters. Several foreign airlines either canceled flights into the French capital, cut them drastically or rerouted passengers via Brussels. The strike also caused a slight disruption in the travel plans of Secretary of State James A. Baker III who was traveling Wednesday from Brussels, Belgium to London for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization summit. The plane carrying Baker was refused permission to land at London's Heathrow Airport because of congestion caused by the French air controllers' strike, authorities said Thursday. Instead, the military aircraft landed at a U.S. Air Force base at Mildenhall in eastern England, the Civil Aviation Authority said. U.S. State Department officials called it ``nothing more than a minor inconvenience.''

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocate Mitch Snyder an Apparent Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 7th graf pvs, ``We are, with attempt to reach Fennelly, autopsy to be done; ADDS new grafs 18-20 with Gonzalez, Barry comment
DOC.TEXT: Homeless advocate Mitch Snyder, who brought himself to the edge of death in many fasts to promote his cause, was found hanged Thursday at a homeless shelter with a note near his body. Police issued a statement calling the death ``an apparent suicide by hanging.'' Spokesman Reginald Smith said a note containing ``suicidal references'' was found near Snyder's body. Police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the suicide note indicated Snyder was despondent over problems in his personal life. ``It was a domestic situation, something to do with his girlfriend,'' one source said. ``The note indicates there were problems there.'' The sources said a second note was found in Snyder's room, one written during the spring. ``It was along the same lines'' as the note found Thursday, one police source said. ``It talked about this possibility, sort of outlined what he might do.'' ``We are greatly saddened by our loss,'' said Carol Fennelly, Snyder's companion of 15 years and his partner in running the shelter. Fennelly said last spring that the couple planned to marry in September. Fennelly did not return telephone calls for comment on the note. Public Health Commissioner George Hamilton said an autopsy would be done Thursday night to determine the cause of death. Snyder, 46, was one of the nation's best-known advocates for the homeless. He was a model for a movie dramatizing his 1984 hunger strike for federal funds to house the homeless. ``What a shock, what a loss,'' said D.C. City Councilwoman Nadine Winter. ``What a loss to people all over the United States.'' Robert Hayes, chairman of the Coalition for the Homeless in New York and founder of the national Coalition for the Homeless, called Snyder ``a great ally.'' ``Mitch was driven, he was no moderate on anything,'' Hayes said. ``He created, almost single-handedly, a movement. It's just a great loss.'' Snyder, who had beaten the federal government in numerous confrontations over the years, lost a battle with the city government on June 26 when a city law guaranteeing overnight shelter to everyone was scaled back because of budget pressures. ``I think that's what did it, I really do,'' said Bill Draughn, a shelter resident. ``It was a slap in his face.'' But Winter said Snyder was not especially despondent after the vote. ``He was tough,'' she said. ``We had talked about where we go from here.'' Shelter resident George Gilchrist said Snyder was under pressure from drug problems that had developed in the past year at the 1,400-bed shelter, a gray, three-story building several blocks from the U.S. Capitol. ``The man tried as best he could to help us out,'' he said of Snyder. ``It's hard to stop something like crack.'' Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, which handles legislation on homeless issues, said Snyder's ``zeal sometimes led him to extreme despondency at the seeming futility of the street people's struggle.'' ``Mitch Snyder was a rare blend of a man of action and an almost ethereal being,'' said Gonzalez. ``He was an untiring advocate for those least able to speak for themselves,'' said Mayor Marion Barry in a statement released by his office. Fennelly said the Community for Creative Non-Violence, which runs the huge shelter, was ``in mourning.'' But she said that ``we are more committed now than ever to continue our struggle to advocate for homeless human beings and to continue our fight for overnight shelter and affordable housing.'' Snyder's abrasive manner and extreme tactics _ including frequent dramatic hunger strikes and a sleepout on grates outside the Capitol _ won him allies ranging from politicians to Hollywood stars. Among them was Martin Sheen, who played him in the made-for-TV movie ``Samaritan: The Mitch Snyder Story.'' But his confrontational personality and approach also made him a controversial figure, even within his own organization. One source close to CCNV, speaking on condition of anonymity, said ``there has been a lot of dissension within the group lately.'' Snyder was criticized last spring by other homeless advocates for trying to thwart the Census Bureau's attempt to count homeless people for the first time. Snyder refused to let Census enumerators into the CCNV shelter, saying, ``These people should be allowed to have their dignity and not be disturbed in the middle of the night to accommodate government grandstanding.'' Snyder announced in March that he was taking some time off to live in a Trappist monastery in Virginia. ``I'm a religious person, and from time to time it's important to renew our relationship with God,'' Snyder told CCNV members. He said he wanted to take time for reflection, ``to do simple work like baking bread.'' Snyder grew up in New York City, and remembered cruising up the Bowery as a boy, his father ordering the car windows tightly closed ``to keep out the bums.'' He married and had two sons, working as a washing machine salesman, vacuum cleaner salesman and job counselor before quitting and walking out on his family in 1969. He wound up in federal prison on an auto-theft charge. While serving time at Danbury, Conn., he got to know the radical priests Daniel and Philip Berrigan, who were in prison for destroying draft records. After leaving prison, Snyder joined an anti-war group in New York. He moved to Washington in 1973, where he found that ``homelessness became the domestic counterpart to what was happening in Southeast Asia.'' Snyder said in a 1989 interview with The Associated Press that the most important influences in his life were three uplifting Hollywood films: ``Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' ``It's a Wonderful Life'' and ``A Christmas Carol.'' ``They taught me the lessons of my life: that good will always overcome evil, and that the most insignificant person can make a difference, provided what he's doing is right.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Red Army Faction Member Returned to West Germany
DOC.TEXT: A suspected member of the Red Army Faction terrorist group who was captured in East Germany was turned over to West German authorities Thursday, the federal prosecutor's office said. Susanne Albrecht was brought to a border crossing between East Germany and West Germany early Thursday, said Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman at the West German federal prosecutor's office. Ms. Albrecht's lawyer, Wolfgang Vogel, said she had declared herself willing to return to West Germany ``because this is for her the best solution in every respect,'' East Germany's ADN news agency said. Vogel is the East German lawyer who worked closely with the former Communist government in arranging several famous spy swaps. In an interview with the Bild newspaper on Thursday, Vogel was quoted as saying Ms. Albrecht had left the Red Army Faction and started a new life in East Germany since moving there in 1979. The 39-year-old Ms. Albrecht, wanted in the 1977 shooting death of a top West German banker, was arrested June 6 outside her apartment in East Berlin by East German authorities. She was among eight other suspected Red Army Faction terrorists arrested by East German authorities in a two-week sweep last month. One of them was later released because the warrant for her arrest had expired. Foerster said Ms. Albrecht would be brought ``at the soonest possible time'' before a federal judge to have charges read against her. The arrest of Ms. Albrecht created a stir after East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said she had told police that former East German secret police had set her up with a new identity. She said she was informed that the East German government disapproved of the group's methods but agreed with its anti-imperialist objectives, Diestel said. The Red Army Faction waged a terrorist campaign targeting financial institutions and NATO establishments in the 1970s and 1980s. The most recent victim, Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, was killed in bomb attack last November. Ms. Albrecht is accused in the 1977 slaying of Dresdner Bank President Juergen Ponto outside Frankfurt. She faces life in prison if convicted. West Germany has a standing request with East Germany that the other seven suspected terrorists also be returned to face charges.

DOC.BYLINE: Gorbachev Appeals For Western Aid In Letter To Thatcher ^By MAUREEN JOHNSON
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed for economic aid from Western leaders in a letter to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at the NATO summit, British sources said Thursday. The two-page letter appeared to contain the first direct reference from the Soviet leader for Western aid to help rescue his beleaguered economic reform program. British sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that Gorbachev made no mention of figures. But he said he was looking for ``positive conclusions'' on the security structure of the new Europe at the two-day NATO summit in London, which opened Thursday, and on aid from a summit next week in Houston, Texas, of the world's top seven industrialized nations. ``The message was essentially that he hoped that the summits would come up with the results that would support the reform program,'' said the British source. Mrs. Thatcher announced at the summit opening Thursday morning that she had received letters from Gorbachev and from President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia within the previous 24 hours. She gave no details but said both leaders were ``as interested in the result of this summit as we are here.'' Gorbachev, British sources said, indicated he was well pleased with the decision by European Community leaders meeting in Dublin, Ireland, late last month to agree in principle to aid the Soviet Union. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand tried in Dublin to persuade the other leaders of the 12-nation trading bloc to give an immediate $15 billion in aid to Moscow. Mrs. Thatcher played a leading role in getting that proposal rejected on ground the money would be wasted unless the community had a clear idea of Soviet needs. Instead the community leaders agreed to order an investigation into the best ways of helping Gorbachev. They will consider the matter again in the fall. Britain, France, West Germany and Italy, the four European Community leaders who will be at the Houston summit, also plan to raise the aid issue there with the leaders of the United States, Japan and Canada. British sources said Gorbachev indicated in his letter to Mrs. Thatcher that he was well-pleased with the outcome of the Dublin summit and said he was ``grateful'' to her ``for getting a positive outcome.'' ``The thrust of the letter was he was very grateful for what came out of Dublin and for the assessment of what was required,'' said the British source.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Teen Wins Violin Gold Medal at Tchaikovsky Competition
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Akiko Suwanai of Japan won top honors Thursday in the violin section of the ninth international Tchaikovsky musical competition, a spokeswoman announced early Friday. Yevgeny Bushkov of the Soviet Union took second place, and Alyssa Park, a 16-year-old high school student from Lexington, Ky., took third place, said Margarita Trubitfina, a spokeswoman for the competition. In addition to taking the first place gold medal, Miss Suwanai, 18, of Tokyo, also received a medal for best performance of the competition, the spokeswoman said. Miss Suwanai had won second prize at the Japan International Competition in Tokyo in 1989 and second prize at the Paganini International Competition in Italy in 1988. Miss Park received three medals in all: for third place, for most talented performer and for most artistic performer. ``I was very honored, but also very puzzled,'' she said in an interview afterward, noting that the international jury awarded her the medals for most artistic and most talented, but then only gave her third place. She admitted to feeling some tension, ``but I just tried to treat it as a concert, and play.'' Anton Barakhovksy and Natalia Likhopoiy, both of the Soviet Union, tied for fourth; David Chan of Del Ray, Calif. finished fifth; Dmitri Berlinsky of the Soviet Union and Lucia Lin of Boston tied for sixth; and Maria Bachmann of Paramus, N.J. finished seventh. Musicians competed in violin and piano, and for the first time since the event was first organized in 1958, voice and cello. The winners in piano, voice and cello were to be announced later Friday. Ten Americans were among the 48 finalists who gave final performances Thursday. ``This is the Super Bowl of musical competition,'' said Daniel Pollack, a competitor in the first competition 32 years ago and now one of the judges. If the most recent Tchaikovsky competition in 1986 was any indication, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could be expected to break off his labors at the 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party in the Kremlin and attend a weekend concert by the winners. ``I am very excited, they told me I am a candidate for first prize,'' said Hans Choi, 31, a South Korean-born singer who lives in New York City. This year, for the first time, not only are the contestants and judges international, but the funding as well. The hard-pressed Soviet hosts turned to Pioneer Electronics of Japan to contribute a $4,000 stereo system to the winner in each of the four categories. Each winner also receives a gold medal and 5,000 rubles, a non-convertible currency that cannot be taken from the Soviet Union. The competition, which began June 14, drew 335 competitors from 51 countries, organizers said. Deborah Voigt, 29, a singer who grew up in Southern California and lives in New York City, said that winning the Tchaikovsky competition automatically boosts a muscian's career. She said Soviet audiences were a treat. ``I am a bit overwhelmed. The audience response has been unbelievable,'' she said. ``I used to think Italians were the best audiences, but now I think Russians make the best audience by far.'' Ms. Lin, a 28-year-old violinist who plays with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, said she came to Moscow because of the competition's reputation. ``It's a lot of work _ stressful and grueling _ but I'm glad I came,'' she said. The Tchaikovsky competition is organized every four years by the Ministry of Culture, Union of Composers and the All-Union Music Society.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Dissolves Legislature in Troubled Kosovo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `The decision...' to CORRECT word ``policy'' to ``Parliament.'' Pickup 8th pvs, `In the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Yugoslavia's largest republic Thursday dissolved the local legislature and government in Kosovo, the troubled southern province it administers, sources and the media said. Authorities from the republic of Serbia also took measures apparently designed to give the republic full control over Kosovo's media. Several leading ethnic Albanian officials and journalists were removed from their jobs at Kosovo's radio, television and the Albanian-language Rilindia publishing house, which publishes a daily newspaper. Witnesses said Serbia's police entered downtown television, radio and Rilindia premises in the provincial capital of Pristina, arresting an unspecified number of ethnic Albanian employees. The state Tanjug news agency reported that TV and radio later went off the air. The Serbian moves could trigger fresh unrest by the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo, the nation's least developed region and the scene of sporadic violence over the past two years. The decision to disolve Kosovo's legislature and government was approved unanimously by all three chambers of Serbia's parliament. It came in the wake of a declaration Monday by 114 ethnic Albanian deputies in Kosovo's provincial assembly to secede from Serbia, Belgrade television said. In the document, Kosovo proclaimed the province of 1.9 million equal to Yugoslavia's six republics and stated that ethnic Albanians, the third-largest ethnic group in the country, would no longer be considered a national minority. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two nominally autonomous provinces. Kosovo, which is 90 percent ethnic Albanian, has progressively lost control of its affairs to Serbia. ``Kosovo's assembly has for a long time acted against the interests of the people of Serbia,'' Belgrade radio quoted a Serbian parliamentary statement that explained the new legislation as saying. The decision to disband Kosovo's 188-member legislature and local government, headed by Premier Jusuf Zeinulahu, was read during Thursday's assembly session, said sources in the provincial capital of Pristina. The Serbian law stipulated that all elected and other officials in the provincial government were suspended. Any legislation passed by the Kosovo assembly after Thursday will be considered illegal, the TV report said. Serbia's parliament also urged federal authorities to replace Riza Sapunxhiu, an ethnic Albanian, who represents Kosovo in Yugoslavia's eight-member collective presidency and has supported appeals for autonomy. About 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with security forces since March 1989 when, in a constitutional amendment, Serbia severely limited the wide-ranging autonomy Kosovo enjoyed under the 1974 charter. Pristina, however, was reported calm following the Serbian action. No members of the security forces were visible on city streets. A delegation of deputies left Pristina for Belgrade to meet with Stipe Suvar, a member of the federal presidency, in an apparent effort to secure federal support in their showdown with Serbian authorities, the TV report said. Serbs, who consider Kosovo the cradle of their medieval kingdom, have alleged that ethnic Albanians were pressuring the remaining Slavs to move out of the province. Ethnic Albanians, who want free elections and a multiparty system, deny this and say the issue has been used by the republic's Communist leader Slobodan Milosevic to gain popular support for his hard-line policies. Serbia's Communist leadership has proposed adopting a new state constitution that would effectively remove any vestiges of self-government currently enjoyed by its southern province. The elimination of Kosovo's parliament under a new constitution would make ethnic Albanians a small minority in the Serbian legislature. ``The decision to dissolve the regional parliament is an illegal one and the Albanian people will not recognize it,'' said Ibrahim Rugova, leader of the Democratic Forum, an ethnic Albanian organization that claims a membership of over 500,000. ``Serbia currently does not have any constitutional right to do such a thing,'' he said, adding that the Forum would urge ethnic Albanians to remain calm ``in the face of this provocation.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez to Return to Service
DOC.TEXT: The ship that caused the nation's worst oil spill when it ran aground in Alaskan waters last year will be returned to service later this summer, officials said Thursday. Repair work on the Exxon Valdez is nearing completion and Exxon Shipping Co. President Gus Elmer is expected Friday to announce plans for returning the supertanker to service. A Coast Guard inspector, however, said the ship is scheduled to start a two-week trial run July 20 to test its systems and obtain certification as a seaworthy vessel. The ship spilled almost 11 million gallons of crude oil when it struck a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24, 1989, sullying hundreds of miles of coastline and killing scores of birds and animals. Former Exxon Shipping Co. President Frank Iarossi has acknowledged, at least implicitly, that the ship's association with the environmental disaster may make it unwelcome in Alaskan ports. He said last summer that the tanker might be renamed and possibly put to work somewhere besides the Pacific Ocean. Since then, however, Exxon officials have kept secret where the vessel will sail once it is repaired and whether it will bear the Valdez name. Exxon spokeswoman Janet Cool said Elmer would answer those questions Friday. She said the ship would return to service this summer, but probably not this month. ``I don't think it will be sailing before August,'' she said. Fred Hallett, a spokesman for National Steel and Shipbuilding Co., where the ship was built in 1986, said the $30 million repair job on the tanker is nearly complete. ``The ship's ready. She's going smoothly,'' Hallett said. ``We're finishing the painting on it right now and we're doing some work in the machinery room.'' The 987-foot-long ship will be floated out of the dry dock later this month for a trial run to determine if NASSCO will need to make any refinements, Hallett said. Lt. Bill Uberti, a Coast Guard inspector, said NASSCO is scheduled to flood its dry dock July 20 and take the Valdez out for two weeks of trial runs. Uberti said he will be aboard the ship part of that time to certify it as seaworthy. ``They'll test all the systems out and we'll ride her a couple of days and that will be it,'' Uberti said. ``If there's a problem, they'll have to fix it before it can go out into service, but I don't anticipate any problems,'' he said. ``The only damage to the ship was structurally, and that's all been fixed.'' Repairs on the Valdez began last August after the 30,000-ton ship was maneuvered into a graving dock, which had less than two feet of clearance on each side. The tanker was placed on supports and hydraulic shorings while workers tore out the mangled steel of the single-hulled ship and replaced it with 3,000 tons of new, inch-thick steel. A couple of boulders that lodged in the tanker when it ran aground were removed and after being examined by parties in the spill litigation, were released to Exxon. The company sent the rocks, one of which was the size of small car, to a construction site where they were ground up. Exxon officials declined to retrofit the ship with a double hull because it was not feasible from an engineering standpoint, Exxon spokeswoman Carrie Chasin said in March. But Hallett said a double hull could have been put on the ship during the repair work. ``It's feasible to put a double hull,'' he said. ``The question is the cost and the time.'' In January, Exxon Shipping Co. paid a $1,000 fine to settle a pollution claim by the Coast Guard. The dispute arose from a pair of slicks and the spillage of about 356 gallons of oil as the ship awaited clearance to enter San Diego Bay.

DOC.HEAD: American Collector Pays $15.1 Million for Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: An American collector paid $15.1 million Thursday for an 18th century Italian cabinet, and autioneers said it was the highest auction price ever paid for a piece of furniture or for an artwork other than a painting. Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, wife of the late Johnson and Johnson pharmaceuticals heir J. Seward Johnson, was in the front row at Christie's auction house and bid for the cabinet, an extraordinary baroque work decorated in gilt, bronze, ebony and pietra dura _ marble inlays of birds and flowers. ``The price beat the previous highest price for furniture and is the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction, apart from paintings,'' said William Hanham, Christie's spokesman. The cabinet, 12{ feet tall and 7{ feet wide, was sold by the 11th Duke of Beaufort to pay inheritance taxes on the estate of his father and to pay for repairs to the mansion at Badminton, his country estate in southwest England. The cabinet had been at Badminton since 1732, the year it was shipped to England from Italy. It was commissioned in Florence about 1725.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, NATO Allies Gambling on Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS ``a'' to ``an'' in lead; INSERTS new grafs 3-4 on Gorbachev request for aid
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Western allies are offering soothing reassurances, and considering a massive financial bailout, to brace Mikhail S. Gorbachev against an uncertain future. It's a big gamble on a Soviet leader who gives himself only two more years to succeed or fail. Gorbachev dramatically raised the stakes for himself _ and the West _ when he imposed a deadline for fixing his country's economic and political problems. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' Gorbachev declared Wednesday. British sources said late Thursday Gorbachev had appealed for Western economic aid in a two-page letter to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the request was not specific, but expressed his hopes for ``positive conclusions'' at both the NATO summit and the economic summit in Houston next week which would enhance European security and bolster his economic reform program. Gorbachev needs a shot of Western cash for a variety of reasons, including a balance-of-payments deficit topping $2 billion _ half of that owed to West German companies and creditors _ and to put a greater variety of foodstuffs and consumer items in Soviet stores at a time of rising domestic tensions. For Bush and his colleagues, Gorbachev's message was clear: If you're going to help, do it now. Later might be too late. Western leaders are fully aware that any successor to Gorbachev might not be as tolerant of democratic and economic changes in the Soviet Union and East Europe as he has been. Gorbachev made his statement as leaders of 16 Western nations were gathering here for a NATO summit. Money for Moscow was not on the official agenda for the talks and there probably won't be any decision on it here. A decision is more likely when leaders of the world's seven richest nations meet in Houston next week for the annual economic summit of industrial powers. However, financial aid for the Soviet Union was sure to be an underlying issue as NATO chiefs met behind closed doors in London. West Germany and France are urging the West to come up with $15 billion or more for Moscow. Bush has been cool to the idea but appears to be softening his objections. At the least, U.S. officials say the president will not stand in the way of a Western European package of assistance. Publicly, NATO chiefs went out of their way to persuade Gorbachev and his conservative critics that Moscow has nothing to fear from the West as the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact teeters on collapse. ``Confrontation and the Cold War belong to the past,'' declared West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Echoing earlier proposals by Bush, Kohl said NATO and the Warsaw Pact should agree on a joint statement ``that we no longer regard one another as adversaries'' and that they renounce the use force. French President Francois Mitterrand advocated ``a solemn declaration renouncing aggression or first use of force.'' Bush took the extraordinary step of urging NATO to throw open its doors for a visit from Gorbachev, reaching out to the leader of the West's longtime adversary. Gorbachev and other officials of the Warsaw Pact would be invited to address a NATO meeting, probably in December. ``There was no negative response to the proposal,'' said Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers. One major purpose of the London meeting is to ease Soviet concerns about the thundering drive to German unification. The Kremlin is looking for reassurances that the new Germany's armed forces would be limited in some way. As a result, Kohl and West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher were working on a plan for negotiations to deal with the issue promptly. The Bush administration has resisted West German efforts to put the German military issue ahead of a treaty now in the works to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops only. But U.S. diplomatic sources said the treaty is likely to have a footnote calling for negotiations on German forces promptly after the U.S.-Soviet troop issue is wrapped up. Early in his administration, Bush struck a cautious approach toward Gorbachev, unsure how far the United States should go in backing him. After months of deliberation, Bush finally decided that Gorbachev was the West's best hope for promoting democracy and economic reforms.
