White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, commenting on Gorbachev's newly prescribed deadline, said, ``We hope he can be successful in less than two years.'' So far, that wish for success has not translated into U.S. bucks for Moscow.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since 1981 and is the AP's chief White House correspondent.

DOC.HEAD: Third Witness Claims to Have Used Drugs With Mayor
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts 3 grafs of FBI testimony after 11th graf, The witness
DOC.TEXT: A business partner of ex-model Rasheeda Moore testified Thursday that she shared cocaine with Marion Barry at a 1986 party and she was ``absolutely positive'' the mayor snorted the drug through a straw. Carole Bland Jackson was the third witness in Barry's drug and perjury trial who has claimed to have seen Barry using drugs. Jackson said she, Moore and Barry and another man used cocaine powder in the bathroom of a Washington apartment after a city-sponsored cruise on the Potomac River. ``The mayor and Rasheeda were sitting on the side of the bathtub and ... cocaine was visible,'' Jackson said. ``I snorted first, then Rasheeda took it, then the other gentleman and Mayor Barry.'' Jackson said she later left after ``the mayor came out and made sexual advances towards me which I declined.'' Moore, who cooperated in the government sting against Barry, testified last week that she and Barry used drugs together more than 100 times. Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis has also testified he used drugs with the mayor. Meanwhile, a federal appeals court refused on Thursday to order that two black leaders be allowed to attend the Barry trial. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson barred Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and an excommunicated priest last week, saying their presence could be ``disruptive and very likely intimidating.'' Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked Carole Jackson if she was sure the mayor has used cocaine after the 1986 river cruise. ``Absolutely positive,'' said Jackson. Jackson also said she used drugs in Barry's presence on another occasion in 1986, but that she did not see Barry snorting cocaine then. She said Barry was then in a bathroom where cocaine was present, holding his hand to his nose, and ``sitting there sniffing.'' The witness and Moore worked together on Project Me, a modeling program Barry asked Moore to set up to teach self-esteem to teenage girls. Moore testified the $180,000 project won speedy approval ``because the mayor told me it would.'' An FBI evidence technician also testified that she removed a ``small, white piece of rock-like substance'' from the sport coat Barry was wearing the night he was arrested at a Washington hotel. Moore has testified that just moments before federal agents burst into the hotel room and arrested the mayor, he had placed a small pellet of crack cocaine in his jacket. Dr. Thomas Lynch, who conducts cocaine tests for the FBI, testified that a crack cocaine pipe Barry was videotaped smoking from contained ``a lot'' of cocaine. Prosecutors also showed jurors a videotape of a September 1986 press conference in which Barry, seen on the tape of his Jan. 18 arrest calling the operation ``a setup,'' defending the use of undercover stings. ``I have no sympathy for those who are crybabies about the fact that we have police officers selling to those who want to buy drugs,'' Barry told reporters in 1986. ``We want everybody to know that the next drug buy may be from a police officer.'' Retchin said the statements showed Barry knew such tactics were used, so Barry cannot complain he was improperly tricked into buying crack cocaine from an undercover FBI agent when he was arrested. Judge Jackson, meantime, set a hearing for Friday on arguments by Farrakhan and Bishop George Augustus Stallings that they be allowed to attend the trial at Barry's invitation. The appeals court rejected Barry's arguments that barring Farrakhan and Bishop George Augustus Stallings, a breakaway Roman Catholic priest, from the courtroom denied him a fair and public trial. The court said Barry could only make that claim on appeal if he is convicted and it sent the matter back to Judge Jackson for further consideration. The judge refused Farrakhan and Stallings admission last week, after the three-term mayor appeared in public with them as they condemned the prosecution of Barry, who is black, as racially-motivated.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-S&Ls
Regulators Seek Recovery of $24 Million From California Thrift
DOC.TEXT: Regulators on Thursday sought a record $24 million from the former chairman of a large California thrift institution accused of squandering deposits on luxury condominiums, trips to Europe and a gun collection. The Office of Thrift Supervision said it was seeking $19 million in restitution and $5 million in penalties from Thomas Spiegel, the former chairman of Columbia Savings and Loan Association in Beverly Hills, Calif. Spiegel, a close associate of former Drexel Burnham Lambert junk bond chief Michael Milken, built the institution into one of the nation's largest thrifts. It had the industry's largest portfolio of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds, valued at $3.7 billion at the end of 1989. Spiegel denied the charges and accused the agency of conducting a politically-motivated ``trial by press release.'' Meanwhile, Edward Harshfield, Columbia's current chief executive, said in a statement that the institution's current management cooperated with the thrift office and said the allegations do not reflect on current management or the institution as a whole. Columbia is still operating, but analysts predict junk bond losses will eventually force government seizure. The $19 million in restitution, if recovered, would go to the thrift, while the $5 million penalty would go to the U.S. Treasury. Regulators ordered Spiegel to establish an escrow account or provide other security guaranteeing payment if their allegations are upheld. They are seeking return of $2.9 million for an unauthorized bonus, $463,000 for improper personal expenses, $6.4 million for corporate aircraft and a luxury hangar, $1.1 million for luxury condominiums in resort areas, $5.7 million for loans to a friend and the use of luxury cars, and $2.4 million for unauthorized payments to a charitable foundation Spiegel controlled. The personal expenses include $7,000 spent on tickets for a Michael Jackson concert, $2,000 on a wine-tasting course for Spiegel and his wife, and $55,000 for a gun collection that included Uzi submachine guns, the thrift office said. It said Columbia lost $5.7 million on $28 million in loans to luxury auto dealer Howard Schneider, who allowed Spiegel to use several of his cars. It also said Spiegel used the thrift's condominiums in Jackson Hole, Wyo.; Indian Wells, Calif., and Park City, Utah, and that Milken's brother, Lowell, frequently used the Jackson Hole condo. The corporate jets and hangar were built in a partnership with Michael Milken, who often used the aircraft for his personal use, regulators said. Thrift office Director Timothy Ryan, who took office three months ago vowing to crack down on S&L fraud, said it was the biggest restitution case yet brought by his 11-month-old agency. ``This is a landmark action ... in more than sheer magnitude,'' he said. ``It exemplifies just how seriously we intend to pursue violations of fiduciary responsibility to protect the taxpayer.'' Spiegel, who stepped down in December, issued a statement complaining that the thrift office had refused to meet with his attorneys or give him a fair chance to respond to the allegations. ``In a panic, for purely political reasons, (the thrift office) is seeking scapegoats to divert public attention from its gross incompetence,'' the statement said. No charges were announced against Milken, but the thrift office said it would continue to investigate links between his junk bond operation and Columbia and other thrifts.

DOC.HEAD: Belly Dancers Protest Religious Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A dozen belly dancers marched in protest Thursday in the southern town of Ashdod, charging that local rabbis were skirting the law in an effort to put a halt to the dancers' undulations. The dancers say the rabbis, prevented by a Supreme Court ruling from banning their performances as immoral, have resorted to threats against owners of clubs and catering halls if the women are hired. One belly dancer, who calls herself Edna and the Snakes, said she lost a contract two weeks ago because the owner of one hall was intimidated by Ashdod's chief rabbis. ``He said the Rabbinate was like a mafia and that they would find some way to take away his kashrut license if I performed there,'' she said in a telephone interview. A kashrut license certifies that food served in an establishment is kosher, that is, it conforms to Jewish dietary law. The certification is considered crucial, as most observant Jews will not eat in non-kosher establishments. In Israel, belly dancing is a popular form of entertainment for special occasions. But it has become part of the battleground between Israel's secular majority and a religious minority which wants the Jewish State to observe strict Orthodox law. In the past, rabbis routinely threatened to take certificates away from establishments where belly dancers performed, saying they violated religious notions of modesty, said lawyer Neta Goldman of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel. But in late May, she obtained a court ruling prohibiting rabbis from withholding certificates for offences unrelated to food. Rabbis now get around the court ruling by threatening to cancel kosher certificates on trumped-up charges that food is not prepared according to dietary law, complained Lea Davish, who runs a Middle Eastern dance school. Michael Cohen, the owner of the Mitzpor entertainment hall in the northern town of Tiberias, said he prohibited belly dancing in his hall after rabbis made it clear to him he stood to lose business if he refused. ``There was an unspoken understanding,'' he said. ``They would send more business to us if we stopped the belly dancing. And it paid off, I tell you.'' Ashdod's Chief Rabbi Yosef Shinen met with a delegation of belly dancers in his office Thursday morning, but could not be reached for comment later. In Ashdod, passers-by reacted enthusiastically to the belly dancers' protest. ``If the rabbis don't want to see the dancing, they don't have to come,'' said Sarit Avraan, 23.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Request To Halt Earth First! Gathering
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a legal foundation's request that he bar the environmental group Earth First! from holding its annual meeting in a national forest in Montana next week. Several hundred members of the organization are expected to begin arriving this weekend for the weeklong Round River Rendezvous at the Beaverhead National Forest in southwestern Montana. U.S. District Judge Charles Lovell rejected arguments by the Denver-based Mountain States Legal Foundation and 77 other groups that want to prevent the gathering, including ranchers, loggers, miners, and off-road vehicle users. ``We are incredibly disappointed,'' William Perry Pendley, the foundation's president and chief legal officer, said in a telephone interview. ``We believe the court must take a group like Earth First! at its word as to the reason it exists and what it will do to achieve its objectives,'' Pendley said. ``What Earth First! has said is it will use violence and terrorism to achieve its objectives to drive people off the public lands of the West.' In oral arguments before Lovell on Tuesday, Pendley said the Forest Service should not allow Earth First! in the forest because the organization allegedly advocates sabotage of developers of the nation's wildlands. ``Tree-spiking and the other acts of sabotage allegedly attributed to Earth First! are serious crimes which ought always to be vigorously prosecuted,'' Lovell said in his decision. ``Speculation that these crimes might be committed by this group at this time and in this area is insufficient to justify setting aside'' the permit. Lovell said the Forest Service had a rational and reasonable basis for issuing the permit, and conducted an adequate environmental review. Pendley said he still believes the Forest Service ``put blinders on'' when it refused to consider potential impacts of the gathering beyond the 30-acre site for which it has a permit. A planned logging operation is only two miles from the meeting site and easily accessible for anyone who wanted to spike trees, Pendley said. Beaverhead spokesman Jack De Golia said forest officials were pleased with Lovell's decision and would have law enforcement officers in the area during the meeting. ``We won't be in (their) camp,' he said. ``Our main purpose is to keep track of things and make sure trouble doesn't come to the camp or leave the camp and travel other places.'' Pendley told the judge on Tuesday that Earth First! encourages tree-spiking, the spiking of motorcycle trails, harassment of survey crews, destruction of logging equipment and other acts of sabotage. Assistant U.S. Attorney Bernie Hubley, representing the Forest Service, disagreed. ``The history of Earth First! has been one of civil disobedience away from the forest,'' he said. ``This group does not have a documented history of doing these types of activities in the forest.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed As Bus Protest Turns Violent
DOC.TEXT: A panicked white motorist on Thursday drove into a crowd of black protesters, killing four, and was then killed by a mob, police said. The incident began when demonstrators, angered by bus fare increases, ordered hundreds of passengers to get off dozens of buses at a depot in the black homeland of KwaNdebele, northeast of Pretoria. Two buses were set afire and several were stoned, while the passengers gathered on and alongside the road, police said. A white motorist approaching the scene apparently feared for his safety and tried to plow through the crowd, said Brig. Hannes Prinsloo of the KwaNdebele police. Four blacks were killed and several more injured. The driver, identified as A.C. Malan, was then assaulted and killed by a mob, and his car set afire, Prinsloo said.

DOC.HEAD: Group of Homeless Say they Won't Move Despite Threatened Arrests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jack Howard, a woman, is cq in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Shaded by the Civic Center Plaza's olive trees, Jack Howard lay on a bed piled with heavy blankets while a 2-month-old kitten nuzzled her chin. The 30-year-old homeless woman expects to be in the same spot when police begin an expected crackdown on people living in the government center. ``I've lived in Civic Center 8{ months. I lost my home in the (October) earthquake,'' she said. ``I'm not moving unless they give us some alternative campsite.'' For now, she can't go to the two so-called multiservice shelters that the city took over this week because they're for men only. And she refuses to move into one of the older shelters or a former hotel the city is offering women. ``I'm safer in this park than in one of those `hot line' rooms,'' Howard said, referring to the one-time hotel rooms the city has available. She explained that occupants often are bothered by crack dealers and rats. The city takeover of the multiservice shelters coincides with the mayor's order for police to begin arresting people sleeping or keeping belongings at the Civic Center. The centers combine shelter with such services as drug and alcohol treatment and job counseling. But homeless advocates criticized the city's plan, saying the 110 new beds the city has made available won't accommodate the up to 350 homeless who sleep in the park. Howard said she is one of about 50 who intend to remain camped at the Civic Center despite an expected wave of arrests sometime Friday. Others, who said they don't want to face jail, lined up for vouchers handed out Thursday morning. Many complained there were not enough tickets to go around. Deputy Mayor Myra Snyder said Thursday that all of the Civic Center's homeless will have access to the vouchers, which admit homeless people to a center that, in turn, refers them to a shelter or hotel room. Snyder said some people have to wait because the workers were only handing out 50 at a time in order to keep an accurate count. ``I prefer not to sleep out here, I prefer to go to the shelter,'' said Greg Hayes, 35, who has been living on and off in Civic Center since his release from San Quentin prison in December. Hayes, who served 54 months for a armed robbery, picked up a voucher. He said he's stayed away from existing shelters because of the dirt and violence and hopes the new shelter will be cleaner. ``You're better off sleeping out here than some of those shelters,'' he said. ``This is the first opportunity to get into something decent.'' Advocates for the homeless charge that the mayor's new policy will force 215 people already staying in one of the two shelters out on the streets to make way for the displaced Civic Center homeless. They said it also will break up couples and force many people into jails, doorways or alleys. In protest, the Coalition on Homelessness plans to bring in homeless people from other areas to the Civic Center to overwhelm the new shelters, said the group's Josh Brandon. The city's plan unfairly targets the Civic Center homeless, while others throughout the city desire shelter as well, Brandon said. ``We simply want to give people who want to get off the streets the opportunity to get off the streets,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Growth Factor Protects Heart Following Attack, Study In Rats Shows
DOC.TEXT: A natural substance called transforming growth factor beta appears to be able to limit damage to cardiac cells following a heart attack, according to a study published in the journal Science. In a study at the Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, a group of laboratory rats induced to have heart attacks suffered 50 percent less cell damage after injections of transforming growth factor beta than did rats that did not receive the TGF beta. ``TGF beta is a growth factor that opposes some of the bad guys following a heart attack,'' said Dr. Allan M. Lefer, a professor at Jefferson. Lefer said his research team simulated heart attacks in 24 rats by partially blocking key arteries in their hearts. In 12 of the rats, the researchers injected a placebo. In the other 12, they injected transforming growth factor beta. For those who received the TGF beta, said Lefer, ``the damage from the attack was much less severe. There was about 50 percent less injury with TGF beta than without it.'' The extent of heart cell damage was determined by measuring the amount of creatine kinase in the heart tissue following an attack. Hearts damaged when the blood supply is interrupted, as in a heart attack, tend to lose creatine kinase, said Lefer. Thus, by measuring for the loss of this substance, researchers could determine the amount of heart damage. Lefer said the TGF beta seems to block the action of other substances, such as tumor necrosis factor, that can cause blood vessels to narrow following a heart attack. Narrowed blood vessels carry less oxygen-rich blood to cells and this causes additional injury following a heart attack. TGF beta is normally present in heart cells, but the study published in Science said that it is missing from rat heart cells damaged by a simulated heart attack. Though TGF beta is produced naturally in the body, Lefer said his research team used a substance produced artificially by Genentech, a California biotechnology firm. Lefer said his team is now conducting additional studies with TGF beta and that any experimental treatment of human heart attack victims with the substance is at least a year away. Jefferson Medical College, where the study was done, is part of Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Special Master Rules In Kentucky-Illinois Boundary Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The boundary between Kentucky and Illinois is the low-water mark on the Illinois side of the Ohio River _ right where it was when Kentucky became a state in 1792, a U.S. Supreme Court mediator has ruled. The exact boundary is of more than map-making interest. Illinois fishermen have long complained of having to buy Kentucky licenses to fish from their own shore. It also could affect certain property tax payments. The problem is that the river no longer follows that 1792 low-water mark, and no one is exactly sure where it was. Therefore, Special Master Matthew J. Jasen said the boundary should be determined by agreement of the two states or a joint survey. If no agreement can be reached, Jasen said he would decide. His recommendation will be considered by the Supreme Court at its fall term that begins in October. His recommendation, issued last week and released Thursday by the Kentucky attorney general's office, is the latest chapter in a decade-long, four-state legal dispute over the location of Kentucky's northern boundary. The ruling from Jasen, a retired New York Court of Appeals judge appointed by the Supreme Court to hear the case four years ago, is what Illinois officials had sought and parallels earlier rulings in the Ohio and Indiana cases. The 1792 border definition was fine until 1909, when dams raised the water level. Kentucky claimed it should control the river up to the new low-water mark, while Illinois, Indiana and Ohio said the 1792 boundary should still hold even though the shoreline had moved beyond it. In a hearing in January, Kentucky officials argued that Illinois has done little to exert its claim on the river. For example, while Kentucky law enforcement officers routinely patrol the river, Illinois makes no such effort, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Foreigner Invades Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Yet another foreign invader has ignored the border and taken up residence in the Great Lakes. A tube-nosed goby, a 3-inch-long fish from the Black Sea region of the Soviet Union, was recently found on an intake screen at the Detroit Edison Co.'s Belle River plant on the St. Clair River. But the goby doesn't appear threatening, unlike a host of other invaders, including the water pipe-clogging zebra mussel, the trout-killing sea lamprey, and the beach-befouling alewife. Like other non-native critters, the goby probably got to the Great Lakes by hitching a ride on ocean freighters which take on water _ and any small free-swimming animals that happen to be in the way _ for ballast. When the ship reaches port on the Great Lakes to take on cargo, the ballast gets dumped. Threatening or no, the goby isn't welcome. Biologists ``don't like to see foreign species end up in our bodies of water,'' said Dave Jude, the University of Michigan scientist who found the fish.

DOC.HEAD: Assault Charges Against Congresswoman Dropped
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors on Thursday dropped an assault charge filed against U.S. Rep. Helen Bentley by a process server who said the congresswoman choked him after he handed her a subpoena. Assistant State's Attorney Cynthia Ferris told Baltimore County District Judge Mike Loney there wasn't enough evidence to prove the complaint by John Burns, 41, against the 66-year-old legislator. Bentley, R-Md., didn't appear in court, but issued a statement afterwards. ``I have said all along that I never assaulted Mr. Burns or touched him and the contention that I slammed this 230-pound man against a wall and strangled him is preposterous,'' said the 5-foot-2 Bentley. Burns said Bentley shoved the subpoena in his face when he walked out of her office June 1 and demanded he take it back. When he turned to face her, she choked him, he said. The subpoena ordered Bentley to be available to appear as a defense witness in the murder trial of a man accused of killing his wife. The victim's son and sister work in Bentley's office. After learning the decision to drop the charge, Burns left the courtroom abruptly. He returned after his lawyer, Stanley Kantor, warned him against saying anything that could place him in contempt of court. After the hearing, Burns refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Girl Dies of Wounds, Suspected Collaborator Killed
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old Palestinian girl shot in the head in a clash with Israeli troops a year ago died of her wounds Thursday. An Arab suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities was discovered dead. The teen-ager, identified as Wafaa Khamis Alian, died at Ein Shams Hospital in Cairo, Egypt, hospital officials said. Arab reporters in the occupied Gaza Strip said the girl was shot in the head during a clash with Israeli soldiers in June 1989. She was treated at Israel's Tel Hashomer Hospital and at Shifa Hospital in Gaza before being taken to Cairo by relatives, they said. In the occupied West Bank, meanwhile, the body of a Palestinian was found before dawn Thursday near the Amari refugee camp. Arab reporters said the man, identified as Feras Hasouneh, 22, was known as a pro-Israeli collaborator and was kidnapped from his house in the camp by five Palestinian activists. The army confirmed the death and said it was being investigated by police and security services. At least 230 Palestinians have been killed during the 2{-year-long uprising by other Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Some 722 Arabs have died of Israeli gunfire, and 45 Israelis have also been slain in the violence. In another development, State Attorney Yosef Harish, responding to an appeal from lawmaker Ran Cohen of the leftist Citizen's Rights Movement, ordered a police investigation into a pamphlet distributed to Jewish settlers, Israel radio said. The anonymous pamphlet, quoted by Israeli media Wednesday, urged settlers to shoot at Palestinian stone-throwers and to carry out vigilante raids. The pamphlet gave detailed instructions on how to obtain guns and avoid capture and it advised settlers to gather explosives from the army, masquerade as soldiers during attacks and leave misleading evidence behind. More than 130 Jewish settlements have been built in the West Bank and Gaza since they were captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. About 75,000 Jewish settlers live among 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Army Official Calls for Caution in Reduction of Armed Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to UPDATE, remarks now delivered
DOC.TEXT: An Army official on Thursday used the reunion of a band of veterans defeated during the first major U.S. battle in Korea as the backdrop for an appeal to Congress to exercise caution in armed forces cuts. ``We must not sacrifice the American soldier on the altar of political expediency,'' Gen. Carl E. Vuono, Army chief of staff, said in remarks at a reunion of Task Force Smith, the first U.S. combat unit in Korea. ``Precipitous cuts of more than 35,000 active component soldiers in any single year ... will fracture the combat capability that may be required to defend our nation's vital interests,'' he said. Named for its commander, Lt.Col. Charles Bradford Smith, Task Force Smith was hastily stitched together from infantry and artillery units after North Korea struck across the 38th parallel early on June 25, 1950. On the morning of July 5, with North Korean troops already in the South Korean capital of Seoul, Task Force Smith was dug in on a ridge commanding a highway and railway line about 22 miles south of Seoul. As the sun rose, the officers and enlisted men of Task Force Smith found themselves looking down on a miles-long column of North Korean trucks jammed with infantry and the first of 33 Soviet-made T-34 tanks. The unit had been issued exactly six high-explosive, antitank or HEAT rounds capable of piercing the armor of that type of tank. But the soldiers soon made a number of unpleasant discoveries. They found that many of their weapons either didn't work or were too light to do the job; that radios had corroded batteries and could not be used to call in artillery support; and no arrangements had been made for the resupply of ammunition that began to run out by early afternoon. They also found that there was no medical evacuation system and 30 or so of the most seriously wounded had to be left behind when the order came to withdraw. In addition, they had been issued no maps of the area and the officers had only the vaguest idea of where they were. The Amy now blames the handicaps under on the rapid demobilization of the armed forces after World War II and on the austere budgets that left units under manned and poorly equipped and soldiers inadequately trained. ``The United States Army _ the victor in the greatest land campaigns of this century only five years before _ was an empty force,'' Vuono said. He said the Army realizes that as the Cold War thaws and the demands for cost reductions to deal with the budget deficit become more insistent, the Army must become smaller. But he said care should be taken that as the Army shrinks, it retains quality and capability.

DOC.HEAD: NEA President Urges Extra Help for Elementary Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 9th graf, ```The arguments ...,' to UPDATE with NEA delegates approving nontraditional certification of teachers; picks up 10th graf, `As the ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Teachers-Preschool
DOC.TEXT: The head of the National Education Association on Thursday called for a $2.2 billion program that would offer an intensive session to prepare elementary students in need of extra attention. Keith Geiger proposed Operation Jump Start during the opening session of the NEA's annual meeting, explaining that the program would be an ``all-out, full-alert effort to give every elementary child who needs it an educational booster shot.'' About one-third of the nation's 26 million elementary students would be involved, he said. In his first address as president to the union's policy-making body of about 8,100 delegates, Geiger asked the federal government to provide half of the estimated $2.2 billion needed for Operation Jump Start. States and local school districts would pick up the rest of the tab. At a news conference, Geiger said those identified for Operation Jump Start would be given a head start on the school year, in classes limited to 15 students. The teachers would be those the students will have during the regular school year, Geiger said. ``We would release this educational surge in an intense two-week period before regular classes in the fall of 1991 _ a little over a year away,'' he said. ``The focus would be on readiness _ on a high-energy jolt for the millions of children for whom more personal relationships with teachers, greater confidence in the school environment, and closer relationships between school staff and families could make the difference between future success and failure.'' Geiger also pointed to a position recently adopted by the NEA's board of directors that public schools should become the primary provider of preschool education. ``The arguments for this preschool position go beyond the child's own development,'' Geiger explained. ``Every major trend points to public school being the center of the community in the years ahead.'' In a key vote late Thursday, the delegates gave a qualified endorsement of alternative routes for certifying teachers. ``The National Education Association remains committed to ensuring that there is a fully licensed, qualified teacher in every classroom _ but recognizes that there may be more than one way to prepare such teachers,'' said the NEA policy statement. Alternative or nontraditional certification for teachers is a controversial issue among educators but has gained in popularity with predictions of future teacher shortages. The NEA document signals the first official attempt by the union to show some support for the concept, although it takes a middle ground between outright opposition to alternative certification and those who feel any college graduate can teach school. In the past, NEA officials have complained that inadequately trained teachers are allowed in the classroom when normal channels to teacher preparation are bypassed. Nontraditional routes to licensure allow mid-career professionals from other fields to become teachers. It differs from emergency licensure because it does not bypass training in teaching methods and other quality control measures. As the 2 million-member NEA, the nation's largest teacher's union, geared up for its four-day convention, the 744,000-member American Federation of Teachers wrapped up its four-day annual gathering in Boston Thursday. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos was the final key speaker at the AFT meeting. He proposed that teacher colleges require all new teachers to be proficient in a second language. Cavazos also said he fully supported multicultural curricula because of the growing diversity of classrooms across the nation. Such an approach gives students early and frequent exposure to many cultures to build an appreciation of people's differences, he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NATO to Extend Olive Branch to Warsaw Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs to update with proposed non-aggression pact; pickup 3rd graf pvs: ``We are''
DOC.TEXT: NATO's foreign ministers agreed early Friday on a draft communique inviting the Warsaw Pact to sign a mutual non-aggression agreement with the West, diplomatic sources said. The tentative proposal ``is basically stating that various countries who sign it are no longer adversaries and should refrain from threat or use of force,'' one source said. The 20-paragraph communique, to be presented to the NATO heads of state for final approval later in the day, also included an invitation, as proposed by President Bush, for Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Warsaw Pact leaders to address a NATO gathering in Brussels later in the year, officials said. The sources, who discussed the draft NATO summit communique on condition they not be identified, said it also calls for the establishment of ``diplomatic liaison'' between the military alliances and proposes the eventual elimination nuclear artillery shells in the region by ``reciprocal arrangement.'' On another major point, the document would certify Bush's proposed shift in longstanding NATO strategy regarding the possible use of any nuclear weapons in the face of superior conventional forces. The communique would describe them as weapons of ``last resort,'' but still would make clear that use of them was not ruled out _ a point insisted upon by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Dutch Foreing Minister Hans van den Broek confirmed ``We have reached agreement on a communique'' as the ministers left Lancaster House. ``We are 99 percent agreed,'' he said. It was Bush who pushed Thursday for the declaration that NATO's use of nuclear weapons would be a highly unlikely last resort, and for inviting Warsaw Pact leaders to meet directly with their NATO counterparts. Bush's eye-catching proposals reflected recognition by the 41-year-old alliance of the easing of East-West tensions in Europe and the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``We are reaching out to old adversaries to emphasize NATO's defensive character and desire to cooperate with adversaries,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman. French presidential spokesman Hubert Vedrine said the invitation to Gorbachev, which also would be extended to other Soviet-bloc leaders, was readily approved. Diplomatic sources said Gorbachev would be invited to address a session of the North Atlantic Council at NATO's headquarters in Brusels, Belgium, in December. A senior U.S. official said Bush and the other Western government leaders almost certainly would attend if Gorbachev accepted. Georgy Shakhnazarov, a personal aide to Gorbachev, said earlier Thursday the Soviet leader was prepared to accept any such invitation. Shakhnazarov was interviewed on the U.S. Public Broadcasting System's ``McNeill-Lehrer Newshour.'' For a while, Bush's proposal for revising Europes's nuclear ``flexible response'' strategy enounctered some resistance. Mrs. Thatcher, the most reluctant of the allied leaders to lower the West's guard, questioned abandoning the threat to launch a nuclear attack promptly to stop a Red Army assault on Western Europe. The proposal ``does not leave ambiguity absolutely clear,'' complained a British spokesman, commenting only on condition of anonymity. He referred to the fact that a commitment to use nuclear weapons only as a last resort could remove some of the uncertainty confronting a potential aggressor about possible retaliation. But after a four-hour meeting of the 16 foreign ministers a British spokesman withdrew his government's objections. He said the communique to be adopted at the end of the summit meeting on Friday would reserve the use of nuclear weapons as a ``last resort.'' And he said that ``no one will be left in any doubt that nuclear weapons might be used.'' Mrs. Thatcher herself suggested that in the midst of warmer feelings for the Soviet Union, she was in danger of being called ``Cold War warrior.'' Fitzwater told reporters that ``the debate is real, the discussion is real'' as NATO embarks on a new approach. But overall, he said, ``we will show that NATO has a new dimension of cooperation with the Soviet Union.'' In that vein, French President Francois Mitterrand proposed ``a solemn declaration renouncing aggression or first use of force.'' He told the allies he was ``not in favor of anything that would artificially perpetuate bloc-to-bloc relations when this no longer reflects the reality.'' Bush, appearing tired after an overnight flight from the United States, steered clear of reporters aboard Air Force One and at the ceremonies that preceded the summit session. He flew to England from Pease Air Force Base, N.H., after a long work-and-play weekend at Kennebunkport, Maine. In London, the leaders gathered around a long oval table in a chandeliered room of Lancaster House, a government mansion. Mitterrand was late. The weather was chilly and it rained intermittently, and the traditional ``family protrait'' of the 16 leaders was moved indoors. West German government spokesman Hans Klein said Gorbachev's mounting domestic difficulties ``came up again and again'' during the summit's first day. But a U.S. official said there was no discussion in Thursday's session of direct aid to the Soviet Union _ an idea pushed by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Bush, too, is easing toward supporting a Western aid package to assist Gorbachev's restructuring program and to smooth the way for German unification by mollifying the Soviets. In the private talks, the 16 NATO leaders also were considering permitting East European countries to participate in some non-military NATO deliberations. Fitzwater said Bush suggested the establishment of liaison offices between nations in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and the alliance. ``The general purpose is to find some way to give them access to NATO in a learning capacity and hopefully one in which they would appreciate where we're coming from,'' he said. Bush's startling proposal to invite Gorbachev to address the North Atlantic Council in Brussels, where NATO has its headquarters, would extend, as well, to the leaders of the six other Warsaw Pact members. NATO's main function always has been to confront the Soviet Union and its East European satellites with massive military might, including a threat to launch a nuclear attack in order to drive back any invasion by the Red Army. But Gorbachev has pledged to withdraw tens of thousands of troops and tanks from Eastern and Central Europe, and a treaty now being negotiated by NATO and the Warsaw Pact would reduce U.S. and Soviet forces further. Bush called for this two-day NATO summit in May to help reshape the Western alliance as a result of the rapidly diminishing military threat from the East. Despite British reluctance, the allies were expected to endorse Bush's idea. Diplomatic sources, declining to be identified, said the Bush proposal was intended to demonstrate that NATO is changing its focus to keep pace with events in the East. Three Warsaw Pact countries, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland, have abandoned the Communist system. Gorbachev, meanwhile, is in the midst of a struggle in the 28th Communist Party Congress in Moscow to gain endorsement of his experimentation with free-market concepts. If NATO adopts the change in strategic doctrine proposed by Bush there still would be U.S. nuclear weapons in Western Europe. But cuts in Soviet troops in Eastern and Central Europe, and a reluctance by the Warsaw Pact allies to support a Soviet invasion, make their use highly unlikely, U.S. officials said. Bush also is ready to consider scrapping the 1,470 U.S. nuclear-tipped artillery shells now based mostly in West Germany and reducing or eliminating an arsenal of 1,560 nuclear bombs deployed in seven NATO countries.

DOC.HEAD: `Die Hard 2' Takes Off With $5.9 million Opening Night
DOC.TEXT: ``Die Hard 2'' opened to strong business, grossing $5.9 million in its first night of release, according to figures released Thursday. Playing on close to 2,500 screens on the Fourth of July, the Bruce Willis action sequel's premiere compared favorably to that of ``Dick Tracy,'' according to statistics compiled by Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc. ``I think the opening is far beyond our expectations,'' said Tom Sherak, president of domestic distribution and marketing for 20th Century Fox, makers of ``Die Hard 2.'' ``The Fourth is not a good movie day, especially if the weather is nice.'' ``Dick Tracy'' collected $9.3 million on its first night, a Friday, but that figure included more than $3 million in T-shirt sales for special early showings. ``Total Recall,'' the biggest hit so far this summer, made just less than $8 million in its first Friday. Last summer, ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' one of the season's most popular crime-fighting films, collected $6.3 million its first day of release, also a Friday. Made at an estimated cost of $62 million, ``Die Hard 2'' is among the most expensive films in Hollywood history. The original ``Die Hard,'' also starring Willis as a crafty policeman in a showdown with international terrorists, opened in July 1988. ``Die Hard 2'' played on 2,020 screens on Tuesday in special ``sneak'' previews, netting 20th Century Fox $3.7 million. Those figures will not be counted in the film's opening weekend results released next Monday, the studio said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Arrives in Uganda to Tumultuous Welcome
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, nearing the end of his six-week tour of Europe, the United States and Africa, arrived in Uganda on Thursday to a tumultuous welcome from thousands of Ugandans, including most politicians. Mandela, coming from London where he pressed for continued economic sanctions against South Africa, landed shortly before noon at Entebbe airport. He was greeted by President Yoweri Museveni, Cabinet ministers, diplomats, dancers and musicians. Mandela, accompanied by his wife, Winnie, inspected a military honor guard, but did not give a speech. Thousands of Ugandans jammed the airport and many more lined the 21-mile route that Mandela took to the capital, Kampala, in an attempt to get a glimpse of Africa's best known former political prisoner. Mandela, the deputy president of the African National Congress, is scheduled to leave Uganda on Sunday for the annual summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity in Ethiopia. On Wednesday, Mandela met with Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The two failed to resolve differences over sanctions and the use of violence. Unlike most other leaders on Mandela's world tour, Mrs. Thatcher openly opposes sanctions and wants those imposed by the European Economic Community relaxed as a reward for South African President F.W. de Klerk's reform program. Like President Bush, who Mandela met in Washington, Mrs. Thatcher also wants the ANC to renounce its armed struggle against the white minority government. Mandela has insisted that the sanctions remain in place to keep pressure on South Africa's government to dismantle the apartheid system of racial discrimination. He has also said the ANC cannot renounce its armed struggle until blacks are guaranteed political rights.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors: Actor Narrowly Averted Heart Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf, ```He feels ...,' to UPDATE with Hackman publicist comment; picks up 10th graf, `Semler said ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gene Hackman, who soon will be appearing in a film called ``Narrow Margin,'' may have avoided a heart attack by a similar measure when he checked into a hospital. An artery leading to his heart had narrowed dangerously and doctors had to reinflate it with a balloon catheter, the cardiologist who treated him said at a news conference Thursday. ``We think we got him just in the nick of time,'' said Dr. Herbert Semler. Hackman, 60, had just finished filming a movie in Europe called ``Dinosaur'' and was vacationing on the Oregon Coast when he began suffering chest pain. He came to Portland and the pain expanded to include his arm. He was admitted Tuesday to St. Vincent Hospital & Medical Center. ``We did a coronary angiogram and found narrowing in one of his arteries,'' Semler said. ``It was in a very excellent area that we could easily reach with a balloon catheter and we dilated it.'' Semler said that if Hackman hadn't entered the hospital when he did, ``the artery would have completely shut down and he would have possibly had a heart attack.'' The doctor said Hackman was feeling fine and would be released Friday at the latest. ``He feels much relieved,'' Semler said. ``The pain is gone. He is up and around and ready to make another movie.'' ``I spoke to Gene; he sounded pretty good,'' Hackman's publicist, Dick Guttman, said in Los Angeles. Hackman thought the chest pain was only indigestion, but felt it was a good idea to have it checked, Guttman said. Semler said the rest of Hackman's coronary arteries look good and the actor can return to an active life. The doctor said he is recommending a program of exercise and improved diet, however. He said Hackman is not overweight, doesn't smoke and has no history of medical problems. ``That's the interesting part _ we see this in otherwise healthy people,'' he said. ``The narrowing comes on as a natural process like gray hair. It could happen to anyone.'' The son of a journeyman pressman, Hackman is a former truck driver and soda jerk who didn't pursue acting until he was in his 30s. His most acclaimed role so far was as the rough-and-tumble narcotics cop Popeye Doyle in 1971's ``The French Connection.'' That performance won him an Academy Award. Among his other film credits are ``Bonnie and Clyde,'' ``I Never Sang for My Father,'' ``The Conversation,'' ``Hawaii,'' ``Lucky Lady,'' ``A Bridge Too Far,'' ``Superman,'' ``The Package,'' ``Reds,'' ``No Way Out,'' ``Target,'' ``Hoosiers'' and ``Mississippi Burning.'' Upcoming releases include ``Postcards from the Edge'' and ``Narrow Margin.''

DOC.HEAD: President Announces Economic Measures
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer on Thursday announced increases in the price of gasoline and flour as part of austerity measures to fight the economic crisis in this Caribbean country. Balaguer did not specify how much gasoline and flour will increase. The price of gasoline doubled in October to 82 cents a gallon. Flour sells for the 11 cents a pound. The 83-year-old Balaguer was re-elected May 16 in a contest that has been tainted by charges of fraud. The Central Electoral Board is evaluating challenges to the results. Balaguer, who will be inaugurated for his sixth term Aug. 16, also announced there will be unspecified salary adjustments to compensate for the increased costs of basic goods. Government heavily subsidiizes both gasoline and flour. The minimum monthly salaries are $69 for public employees and $96 for private sector employees. But inflation is running at least 50 percent a year and electricity blackouts and currency devaluations are common.

DOC.HEAD: Victims Of Postwar Anti-Semitic Pogrom Honored After 44 Years
DOC.TEXT: After 44 years, a memorial plaque has been placed on the site were dozens of Jews were killed in a 1946 pogrom, but incidents of anti-Semitic vandalism marred the tribute to the victims, a newspaper reported Thursday. The plaque was defaced last week and tombstones in the Jewish cemetery were defiled Tuesday night, the Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper reported. The newspaper said a performance by an Israeli group and a discussion meeting by local journalists were disrupted. On Wednesday, local residents and municipal authorities attended an official ceremony to formally unveil the plaque in this central Polish city. ``Rain is failing, it is God crying,'' said Zygmunt Nissenbaum, chairman of the Jewish philanthropic Nissenbaum Fund, during the ceremony. On July 4, 1946, rioting Poles attacked a building sheltering Jews who had survived the Holocaust and were traveling to Palestine. They killed 42 people and injured scores more. The attack came as the city was swept by an anti-Jewish hysteria, fueled by false rumors that Jews had abducted a Christian child. The Soviet-backed Communists later blamed the pogrom on nationalists loyal to the Polish government in exile in London, while others called the pogrom a Communist police provocation. Nine people were convicted and executed for their roles in the pogrom. But shortly after their trial, the Communist authorities banned publication of documents about the attack and it became a so-called ``blank spot'' in Polish history. The memorial plaque _ with an inscription in Polish, Yiddish and English _ is embedded in the wall of the house on Planty Street where the slayings took place. During the unveiling ceremony, a letter was read from Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who was instrumental in erecting the plaque and keeping alive the issue of the pogrom in overwhelmingly Catholic Poland. Recalling previous attempts to honor the victims, Nissenbaum recalled that he was surrounded by armed police when he went to the local Jewish cemetery in 1986. He said he was told not ``to take up the Kielce issue,'' Gazeta Wyborcza said. In 1987, Nissenbaum said he was allowed to place a tombstone honoring the pogrom victims in the cemetery. Last year, a Solidarity-led government took power in Poland, ending more than 40 years of Communist rule. The new government has condemned anti-Semitism, re-established diplomatic relations with Israel and fostered efforts to honor the thousand-year Jewish tradition in Poland. Before World War II, Poland was home to more than 3 million Jews _ most of whom later died in the Nazi Holocaust. Only a few thousand Jews remain in Poland. Most of the Holocaust survivors either emigrated or fled the country after anti-Semitic campaigns orchestrated by Communist authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Police Issue Sketch as `Dartman' Claims 46th Victim
DOC.TEXT: A sketch of a man who fires darts at women was released by police Thursday, hours after the mystery assailant launched his 46th known attack on a midtown Manhattan street. A woman found a homemade dart dangling from the backside of her clothes when she returned to her office from a lunchtime shopping trip, said Chief of Detectives Joseph DeMartino. Like 17 darts recovered after previous attacks, it was made from a pin or needle with a paper stabilizer and probably was blown through a straw, somewhat like a pea-shooter, he said. The woman was the 46th pedestrian known to have been hit by the dart shooter since June 26, police said. All were women, usually wearing business clothes or skirts, DeMartino said. The police sketch of the ``Dartman,'' as New York's tabloids have dubbed the city's latest bizarre criminal, shows a black man with a mustache and neatly trimmed beard. Police say he is 5-feet-6 to 5-feet-8 inches tall, weighing 135 to 150 pounds, possibly wearing glasses and carrying a black bag. DeMartino said the man approaches women from behind and shoots the homemade darts at them through a straw or something similar. He has said nothing to any of the victims, DeMartino said. All the attacks have occurred on busy streets in a midtown area encompassing the garment district, Times Square and Rockefeller Center. DeMartino said there had been no serious injuries and urged women to remain calm. He said the needles and pins recovered had not been doctored in any way.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir Gov't Gives Police Sweeping Powers
DOC.TEXT: The government of the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir on Thursday gave security forces sweeping powers to crush a bloody Moslem secessionist campaign that has left at least 666 people dead this year. Under the new act, security personal will be permitted to fire on suspects and to search and destroy buildings. The act also bans the assembly of more than five people in public places, Press Trust of India reported. Gov. Girish Chander, in a statement issued in the state's capital of Srinagar, said he made the declaration to deal with ``the terrorist,'' a term he uses to describe Moslem militants. The streets of Srinagar were mostly deserted Thursday as the result of a threat by Moslem militants to attack private transport in the Kashmir valley. The militants issued the threat Tuesday, saying security forces were using private cars for surprise raids on guerrilla hideouts. The ban will be in force until Aug. 8, the militants said in a statement issued to local newspapers. Any vehicle defying their ban may be attacked, they said. The valley, part of Jammu-Kashmir state, has been gripped by a Moslem insurgency since the beginning of the year. At least 666 peole have been killed since the government cracked down on the simmering insurrection on Jan. 20. Jammu-Kashmir is the only state in mostly Hindu India to have a Moslem majority. The Kashmir valley was a focus of dispute between India and Moslem Pakistan when the subcontinent was divided along religious lines in 1947. Kashmir was predominantly Moslem but its Hindu ruler opted for union with India. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the disputed valley.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Fires into Church Group, Hitting Off-duty Policeman and Two Others
By ELINOR MILLS
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A man fired into a church group Thursday, wounding three people, then surrendered after a two-hour standoff in a neighboring house, police said. Clifton Phillip Jeter, 23, of Los Angeles was arrested and booked for investigation of eight counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. Police spokesman Leo Speliopoulos said the five extra complaints came from people at whom the attacker pointed a firearm and who felt their lives had been threatened. The motive could not immediately be determined, Speliopoulos said. ``It just appears to be a random shooting,'' he said. The incident occurred in a parking lot behind a center of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Speliopoulos said. More than 100 girls and adults were in the parking lot, either boarding buses for a church camp or saying farewell to the campers, he said. According to police, off-duty Officer Steve Checketts saw the man in a corner of the parking lot and told him to drop his handgun. The man then shot Checketts, 43, hitting him in the left arm and chest. The gunman then squeezed off shots into the crowd and fled to the nearby residence of Samuel Sanchez Jr., who had met Jeter at a party Tuesday night and invited him to stay at the house while he looked for a place to live, Speliopoulos said. The gunman was the only person in the house at the time he surrendered, police said. Checketts' condition was upgraded to serious from critical after surgery. Another bullet hit Elaine Beech, 47, in the left ankle. She was treated at a hospital and released. Amy Garrard, 17, was grazed on the leg and treated at the scene. ``We were just waiting to start to load the buses when all of a sudden I thought I heard what was a firecracker,'' said Gene Williams, whose 14-year-old daughter was going on the trip. Williams said he then heard Checketts yell, ``Gene, I've been shot! Call 911!'' Williams ran into the church and called the emergency number. ``I think initially everyone thought it was a prank, then when Steve started yelling we realized it was for real,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Workers End 25-Day Strike
DOC.TEXT: More than 6,000 Honduran health workers ended a 25-day strike Thursday after the government dropped a plan to privatize some services in state hospitals. The 14,000-member Medical Workers' Union objected to the privatization of food, janitorial and security services in six of the country's larger hospitals. Union leaders said strikers would return to work Friday morning. Health Minister Cesar Castellano announced the decision to drop the privatization plan at a news conference Thursday. Doctors and nurses who belong to the union did not take part in the strike. Army medics were called in to assist during the strike. Some 15,000 people remain on strike in sympathy with 10,000 banana workers who walked off their jobs 11 days ago in a protest against the U.S. banana giant Chiquita Brands International Inc. The banana workers, who earn slightly over $15 a day, were asking for a 60 percent pay raise. Talks aimed at ending the strike began Saturday in the northern city of San Pedro Sula.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Tightens Controls on Power Saws to Protect Rain Forest
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday imposed stricter controls on the sale and use of power saws in an effort to protect the Amazon rain forest. Power saws must be registered with the government, and landowners will need a license to cut down trees, the Brazilian Institute for the Environment said. Stores that sell power saws also must be registered, the institute said. Manufacturers of saws will be required to put the I.D. number and production series in a readily visible place on the equipment. ``We are transforming an instrument of work into a weapon that will impede the destruction of the plant covering of Brazil,'' institute president Tania Munhoz told reporters. The sale of power saws without a license will be considered a crime against the environment, carrying a penalty of up to three months in jail and a fine of as much as $500, she said. Ms. Munhoz said there are more than 400,000 power saws in Brazil. Until now, there were no controls on their use, especially in the vast Amazon jungle. The government estimates that 8 percent of the 2 million square-mile wilderness has been destroyed by farmers and ranchers.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Hit by Hailstorm, Makes Emergency Landing at Philadelphia Airport
DOC.TEXT: Hail tore the nose cone off an Eastern Airlines jetliner Thursday, forcing the pilot to make an emergency landing at Philadelphia International Airport soon after it left Newark, N.J. There were no injuries, Eastern Airlines spokesman Robin Matell said in Miami. Flight 161, a DC-9 bound for Atlanta with 42 passengers and a crew of five, landed in Philadelphia at 3:50 p.m., Matell said. ``The pilot was climbing out of Newark at between 10,000 and 15,000 feet. There was heavy storm activity and apparently the nose was blown off,'' he said. ``There was very heavy hail, and wind and thunderstorms in the area.'' ``It's a fiberglass dome and that was shattered by the hail,'' said Matell. ``To the best of our knowledge there was no structural damage to the plane.'' The pilot flew by the airport tower to allow a visual inspection of the landing gear, then landed, said Dan Korzeniowski, the airport's deputy director of aviation. ``It was a very safe and normal landing,'' he said. An airport employee said some passengers said they noticed a rattling noise during the flight, but other than that ``nothing out of the ordinary.'' The passengers were put on another Eastern flight to Atlanta. Korzeniowski said the nose cone of an aircraft is part metal, but mainly fiberglass, because the radar and other instrument systems are kept there. There were some pockmarks along the edges of the wings and the tail, ``but other than that there was minimum damage to the aircraft itself,'' Korzeniowski said. Matell said the incident was being investigated by Eastern, the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Denies Claim it Trained Guerrillas at Mexican Drug Trafficker's Ranch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS grafs 6-7, `Judge Edward ...,' with 2 grafs to reflect AP obtained report, although informant's name was deleted; EDITS throughout to reflect informant unidentified in report; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An informant claims the Central Intelligence Agency trained Guatemalan guerrillas at a ranch owned by Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero, according to a Drug Enforcement Administration report. The allegation, made in an interview with the DEA, was denied Thursday by a CIA spokesman in Washington, D.C. ``The whole story is nonsense,'' spokesman Mark Mansfield said. ``We have not trained Guatemalan guerrillas on that ranch or anywhere else.'' Caro is serving a prison term in Mexico for the murder of U.S. DEA agent Enrique Camarena at Caro's home in 1985. The DEA report surfaced this week in the U.S. District Court trial of four other men allegedly involved in Camarena's torture and murder. Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered prosecutors to give the report to defense attorneys. The Associated Press obtained a copy, although the informant's name and other identifying information was blacked out. The Los Angeles Times on Thursday identified the informant as Laurence Victor Harrison. The newspaper said Harrison ran a communications network for traffickers and cohorts in Mexican law enforcement in the 1980s. The ranch purportedly used to train guerrillas is in Veracruz, Mexico. The bodies of Camarena and his pilot were found on a ranch near Guadalajara. The informant told the DEA on Feb. 9 that the CIA used Mexico's Federal Security Directorate (DFS) as a cover for the guerrilla camp. ``Representatives of the DFS, which was the front for the training camp, were in fact acting in consort with major drug overlords to ensure a flow of narcotics through Mexico into the United States,''' Harrison said. Sometime between 1981 and 1984, members of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police who went to the ranch on a separate drug investigation were confronted by the guerrillas, the report says. ``As a result of the confrontation, 19 MFJP agents were killed. Many of the bodies showed signs of torture; the bodies had been drawn and quartered,'' the informant said. Not contained in the DEA report are any specific statements as to whether the CIA knew who owned the Veracruz ranch, why Guatemalans were being trained there or if any marijuana was being cultivated there. The informant also told the DEA in a Sept. 11, 1989, interview that CIA personnel once stayed at the home of Mexican drug trafficker Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo, who was convicted and imprisoned in Mexico in the Camarena case. Harrison testified in the Camarena case that he lived at Fonseca's house in 1983 and 1984 while installing radio systems. He carried an Interior Ministry credential which he used while serving as a guard on Fonseca's drug convoys. Harrison also has testified that he decided in September to become a government witness. In testimony Harrison has said he audited classes at the University of California, Berkeley, in the late 1960s, went to Mexico for the first time in 1968 during a student rebellion there, and settled there in 1971. He has denied ever working for a U.S. government agency.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Threatens Legal Action on Proposed All-German Election
DOC.TEXT: The main opposition Social Democrat Party on Thursday criticized the government for its proposal to hold separate East German and West German elections to an all-German Parliament. Opposition leader Oskar Lafontaine accused Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union of ``manipulating to gain an advantage with undemocratic decisions.'' He said separate elections would give Kohl's party an unfair advantage in the elections. The Social Democrat chairman, Hans-Jochen Vogel, said he was considering filing a complaint with the Supreme Court in Karlsruhe. Vogel questioned the legality of ``parliaments in two nations being elected for one (nation) that does not yet exist.'' West German law requires that political parties capture a minimum 5 percent of the total vote to be represented in Parliament. East Germany has no such rule. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has proposed that East Germany and West Germany abide by the 5 percent hurdle in same-day elections for an all-German parliament. But he said the vote should be tallied separately in each country. That would give small East German parties a chance to compete by reducing the number of votes needed for representation. The Social Democrats said Thursday the intention of the plan is to benefit Kohl's party by dividing the vote in East Germany. They have demanded the votes are tallied throughout a united Germany. Reinhold Kopp, Lafontaine's chief of staff, told reporters Thursday in Bonn the opposition-controlled upper house of parliament would introduce legislation to ensure one united vote. ``The basic law of election equality is not up for disposal,'' Kopp said. Lafontaine is Kohl's chief rival for chancellor in the expected December all-German elections. He said agreement on all-German elections might be legally impossible if East Germany did not first declare itself merged politically with West Germany. Under the government's proposal, East Germany would declare itself merged with West Germany under the West German constitution following the elections. The East German Cabinet on Wednesday set Dec. 2 as the date for all-German elections. De Maiziere, who was strongly backed by Kohl and won East Germany's first free elections March 18, also supports the election plan, sources in East Berlin said.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold fell 67 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets on Friday, opening at $361.18. It closed at $361.85 Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Peruvian President-Elect Hit by Truck
DOC.TEXT: The 13-year-old son of president-elect Alberto Fujimori was injured after he was struck by a pickup truck Thursday night, the teen-ager's said. The youth, Hiro Alberto Fujimori, was in stable condition, said Pablo Higushi, the president-elect's brother-in-law. Doctors plan to operate on the boy's right leg, he said. Hiro was learning to ride a motorcycle when he was struck by the pickup truck, police said. He was thrown at least 10 feet by the impact, they said. Police would not say if they plan to charge the truck driver with the accident. Fujimori is to return to Peru on Friday after a weeklong trip to New York and Japan, where he has been campaigning for economic aid for his impoverished nation. Fujimori won a June 10 runoff presidential election by a landslide, beating novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. He will take office July 28. Fujimori and his wife, Susan, have four children.

DOC.HEAD: Fires Close Alaska Highway Near Threatened Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE with evacuation of Tok, burned Coast Guard station, quotes from governor, emergency measures taken, other details. Picks up 17th graf pvs: `Most of ...'
DOC.TEXT: A raging wildfire Thursday forced residents of a small town to abandon their homes, burned a Coast Guard station and other buildings, and blocked the Alaska Highway, the main road into the state. ``The fire is out of control. We're throwing everything at it we have _ tankers, bulldozers, people, and it isn't working,'' said state forester Bob Dick. He could give no estimate of the fire's size, except to say it was ``substantilly larger'' than the 14,000 acres it had consumed by Thursday morning. The blaze was among 159 raging across some 172,500 acres of Alaska. The biggest fire covered about 30,000 acres near Beaver, about 110 miles north of Fairbanks, but authorities said no structures were threatened there. Gov. Steve Cowper declared a statewide state of emergency, and called on the Alaska National Guard to help fight the fires. Sirens sounded through Tok, a town of some 900 people about 175 miles southeast of Fairbanks, and emergency personnel went door to door telling residents to leave their homes and go to the community school in town. Flames were within a mile of houses near the Tok airport and on the southeast edge of town, authorities said. The fire was burning the Coast Guard's Loran Station Tok, which provides electronic radio signals to help guide aviators and mariners. Coast Guard volunteers flew to the station earlier in the day from Kodiak to try to clear a fire line around the building. A weigh station along a nearby highway and an abandoned house outside town also were burning, authorities said. The Tok and Tanacross airports near the community were closed. The Glenn Highway was closed Thursday morning from about one mile south of Tok to about seven miles south, and the Alaska Highway was closed between the Tok Airport and the Tanana River crossing, about 10 miles east of town. ``Flames are crowning over the Tok Airport, swelling up over trees and rolling real fast,'' said a dispatcher at the Alaska state police office in Tok. ``The sky is black and the whole area is completely choked in.'' Crews cut a fire line linking the highways and tried to conduct a controlled burn, but the fire jumped the fire break, said Sue Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the federal Bureau of Land Management. Dick Jackson, the Fairbanks North Star Borough's emergency services director, was in Tok to help with the evacuation plan. Red Cross officials were en route to the town Thursday evening from Fairbanks. The road to Fairbanks remained open. ``We've had a couple hundred tourists come in so far today. There's a lot of smoke in the area and they're wondering what's going on,'' said Loretta Goneau, a clerk at the visitors information center in Tok. ``What's bothering us the most is breathing. There's burnt spruce needles falling out of the air,'' resident Mellie Terwilliger said ``You can see but you go around with your lights on.'' Some residents wore masks to filter out smoke. Gov. Cowper flew over the area Thursday afternoon. ``It's potentially a very dangerous situation,'' he said. He credited state agencies' work, but said there were insufficient forces to fight the numerous blazes. ``From the air you ... could see the fire spread,'' the governor said. ``We had to get upwind of it before we could actaully see it _ the fires are that massive.'' Most of the fires were blamed on heat, low humidity and a rash of lightning strikes. The fire danger was extremely high in much of Alaska, Mitchell said. Temperatures approached 90 degrees throughout much of the interior Wednesday. The heat dries out Alaska's forests and gives rise to late afternoon thunderstorms and wind gusts, Mitchell said. On the Kenai Peninsula, however, drizzle and temperatures in the 40s and 50s helped firefighters curb a series of blazes that broke out near Ninilchik. ``That's the only good news,'' said Mitchell. ``We like that kind of weather.''

Western nations agreed to provide millions of dollars in aid to help revive the stricken economies of four East European countries, but made no move to help the Soviet Union. Foreign ministers of two dozen Western nations on Wednesday ducked the troublesome question at a meeting called to extend an aid program, initially set up only for Poland and Hungary, to others in Eastern Europe. They said in a final statement they discussed the situation in the Soviet Union and ``underlined their interest in positive developments'' toward a democracy and a free-market economy. The issue of aid to the Kremlin, which pits the United States for the most part against West Germany and France, was expected to surface at the summit of NATO leaders opening today in London.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev says that if Soviet citizens aren't better off in two years, he and the rest of the Communist leadership will resign. Gorbachev's remarks to reporters Wednesday, which were shown on national television, marked the first time the president and party leader gave himself a deadline for reversing the country's economic and political downslide. ``I think that in two years, if there are no changes, this leadership must go,'' Gorbachev said as he entered the Kremlin Palace of Congresses on the third day of the Communist Party's watershed 28th Congress. A Western journalist on the scene said Gorbachev had been asked what should happen if there are no improvements in the Soviet Union in two years.

Hormone injections can reverse some of the damage of aging on the body and give people back the firmer flesh of their younger years, a study released today says. Researchers found that injections of human growth hormone, a once-rare protein made through genetic engineering, will help old people build up sagging muscles, take off flab and grow more youthful-looking skin _ turning back the clock as much as 20 years in just six months. However, they caution that the treatment is not the fountain of youth, and should not be used routinely until questions are answered about its long-term effects and possible hazards. And while it will firm up bodies, it will not undo many of the other ravages of aging, such as failing eyes and dying brain cells.

Americans celebrated Independence Day by exercising their freedom of speech with protests in California and Florida, cutting a birthday cake for 25,000 in Philadelphia and building a world-record sandcastle in South Carolina. The traditional fireworks, parades and picnics also marked the Fourth of July festivities on Wednesday. The holiday was a record hot one in many parts of the nation, sending millions to beaches. Among high temperatures were 105 in Enid, Okla., 104 in East St. Louis, Ill., and 100 in Baltimore. ``You can't see the grass, the sand or the water, it's so crowded out there,'' said Chicago police Sgt. Mike O'Brien, stationed on the city's lakefront.

A jury convicted a Christian Science couple of manslaughter in the death of their 2{-year-old son in a case that weighed religious faith against parental responsibilities to provide medical care. Some jurors cried after finding Ginger and David Twitchell, both 34, guilty Wednesday of involuntary manslaughter in the 1986 death of their 2{-year-old son, Robyn, who suffered a bowel obstruction. ``It has been hard on everyone and it was certainly hard on'' the jury, David Twitchell said minutes after the verdict was read. ``This has been a prosecution against our faith.'' But prosecutor John Kiernan said the case was about crime, not religion.

Wisecracking TV brat Bart Simpson may be an underachiever and proud of it, but he's no slouch when it comes to big bucks merchandising, dude. He's even bigger than E.T. Products bearing the cartoon character's bulging eyes, spiked hairdo and rebellious wit are the hottest items at the Atlanta National Gift & Accessories Market, which opened this week, exhibitors said Wednesday. Vendors stocking up for back-to-school and winter holiday items are drooling over Bart T-shirts, college insignia sweat shirts, refrigerator magnets, key rings, buttons and posters.

NATO leaders Thursday quickly approved a proposal by President Bush to open the military alliance to a visit by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They also moved toward accepting Bush's call for declaring the use of nuclear weapons in Europe a highly unlikely last resort. Bush's eye-catching proposals, which would shift basic NATO war-fighting doctrine, reflected recognition by the 41-year-old alliance of the easing of East-West tensions in Europe and the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``We are reaching out to old adversaries to emphasize NATO's defensive character and desire to cooperate with adversaries,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman.

Communist Party leaders will consider a proposal to change their party's name in order to regain the people's trust, a spokesman said Thursday. Col. Gen. Dmitri Volkogonov, a prominent historian, proposed that the party change its name to something like ``The Party of Democratic Socialism,'' spokesman Alexander Lebedev said. However, the idea was unlikely to win support at the 4,657-member party congress, a poll by the congress' sociological service found. It reported that 80 percent of delegates favored keeping the name as it is, and only 14 percent backed changing it, according to the nightly news program ``Vremya.''

The Albanian foreign ministry on Thursday promised to grant passports to the hundreds of Albanians who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in a desperate attempt to flee their Communist homeland. Hundreds of other would-be refugees gathered outside embassies in the Albanian capital, Tirana. Dozens gained entry into embassy compounds, raising the number of asylum-seekers to close to 400, diplomats said. In a statement carried by the official Albanian news agency ATA, the foreign ministry also appeared to deny a report that Albanians would no longer be able to apply for visas at embassies of the countries they wished to visit. ``The Albanian authorities ... are ready to grant passports, even to those citizens who are still in the foreign embassies and who shall ask for such a thing,'' the ministry statement said.

Officials permanently closed five Paris museums to individual visitors Thursday, an unprecedented step prompted by three art thefts in one day, including a Renoir sliced from its frame at the Louvre. The city's major museums will remain open, but security will be tightened, said Jacques Sallois, director of national museums. Authorities plan to examine existing security systems and develop new ones similar to those used in banks. Police said it was possible that the same person or group hit all three museums during a span of several hours Wednesday, moving from one museum to another in the middle of the day. In addition to the Renoir, an 1816 painting by Paul Huet was stolen from the Carnavalet Museum, and an 1870 work by Ernest Hebert was stolen from a museum named after the artist.

Homeless advocate Mitch Snyder, who brought himself to the edge of death in many fasts to promote his cause, was found hanged Thursday at a homeless shelter with a note near his body. Police issued a statement calling the death ``an apparent suicide by hanging.'' Spokesman Reginald Smith said a note containing ``suicidal references'' was found near Snyder's body. Snyder, 46, was one of the nation's best-known advocates for the homeless. He was a model for a movie dramatizing his 1984 hunger strike for federal funds to house the homeless.

Savings and loan regulators Thursday announced conflict-of-interest charges against President Bush's son, Neil, and ordered him to answer them at a public hearing in September. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision alleged that the younger Bush, as a director Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, voted to approve loans or business deals totaling more than $100 million with a business partner, Bill L. Walters.
