Bush, in a reply, denied he had violated his duty as a director and either denied the specific charges or said he ``lacks sufficient present knowledge or information to form a belief as to the allegations.'' Both the administrative charges, filed in February, and the reply, filed a month later, were made public Thursday for the first time under a new thrift office policy. The House Banking Committee had obtained and released a preliminary draft of the charges in June.

Although two Christian Scientists were found guilty of manslaughter for withholding medical treatment from their son, the debate continues over a key aspect of the case: When should the government overrule religious beliefs that affect children? Medical experts on Thursday applauded the verdict against David and Ginger Twitchell, saying it would help protect children. But a constitutional scholar said the decision reflects a ``fundamental unfairness'' because the Twitchells thought they were protected by a 1971 state law that exempted spiritual healing from child abuse statutes. The prosecution argued that the statute _ which states that children will not be considered neglected or abused when ``treated by spiritual means alone'' by an ``accredited practitioner'' _ did not exempt the Twitchells from manslaughter laws.

About 5,300 rebels fought government troops in Monrovia's suburbs Thursday, according to an insurgent source in neighboring Ivory Coast, while soldiers ransacked stores and restaurants. President Samuel Doe's advisers continued to desert as the rebels tightened their grip on the capital. On Wednesday, Doe's most trusted commander, Lt. Gen. Charles Julu, left Liberia, weakening the president's already fragile position, U.S. officials in Washington said. In the city's eastern and western suburbs, growing numbers of rebels battled soldiers for a fourth consecutive day. The rebels now control all roads into Monrovia.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Promises Through the Eras: Some Get Broken
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: That's the trouble with catchy phrases _ they're catchy. So when George Bush said yes, or at least maybe, to new taxes, everybody in America already knew that he had said no 1,000 times and said it in a catchy way: ``Read my lips _ no new taxes.'' Bush is not the first president to break a campaign promise, but he was so downright unequivocal that his about-face will go down as part of the history of the Bush presidency. He put himself among the giants of promise-breakers: _Woodrow Wilson, who ran for re-election in 1916 on the slogan, ``He kept us out of war'' and five months later asked Congress for a declaration of war. _Franklin D. Roosevelt, who, running against Herbert Hoover in 1932, accused Hoover of running up ``a deficit so great that it makes us catch our breath.'' FDR, of course, became a deficit king in office. _FDR, again, who in the 1940 campaign said, pretty unequivocally: ``I have said this before but I'll say it again and again and again _ your boys are not going to be sent into any foreign wars.'' A year later, American boys were being sent into foreign wars. _John F. Kennedy, who said in campaigning that it would take a mere ``stroke of the presidential pen'' to end racial discrimination in federally assisted housing. Once in office, he took 18 months to issue a timid executive order covering very little of the country's housing. _Lyndon B. Johnson who, even as his administration was making plans to escalate in Vietnam, told voters: ``We don't want our American boys to do the fighting for Asian boys.'' And, ``We don't want to get tied down to a land war in Asia.'' Shortly thereafter, he sent the first of 500,000 American boys into an Asian land war. _Ronald Reagan. He promised he would never deal with terrorists. Then came the Iran-Contra affair in which he sought to swap arms for hostages. What most presidents say when they feel compelled to splatter a campaign promise is what Bush said: circumstances changed. Few blamed FDR for asking for a declaration of war after Pearl Harbor. Few held his deficits against him when they saw the bread lines shortening. And so when Bush says the deficit is getting bigger than he'd ever imagined, big enough to threaten prosperity, he is betting that people will go along. They probably will, if the rest of the bargain is kept: if he keeps the economy perking. Bruce Buchanan, a University of Texas political scientist, says whether the public forgives politicians for broken promises depends not so much on the breaking as on the consequences. ``It may well be that he'll escape punishment and other Republicans will feel the pain,'' says Buchanan. ``By time the 1992 election rolls around, there may be no consequences for Mr. Bush.'' On this subject, a professor has written a book. He is Jeff Fishel, professor of government at American University, and his book is ``Presidents & Promises.'' He tries to quantify broken promises. He studied the campaign promises of five recent presidents _ Kennedy, Johnson, Richard Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Reagan _ and compared them to proposals actually advanced when the candidates became president. He puts the presidents' proposals in seven categories, the first two of which are ``fully comparable'' (to campaign promises) and ``partially comparable.'' If one adds the percentages, it turns out that Kennedy tried to make good on more of his promises than any of the five; Reagan scored lowest. But all batted over .500. Sixty-seven percent of Kennedy's proposals were made in fulfillment of his campaign promises. For Johnson, it is 63 percent; Nixon 60 percent; Carter 65 percent; Reagan 53 percent. Fishel tracked 133 promises by Kennedy; 63 by Johnson; 153 by Nixon; 186 by Carter; and 108 by Reagan. He calls his methods ``crude, very broad indicators ... that do not and cannot fully address the complexities of candidate pledge or presidential fulfillment'' _ but conclusive enough to find the results commendable. He concludes it is ``remarkable that, once elected, every president, from Kennedy through Reagan, has demonstrated considerable good faith, seeking through legislation or executive order to follow through on a majority of his campaign pledges.'' Evidently he harbors low expectations. For that matter, so does the public. In a Gallup Poll published at the end of May, 74 percent of the participants said Bush would not be able to keep his no-new-taxes pledge. They read his lips, but maybe they'd read history, too.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has been watching presidents make and break promises in Washington for 22 years.

DOC.HEAD: Indonesia Tries to Awaken U.S. Interest
DOC.TEXT: Indonesia plans to spend 18 months celebrating its rich and diverse culture in the United States to promote trade, tourism and investment. ``The main aim of the festival is to acquaint the general American public with Indonesia in all its aspects, but especially its culture,'' said Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, who initiated the project. He is a former Cabinet minister in charge of foreign affairs and a graduate of Yale University Law School. ``Some people call it a coming out party,'' he said. Although the world's fifth most populous nation with more than 175 million people, 13,677 islands, 450 languages and the largest Islamic community on Earth, Indonesia sometimes seems invisible. Officials tell of Americans who confuse it with India or Indochina. On the other hand, many Indonesians shun publicity. Some would be pleased if the world would just leave them alone. Geography has something to do with this. No external enemy threatens. And there is a true remoteness to be felt in parts of Borneo, the islands beyond Bali and highland Sumatra. Language and culture also play a part. Much of Indonesia's literary tradition is oral and rooted in specific islands. It doesn't travel well or translate easily. The Yayasan Nusantara Jaya (Great Archipelago Foundation) which Mochtar heads planned the massive promotion because there is less awareness of the country among Americans than in Asia or Europe. Also, the United States is Indonesia's second largest trading partner after Japan and a potential source of tourists. ``Americans have run out of countries to discover. Indonesia is one of the countries they see as a last frontier,'' Mochtar said. Jakarta has scheduled ``Visit Indonesia Year 1991'' as a major tourism campaign. His foundation is private, and the more than $6 million it raised for the festival came from donors such as major oil companies and the Rockefeller Foundation and Ford Foundation. Officials said the last time Jakarta tried to penetrate the American market through a prolonged effort was with an elegant pavillion at the 1964 New York World's Fair. Another catalyst for the festival was the successful 18-month celebration of India which drew much attention in 1985. Ted Tannen, who designed the Indian show, is doing the same for Indonesia. Five years in preparation, The Festival of Indonesia 1990-91 comprises exhibitions, live performances, movies and TV programs in 13 cities. The official opening is scheduled Sept. 16 at the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington. Preliminaries include a showing of classical sculpture from the 8th through the 15th century, which opened July 1 at Washington's National Gallery of Art. Pieces from Indonesia's museums and archaeological services are supplemented by items loaned by European and U.S. collections. ``This will fall during the summer, when there are thousands of people visiting the city, so we don't want to miss the chance to promote the upcoming festival,'' said operations manager Rahmad Adenan. Indonesia's artistic styles range from the primitive carvings of New Guinea and other islands to the finely crafted gold work of Sumatra and Java. Much of the folk art has never been seen in the West, except in a few museums. Four exhibits are the core of the festival, acting as centerpieces to scores of ancillary events. They are ``The Sculpture of Indonesia,'' ``The Court Arts of Indonesia,'' ``Beyond the Java Sea'' and ``Modern Indonesian Art, Three Generations of Tradition and Change, 1945-1990.'' Affiliated programs include exhibitions of traditional puppetry, classical manuscripts and textiles. Museums presenting the core exhibitions include the National Gallery and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, Houston's Museum of Fine Arts, the Dallas Museum of Art, Los Angeles' Natural History Museum and San Francisco's Asian Arts Museum.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Merchants Profit From War by Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Eleven years ago, Sarajuddin Aryobi was a small-time merchant struggling with the family livestock business. Then the Soviet army entered Afghanistan and Aryobi struck it rich. Mohamad Fariq's transport business barely paid expenses in 1975. Thanks to the 12-year-old civil war between the Soviet-backed government and Moslem guerrillas, Fariq now owns 250 trucks. To celebrate his success, and display it, Fariq recently yanked out a front tooth and replaced it with a gold one. War and political chaos have created a smuggler's paradise. The flood of more than 5 million Afghan refugees to Pakistan, Iran, Dubai, Western Europe and the United States has caused great misery, but from it has blossomed a global network of import-export businessmen. Truckers, currency dealers, buyers and sellers are scattered around the world, and making money has become even easier since the government in Kabul discarded Marxist theory. Kabul's streets are lined with car repair shops that switch steering wheels from the left to the right so vehicles can be sold in Pakistan and India. Towers of new truck tires awaiting re-export stand like totem poles in alleys of the old city's bazaar. ``Our business climate is better than paradise,'' former Finance Minister H.H. Tarzi said in an interview. ``I myself would like to be an Afghan businessman.'' Before the war, Afghanistan was dirt poor. Its per capita gross national products, $115, was among the world's lowest. Twelve years of war and the failed communist experiment has made the country even poorer. Afghanistan has no heavy industry and its natural gas wells have been capped for more than a year. Its only exports are traditional: carpets, dried fruit and karakul, the curly fleeced skin of newborn lambs. The name of the game in Afghanistan is re-export _ which usually means smuggling _ to Pakistan, Iran and India. Aryobi's firm, Saraj Trading Co., operates from a mud-brick courtyard off an alley in Kabul. He estimates that $1 billion worth of goods are smuggled to Pakistan, India and Iran each year. During the 1980s, re-export to the Soviet Union hovered around $400 million a year, said Aryobi, who got into the import-export business by selling Japanese TVs to Soviet soldiers. The Soviet trade dropped to about $50 million when the Soviet army left in February 1989, after more than nine years in Afghanistan. Smuggling profits don't stay long in Afghanistan. Aryobi uses Deutschebank in Frankfurt and Fariq, his trucker, has accounts with Chase Manhattan in New York. Afghan businessmen can make a success of smuggling because the economies of Pakistan, Iran and India remain generally closed to the outside world. Ever since Pakistan and India won independence from Britain in 1947, they have tried to protect local industry by imposing huge tariffs on imported goods. Customs duties are 150 percent for tires and can reach 200 percent for television sets. Iranian tariffs also are high. Some countries, like Japan, make things better; others, like China, make them cheaper. Enter the smuggling Afghans. Afghanistan always has been a marketplace. Centuries before Christ, traders crisscrossed its mountains on their way to the Middle East and Asia. Silk routes to China passed through Afghanistan, and Chinese curios still turn up in the dusty junk shops of Kabul's Chicken Street. Before the civil war, an estimated 50 percent of Afghanistan's imports were re-exported. Now, with the collapse of the economy, the Chamber of Commerce says about 95 percent of imports are shipped out again. The business centers on the aging warehouses along the muddy Kabul River. Trucks heavy with goods inch out of dusty alleys and bounce over potholed streets. Boys prod tires with pressure guages. Drivers with full black beards and wildly colored turbans check their AK-47s, firing rounds into the air. A year after the Soviet army arrived in December 1979, Aryobi abandoned his livestock business for import-export. A chance meeting with a Japanese businessmen brought him his first shipment of television sets. Since 1980, Aryobi says, about 500,000 TVs have moved through his riverside warehouses to neighboring Pakistan and some have gone on to India. He also re-exports 100,000 pairs of tires a year, usually Indian tires to Pakistan and Japanese to India. Aryobi, 35, does not flaunt his wealth, but 43-year-old Fariq is nouveau riche, his shirt unbuttoned, barrel chest draped in golden chains, fingers laden with rings of lapis lazuli. When Fariq replaced the tooth with gold last year, he didn't use a painkiller. ``I wanted to feel my wealth,'' he said, flashing a newly metallic smile. In 1983, Aryobi's profits became a political liability. The communist regime of Babrak Karmal imprisoned him for ``price gouging'' and he spent nearly three years in solitary confinement. The government's attitude toward business began to change after 1986, when the Soviets installed Najibullah, who uses only one name, as president. Under a policy called National Reconciliation, Najibullah returned to the traditional Afghan way of solving problems. Merchants, tribes and local militias were given autonomy as long as they pledged loyalty to the government. Afghanistan's central bank recognized the bustling currency market in Kabul's old city. State monopolies on sugar and food transport ended and some state-run firms were sold to private investors. The biggest boon came when the state-run Afghan Cart Company began to encourage smuggling by selling merchants licenses to import goods, including televisions and other electronic items. ``We needed the money,'' explained Tarzi, the former finance minister. More than 15 percent of government revenues now come from sales of such licenses. A recent Aryobi deal illustrates the intricacies of Afghan re-export. In early February, a Pakistani trader wanted to smuggle Indian tires from Afghanistan to Pakistan. He went to Peshawar, Pakistan, and deposited 50 percent of the purchase price with a currency dealer, a refugee from Afghanistan. The currency dealer sent a telex to his uncle in Kabul's currency market, authorizing him to pay Aryobi the funds. Aryobi, who doesn't like to keep money in Kabul, transferred a portion to his bank in West Germany through Afghan money dealers in Dubai. He got in touch with Fariq and, within a week, drivers were hauling Indian tires east to Pakistan. On the way, the trucks passed through hostile territory, controlled by Afghan rebels. Truckers paid off the guerrillas, who operated ad hoc ``toll booths'' along the way. The tires arrived at the frontier at night and were smuggled into a warehouse. The next morning, a string of pickup trucks moved them to Pakistan's biggest city, Karachi, where they were sold. The Pakistani trader then paid the balance in Peshawar. ``We always work like this,'' Aryobi said, fingering copies of the telex traffic. ``It's pure trust. That's the Moslem way.''

DOC.HEAD: 45 Years in Jungle To Avoid ``Disgrace'' of Surrender
DOC.TEXT: Shigeyuki Hashimoto says just watching the pace of modern Japanese life makes him tired, but he has a rare perspective: Hashimoto spent 45 years as a guerrilla fighter in the Malaysian jungle. He was working in Malaya when World War II ended and joined guerrillas of the Malaya Communist Party. ``I always missed Japan and always wanted to come back, but to do so would require a surrender,'' Hashimoto said in an interview. ``Japanese people in my generation were taught that surrender was more disgraceful than death.'' Hashimoto, 71, and 79-year-old Kiyoaki Tanaka emerged from jungle sanctuaries on the Malaysia-Thailand border in January when the Communist guerrillas ended one of the world's longest insurgencies. Belief in the shame of surrender made fierce fighters of Japanese soldiers and motivated a few to hold out on remote islands long after the war ended. The last member of the Japanese Imperial Army to surrender was Lt. Hiroo Onoda, who gave up in the Philippines in 1974. Hashimoto and Tanaka were not in the wartime army, but were working for a Japanese ironworks in Malaya when the war ended. They joined the guerrillas, fighting British colonial troops first and, after Malaysian independence in 1957, the non-communist government. ``Japan invaded Malaya and other Southeast Asian countries during the Pacific War claiming it would free the region from the colonization of European countries and the United States, but history has proven that what Japan really did in the region was not better than what other invaders had done,'' Hashimoto said in an inverview. ``After Japan surrendered ... I thought about what I could do for Malaya's independence and decided to help the communist forces, which were also fighting for independence,'' he said. ``Japan may have surrendered, but we were still fighting a war against Britain. ... I was never a communist, but we fought for a common goal. They also accepted us very warmly.'' Hashimoto said he was one of seven Japanese civilians and about 14 soldiers who joined the guerrillas in 1945, and that only he and Tanaka survived. He would not give details about the many years in the tropical jungle, but said life there was ``quite comfortable because it was never cold and there was plenty of food.'' ```We ate almost everything,'' including the meat of elephants, tigers, monkeys and wild pigs, he said. Since his return to Japan, Hashimoto has lived with his younger brother, Noriyuki, in a two-bedroom apartment in Chiba, just east of Tokyo. He is not eligible for a veteran's pension, but said a small welfare payment was enough for his modest needs. He said he rises before dawn, as he did in the jungle, and goes for a walk around the town, then spends the day reading and watching television. Beginning in 1970, the guerrillas had shortwave radio and Hashimoto learned of his homeland's postwar redevelopment. ``I knew Japan had fully recuperated from the destruction of the war and had become a major economic power,'' he said. Even so, the modern scene amazed him. ``I never saw that many people and cars in my life,'' he said. ``It got me tired just by looking at them. People in the street were also walking very fast.'' Of Japan's proper role in the world, he said: ``We should always think in terms of what's good for the rest of the world as well as what's good for Japan. ``One country should never cause troubles in other countries for the sake of its own gains. In that sense, it was wrong for Japan to expand to the Southeast Asia in the way it did and start the Pacific War against the United States.'' Freedom, he said, is ``a beautiful thing, but my feeling is that some people are taking the spirit of freedom wrongly and thinking they are free to do anything. I think it is important for us to know that real freedom should not cause troubles for others.'' Hashimoto said he would spend his remaining days visiting relatives of fallen comrades. ``I am too old to start something new, but I want to go around Japan to meet families of my colleagues and tell them how they were doing in the jungle,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Time was when buying a can of beans was as easy as pie. You had to consider whether the beans would be tasty and nutritious and wouldn't have too much salt. It's not that simple any more. Now a savvy consumer considers whether he should be buying his beans in biodegradable containers and, beyond that, the social policies of the company that cans the beans. Does it hire and promote women? Trade with South Africa? Also manufacture cigarettes? Pollute? Recycle? Test its products on animals? Some investors also are raising questions like that. They want to know whether the companies they support do more than merely make a profit. They want their investment dollars to have a social conscience. That process of looking into corporate policies has been given a lot of names: ``green consumerism,'' ``economic democracy,'' ``corporate responsibility'' or ``empowerment.'' Opponents might call it supermarket socialism. ``We call it casting an economic vote,'' said Leslie Gottlieb, representative of the Council on Economic Priorities, a 21-year-old nonprofit research organization and a proponent. ``In the '90s, people have a need to be empowered,'' she said. ``They want to know the policies behind the companies they support and invest in. We no longer want to be guided only by advertising slogan.'' Last year, the council published a booklet, ``Shopping for a Better World: A Quick & Easy Guide to Socially Responsible Supermarket Shopping,'' which rates companies and products on 10 criteria. The council took a chance and initially published 100,000 copies. The booklet is now in a mass market paperback published by Ballantine. Total sales have exceeded 699,000. Growth has been rapid, too, in investment funds that buy stocks only in firms that meet ``social responsibility'' criteria. The ``socially responsible'' investment funds of Calvert Group of the Washington suburb of Bethesda, Md., favor firms that avoid South Africa, Northern Ireland, nuclear power, weapons of mass destruction and animal testing; have progressive records on equal opportunity and promotion of women into the corporate boardroom; make safe, non polluting and recyclable products and use alternative fuel sources. ``It turns out that of the top 1,000 publicly traded companies, 60 percent pass our criteria,'' said Steve Schueth, Calvert vice president for socially responsible investing. John Schultz, president of the Social Investment Forum, a Minneapolis-based trade association, said the amount of money put in such ``screened'' investments went from $40 billion in 1984 to $500 billion this year. Schueth said the phenomena goes back to the 1920s, when church groups steered their investment money away from stocks in tobacco, alcohol or gambling firms. ``Socially responsible'' investing is much further advanced in Europe, where it is pushed by the ``green'' environmental movement. In America, ``it is growing, but it is still minuscule because 99 percent of all decisions are made on other grounds,'' said sociologist Amitai Etzioni of George Washington University, who has kept an eye on the phenomenon. ``It is still so small that statistics cannot put a handle on it,'' he said. ``I don't know if it is one-eight of 1 percent or one-eighth of one-eighth of 1 percent. ``It is essential to note that we are only talking about what business does at the margins,'' Etzioni added. ``No one in his right mind thinks that business should dedicate itself solely to doing good.'' Still, there's a philosophical argument against subjecting business decisions to a ``socially responsibility'' test. Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman, a well-known conservative, makes a distinction between how people spend and invest their own money and other people's money. With their own money, they can do what they like, he said; but if they spend or invest on behalf of others it is irresponsible to make the decision on criteria not specified by the money's owner _ usually to maximize profits or get the best buy. ``I doubt very much that much of the endowment of Harvard University, to take one example, was contributed by people who intended that Harvard should sacrifice income for some supposedly superior purpose,'' said Friedman. (Harvard may disagree. The university announced recently that it has weeded tobacco stocks from its endowment's portfolios.) Argued Friedman: ``The fundamental principle is very simple. Responsibility is individual and not social. The very concept of social responsibility is a snare and a delusion.'' As for whether the movement is a growing and permanent one, that depends. Said Schultz: ``If you make the decision that a corporate relationship to society is important, it is very difficult to unmake the decision.'' He said it was ``the kids at the school lunch counter'' who compelled the nation's major tuna canners to stop buying tuna that had been caught by methods that also kill dolphins. As adults, he said, those kids will continue to press for business decisions made with a social conscience. Said Friedman: ``If society continues moving in a socialist direction, then it will be a permanent part of the landscape. If we should move in the opposite direction, then it will not be a permanent part.'' So there's no telling if it will ever be easier to buy a can of beans.

DOC.HEAD: Rice Boom Brings Prosperity to Vietnamese Villages
DOC.TEXT: Dramatically larger crops have brought television and motorbikes to once-poor villages and turned a nation with chronic food shortages into the world's third-ranking rice exporter. Nature has been kind the past two years, but the engine for growth has been the Communist Party's retreat from the disaster of collective agriculture and adoption of free-market policies that gave farmers incentives. Vietnam's rice boom may be the biggest success story of the economic reforms many communist-ruled countries adopted in recent years. Industry and other sectors of the Vietnamese economy have fared poorly. Truong Cong Tin, deputy director of the government Institute of Agricultural Science of South Vietnam, said agriculture appears able to lift Vietnam's overall economic development. About 80 percent of the 65 million Vietnamese work on the land. Aid officials said the progress in traditionally impoverished villages of the north may help reduce the huge flow ``boat people'' out of the country. In 1988, the north imported 300,000 tons of rice and appealed for emergency foreign aid for provinces where millions of people were hungry because of devastating typhoons. Officials said some farmers had to eat their rice seed stocks. Now the north feeds itself for the first time in decades and last year even exported about 40,000 tons of rice, said Tran Bach Ngoc, an official of the state rice export company Vinafood. The south produced the rest of the record 1.4 million tons of rice exported. Officials said Vietnam had exported about 600,000 tons of rice in the first half of 1990 and the year's total might surpass 1989. They said improvements, such as replacing antiquated milling machines, could make Vietnam a threat to Thailand and the United States, the leading exporters. ``Before, we worked in the fields very regularly, sometimes eight hours a day, but we didn't work very hard,'' said Le Minh Re, 51, of Da Ton village on the outskirts of Hanoi, the national capital in the north. ``We did not get the amount of rice equal to the effort. Now if we work hard, we will have more rice and can use it for our own needs. Now even some city people rush here to rent out land from the cooperative to farm.'' Re is starting a lucrative silkworm industry and building a house for his son. Brick houses have replaced most thatched huts in Da Ton and a new school was built last year. Farmers who once took their goods to market on bicycles use Japanese-made motorcycles. One of every five families has television. ``Some bought black-and-white TVs and now they've changed to color,'' said the head of the cooperative, Le Van Bui. During the interview, he was distracted occasionally by the late-morning soap opera. Bui and other officials identified the key reform as Communist Party Resolution 10, adopted in April 1988 after several years of poor production. Resolution 10 gave farmers long-term leases on the land, encourageing them to enrich it. It also reduced the role of the cooperative so farmers would do most of the work individually, not as part of unmotivated work groups. Today, cooperatives like the one at Da Ton are involved in helping farmers get supplies and technical aid, not in actual production. Improving a system introduced in 1981, authorities also increased the amount of the crop farmers could sell on the free market, and low prices paid by the state were brought into line with the free market. Greater state investment and technical improvements increased production, particularly in the Mekong Delta of the south, where one of the world's great rivers nourishes verdant ricelands. Last year, the government provided irrigation for about 250,000 acres of rice paddies that had depended on rain, said Tin, of the research institute. He said that allowed two good crops a year instead of one, and with the addition of fertilizer, the farms switched to high-yield varieties that produce two or three times as much grain. To boost production further, he said, the government must increase support to farmers and attract foreign investment in agriculture. An immediate problem is a fertilizer shortage that Western businessmen said was hurting production. The Soviet Union has supplied 90 percent of Vietnam's needs under a barter contract that expires this year, but says future economic deals must be based on commercial merit, not the ``fraternal socialism'' of the past. Frictions could increase in the global rice trade. Vietnam, whose major customers include China, India and African countries, has penetrated traditional Thai markets with prices $30 to $40 a ton lower than Thailand's. After Thailand complained, the Vietnamese agreed to raise their prices.

DOC.HEAD: Taking On the Health-Care Challenge
DOC.TEXT: You can look at it as a problem to be solved, which is probably why it hasn't been, or you can view it as an opportunity. It is health care, and how it can be made affordable. Americans haven't dealt well with the issue in the past. They have even tried to ignore it, but it won't be ignored. They have attempted to make it somebody's else's responsibility, but by its nature it is very personal. The issue seldom has been faced head-on. Individuals attempt to pass responsibility to insurers, government and business. Government fears the responsiblity, and so does business, and the two have bucked the issue back and forth for decades. None has managed to keep the costs down _ not the individual, not the insurer, not the government, not the provider _ and so those costs rise every year at a rate that exceeds the consumer price index. Last year, health care costs jumped 8.5 percent, nearly double the general rate of inflation. You can look back 20 years or so, and month by month the story is almost always the same: The rise in health care costs leads the list. In a sense, the issue _ on the critical list for decades _ now is becoming grave. It is eating up the gross national product; it accounts for 12 percent now, and seems headed for 15 percent, maybe by the year 2000. U.S. per capita spending on health care is double that of Germany or France. Last year, says consultant Foster Higgins & Co., the bill for employer-sponsored medical plans jumped 20 percent to $2,600 per employee. The future holds this: a growing bill for AIDS, and a population that not only is growing older but living longer. By the turn of the century about 13 percent of the American population will be over age 65. The picture just described is gloomy. Almost always it has been portrayed that way, and there has been a very un-American tendency to be routed by the facts and, it must be conceded, even to lie down in defeat. Gradually, however, more American business people are viewing the situation as one ripe for innovative approaches. Where such a challenge exists, they reason, there must be opportunity too. Here are some of the ways: _Hospital management companies. These were the first businesses to accept the challenge, and some have demonstrated they can provide good health care and make a profit. Now, some see the gravity of the health care situation as offering a new opportunity, especially in acute care facilities. _Health education programs. They are becoming more vital to corporate plans, putting the emphasis on prevention. The cost of prevention, business now recognizes, is a small fraction of the cost of correction. _Incentive programs, such as that developed at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital by Dr. Douglas Ratner, to encourage better living habits and thus avoid costly treatments when health deteriorates. His program, Wealth From Health, offers cash benefits to workers who take responsibility for maintaining their health through sensible living styles. The program is now under consideration by corporations. _Free-standing surgery centers. They specialize in surgical procedures rather than treating a full range of medical problems. Limited in scope, they are proving to be efficient medically and financially. _Rehabilitation centers. Why maintain patients in fully equipped hospitals when they don't need such services? Companies specializing in rehabilitation have shown they can help patients, and make a business profit doing so. _Home health care. Some of the fastest growing young companies are in this field. In a sense, they bring the hospital _ a very stripped down version _ right to the patient's home.

DOC.HEAD: Early Evening With a ``Scuff'' Called Duvall
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In auto racing, a ``scuff'' means a tire that's been around the track a couple of times, that's got a few bumps and bruises. A new tire is too slick, drivers say, and needs a lap or two to ``scuff'' it in. In acting, there are scuffs as well. One might be defined as a straight-talking Academy Award winner who wants directors to leave him alone, will turn down a part if the money's not right and has little use for the old Hollywood movies. Someone, perhaps, like Robert Duvall. ``Some actors like to talk a lot, and I don't particularly like to talk a lot,'' Duvall says, leaning forward, coming down hard on the word ``like.'' ``You just go out and do it. Sometimes you should film rehearsals, there's something in rehearsals that's lost in film.'' Duvall will tell you he didn't care about auto racing before making ``Days of Thunder'' and doesn't care about it now. He also didn't spend much time talking to star Tom Cruise (though he respects the young actor), and would have preferred a less elaborate production, one that didn't have ``15 chiefs putting in their opinions.'' But the actor did enjoy hanging out with race car builders while doing location work in the Carolinas, part of the research that went into his role as crew chief and mentor to Cruise, a flashy, hot-tempered driver. ``When the guy comes with the blueprints from Detroit, these guys don't need blueprints,'' Duvall said in an interview at his apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side. ``They just do it off the top of their heads. They're sleepers, in a way. There are some pretty bright guys out there, and sometimes you count them out. ``Guys like that are off-the-cuff guys. An awful lot of knowledge is given off the cuff. These guys are a reservoir of information.'' Duvall has always prided himself on being that kind of actor, getting inside his characters without worrying about motivation or the Method or any other fancy technique. In ``Days of Thunder,'' he plays Harry Hogge, a tight-lipped kind of guy, a philosopher tucked under a race cap muttering wisdom about brakes and tires, talking like a man who's answering questions asked long ago. Check out Duvall's apartment and you'll think a lot about history. The outside is unimpressive, a modest-looking brownstone notable only for a long, gray awning; it's the kind of building you walk right by. But inside, the ceilings are over 20 feet high, and the walls are covered with tapestries, books and country music tapes. The building dates back to the turn of the century, and the great tenor Enrico Caruso once lived in his apartment. On the mantelpiece sits the Oscar he won as country singer Mac Sledge in ``Tender Mercies.'' Family pictures are propped up on the piano and sketches of tango dancers _ the profession of Duvall's fiancee _ hang throughout. ``By the time the shade had reached the river, Augustus would have mellowed,'' Larry McMurtry wrote in the novel ``Lonesome Dove,'' describing the ex-Texas Ranger played by Duvall last year in the acclaimed television adaptation. It's early evening, and Duvall, dressed in a striped polo shirt and slacks, mellows as he talks about his long career; all else is quiet except for an antique French clock that chimes gently in the background. ``Way back when I was in college,'' recalls Duvall, born in 1931, ``there was a wonderful man named Frank Parker, who had been a dancer in World War I. We did a full-length mime play and I played a Harlequin clown. I really liked that. ``Then, I played an older guy in `All My Sons,' and at one point I had this emotional moment, where this emotion was pouring out. Parker said at that moment he didn't think acting can be carried any further than that. And this guy was a very critical guy. So I thought, at that moment at least, this is what I wanted to do.'' He appeared on stage in New York in the late 1950s and broke into film in 1962 as Boo Radley in ``To Kill a Mockingbird.'' He's since played scuffs in uniform (``The Great Santini,'' ``Apocalypse Now,''), scuffs in cowboy hats (``Tender Mercies,'' ``True Grit'') and scuffs in suits (``The Godfather,'' ``Network''). Duvall won the best actor Oscar in 1983 for ``Tender Mercies.'' He's received Academy Award nominations for best actor in 1980 for ``The Great Santini,'' and for best supporting actor in 1972 for ``The Godfather'' and ``Apocalypse Now'' in 1979. He considered appearing in ``The Godfather III,'' scheduled for release in November, but said he couldn't agree on salary. ``I've lost projects I really liked, and then 24 hours later ...,'' he said, pausing, marking off the time with two quick handslaps, ``I've forgotten all about it.Sometimes just the will to do it is the hardest part. I lose something, so what? No big deal.'' It's an unromantic view, similar to the thinking of playwright Horton Foote, who won Oscars for the screenplays of ``Tender Mercies,'' and ``To Kill a Mockingbird,'' and wrote the upcoming Duvall film, ``Convicts.'' ``My first memory was of stories about the past,'' Foote once observed. ``A past that, according to the storytellers, was superior to the life then being lived. ``It didn't take me long, however, to understand that the present was all we had, for the past was gone and nothing could be done about it.'' ``You go to old movies,'' Duvall said, ``and you see crappy acting, except for a handful like Spencer Tracy. `Gone With the Wind' is a travesty. That's one of the worst movies I ever saw in my life. I can go see a student film better than that one. ``I've got a quarter of my career left and I got a lot of stuff I want to do. When I was doing `Colors' in 1988 with Sean Penn, someone asked me how I do it all these years, keep it fresh. Well, if you don't overwork, have some hobbies, you can do it and stay hungry even if you're not really hungry.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thursday AMs, July 12

DOC.HEAD: 300-Year-Old Battle Still a Current Event in Ulster
DOC.TEXT: Three centuries on, the Battle of the Boyne still counts as a current event in Northern Ireland. Every 12th of July finds hundreds of flute and drum bands out on the streets of villages and towns, rattling windows with thunderous lambeg drums and tootling stirring ditties that cast the Battle of the Boyne as a Protestant triumph over a Roman Catholic despot. Stern men in dark suits and bowler hats, black umbrellas tightly furled, march in the orange sashes of the Loyal Orange Institution. Banners salute King William III, ``King Billy,'' the victor at the River Boyne. ``Your Fourth of July, your Declaration of Independence, is seen by Americans as the point in history where they secured their freedom, secured their liberty as individuals from an oppressive, tyrannical power,'' said Ronnie Hanna, general manager of the Ulster Society. ``We would see 12th of July in similar terms.'' ``If you were an Englishman ... you might say this is a kind of bizarre continuation of a religious controversy,'' said A.T.Q. Stewart, a professor of history at Queen's University in Belfast. In fact, Stewart said, ``it is about a problem that exists now.'' That problem, which underlies 21 years of violence and nearly 2,800 deaths, is a population divided between 1 million Protestants loyal to British rule and 600,000 Roman Catholics who identify with Ireland. The parades combine history and current events. As they have every year since 1985, Orangemen will reaffirm their opposition to the Anglo-Irish Agreement, which gave the Irish government a say in the province's affairs. The 12th is a public holiday in Northern Ireland, but not a mandatory one. It is a Protestant holiday, honoring a Protestant king. ``The Sash My Father Wore,'' one of the most popular of the Orange marching songs, says the winners at the Boyne fought to maintain ``our unity, religion, laws and freedom.'' An exhibition at the Ulster Museum, however, stresses that the battle was an episode in a larger European struggle against King Louis XIV of France. ``None of the kings in conflict cared particularly about Ireland and the Irish,'' says a panel at the exhibit. ``James came to Ireland solely to recover his English throne, William solely to defeat James.'' James II, a convert to Roman Catholicism, was removed from the English throne in the ``glorious revolution'' of 1688. His daughter Mary and son-in-law, William of Orange, were invited to rule. With backing from Louis XIV, James tried to make a comeback through Ireland. On July 1 (July 12 on the modern calendar), William commanded Dutchmen, Danes, French Huguenots, English, Germans and northern Irish Protestants. The forces James led were from France, Germany, England and Ireland. James made his stand at the Boyne, the last physical obstacle between William's army and Dublin. William had superior numbers and proved to be the superior tactician. ``Inevitably, it was all far more complicated than the traditional symbols, even to the point that there were people from the same families on different sides,'' said William Maguire, curator of the Ulster Museum exhibition. Indeed, Pope Innocent XI sided not with the Catholic Louis, but with King William. The Protestant king's men wore sprigs of green, a color now always identified with Ireland and opposed to the orange. ``What often strikes me as a historian is that everybody knows today that what's happening is immensely complicated, and everyday life is immensely complicated, and yet you are somehow expecting a simple version of the past and are content with it, as if the past never was real life,'' Maguire said. James fled Ireland after the battle, although his forces were not finally defeated until the battle at Aughrim in western Ireland in 1691. ``The Irish attached a rude name to James, called him James the s---,'' Maguire said. ``That's his popular Irish title, and James went off blaming the Irish for letting him down, quite unjustly.'' The Orangemen, with their banners showing King Billy astride a pawing white horse, often have cast the battle on religious lines. The old marching song ``Protestant Boys'' recalls ``when James, half a bigot and more of a knave, with masses and Frenchmen the land would enslave.'' Catholic nationalists and Protestant unionists agree on what William represents. In the 1920s, Irish rebels attacked the statue of William in Dublin, even to the extent of trucking it to a junkyard and lopping off its head. The Boyne Valley is in Ireland, halfway between Dublin and the border with Northern Ireland. The Orange Order's hopes for a big 300th anniversary ceremony on the battlefield were dropped because of strenuous opposition. Although the songs sometimes give the impression the Orange Order fought at the Boyne, it was founded in 1795 after a skirmish between Protestants and Catholics in County Armagh. In his book ``The Narrow Ground,'' Stewart notes that Orange parades were blamed for half a dozen riots in Belfast between 1813 and 1914. It was a Protestant parade that led to street battles in Londonderry in 1969 that drew the British army into Northern Ireland and revived the Irish Republican Army's armed campaign against British rule. ``The provocation alleged by Catholics may arise simply from the fact that Orangeism is a symbol of something intensely hated; or from the display of party colors and playing of party tunes, or from that most menacing of sounds, even to Protestant ears, the thunder of Orange drums,'' Stewart wrote. For unionists, history is a 17th century drama of peril, resistance and triumph. The threat came in 1641, when the Irish rebelled and murdered Protestant colonists; resistance in 1688, when the apprentice boys slammed the gates of Derry against James; victory in 1690. ``You have to remember that 1641 was within living memory for most people in the 1690s,'' Hanna said. ``This is why people rushed to Londonderry in 1688, 1689, because they thought it was a rerun of 1641.'' ``It has often been said that we have a siege mentality,'' said George Patton, executive officer of the Orange Order's Grand Lodge in Belfast. ``I'm not sure whether it's a mental state, or an actual thing. We've been under attack almost continuously. We're still under siege to a degree. Today, it's the IRA murdering our people.'' Patton said the three Orange lodges will be out marching early in his village of Scarva, population 400, then travel to Tandragee for the district parade with 18 other lodges, then join a countywide parade. On the 13th, Scarva is overrun with 50,000 people or more for the annual ``sham fight,'' a half-hour Battle of the Boyne with wooden swords. The Orange Order has about 100,000 members, including most of Northern Ireland's leading Protestant politicians, and is a potent force in the province. ``It's due to the Orange Order largely that the Battle of the Boyne has been singled as being the crucial thing,'' Maguire said. ``The Battle of Aughrim was a far greater battle, far more decisive, far more bloody. But of course, from a public relations point of view it was far less interesting. There were no kings there.''

DOC.HEAD: Ireland Says `No Thanks' to Orange Invasion
With AM-Battle of the Boyne
DOC.TEXT: Frank Godfrey thinks the Battle of the Boyne is part of Ireland's common heritage, north and south. Michael Bell says the battle ``symbolizes everything that's rotten in Ireland.'' Bell's view prevailed when people living near the mouth of the River Boyne contemplated the prospect of thousands of members of the Loyal Orange Institution coming to commemorate the battle. ``It would lead to possible injury, confrontation and loss of life,'' said Bell, the local member of Parliament. He estimates security would have cost 500,000 Irish pounds ($800,000). ``We didn't have anything to celebrate,'' he said. ``We lost the battle. If people wanted to celebrate something that is effectively a symbol of the divisions in our country, I didn't think we should be part of that.'' ``My answer to that is that we didn't lose the Battle of the Boyne; we lost nothing, in fact,'' said Godfrey, a member of the local council who lives outside Drogheda in a thatched farm house identified in big painted letters as ``Boyne Cottage.'' ``The battle of the Boyne was fought between two foreign monarchs, King William of Orange, a Dutchman, and King James II, an Englishman,'' he said. ``The battle could have been anywhere in Europe, and it was fortunate that it was here. ... It's part and parcel now of our history and our common heritage.'' George Patton, executive officer of the Orange Order's Grand Lodge in Belfast, said landowners at the battle site asked as much as 50,000 pounds ($80,000) to rent a field for the day and the order couldn't buy adequate insurance. ``Oh, there was a lot of hostility toward it, yes,'' he said. ``There were statements made by elected representatives, and if I had said a similar thing about nationalists or Catholics in Belfast, I would be in the Crumlin Road (prison) for incitement to hatred.'' An unscientific telephone survey by The Drogheda Independent found most of those responding opposed to an Orange celebration, editor Paul Murphy said, but added: ``If I had to judge it, I would say the people of Drogheda are largely indifferent.'' Murphy said there had been more controversy over the opening of Irish Cement's new shale quarry near Godfrey's cottage in Donore. Local opponents of the quarry have the vocal support of Northern Ireland Protestants, who resent the desecration of the battlefield. Unlike Britain, Ireland issued a postage stamp commemorating the battle. Drogheda's civic fathers loaned their mace and sword, given to the town by William III, to the Ulster Museum in Belfast for its exhibition. The Irish government declares its door open to Northern Ireland's Protestants, but Godfrey said: ``When they came knocking and said they want to come down and have a religious service on the site of the Battle of the Boyne ... the government practically ignored the plea.'' Bell said: ``Thirty thousand Orangemen. We need that like we need a hole in the head.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, July 11

DOC.HEAD: `The Sash My Father Wore' Is Orange Hit
With AM-Battle of the Boyne
DOC.TEXT:
There will be many tunes at 12th of July parades in Northern Ireland, but one likely to be heard everywhere is ``The Sash My Father Wore.'' Although the Orange Order was founded nearly a century after the Battle of the Boyne, the song connects its traditional orange sash with the victory of King William III in 1690 and the battles at Derry, Aughrim and Enniskillen:
Sure I'm an Ulster Orangeman, from Erin's Isle I came, To see my British brethren all of honor and of fame. And to tell them of my forefathers who fought in days of yore, That I might have the right to wear, the sash my father wore!
Chorus: It is old but it is beautiful, and its colors they are fine. It was worn at Derry, Aughrim, Enniskillen and the Boyne. My father wore it as a youth in bygone days of yore, And on the Twelfth I love to wear the sash my father wore.
For those brave men who crossed the Boyne have not fought or died in vain, Our unity, religion, laws, and freedom to maintain. If the call should come we'll follow the drum, and cross that river once more, That tomorrow's Ulsterman may wear the sash my father wore!
Chorus.
And when some day, across the sea to Antrim's shore you come, We'll welcome you in royal style, to the sound of flute and drum, And Ulster's hills shall echo still, from Rathlin to Dromore, As we sing again the loyal strain of the sash my father wore!
Chorus.

DOC.HEAD: Private Armies Control Much of Central Colombia
DOC.TEXT: An alliance of private armies apparently financed by drug traffickers has taken over this tropical town and much of central Colombia. After driving out leftist guerrillas, the vigilantes also evicted beggars and prostitutes and opened dozens of schools. ``Welcome to Puerto Boyaca, the anti-subversive capital of Colombia,'' says a sign at the town's entrance. The private armies have become a dreaded part of Colombia's violent society, and the government says they have turned into right-wing death squads. Ranchers organized them, with the army's blessing, about 10 years ago to fight guerrillas who were extorting money as a ``revolution tax.'' If the money was not paid, guerrillas would kidnap ranchers, burn down their buildings and rustle their cattle. Drug traffickers got into the act when the ranchers ran short of money and weapons, says a report by Colombia's secret police that was seen by The Associated Press. Death squads began roaming the region, and the army has been either unable or unwilling to stop massacres of peasants. Vigilantes surrounded houses of suspected leftists, called the inhabitants out and shot then down. In Segovia, a central Colombian town with a leftist mayor, gunmen drove through the streets and shot 43 people to death. Cocaine barons were glad to help the vigilante operation because leftist guerrillas had kidnapped several members of their families for ransom and the traffickers had bought hundreds of thousands of acres in the region as investments. With the guerrillas gone, the private armies have offered to lay down their arms if a deal can be struck with the government. At the end of June, Interior Minister Horacio Serpa said the government was willing to take action leading to conditional amnesty for such minor offenses as illegal posession of weapons, but not for murder. Ivan Duque, spokesman for the armed groups, said Serpa's statement was vague and ``does not offer any guarantee to farmers and ranchers that they will be protected against guerrillas.'' A prominent human rights activist said of the ranchers: ``They have set up a mini fascist state right in the middle of Colombia.'' He asked that his name be withheld because of a recent attempt on his life. Puerto Boyaca is a rough town of dirt streets lined with concrete buildings. Hard-looking men in cowboy boots and Panama hats hang out at the pool hall, some wearing mirrored sunglasses, open shirts and gold chains. Parked outside are Ford Broncos and Chevy Blazers, status symbols of underlings in the cocaine traffic. The town is about midway on the Magdalena River, which runs almost the length of Colombia and empties into the Caribbean. The private armies control the Magdalena Medio, a surrounding region that covers much of central Colombia. In the past decade, tens of thousands of Colombians have been killed by drug traffickers, leftist guerrillas and right-wing paramilitary groups. ``The self-defense groups managed to ... create this climate of peace you see here in Puerto Boyaca,'' Duque said. The vigilante spokesman recently was elected an alternate federal senator. Peace does reign in the town, but critics say that's because all opposition has been silenced. Local politics and the press are controlled by the Association of Cattle Ranchers and Farmers of Magdalena Medio, known by its Spanish acronym Acdegam. Members say the association provides vital services neglected by the central government. It runs 33 schools and a pharmacy, and even offers classes in dance and painting. The building Acdegam occupies is painted pink. Plastic flowers adorn the halls and desks. Human rights groups say the organization is a front for death squads. ``Paramilitary groups from Magdalena Medio have ordered the massacre of many innocent peasants,'' said the activist who spoke with an AP reporter. Duque and the mayor of Puerto Boyaca, Gustavo Londono, described allegations of atrocities as a plot by leftistss to discredit honest ranchers and farmers. ``We are not drug traffickers, murderers or robbers,'' Londono said. People who live in Magdalena Medio were subjected first to extortion, kidnappings and murder by leftist rebels, then to the right-wing vigilantes who replaced them. ``How can anyone speak out against what's going on here?'' said a 23-year-old woman sitting with her baby in Puerto Boyaca's park. ``They control everything.'' According to the police report, ``the economic crisis confronting the self-defense groups was resolved through an alliance with drug trafficking'' in 1985. In return for money, the private armies helped process and smuggle cocaine and killed opponents of drug trafficking, it said. No one, including the government, denies that elements of the Colombian army initially armed and trained vigilante groups. ``It was the government which created them by decree, armed them, and trained them, but when convenient, the government washes its hands of everything.'' Duque said. The report by the secret police implicated the armed groups in a 1988 massacre of 20 peasants in northern Colombia and other atrocities. It said they were involved in many of the 1,000 murders since 1985 of members of the left-wing Patriotic Union Party. Magdalena Medio's private armies have close ties to armed right-wing groups elsewhere in Colombia, the report said. The government has accused Henry Perez, reputed leader of the private armies, and Luis Rubio, former mayor of Puerto Boyaca, of ordering massacres of peasants. Both are at large. A judge who issued arrest warrants for them has been murdered. Duque, who leads peace negotiations with the government, said the private armies are fed up with violence and want to emulate guerrilla groups that have laid down their arms or are in the process of doing so. ``The greatest danger in Colombia is being alive,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Environmental Group Changes Tactics But Not Its Goals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Monday reference in 6th graf
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Perched high in a redwood tree, his head fixed squarely in the rifle-sight of a policeman below, Earth First! activist Dan Johnson watched as a logger climbed toward him. Then a strange thing happened. The logger stopped a few feet below Johnson and the two began to talk, about trees and jobs and spotted owls. ``Of course, I saw a lot of holes in his arguments, but he probably saw a lot in mine, too,'' Johnson recalled. ``We had a really good talk, up there in the tree.'' Talking? It's new ground for Earth First!, whose militant approach to defending nature has angered authorities and embarrassed mainstream environmentalists for 10 years. Earth First! has put on a kinder, gentler face for ``Redwood Summer,'' its campaign to halt logging in California's last unprotected groves of ancient redwoods. Pounding spikes into trees to make logging hazardous is out. Climbing trees, and refusing to leave when lumberjacks arrive, is in. As Earth Firsters nationwide gather for a camp-out starting Monday at Montana's Beaverhead National Forest, organizers from California see the nonviolent approach as a way of widening their group's appeal. They hope to attract activists from around the nation and convince local timber workers that Earth First! targets corporate bosses, not the rank-and-file. But the change is more than just tactical. Stung by FBI investigations, death threats and a car bombing in May that injured two activists, many Earth Firsters are running scared of the violence stirred up by their own burn-the-bulldozers brand of rhetoric. Any softening is relative, of course. Earth First! still ranks as perhaps the nation's most extreme environmental group, with a famous contempt for authority and a prickly adherence to its credo, ``No compromise in the defense of Mother Earth.'' The group's founding in 1980 was inspired by the late Edward Abbey's novel ``The Monkey Wrench Gang,'' which romanticized environmentalists who destroyed billboards and bulldozers while plotting to blow up Arizona's Glen Canyon Dam. In 1981, Earth First! activists draped a 300-foot banner, painted to resemble a crack, over the dam. In 1983, co-founder Dave Foreman was dragged 100 yards by an Oregon logger's truck when he lay down in front of it. More recently, Earth Firsters have chained themselves to tree-crushing machines in Texas, blocked logging roads in Washington, and occupied road-building equipment in Arizona. This summer in Northern California, more than 50 have been arrested for sitting in trees, blockading sawmills and picketing government offices to protest the cutting of old-growth redwoods. Such acts of civil disobedience are the public side of Earth First! But police believe the group is more destructive when nobody's looking. Last year in Arizona, an 18-month FBI investigation ended with the arrests of three Earth First! activists who allegedly cut through the leg of an electric transmission tower. The FBI claimed they were practicing for an assault against nuclear facilities in California and Colorado. Foreman also was arrested, on charges that he helped plan the scheme. All four have denied the charges; Foreman faces trial in September. Earth First! leaders insist the group does not condone property destruction. ``It's not Earth Firsters who monkey-wrench. It's individuals,'' said Darryl Cherney, one of the two activists injured May 24 in Oakland when a pipe bomb exploded in the back seat of their car. Cherney, 33, suffered a cut over one eye. Judi Bari, 40, suffered a broken pelvis and is still hospitalized. Immediately after the explosion, authorities portrayed Cherney and Bari as inept bomb-makers transporting the device for some terrorist purpose. But charges have yet to be filed against the pair, and they insist they were victims, not perpetrators, of the blast. Cherney said he and Bari had received more than 30 death threats since announcing plans for Redwood Summer in March. One letter, from ``The Stompers,'' claimed to be from disgruntled timber workers. It warned: ``If you want to be a martyr, we will be happy to oblige.'' Authorities said they are investigating all angles. ``We haven't ruled out the possibility that they might have been targets of the device rather than transporters,'' said FBI spokesman Duke Diedrich. But Earth First! doesn't trust the FBI. Foreman claims the bureau wants to discredit Earth First! He has obtained FBI wiretap transcripts in which an undercover agent tells other agents that Foreman's arrest would ``send a message'' to radical environmentalists. ``That's all we're really doing,'' the agent said, then noticed his microphone was on and added, ``We don't need that on tape. Hoo boy.'' The FBI probe compounds problems Earth First! has brought on itself. Once just a handful of self-described ``rednecks for wilderness,'' the group now claims about 5,000 activists in dozens of chapters nationwide. There are no membership requirements, no central control _ and sometimes it seems as if there's no control at all. Redwood Summer organizers have recruited protestors from around the nation. The result has been an ideological stew of hippies, anarchists and pagans, to name a few, all marching under the Earth First! banner. ``We used to be a small, autonomous group,'' said Mickey Dulas, a California Earth Firster since 1987. ``Now there are people arriving every day. We don't know their tolerance for violence. We don't know if they're narcs.'' One previously high-profile California activist is in hiding, reportedly fearful of death threats and FBI infiltrators. And Foreman won't attend this week's national gathering. ``I think the law enforcement agencies are going to disrupt things,'' he said. Paranoia has infected the movement. ``Unfortunately, along with our many battles for wilderness, we must now also wage a battle of self-preservation,'' editor John Davis wrote in the latest issue of the Earth First! Journal, the group's newsletter. But Davis is confident the cause will prevail. ``Earth First! has prospered through the years,'' he wrote, ``largely because we are too disorganized to squelch.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Battle Radical Environmentalists for Public Sympathy
With AM-Earth First
DOC.TEXT: Loggers, miners and ranchers burned by monkey-wrenching ``eco-warriors'' no longer have to suffer silently. They can call 1-303-TESTIFY. The hot line _ the letters stand for ``Tell of Environmental Sabotage and Terrorism Interfering with Freedom '' _ is run by the Mountain States Legal Foundation, a conservative law firm that believes the news media have glamorized the bulldozer-burning, tree-spiking exploits of radical environmentalists such as the Earth First! group. ``They all treat these people as some modern-day Robin Hoods whose concern is not the poor of the forest, but the trees. And I think that's a terrible disservice to the American people,'' said foundation president William Perry Pendley. Pendley's mission: to rally those who believe in multiple use of the nation's public lands and galvanize public opinion against environmentalists who would ``lock up'' those lands for wildlife. The Denver-based legal foundation carries on work begun in 1978 by its first chief legal officer, James Watt, who later rose to the top of environmentalist hate-lists as President Reagan's interior secretary. Watt no longer is with the foundation, but its work continues, funded by individuals, timber and ranching groups, and corporations. Pendley said he favors a thriving environment with lush forests, sparkling streams and fresh air. But he also values the logging, mining and grazing that help feed, clothe and shelter Americans. ``Our belief is ... we can protect the environment and still have respect for property rights, and still have an economic system,'' Pendley said. That message is no easy sell, he said. It must compete with the cuddly critters inevitably featured on posters urging people to ``Protect Wildlife.'' ``Being an environmentalist is a feel-good thing. It doesn't ask you to make any hard decisions whatsoever. It just says `feel good, care, like animals,' '' he said. ``What can I put up (on posters) _ `Cut Trees?' `Produce Income?' `Graze Cattle?' `Mine For Ore?' It's not feel-good.'' Instead, Pendley hits the road. He regales sympathetic industry groups and trade associations with horror stories gleaned from newspapers and from the several calls that come in each month to the hot line. He tells of 18-inch spikes driven into trees to spoil them for logging, of cattle killed on public land, of tiny spikes scattered on the ground to puncture trail-bike tires. Records of the hot line calls are filed away; eventually, Pendley's group hopes to collect enough evidence to file a suit against the environmentalists. ``I frankly think that a lot of these people, a lot of the environmental terrorists, are just thugs that get off on violence, that enjoy vandalism, that enjoy sabotage,'' Pendley said. ``And they say, `Hey, we're doing this for the environment, so it's OK.' '' Pendley has little chance of swaying unrepentant Earth First! activists, who call his hot line with news of what they consider real vandalism: federally approved timber sales, drilling and road projects. But he hopes for better luck in appealing to the public. ``We have the working men and women of this country who believe in what we believe in,'' he said. ``When they are put at risk, in a situation when they are threatened with the loss of their livelihoods and futures, then they become energized and activated.''

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Students Demand Better University Conditions
DOC.TEXT: It's not grades and social events that preoccupy science students at Ho Chi Minh University, but crumbling buildings, primitive equipment, tattered books and crowded dorms. In a decrepit building that wasn't new in French colonial days a half century ago, a stairway reeked with the stench of a toilet. In the physics lab, students used equipment that belonged in a museum. The newest book in the dusty chemistry library was published in 1974. Students said those who had to live on campus were packed seven or eight to rooms about 14 feet square that had one table, a single light bulb and only intermittent electricity. Medical students said they didn't get enough to eat. ``That's why we are so skinny,'' said Tran Thanh Cuong, 27. For the past two years, Vietnamese students have been increasingly vocal in demanding better conditions and even got the Marxist curriculum revised. Sources said the authorities have yielded in hopes of avoiding the kind of student protests that challenged the Chinese regime last year, helped bring down Communist governments in Eastern Europe and cause street battles with police in South Korea. Although the leadership may fear it, students in Vietnam don't appear ready to demonstrate for democracy. Vietnamese and Western sources say there have been no major demonstrations since the war ended in April 1975. No students have been detained for political activity, but any who advocated overthrowing the Communist Party would be arrested, said Do Van Chung, head of the Education Ministry's department of student enrollment and management. ``I'm sure some students think they can follow the example of the Chinese students, but we haven't seen it openly expressed,'' he said. A Westerner said he heard many people question Communist rule during his year at a Vietnamese university, but never a student. ``I ask them and they say, `Here, we are concentrating on money for food','' the Westerner said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Chung said students are ``the central issue in all the universities and colleges'' and teachers must meet them often to hear complaints. He said this was part of the government's 3{-year-old reform program, not a reaction to events abroad. Last year, the government doubled the stipend given each student, which still equals less than $6 a month, and said admission to universities would depend on examinations, not family connections. The first privately financed university, Thang Long, has opened in Hanoi, the capital. In 1988, several hundred students in Ho Chi Minh University's economics school got the more dogmatic Marxist tenets deleted from the curriculum and study of free markets included. They made their demand in a rare teach-in, said Nguyen Cong Khe, an editor of the Weekly Review of Youth magazine, which joined other publications in supporting the students. Most of the complaining is in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, capital of South Vietnam, but grumblings also have increased in the north, which has been under Communist authority since 1954. Hanoi University's rector, Nguyen An, said the school responded to complaints last year by renovating the cafeteria and dormitories, but the students ``are far from satisfied; their demands are always increasing.'' Chung said 165 students at Hanoi's Transportation College boycotted a meal last year to protest bad rice. He said the government ordered the rice replaced, criticized the rector and fired the cafeteria manager. Many students interviewed said they feared unemployment after graduation and Chung said the government was reducing the number of student places in the universities because of the bleak job situation. Vietnam, with a population of 65 million, has only about 120,000 full-time students at its 98 colleges and universities. A Western source said Vietnamese students, unlike those in China, had little sense of collective interest and no tradition of protest. Most are from the conservative countryside, and few Vietnamese have studied in the West since 1975. Clearly there are anger and frustration of the kind that, in Burma in 1988, turned scattered fights and economic protests into a nationwide uprising against the government. Several weeks ago, some Vietnamese and Cambodian students at Ho Chi Minh University were injured in a fight over the theft of a motorbike. Late in 1989, a group of students vandalized the Ky Hoa amusement park in Ho Chi Minh City after a drunken quarrel with a guard there, said Nguyen Thi Ngoc Phuong, a teacher at the university. In another incident last year, university students beat up two security men after arguing over a bicycle collision and authorities jailed the men briefly to placate the students, Ms. Phuong said. In both cases, she said, the students shouted for ``more democracy,'' but meant the freedom to do as they pleased.
