DOC.HEAD: Preservationists Wage Battle To Forestall History's Erosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Merrily is cq in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: The pamphlet had been buried in a time capsule for more than a century, its authors long dead. And by the time it reached Sherelyn Ogden, the words within had been lost to the ravages of acid and time. ``I unwrapped it, and it was a little heap of crumbs, just a heap of crumbs,'' she said. ``There was just no way of telling what anything was.'' Ogden is a document preservationist, but this pamphlet _ printed on the acidic paper that came into vogue after the Industrial Revolution _ was beyond preservation. It was a casualty of the war being waged to halt the disintegration of our nation's history before it all turns to dust. ``It's very urgent,'' said Merrily Smith, a preservationist at the Library of Congress. ``Almost all of the books that were produced after 1850 had a lot of acid in them. There's huge numbers of brittle material. ``And if the movement towards embrittlement can't be stopped, then we're looking at a tremendous loss of scholarship,'' she said. The problem dates to the middle of the 18th century, when demand for paper exploded. Manufacturers abandoned the traditional cotton and linen rags from which they made paper for cheaper, more available wood pulp. To keep ink from spreading over this low-quality paper, the manufacturers added aluminum sulphate and alum-rosin, chemicals that cause paper to become increasingly acidic and brittle over time. While Europe also is affected, the situation is considered critical in the United States, due to the relative youth of the nation's paper record. Today, an estimated 77 million books in American research libraries are dying. The New York Public Library has said 70 percent of the books printed in this century will be unusable by the year 2000. Some 3.25 million volumes in the Library of Congress alone are considered too brittle to be subjected to normal handling, Smith said. Staff members at the Northeast Document Conservation Center, the nation's largest, are working to preserve some of the best of America's past. In addition to classic volumes of writing, the center has rescued original drawings by Frank Lloyd Wright, Benedict Arnold's oath of loyalty to the United States and John F. Kennedy's fourth-grade report card. The pace at the Northeast Center in Andover does not seem frantic; staff members sit on high stools under warm and bright lights, their heads bent as they touch cracked and stained pages. Some, wearing white aprons, poke at paper floating in the large shallow baths that take up much of the room. On a recent day, the book bindery was still, but for the small gestures of a single staff member peering at shreds of paper _ some no bigger than a fingernail _ strewn about a large easel. Ann Russell, the center's executive director, agrees that the task of stalling the erosion of millions of books is no less than an emergency. Every day is another book too brittle to be read, an ineradicable stain on an Ansel Adams original print, a piece of history gone. ``Some of the kinds of materials we work on, like nitrate photographic negatives, some of our clients are monitoring their collections and every month they can say how many more of them have faded,'' Russell said. ``They're just watching their images disappear.'' The cost of the conservation war will be dear, in part because of its labor-intensive nature. At the center, workers peel away damaging adhesives, remove the books from their bindings and wash paper in a buffer solution. They add new backings of Japanese paper, which is strong, translucent and acid-free. They touch up photographs and rebind books in leather with tones painstakingly matched to the original. They keep a written record of all that they do. In one case, the patient was a huge map of Europe used in the field by General John J. Pershing in World War I, with 1,200 tiny pins to mark troop movements and color codes signifying each unit's strength. Staff members picked off the pins, recorded their locations and the colors underneath, treated the map and returned each pin to its spot. The project, commissioned by the West Point museum, took two months. The Committee for Preservation and Access reported a typical large university research library would spend $240 million over 20 years to maintain and microfilm its holdings. Books can sometimes cost $1,000 and up to salvage, said Ogden. The Massachusetts town of Marblehead paid $150,000 for the center to preserve handpainted wallpaper hanging in a historic mansion. In addition to having their collections restored book by book, institutions also may use mass deacidification processes, which employ chemical solvents and do not involve taking apart the book. These methods are much cheaper, averaging between $5 and $10 a volume, Smith said. Libraries also are putting parts of their collections on microfilm, which can cost about $50 per volume, Smith said. A concerted effort to identify the nation's most complete collections and microfilm them is under way, led by the National Endowment for the Humanities, Russell said. Hope for the future, however, experts agree, lies not only in a mad scramble to hold on to what's been written. Today's books must be printed on acid-free, or alkaline, paper, preservationists say. Paper manufacturers are beginning to listen, Russell said. ``It's finally starting to happen. At this point, they've really heard the message,'' she said. ``Every major manufacturer has at least one alkaline mill, and now they have some stake in promoting this as a product.'' The change comes none too soon. The advance of brittle books is outpacing the preservationists, they say. In the Library of Congress, which spends ``millions'' on preservation, workers transfer between 11,000 and 13,000 volumes on microfilm per year, Smith said. Meanwhile, about 70,000 of the library's volumes move into brittle status annually, she said. ``It's not for lack of interest or for lack of money,'' she said. ``It's just that there's lots of money to be spent on this. I would say it's a race against time and we're losing.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Eye Savings and Loan Crackdown as Crime Bill Nears Vote
DOC.TEXT: Private citizens frustrated by the pace of prosecution in the $325 billion savings and loan mess could themselves sue alleged defrauders and pocket damages under a plan sponsors want to add to the Senate's omnibus crime bill. The so-called ``bounty hunter'' plan is drawing fire from the Justice Department, which says it might end up snarling criminal investigations already under way. But sponsors say it could prove to be precisely what is needed to prod the cleanup into high gear. ``The United States has just experienced the greatest financial theft in our history _ carried out by thousands of people _ and the wheels of justice grind with agonizing slowness,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. The General Accounting Office estimates that the savings and loan bailout will cost taxpayers between $325 and $500 billion, depending on inflation, interest rates and other economic conditions. The bounty hunter plan is the last unresolved point in the wide-ranging crime package, which is set for a vote on Wednesday. Chief provisions of the package call for curbs on nine semiautomatic assault weapons, plus capital punishment for 30 federal crimes ranging from presidential assassination to espionage. Some Senate liberals are disgruntled about the death penalty provisions and conservatives are ill at ease with any restrictions on the right to bear arms. Always anxious to show crime-fighting zeal in an election year, though, senators are expected to whisk the package through without difficulty once the savings and loan dispute is wrapped up. The bill then goes to the House, where the Judiciary Committee already is at work on a distinctively different anti-crime blueprint. The ``bounty hunter'' plan is cosponsored by Simon and Sen. William V. Roth Jr., R-Del. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., has urged something similar. Endorsed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, the plan would cover savings and loan fraud under the False Claims Act _ which allows individuals to file fraud suits and pocket a portion of the damages as a reward. Of course, those filing suit would have to have inside knowledge of specific savings and loan fraud. And before setting off on their own, they would first have to give federal prosecutors a chance to act on the problem. Critics at the Justice Department, however, say the False Claims Act is unconstitutional and ought to be junked. The department prevailed on senators two weeks ago to postpone action on the plan. It argued that federal agents on the trail of S&L swindlers were liable to get sidetracked into endless reviews of individual claims under the measure. It also said the plan might spawn a quagmire of conflicting court cases and ultimately torpedo efforts to put S&L crooks behind bars. By postponing action on the proposal, the Senate gave sponsors additional time for their sales pitch. There's a game plan, however, in case talks fizzle. If that happens, lawmakers intend to go ahead and vote on the crime package and bring the savings and loan provisions to the floor later as a separate bill. The Senate already has done the hard work on the crime bill, maintaining its curbs on semiautomatic assault weapons despite a fierce lobbying campaign by the usually influential National Rifle Association. In other Capitol Hill action this week, congressional budget negotiators plan to meet with White House counterparts in search of an agreement to cut the federal budget deficit by $50 billion in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1. Agreement has been elusive after nearly two months of talks. But the bargaining intensified after President Bush eased his position against taxes on June 26 _ saying he now believes they must be included in any budget pact. Participants say they hope a package of higher taxes and spending cuts can be agreed to before Congress leaves for its August recess. The Senate Armed Services Committee has scheduled closed sessions much of the week to craft a defense authorization bill for the next fiscal year. Controversial issues on the agenda include the Bush administration's planned purchase of 75 B-2 stealth bombers at more than $815 million each, spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative and the fate of the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft. Complicating the issue is uncertainty over the size of the total budget. President Bush has proposed $307 billion in military spending, but lawmakers have balked at that amount. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services panel, has said that the committee will fashion two bills _ one to his budget range of $289 billion to $291 billion and another to the Senate Budget Committee total of $286 billion.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Summit-By The Numbers
What the Leaders Want Out of the Summit
DOC.TEXT:
When leaders of the world's seven richest industrial nations gather here for their 16th annual economic summit, the talks are likely to focus on Soviet aid, global trade disputes and environmental degradation. Here are sketches of the leaders and their priorities for the summit.
UNITED STATES President Bush has proclaimed ending the stalemate on global free trade talks as his No. 1 priority for the summit. But to achieve that goal, he needs to reach a compromise with the Europeans, who are resisting America's call for a 10-year phase-out of costly farm subsidies. Perhaps as a bargaining ploy, Bush intends to show the world leaders a good time in his adopted hometown, kicking things off with a rodeo, barbecue and country music extravaganza Sunday night. Bush has been riding high in the public opinion polls but he has been jolted by the adverse reaction to his turnaround on the question of tax increases.
JAPAN Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was considered a stopgap head of government when he assumed the leadership role in August 1989 after two predecessors resigned in quick succession. Yet, he led his conservative Liberal Democratic Party to a strong victory in February elections and now stands strong in the polls. He has made easing trade tensions with the United States a high priority and has forged a close working relationship with Bush. Kaifu will push for ending economic sanctions imposed on China following the pro-democracy crackdown. But Kaifu's bid to unfreeze $5.2 billion worth of development loans is opposed by other summit countries.
WEST GERMANY West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is steering his country to unification with East Germany and has made no secret of his desires to be the first chancellor of a unified Germany. To win Soviet support for speedy unification, Kohl is pushing for an economic aid package for the Soviet Union. While denying that they are trying to ``buy off'' the Soviets, West German leaders concede that they need Soviet agreement on various aspects of unification, such as the disposition of the 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany.
BRITAIN British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is the dean of summiteers, having celebrated her 11th year in office in May. But high inflation and an unpopular new tax have left her Conservative Party trailing in the polls. Thatcher must call an election by June 1992 and for the first time since she came to power, polls now show that a narrow majority of Britons think she will be defeated. Her main aims at the summit will include arguing against any large-scale handouts to the Soviet Union.
FRANCE President Francois Mitterrand's popularity ratings have dropped sharply in recent months, but he still has five years to go in his second seven-year term and thus isn't considered in severe difficulty. Mitterrand is expected to join Germany in pushing for a Soviet aid package. Mitterrand, long a champion of greater aid to the developing world, will push for more extensive efforts to trim the $1.3 trillion Third World debt burden.
CANADA Prime Minister Brian Mulroney comes to Houston with a satchelful of political problems. He has just lost his battle for ratification of a constitutional amendment giving Quebec distinct status and his popularity rating is at the lowest point for any Canadian prime minister in history. He is expected to use the economic meeting to reassure Canada's foreign partners that the country is not falling apart and Canada remains a safe place for foreign investors. Mulroney also seeks a commitment for more resources to fight global pollution.
ITALY Premier Giulio Andreotti, a virtual fixture in Italian government for 40 years, heads to the summit with the perennial problem facing Italy's coalition Cabinets _ bickering among the partners. The Christian Democrat six-time premier has headed this coalition since July 1989. Italy plans to push for cancelling the debt owed to governments by the world's poorest countries. He will also voice support for the Soviet aid proposal and urge a crackdown on auto emissions as a way of protecting the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Pope's Coming Visit Signals End of Church-State Conflict
With BC-Change in Burundi
DOC.TEXT: The first visit to this predominantly Roman Catholic nation by Pope John Paul II will symbolize the end of a conflict between church and state. John Paul, on his sixth tour of Africa in September, will be greeted in Burundi by President Pierre Buyoya, an army major who seized power in a coup prompted by his predecessor's crackdown on Catholics. Between 1985 and 1987, Col. Jean-Baptiste Bagaza expelled most foreign missionaries; detained local priests, including one who died in prison, and prohibited church services during the week. Bagaza, a member of the ruling minority Tutsi tribe, accused the church of sowing the seeds of revolution among the majority Hutus. Some churches were banned, including Jehovah's Witnesses and Seventh-day Adventists, and several Catholic organizations were proscribed. By early 1987, religious education had been halted, prayer meetings in villages were forbidden and all church councils had been dissolved. Discontent spread among Burundi's 6 million people, two-thirds of whom are Catholics. Buyoya took advantage of the angry mood to overthrow Bagaza on Sept. 3, 1987. He has encouraged the return of foreign missionaries, sought the advice of church leaders in unifying the country and lobbied vigorously for the papal visit. ``The pope's arrival will signal the end of an ugly chapter in our history, and the Catholic church can only profit from that,'' said the Rev. Adrien Ntabona, secretary-general of the Catholic Bishops' Conference. Residents of this scruffy capital on the shores of Lake Tanganyika are benefiting from the pope's pilgrimage two months before he arrives. Bulldozers and graders are repairing main roads and potholed streets. Government buildings are being given a facelift and homeowners are promised handsome rewards for renting rooms to Catholics from out of town. Several of Burundi's 204 Catholic priests advised Buyoya's military government on the unity charter he announced in May. Ntabona said: ``The significance of the pope's visit is that it comes at a time when our church is being renewed and revitalized. The church is today socially better organized than any other group, including political parties, and it is in a strong position to influence unity between the two peoples.'' With government support, priests are broadcasting sermons explaining what unity will mean to Hutus and Tutsis. ``Most Hutus and Tutsis want peace,'' Ntabona said. ``Only a few extremists want conflict. The church can help the moderates triumph.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor, Aides Try to Reduce AIDS Among Street Prostitutes
DOC.TEXT: The streetwalker's hollow eyes gave her away: She needed a fix. Behind her on the empty street, a van approached and she glanced over. Maybe she could turn a quick trick. The driver of the white Dodge had a different idea. He wanted to test her blood for AIDS and ask a few questions, and he offered a bag of condoms and $10 _ three times the amount she might make for a sexual favor. But more, he offered to open a rare line of communication with a world ravaged by AIDS. ``I really need your help,'' said Vanessa, 37, as she stepped into the van. She nestled into the comfortable back seat and stretched out her thin arm. The inch-long track marks along its length told her tale. They also indicated a more than one-in-two chance she was infected with HIV, the AIDS virus. Vanessa is one of 1,600 streetwalkers a New York doctor, Joyce Wallace, has tested and counseled about AIDS. Ms. Wallace's van and a crew of six roam New York's red-light districts. She has found that in the nation's largest city, a third of all streetwalkers are infected with AIDS. Equally important, she found most were infected by dirty needles or drug-using boyfriends _ not by their clients. And in a separate study, she found scant evidence streetwalkers are passing the virus to clients. A national study by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control reached similar conclusions. The incidence of AIDS infection among prostitutes ranged from zero in southern Nevada to almost 50 percent in northern New Jersey. In the open back of Ms. Wallace's van, driver John Reid gently asked Vanessa about her sex and drug habits while Karen Heagarty took a blood sample. They listened to her story. ``It's like fighting a war down here,'' said Vanessa, dressed in a tight skirt and white halter blouse. ``Before I end up dead, I want to get out of this.'' Ms. Wallace has heard this tale many times over the past eight years. In 1982, with a boyfriend in tow for protection, she began combing the 11th Avenue ``stroll'' in Manhattan to test street women and question them about their sex and drug practices. In 1988, Ansell Inc., which manufactures Lifestyle Condoms, donated a $15,000 van. Last year, with a $140,000 grant from the CDC and the state Department of Health, Ms. Wallace and her staff began cruising areas prostitutes were known to frequent. The van is ready for war. Armed with boxes of condoms, needles and pamphlets on safe sex, Ms. Wallace's team does battle three times a week. Besides the $10 and a clear plastic bag of condoms streetwalkers are given, they get an additional $20 if they stop by Ms. Wallace's Greenwich Village office to pick up their test results. ``These are throwaway women,'' Ms. Wallace said. ``Their contact with the establishment is only occasional. It's a judge, a police officer who wants to move them off a street corner, a school that failed them.'' Data from this year has not yet been tabulated. But from the 950 women tested last year, Ms. Wallace drew a startling profile: _Homeless: 45 percent. _Drug users: all but 48. _Mothers: 88 percent. The children of 90 percent lived in foster care or with relatives. _High school dropouts: 50 percent. _Black: 49 percent; Hispanic: 27 percent. _HIV infected: 33 percent. The high incidence of poverty and drug addiction brings added risk of AIDS infection for both the woman and her client, former prostitutes said. Many streetwalkers today are amateurs, not the ``professional'' women of previous years, said a former prostitute of eight years and drug user of 10 who asked to be identified only as Joellen. ``They run down the price because they are basically keeping a drug habit, they don't take the time to screen their partners and they often don't use condoms,'' said Joellen, of Prostitutes of New York, a support group. Women are working longer to make the same money, Joellen said. The price of a trick is $3 for streetwalkers in some neighborhoods. Prostitutes who work out of brothels or hotels earn more. Streetwalkers used to earn up to $40 for a trick, Joellen said. Despite the potential risk of AIDS, the clientele hasn't changed, she said, drawing a profile of the average john in New York as either an awkward college-age man or a ``suburban daddy.'' Johns are ``just as resistant to using condoms as they ever were,'' Joellen said. Beverly, a 27-year-old streetwalker, said some men will pay more for sex without condoms. ``The men somehow think they are immune to AIDS,'' Joellen said. On the whole, the johns are not yet being infected with AIDS, although the risk is there. Ms. Wallace has tested the blood of 500 men who say they have had contact with prostitutes since 1978, and has found only three who apparently were infected by it. Each of the three had had more than 600 encounters with hookers and had never used condoms. About half the streetwalkers said they used condoms with clients at least some of the time. Most did not use them with husbands or boyfriends. Most streetwalkers were infected by their intravenous drug-using boyfriends or through their own drug use, Ms. Wallace said. At least 58 percent of the women who injected drugs were infected with AIDS. Ms. Wallace is raising money for the city's first drop-in center specifically for prostitutes, a place to get medical treatment, eat a hot meal, take showers and be counseled. Back on the street, Vanessa stepped from the van clutching condoms, information about drug rehabilitation programs _ with waiting lists a mile long _ and a number to call for her test result. ``I want to start over but there's not much chance for me,'' she said. ``Where do I begin?''

DOC.HEAD: Homes Are Filled with Potential Dangers
DOC.TEXT: Marie Steinwachs admits she, of all people, should have known better. Steinwachs, assistant director of the Household Hazardous Waste Project at Southwest Missouri State University, was washing dishes recently when she decided to add a dash of bleach to the water. A flu had struck her household and she wanted a little extra germ-killing punch. But soon after adding the bleach, Steinwachs felt her throat tighten and her eyes water. ``I grabbed the bottle of dishwashing liquid and sure enough, the label said `Do not mix with chlorine bleach,' '' she said. American homes are filled with products that can cause serious injury or death if used or disposed of improperly. With an estimated 27,000 household products containing hazardous materials available in stores, even experts like Steinwachs make mistakes that put health and the environment at risk. Informing adults and children about the dangers of everyday products, from aerosol sprays to wood preservatives, and suggesting safer alternatives is the mission of the Household Hazardous Waste Project. Founded in 1987, the state-funded program is gaining attention for its education efforts in an era of increased health and environmental awareness. It recently received one of 21 ``Renew America'' awards from the National Environmental Awards Council, a coalition of environmental advocacy groups. President Bush honored project founder and director Sondra Goodman and other winners at the White House. Perhaps the Waste Project's biggest claim to fame is a 178-page booklet _ printed on recycled paper, of course. The booklet spells out which products can endanger health and pollute the environment, recommends safer alternatives, and advises how to safely use, store and dispose of hazardous products. About 7,000 copies of the ``Guide to Hazardous Products Around the Home'' have been distributed in the United States, Canada, Europe and Japan, Goodman said. Goodman, an agronomist by training, said the Waste Project grew out of a curiosity about the possible dangers posed by cleansers and chemicals she used in her home. ``I began to research the issue and I was really surprised by some of the health aspects of these everyday products,'' she said. ``I thought, `This can't be right.' '' For example, Goodman said she had no idea the mothballs she placed in her closet were classified as a pesticide and could spread poisonous vapors. Nor did she know that tossing a worn-out ``button'' watch battery into the trash could put humans and wildlife at risk. Such batteries can leak or explode, injuring trash haulers, and the lead, mercury and other metals they contain can seep into the soil in landfills and pollute ground water. ``Once I became aware of the dangers many household products pose, I changed my buying and usage habits to make my home more safe,'' she said. She also helped start the Waste Project, with input from a variety of community health groups and a grant from an agency of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources. Goodman and her five-member staff operate on a $115,000 annual budget. They lend their expertise to cities, civic groups and businesses around the state. Project members also help set up or direct consumers to recycling outlets for waste oil, transmission fluid, automotive batteries, paint and button batteries. In addition, they answer thousands of calls about the use, storage and disposal of such wastes.

Editors: The ``Guide to Hazardous Products Around the Home'' sells for $9.95 postpaid from the Household Hazardous Waste Project, 901 S. National, Box 108, Springfield, Mo. 65804. It also is available in some bookstores.

DOC.HEAD: Keeping Your Household Safe
With BC-EXP--Household Hazards
DOC.TEXT: Here is some advice from the ``Guide to Hazardous Products Around the Home'':
DOC.HEAD: Before you buy a product:
DOC.TEXT: Read the label. Make sure it is the product you want to buy and that you're comfortable with the ingredients. Buy the least hazardous product. Let the signal words serve as a guide. With pesticides, ``DANGER'' means highly toxic, ``WARNING'' means moderately toxic, and ``CAUTION'' means slightly toxic. With household products, ``POISON'' means highly toxic, ``DANGER'' means extremely flammable or corrosive or highly toxic, ``WARNING'' or ``CAUTION'' means less toxic. Buying products labeled ``non-toxic'' may be a way of identifying a safer product; however, be aware that the word non-toxic is an advertising word and has no federal regulatory definition. Avoid aerosol products. Aerosol disperses the substance in tiny droplets that can be inhaled deeply into the lungs and absorbed into the bloodstream. In addition, aerosol cans may become explosive when heated.
DOC.HEAD: Once it's in your home, use it safely:
DOC.TEXT: Read labels carefully before using hazardous products. Use the proper safety equipment when working with hazardous chemicals. Leave products in the original containers with the label that clearly identifies the contents. Never put hazardous products in food or beverage containers. Do not mix products unless directed to do so by label directions. This can cause explosive or poisonous chemical reactions. Even different brands of the same product can contain incompatible ingredients. Use only what's needed for a job. Twice as much doesn't mean twice the results. Follow label directions. If pregnant, avoid toxic chemical exposure. Many toxic products have not been tested for their effects on fetuses. Avoid wearing soft contact lenses when working with solvents and pesticides. They can absorb vapors from the air and hold the chemical near your eyes.
DOC.HEAD: Store it safely: Keep products out of reach of children and animals. Store hazardous products on high shelves or in locked cabinets, away from food. Make certain products are clearly labeled. Make sure lids and caps are tightly sealed and childproof. Store volatile chemicals or products that warn of vapors or fumes in a well-ventilated area, out of reach of children and pets. ^End advance for July 9

DOC.HEAD: Prenatal Test Detects Down's Syndrome in One Day Instead of Weeks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Down Syndrome' in 11th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A new test can detect Down's syndrome in fetuses in one day rather than the standard three weeks, a company says. The procedure should not replace standard testing yet, but in the future it may provide faster and cheaper results for expectant couples, said Stephen Turner of Oncor Inc. The company, based in Gaithersburg, Md., said its testing system can detect abnormal numbers of certain chromosomes in fetal cells that are extracted from the womb using standard procedures. Down's syndrome is a form of mental retardation caused by having three copies rather than two of chromosome No. 21. It occurs in about one in every 800 births. Oncor said its testing system can also detect disease-causing, abnormal numbers of copies of chromosomes 13, 18, X and Y. But it cannot detect other chromosomal abnormalities or defects in specific genes, Turner said. Oncor, which develops genetic tests, started selling the Down's syndrome portion of the system in June. Traditional chromosome testing takes about three weeks because once cells are extracted from the womb, they must be grown in the laboratory and treated before their chd chromosome analysis. It can indicate high-risk samples for priority testing and confirm cases that were difficult to diagnose, Turner said. In the future, he said, he believes the test will be used by itself to ``allow a one-day answer to people and eliminate the anxiety they have now'' in waiting three weeks. It should also cut the cost of testing, he said. Dr. Charles Epstein, chairman of the National Down Syndrome Society's science advisory board, said the new test could be useful if further research shows it to be accurate. People who seek chromosome testing are ``under tremendous emotional stress and would like to get the answers more quickly,'' he said. Aubrey Milunsky of the Boston University School of Medicine said he believes the test's accuracy will prove acceptable, and that it could promote chromosome testing for women younger than 35. Insurance companies generally will not pay for testing in such women because they run less risk of chromosomal abnormalities than older women do. Most laboratories charge $600 to $800 for the standard analysis, Milunsky said. The new test should be far less expensive, so more younger women could afford it, he said. Insurance companies might eventually cover it, he said. If a test result is negative, a woman could be assured with a high degree of certainty that her fetus is free of the abnormalities the test seeks, he said. A positive result should be confirmed by standard analysis, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Hot Spot' Forms Hawaii Islands
DOC.TEXT: Hawaiian folklore tells of the movements of the volcano goddess Pele from one island to another. Without knowing it, the tellers of these tales were chronicling the scientific process that formed the Hawaiian archipelago. Legend has it that Pele was being chased from island to island by her sister and nemesis, Na Maka o Kahai, goddess of the sea. In reality, the ``chase'' was the formation of the islands, part of a 900-mile string of volcanoes that have been active on the Pacific plate for 70 million years. These volcanic islands were formed after passing over a ``hot spot'' in the Earth's mantle that remains in a fixed location under the plate, said Reggie Okamura, who has studied volcanoes at the U.S. Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Observatory for 32 years. This hot spot remelts the portion of the rock passing over it, creating magma. The intense heat forces the magma to rise through the crust. The new magma builds on the previous eruptions in a layered fashion to form massive undersea mountains whose tips eventually rise above sea level and become islands, he said. These are known as shield volcanoes because of their gently sloping contours. ``The process that's happening now pretty much is what happened earlier to form the other islands,'' Okamura said. The Pacific plate is moving northwesterly at a rate of about four inches a year, Okamura said. Each island _ beginning with Kauai and Niihau and followed by Oahu, Molokai, Lanai and Maui and Hawaii _ were active volcanoes at one time. A large portion of Hawaii Island, the youngest in the chain, currently sits over the hot spot. It is the island's location that presently accounts for the volcanic activity at Kilauea, which has been in continuous eruption since 1983. About 160 acres of new land have been created as a result, Okamura said. Three of Hawaii Island's five volcanoes have been active in the last 200 years. The other two, which already have passed over the hot spot, have been dormant for 3,000 and 6,000 years, respectively. Scientists say a new seamount is forming southeast of Hawaii Island and is about 600 feet below the surface. When it breaks sea level, thousands of years from now, Loihi will be the newest Hawaiian island, Okamura said. The process that forms Hawaii's volcanoes is different from the one that forms volcanoes on the continental United States, such as Mount St. Helens, which blew its top off in a spectacular eruption in 1980. The Cascade range that includes Mount St. Helens was formed by the subduction of the Juan de Fuca plate with the North American Continental plate. As the Juan de Fuca plate is pushed deeper into the earth, the friction melts the rock to form highly pressurized magma that can be released with explosive force, Okamura said. While lava from Hawaii's volcanoes sometimes shoots hundreds of feet into the air, it's unlikely enough pressure could be built up to cause such a violent eruption as the one at Mount St. Helens, he said. Magma _ called lava only after it reaches the surface _ moves through the island's volcanoes via a series of tubes and vents. The tubes are formed when the crust over a lava flow cools, thickens and stops moving. The rest of the lava continues to pass under it. The tubes and vents are created by a system of dykes and sills. Most of these are found in fractured areas of the volcano known as rift zones. Lava also can flow over the volcano's crater, or caldera, Okamura said. There are two kinds of lava _ pahoehoe and a'a _ identical in chemical composition. Pahoehoe lava is black and smooth and swift-moving. A'a lava is rougher, more fragmented and slower-moving. Most lava erupts as pahoehoe, with some changing to a'a as its temperature and gas content decrease. The lava mainly is composed of silica, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, sodium and other minerals, Okamura said.

DOC.HEAD: Fat-Eating Couch Potatoes Face Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer
DOC.TEXT: People increase their risk of colon and rectal cancer when they eat a lot of saturated fat and don't exercise, according to a study of Chinese residents of North America and China. ``This is a message everyone needs to hear _ not just the Chinese,'' said Stanford University epidemiologist Alice S. Whittemore, chief author of the study. The findings are to be published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute this month. ``We began the project because we noticed that the rate of colorectal cancer is four to five times higher among Chinese-Americans than among Chinese in China,'' said Anna Wu-Williams, a co-author at the University of Southern California. She said the rate of colorectal cancer among Chinese men in Los Angeles County and San Francisco was close to rate of white men in those areas, so the researchers set out to find out what changed after the move to the United States. Wu-Williams said the study found about a fivefold increase in risk of colorectal cancer associated with a sedentary lifestyle and a diet with more than 20 grams (about two-thirds of an ounce) of saturated fat a day for men in North America. The risk of colorectal cancer is increased only about 20 percent among sedentary people who eat a low-fat diet, she added. The university said the researchers interviewed 905 colorectal cancer patients and 2,488 healthy people. All were Chinese. About half of each group lived in China and half in North America. The researchers compared patterns of diet and activity. After lung cancer, colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States, with an estimated 110,000 new cases of colon cancer and 45,000 new cases of rectal cancer this year, according to the American Cancer Society. The group said annual U.S. deaths total 60,900 from colon cancer and 7,600 from rectum cancer. The cancer group said previously identified factors that raise the risk of colorectal cancer include inflammatory bowel disease and a personal or family history of cancer or polyps in the colon or rectum. It listed a high-fat, low-fiber diet as a suspected risk factor.
DOC.HEAD: Terminal Disease Was Common Ground that Led Couple to Altar
DOC.TEXT: It all started with a letter. He wrote her because he'd heard they had something in common. They talked some on the phone and eventually met. ``Pretty quickly we decided we were right for each other,'' he said. What Melissa Mery and Peter Bennett had in common was the inherited, incurable, life-threatening disease called cystic fibrosis. What kept them together _ and led to their recent marriage _ has less to do with disease than with the contagiously positive attitude they share. ``Their marriage is a remarkable thing,'' said Nemr S. Eid, Mery's physician and co-director of the CF clinic at Kosair Children's Hospital. ``The reason it's remarkable is that CF has been considered to be fatal and is very scary to people. But here we have two youngsters with the disease deciding to face life together with enthusiasm and courage and stamina.'' Each understands the other's symptoms, why they cough a lot and easily get short of breath. And they could skip the part about why they must take pills at mealtimes or go through painful and time-consuming physical therapy several times a day or sleep with oxygen tubes in their noses. At 24, Bennett can describe how his disease has affected him with a mix of emotional insight and medical knowledge. The day before his wedding, he polished off the thesis for his master's degree in mechanical engineering. He's waiting for word on a job. Mery, 20, is softer-spoken. She has contributed stories about her experiences to local and national publications. And she's now plotting what will be their masterpiece, she says _ a joint autobiography. Bennett and Mery already have lived well beyond the age anyone thought possible at the time they were diagnosed _ he at 6 months; she at 3 years. Because of advances in both treatment and understanding of the disease, half of all people with CF now live beyond age 21. When they considered marriage, they thought about problems they might face with employers, medical bills _ and, most of all, watching the one you love repeatedly battle disease. ``Each time one of us has been sick, we've been looking at how we support each other,'' says Bennett. ``If Melissa's in the hospital, for example, is it going to bring me down? If I'm doing bad, will it bring her down?'' What they found is ``the reverse,'' he says. ``We look at the positive things.''
DOC.NOTE: End advance for July 9

DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods in May regained their 2.1 percent loss of a month earlier, the government said in an indication industry may be starting to recover from a slump. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that orders for both durable and non-durable goods rebounded 2.1 percent to a seasonally adjusted $240.9 billion.

Northwest Airlines Chairman Alfred Checchi wants to meet with the Machinists union to discuss the possibility of Northwest buying Eastern Airlines, a union spokesman said. The spokesman said Tuesday Machinists officials met in Washington to discuss problems integrating Eastern employees into Northwest's operation. He said the meeting was a prelude to one with Checchi, but no time was set. Checchi has made public his intention to expand Northwest, possibly by buying an entire airline or parts of one.

Already sluggish global economic growth is likely to slow further in 1990, and growth in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union is virtually at a standstill, according to a U.N. report. The 1990 World Economic Survey by the U.N. Department of International Economic and Social Affairs, released Tuesday, said world economic output increased by 3.1 percent in 1989, compared with 4.4 percent in 1988. It noted diversity in economic performance and said that industrialized market economies continued to expand, growing by 3.5 percent. Although that was lower than the 4.3 percent in 1988, it was stronger than had been expected, the report said.

American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it is buying selected assets of Western Union Corp.'s Business Services unit for $180 million. AT&T said Tuesday it will buy Western Union's electronic mail service, Telex, enhanced facsimile transmission, computer-to-computer electronic data interchange, voice mail and packet-switched networks, which send large amounts of information quickly.

The Energy Department said it will need almost 50 percent more money and twice as many people to clean up nuclear weapons waste over the next five years than it previously thought. Key members of Congress said Tuesday they will provide the extra money, $28.6 billion instead of the $19.5 billion estimated last November, if the department can show it will be well used. A new department report said cleanup will cost about $6 billion in each of the next five years. It said the extra costs were mostly the result of the discovery of additional wastes and tougher regulations.

A Canadian oil pipeline company said it will seek to build a pipeline under the environmentally sensitive waters of Puget Sound to keep tanker traffic out of the narrow, rocky channels. Trans Mountain Pipe Line Co. Ltd. on Tuesday revived an idea rejected a decade ago by environmentalists and the state after a bitter fight. The announcement followed the release of a regional oil-spill task force report that recommends serious consideration of an offshore terminal and pipeline to reduce the risk of oil spills in Puget Sound.

Farmers spent an estimated $124.1 billion on production expenses last year, up 4.9 percent from $118.4 billion in 1988, according to a preliminary report by the Agriculture Department. That was still far below the record level of $131.8 billion spent in 1981, just before a general financial crunch that stalled expansion in the nation's agricultural sector. The report by the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service, released Tuesday, showed 1989 expenditures rose for all major categories farm and land improvements, which dropped 6.3 percent, and fuel, which declined slightly.

Western nations agreed to channel millions of dollars in aid to help revive the stricken economies of four East European countries but made no move to help the Soviet Union. Foreign ministers of two-dozen Western nations on Wednesday ducked the troublesome question at a meeting called to extend an aid program, initially set up only for Poland and Hungary, to others in Eastern Europe. They said in a final statement they discussed the situation in the Soviet Union and ``underlined their interest in positive developments'' toward a democracy and a free-market economy.

Automakers that got high grades in J.D. Power and Associates' annual quality survey are shifting their advertising operations into high gear. This year, consumers can expect to see advertising about Power's latest Initial Quality survey rankings from Toyota Motor Corp. and its Lexus Division; Mazda Motor Corp. for its trucks; and General Motors Corp.'s Buick Division, the highest-ranked U.S.-made cars.

The stock market's best-known index posted its fifth consecutive gain Tuesday to finish above 2,900 once again. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.37 to close at 2,911.63. The dollar ended mostly lower. Bond prices rose slightly in light pre-holiday trading. Gold futures prices advanced for the fifth straight day; coffee futures advanced while energy futures, livestock and meat futures and grain and soybean futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Happy Thoughts About Higher Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Improve your personal finances by paying higher taxes! Outlandish as it may sound, that's the idea bandied about by many financial analysts these days. So far, sophisticated investors on Wall Street seem to be buying it. Of course, only a short time has passed since President Bush's reversal late last month of his long and outspoken stand against tax increases. Assuming that he and Congress now will agree on a plan aimed at raising revenues of the federal government, it remains to be seen what specific form the tax measures might take. Still, people in the investment world, long noted for free-market preferences and distaste of anything that smacks of bigger government, have so far behaved as though they are pleased to see what has happened. Indeed, the news was greeted by a rise in both stock and bond prices as interest rates fell. That reaction goes against a lot of traditional thinking about economics and finance. How well would an economy already struggling with tight credit conditions and weak consumer spending bear the added burden of a tax increase? What havoc might a recession wreak on the investment markets at a time when the stock market has only recently hit record highs? Most economists concede that those are legitimate and worrisome questions. For the moment, however, they say investors seem to be betting that such perils will be averted. The optimistic case rests on two main expectations _ that a tax increase would help break a persistent logjam in Washington and reduce the federal budget deficit, and that interest rates would drop as a result, probably with a push from the Federal Reserve. From that, individuals and family money managers might reap such prospective benefits as lower mortgage rates, and support for the slumping real estate market. Bond prices would rise, taking with them the net asset values of the public's large holdings of income mutual funds. Progress on the deficit, furthermore, would bring relief on what John Connolly, an analyst at the Wall Street firm of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., calls ``the No. 1 economic problem of the United States _ the failure of domestic savings to satisfy our investment needs.'' Dependence on foreign capital to fill the gap has helped drive U.S. interest rates to persistently high levels in comparison with the inflation rate, Connolly says. The government's borrowing to cover its deficit has diverted capital that could be contributing to prosperity and growth in the private economy. Much of this argument is general and theoretical. It provides no specifics on how savers and investors can make their paychecks and savings stretch further. Some also might protest that lower interest rates could actually cause savers more pain than gain in the short run, by reducing the dollar returns available on investments like money-market mutual funds and bank certificates of deposit. But anything that provides long-term influences for lower interest rates and higher stock prices would logically stand to help the budgets of a great many households. Eventually, a more prosperous economy and a government on sounder financial footing might put pressure on politicians to lower taxes once again. That, at least, is the kind of reasoning that has governed the response of large investors so far. If their optimism should falter, it stands to reason that they will serve notice of their change of heart in the financial marketplace. The ``announcement'' would come in the form of a drop in the stock market and a rise in interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Delegation Tours Grain Exchange
DOC.TEXT: When the opening bell rang and traders at the Minneapolis Grain Exchange started shouting and gesturing wildly, eight agriculture officials from the Soviet Union appeared both amused and confused. The Soviet delegation toured the Grain Exchange Tuesday to learn more about buying and selling in a free market economy. ``It's not just me. The majority of us do not understand,'' said Victor Shtepo, a deputy of the Supreme Soviet. Under an agreement signed last month by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Union will buy at least 10 million metric tons of wheat each year over the next five years. ``We would hope that by that time, the Soviet Union will have a very active cash and futures market that may link with the Minneapolis market, and we could trade spring wheat around the world,'' said James Lindau, president of the Grain Exchange. Lindau said the Minneapolis Grain Exchange ``represents a significant model of what might develop in the Soviet Union.'' During the tour, the Soviet visitors were able to see firsthand the grading of grain to determine its price and to observe the furious activity of transactions in the trading pit. The Soviet officials questioned Lindau about the workings of the market system, asking how prices are determined, how much money the traders make and how information is relayed to other parts of the world. The delegation also watched a slide presentation about the Grain Exchange and the trading process. Because of similar climates in Minnesota and parts of the Soviet Union, a type of wheat known as hard red spring wheat is a productive crop in both places, Lindau said. He said Minnesotans are in a good position to help Soviet farmers increase their knowledge and technology. ``We know the difficulty in trying to grow crops in the northern climate where weather is probably our worst enemy,'' he said. The Soviet visitors said they were happy with the tour. ``Whether we want to our not, we've got to move to a free market,'' said Boris Palagnyuk, a Supreme Soviet deputy. ``We're very happy that this was included in our programs.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Share Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen on speculative buying today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell on profit-taking, market analysts said. The dollar closed at 151.00 yen, up 0.70 yen from Wednesday's close of 150.30 yen. It opened at 150.65 yen and ranged between 150.55 yen and 151.15 yen. Buying by life insurance companies gave the dollar upward momentum throughout the day, dealers said. It fluctuated as the life insurers sold to take profits, but remained above Wednesday's levels because of demand from overseas investors, they said. ``The life insurers are buying as a purely speculative hedge,'' said Kaneo Ogino of Goldman Sachs in Japan. ``The market was moving quickly.'' He said the dollar seemed to be testing a ceiling of 151.15 yen. The U.S. currency had been mainly declining since June 25, when it closed at 155.62 yen. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 94.25 points, or 0.29 percent, to 32,351.67 yen. The index gained 31.32 points on Wednesday. An estimated 430 million first-section shares changed hands in thin trading. Stock prices gained momentum late in the morning as index-linked buying nudged the market out of its early doldrums, traders said. Buying has been sustained recently by dealers and institutional investors anxious to support the market before new issues resume Friday, traders said. ``There was strong institutional support for the last few days, but today the institutions wanted to take profits,'' said Christopher Leighton, sales manager at Schroders Securities. New share sales were suspended in January, when the Tokyo market began a 3-month-long nosedive in which the Nikkei shed one-quarter of its value. The resumption of equity issues is seen here as one sign that the market is back to normal, although some dealers said they questioned the amount of support available for more shares. ``It's difficult enough to interest people in what stocks are available now,'' Leighton said. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 86.86 points as of 4 p.m. (3 a.m. EDT) from Wednesday's close of 87.11 points. The yield stood at 7.220 percent, up from the previous day's 7.165 percent.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell Thursday, hurt by a lack of direction and poor sentiment. One dealer compared the market's mood to London's weather. ``There is a low generally over the city, with nothing to blow it away,'' he said. Compounding the problem was growing concern that the pound's strength would hurt companies with overseas earnings, dealers said. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was down 11.8 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,343.7, near the session low of 2,341.8 reached at midmorning. Volume was 240.3 million shares, compared with 234.4 million at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Ice on the Horizon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS $500 million to $500 billion in 13th and 15th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: Here is an icy thought that, oddly, might make a hot summer seem even hotter: The savings and loan bailout, which could cost taxpayers $300 billion, may be just the tip of the iceberg. If the tip is equal to a sum of that size, the single most expensive governmental cost in peacetime, then how massive must the bulk of the berg be? Conceivably, in the trillions of dollars, says economist Ronald Utt, who points out that financial obligations of agencies underwritten by the federal government now total $5.8 trillion. ``And much of that obligation is in bad shape,'' says Utt, vice president of the U.S. Chamber Foundation, a former employee of the White House Office of Management and Budget and a former Heritage Foundation fellow. Potentially, he says, these financial obligations represent a staggering breakdown of government. And, a growing number of critics are saying, the lack of public information on the matter represents a communications breakdown. Most people, it seems safe to say, cannot imagine that other financial breakdowns are threatened, reasoning that if that were so they would have heard of them. But that logic breaks as throroughly as the communications. The obligations Utt refers to are spread among deposit insurance programs, loan and pension guarantees, direct loan programs such as those administered by the Small Business Administration, and debts of five government enterprises. Utt's chilling observations are contained in a paper written for Heritage, a conservative think tank whose opinions sometimes have been influential in the Bush and Reagan administrations. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., says Utt, is by no means the only federal credit program confronted with huge losses. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Federal Housing Administration lost money in 1988 and 1989 and seemed destined to lose again in 1990. The FHA, he says, has seen the level of claims against its shrinking reserves rise nearly three times in three years. Further, he states, ``Half of the farm loans made by the Farmers Home Administration are in default, and half of these defaulted loans have been in that condition for more than three years.'' On and on it goes. The federal government, he notes, stands behind nearly $500 billion in guaranteed Veteran's Administration and FHA mortgages, $48 billion in guaranteed student loans ... ``... and a host of other guarantees ranging from rural electrification to shipbuilding loans, and from small business disaster loans to loans for building plants to convert grain to ethanol.'' All together, he estimates, the contingent liability associated with loan and deposit guarantees totaled $3.5 trillion at the end of fiscal 1988. And other insurance programs _ flood insurance, for instance _ add $500 billion more. How could such massive obligations not rise to the surface and break more forcefully into the media? How can such dangers lurk so near and not cause more concern? Utt doesn't have an answer to those questions, but he does suggest that both Congress and taxpayers played a role. Most lawmakers, he says, ``tried to convince Americans that the crisis was just an isolated incident, and that the vast bulk of the government credit programs are well-managed and pose little risk to the taxpayer.'' And for their part, many taxpayers have wished this to be so. It isn't, says Utt, who advocates passage of an Omnibus Credit Solvency Act ``to fundamentally restructure these many programs in order to reduce taxpayer exposure to costly program failures.'' Before it is too late, he adds.

DOC.HEAD: Rainy Forecast Pressures Corn, Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices dropped sharply in early trading this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after the National Weather Service issued a rainy weather forecast for the Midwest. Wheat and oat futures also fell. The contract for March delivery of corn plunged the permitted daily limit of 10 cents a bushel within the first half-hour of trading, largely in reaction to a six-to-10-day outlook issued Wednesday by the weather service. The forecast was for above-normal rainfall over most of the Midwest during the latter half of next week. Some private forecasters continue to predict an extended period of hot, dry weather in the southern Corn Belt. But the fears of widespread crop stress that boosted corn and soybean prices earlier this week are fading, said Walter Spilka, a grains analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``The bottom line is probably that those traders who were buying in anticipation of a weather event now are selling in anticipation of a non-event,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were 3 cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.20} a bushel; corn was 3 cents to 9{ cents lower with July at $2.87 a bushel; oats were 5 cents to 5} cents lower with July at $1.35 a bushel; soybeans were 17 cents to 21 cents lower with July at $6.30{ a bushel. Livestock futures were narrowly mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies were down sharply. Live cattle were .03 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 72.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .50 cent higher with August at 83.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .08 cent higher with July at 61.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .07 cent to 1.82 cents lower with July at 56.60 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower on Tuesday. The markets were closed Wednesday for Independence Day.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn Plant Adds Jobs But Raises Quality of Life Questions
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Author Peter Jenkins likes to tell the story about how he walked across the country and picked Middle Tennessee for his home. Then came the day he heard General Motors Corp. had decided to build its biggest automobile plant a mile from his 150-acre farm. Neither he nor many Tennesseans are sure the impact from the investment, which is costing GM at least $3 billion, is totally welcome in the rolling hills and horse country, now facing pressures ranging from overcrowded schools to new sources of pollution. ``I look out my window at night and I see this red glow. They keep the lights on there,'' Jenkins said in an interview. GM's Saturn Corp. plant, nearly complete, is expected to begin sending cars to dealers nationwide any week now. But life in tiny Spring Hill has long since changed. The solitude of Spring Hill, population 1,094, was shattered first by news media publicizing the bucolic charm of the area, one of several GM was considering as the home for what it hoped would be the car of the future. Then came the speculators, who drove up the price of real estate after GM's July 30, 1985, announcement that it had determined Spring Hill was the ideal location. The company's first new nameplate since 1917 _ the compact will compete primarily with the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla and cost $10,000 to $12,000 _ will be built here by a combination of Tennesseans and transplants from other GM factories, many of whom were laid off in earlier cost-cutting drives. For many Tennesseeans, there is irony in GM's migration to their state. Decades ago, during the Depression and war-boom years, the migration mainly went the other way, as Tennesseeans moved north seeking jobs in Detroit. Tennessee politicians were elated when GM announced it would build a plant and hire 6,000 employees to produce a car line called Saturn. That number has since been halved, but the financial impact on the local economy has nonetheless been far-reaching. For example in Maury County, where the plant is based, $200 million has been spent for goods, services, salaries and taxes. GM provided $1.25 million for a new Spring Hill city hall. At the same time, the impact of such a major new employer has strained government services, especially public education. Maury County school officials are building a new elementary school and need about 30 new teachers to deal with 800 additional students _ an 8 percent increase in 1991 enrollment. ``The new elementary school, we believe, should relieve overcrowding in the elementary grades,'' Maury County school Superintendent Jerry Battles said. ``However, we expect a continuing enrollment pressure at our middle school and high school.'' In addition, the influx of non-Tennesseeans has created greater pressure to accomodate people from diverse cultural and ethnic backgrounds, which center largely along the differences between Southerners and Northerners. ``A lot of the automotive plants up North are in the downtown area. So, those people may be urbanites and accustomed to a faster pace of life than the people who live in the smaller towns in Middle Tennessee,'' said Dan Cornfield, a sociology professor at Vanderbilt University. ``There seems to be schisms between Northerners who've moved down and Southerners who've lived here. They don't always share the same lifestyles. So, you may get a segregation of people, not in terms of race.'' Almost half of the transplanted Saturn workers have settled in Maury County, which includes Spring Hill and Columbia, the county seat, the Maury County Chamber of Commerce has estimated. About a third moved north of Spring Hill in Williamson County, an affluent bedroom community next to Nashville. For transplants and natives alike, the biggest drawback to GM's arrival has been housing prices, which have multiplied and made it difficult for many families to find affordable places to live. ``The cost of land came back down from the high, but it's still higher than it was on announcement day,'' said Bill Chaffin, an official of the Maury County Chamber of Commerce. ``We have crowded streets that fall under the heading of _ I guess you'd say _ a problem. We've had a lot of interesting new people move in, which is not a problem. We've had our anxieties of growth.'' That kind of anxiety is the last thing author Jenkins expected when he'd finished ``Walk Across America.'' ``I think that for those of us who live in Middle Tennessee _ not just Spring Hill _ when you have a corporation as strong and as mighty as General Motors, we have to make sure we protect the lifestyle we love, the pace of life and the quality of southern lifestyle which I chose over any other lifestyle. ``We need to be vigilant _ and people tend to lose that sense of vigilance _ before it's too late,'' he said. End adv for Monday July 9

DOC.HEAD: Offshore Strike Reported Crumbling
DOC.TEXT: Some offshore oil workers were returning to work on the fifth day of a strike over wages, and Norwegian petroleum production was up to half the normal level, the national news agency NTB reported Thursday. Phillips Petroleum Co. of Norway said workers called off their walkout at the Ekofisk fields, a key junction for pipeline deliveries of natural gas to Europe. Production from some other Norwegian North Sea fields is routed through Ekofisk to Britain and West Germany. ``In theory production from all seven Ekofisk area fields can begin on Thursday, within 12 to 16 hours'' said Sander Bull-Gjertsen of Phillips. Ekofisk produced 220,000 barrels a day of crude in April. About 4,000 workers went on strike Sunday when the Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers and the Norwegian Confederation of Business and Industry failed to reach agreement on demands for wage increases and protection of jobs from automation. The government invoked compulsory arbitration, making the strike illegal, on Monday. Officials said they acted to protect the national economy. Phillips, meanwhile, dismissed several workers, sent lay-off warnings to 161 people and flew in alternate crews. About 1,000 oil workers initially defied the government order and appeals from the Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers union to return to work. But the strike gradually lost support during the week. Workers were reported on the job at fields besides Ekofisk Thursday and the national oil industry association said ``there is now a certain hope'' of the strike ending at additional fields.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Lending Drops, Due Partly to Cut in Loans to China
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, bgng Loans to, to CORRECT figure to $700 million; picks up 5th graf, Just after
DOC.TEXT: Lending by the World Bank, the biggest source of aid to the Third World, has declined in the past 12 months for the first time since 1985, the bank reported today. The decrease was due partly to a reduction in loans to China after tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square last year. Figures for the bank's year, which runs from July 1 to June 30, were made public by Moeen A. Qureshi, a Pakistani who is the bank's senior vice president for operations. New loans for the year just ended came to $20.7 billion. That was $600 million less than the $21.3 billion of the year before. Loans to China dropped by more than $700 million falling to $590 million from $1.3 billion in the year before the suppression of the democracy movement. Just after the Chinese government moved its military forces against demonstrators, Bank President Barber Conable withdrew $780 million worth of loans for China from consideration. Then President Bush asked the bank to halt lending to China. Later there was international agreement that new loans should be limited to basic human needs. The past year also brought a large drop in World Bank lending to India, where loans fell to $1.9 billion from $3 billion the year before. But bank officials said that was a coincidence and not the result of policy. Mexico displaced India as the biggest borrower, taking $2.6 billion compared with $2.2 billion in the previous year. Lending by the bank had been rising steadily, and is expected to increase again in the next 12 months. The bank is now playing a much bigger role in what used to be considered the ``Second World,'' European countries that have been under communist rule. ``We have initiated lending to Poland for a total of some $780 million this fiscal year ... and have continued our programs in Hungary,'' Qureshi said at a news conference last week. ``We are preparing support programs for Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia, both of which are expected to become bank members in the coming year, and are ready to resume our activities in Romania.'' The late Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu paid off almost all Romania's debts but the country has remained among the bank's 151 member countries. The Soviet Union has never belonged. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady spoke recently of creating some tie between the Soviets, the bank and its sister organization, the International Monetary Fund. The Soviets will be a member of the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, but for three years it will be able to borrow only as much as it contributes in the form of paid-in capital.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound's Lead Bank Creditor Wants Bankruptcy Case Moved to Dallas
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Greyhound Lines Inc.'s largest bank creditor have asked that the bus company's bankruptcy case be moved to Dallas. In a motion filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Brownsville, attorneys for Security Pacific Business Credit Inc. accuse Dallas-based Greyhound of ``forum-shopping'' in filing for protection from creditors in Brownsville. ``The filing of these proceedings in Brownsville exemplifies ... the use of the venue statue as a tactical weapon to unfairly disadvantage creditors in this proceeding,'' the filing said. It notes that most of the expected witnesses either live or work in the Dallas area, or can travel there with ease; and that the company's records are in Dallas, as are attorneys for most of the parties. It also says few of the company's debtors are in the Brownsville area. Greyhound sought Chapter 11 protection on June 4, citing costs associated with a violent strike by bus drivers. Greyhound's Eagle Bus Manufacturing Co. Inc. subsidiary is located in Brownsville. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Dunn said the company would oppose the move. No hearing on the request has been set. Security Pacific Business Credit, an affiliate of Security Pacific Corp., has a $147.2 million secured claim against Greyhound. An attorney for the main creditors' committee said the group has not decided whether to oppose or support the change in venue.

DOC.HEAD: Utility Names New Chief
DOC.TEXT: An executive of TRW Inc. has been named president of Florida Power & Light Co., the nation's fourth largest investor-owned utility said Thursday. Stephen Frank, 48, will replace Robert Tallon, who retired as president June 30. He is expected to join the Miami-based utility in mid-August as president and chief operating officer. Frank is executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Cleveland-based TRW, which provides products and services for space, defense, automotive and information systems markets. Frank said he has just begun studying FPL operations and had no immediate comment on such issues as proposed expansions to meet power demands in fast-growing areas of Florida. ``These are obviously topics I will be dealing with, but I really have not had an opportunity to adequately review the situations,'' said Frank, who previously worked as vice president and controller at GTE Corp. and spent 18 years at U.S. Steel Corp. in Pittsburgh. ``I think the company and the area are both very exciting because of growth possibilities,'' said Frank. FPL, which has 3 million customers, accounts for about 75 percent of the revenues for its parent, FPL Group Inc..

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Fishing Fleet Hits Tough Time
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Joel Vazquez never thought independence in Namibia would make any difference to his life as an ocean-roving commercial Spanish fisherman. He soon found himself beached like a trawler at low tide. When the new southern African nation was established in April, it ordered the Spanish fleet, one of the Western world's largest, to vacate the rich waters off the Namibian coast. The move idled Vazquez's ``Ur Elza'' and 34 other trawlers, along with 1,500 crew members. ``A fisherman with a true calling for the sea doesn't know what to do when he faces life on land,'' said Vazquez, 36. The fishing crisis could spell an end to his 13 years at sea. The ships forced from Namibia are part of the 175-vessel deep-sea fleet that forms the heart of the Spanish fishing industry. It directly employs 5,000 people and indirectly employs an additional 45,000 canners, marketers, shipbuilders and suppliers. Ninety percent of the fleet is based in the jagged estuary of Vigo of northeast Spain, the most important fishing port of the 12-nation European Community. Industry officials say much more of the fleet will be forced to drop anchor indefinitely because other countries besides Namibia have moved to evict foreign fleets from heavily fished breeding grounds. Argentina began shutting out Spanish trawlers last year, and the United States and Canada banned them from territorial waters in the early 1980s. Morocco has restricted foreign fishing off the Saharan banks, and Britain is limiting access to waters off the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic. Spain's commercial fishermen partly blame Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez for failing to challenge the increased protectionism. The government says that's part of the price for Spain's membership in the EC, which has given it less control over guarding the overseas interests of many Spanish businesses. ``The result has been a growing economic depression for Vigo-based ship owners and all related sectors,'' said Gloria Sio, editor of the industry magazine Industrias Pesqueras. Sio said the presence of the idled ships in Vigo harbor underscores what she called the administration's failure to control public financing for new ships while fishing grounds kept diminishing. ``Right now, there are at least 40 ships too many for the places available to fish,'' Sio said. Statistics compiled by the Ministry of Agriculture's fishing division show how the industry has become less productive and the country more reliant on imports. In 1987, for example, the deep-sea fleet's catch totaled nearly 635,000 tons, vs. about 553,000 tons last year. Frozen-fish imports have nearly tripled since 1984 to roughly 28,000 tons, while exports have declined by more than 28 percent to roughly 25,000 tons. For now, the ministry has approved a plan to pay idled fisherman their average monthly wage of about $600, with a stipend to cover social security payments. The Namibian government says part of the reason for the eviction order to the Spanish ships was to assess the productivity of domestic breeding grounds that produce Hake, an important food fish. But the Namibians have said a study will take at least four months, and they won't open negotiations on a new accord with the Spanish until afterward. ``Our future is totally uncertain,'' said Jose Fuertes, managing director of Spain's Hake Fishing Ship Owners Assocation. ``The administration has had plenty of time to see Namibian independence coming and to reach a bilateral accord to permit Spanish fishing, but it was just incompetent,'' he said. Unions and shipowners are outraged that Spain and the EC are not fiercely defending the Spanish fleet's right to fish overseas. On May 31, 5,000 people marched through Vigo as the Citizens Movement to Save the Fleet, with backing by politicians, fishermen's unions, shipowners associations and chambers of commerce. Gonzalez's Socialist party and the Socialist General Workers Union were absent. Serafin Sa, spokesman for the Communist Fisherman's Union, claimed EC Fishing Commissioner Manuel Marin, a Spanish Socialist, has been inept in defending the interests of Spanish fishermen against those of low-cost fishing nations such as the Soviet Union, Romania and Poland and in foreign fishing banks, especially those off Canada. ``The great irony is that while Spanish ships are being forced out of foreign hake and cod banks from Canada to Argentina, these countries are using basically protectionist measures in turn to dominate our own EC markets,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Big Three Report Sales Rise in Late June
With BC-MI--Auto Sales-Table
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Big Three automakers said Thursday that late-June sales of North American-made vehicles rose 7.1 percent compared with last year, stoked by strong truck sales. For the first six months of the year, Big Three car and truck sales were 6.3 percent behind last year. The six-month period provides a better picture of the companies' sales than the 10-day periods. This year's sales rate for domestic vehicles overall has been meandering below last year's rate. Recent economic reports have shown slow growth in the economy coupled with slightly weakened consumer confidence. Those factors, along with automakers offering reduced incentive packages compared with last year's, have combined to depress car and truck sales overall. But strong sales of trucks by General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. bucked that trend in late June. Chrysler Corp.'s truck sales lagged behind last year's pace. The Big Three said they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 39,716 during the June 21-30 period this year compared with a rate of 37,084 during the same time last year. Car sales were up 3.7 percent and truck sales rose a hefty 12.8 percent in late June. For the first half of the year, Big Three car sales were off 9.8 percent and truck sales were down 1.6 percent compared with the first six months of last year. Together, cars and trucks made by the three companies were selling at an average daily rate of 33,025 through June of this year, compared with the 35,260 daily vehicle sales average last year. GM was the only one of the Big Three to report gains in late-June sales of cars and trucks. The nation's largest automaker said its car sales during the period rose 12.9 percent and truck sales increased 29.9 percent, for a combined 17.8 percent increase. For the first half of 1990, GM's cars and trucks were selling at a rate 3.5 percent lower than last year. Ford reported its combined car and truck sales for late June were up 2.7 percent from last year's rate. A 4.7 percent decline in car sales was offset by a 14.1 percent increase in truck sales, mainly because of the new Explorer sport-utility vehicle. During the first six months of this year, Ford's car and truck sales were down 7.8 percent. Chrysler, which has been struggling all year with sagging sales, reported an 11 percent decline in its vehicle sales in late June, with car sales falling 10.8 percent and truck sales dropping 11.3 percent. So far this year, Chrysler's car and truck sales rate is 13 percent lower than last year.
