DOC.HEAD: Sikorsky At Work On Unmanned Air Surveillance Vehicle
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It looks like something that should be piloted by little green men from Mars, but Sikorsky Aircraft's newest flying machine doesn't need anyone in the cockpit, extra-terrestrial or otherwise. After four years of secret research, the helicopter pioneer has unveiled the Cypher, its entry in the race to develop a pilotless aircraft. The Cypher looks like two large ceiling fans bolted together to form the spokes of a fiberglass doughnut. It's 5} feet in diameter and weighs about 300 pounds, light enough to be carried by two people. A mock-up sits inside a storage building at Sikorsky's headquarters in Stratford, Conn. awaiting wind tunnel tests. Sikorsky, a division of United Technologies Corp., won't start production until it receives orders for the Cypher. But company executives predict the aircraft, known in the industry as an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle or UAV, will be a big hit with military and civilian customers for reconnaissance missions, search-and-rescues, fly-overs of forest fires and surveillance of illicit drug operations. ``You can just use your imagination and think about Mount St. Helens or Chernobyl, anywhere you want to get in without risking life,'' said William Tuttle, a Sikorsky spokesman. The American military has used remote-control airplanes for years, mostly as decoys to draw enemy fire away from planes with pilots aboard. But Pentagon strategists have decided they need a more versatile, helicopter-like aircraft that can take off and land vertically and maneuver in inaccessible areas. ``If Custer had one of these UAVs, he might have won at Little Big Horn,'' said Ray Coleman of the Pentagon's Joint Office for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles. The office was established in 1988 to look at the most promising vehicles. It invested a modest $160,000 in research on the Cypher last year, although Congress has prohibited the office from spending money on actual production. Work on the Cypher began in 1986 when Sikorsky was awarded an eight-month study contract by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. The company refused to discuss the actual cost of Cypher, because of the intense competition for government contracts. The Cypher uses technology developed by Sikorsky nearly two decades ago for its XH-59A helicopter, which used a coaxial rotor or double rotary blade to operate. The double blades rotate in opposite directions, giving the craft greater stability, especially on takeoffs and landings. The blades rotate within a fiberglass tube, where the Cypher's fuel and payload are stored. The Cypher is controlled by a computer programmed before takeoff, but its flight pattern can be altered after takeoff if necessary, said James Cycon, Sikorsky's chief engineer for the Cypher project. Sikorsky engineers say they're particularly proud of containing the blades within a tube, because the innovation makes the Cypher safer for people on the ground during takeoffs or landings. The blades of competitors under development are exposed, like a helicopter's. Cycon said the Cypher is designed to hover 8,000-10,000 feet in the air for about four hours. It can carry a 150-pound payload, such as a surveillance camera. The Cypher can be launched vertically from a small area, like the deck of a patrol boat. Sikorsky also is studying the possibility of launching Cypher from Black Hawk helicopters, which it makes for the Army. Sikorsky first flew a radio-controlled, 5-foot-diameter version of the Cypher in the summer of 1988 in West Palm Beach, Fla., to prove it could actually fly using the coaxial rotor technology, Cycon said. That vehicle has since been retired and is on display at Sikorsky headquarters. During the design work for Cypher, Cycon kept a sign on his wall that said, ``Time to make the doughnuts,'' and says his children are still kidded about having a father who makes flying saucers. Cypher's success would allow Sikorsky to expand into new markets in the face of defense cuts. The company has already been forced to lay off about 300 of its 12,000 workers because of lower military demand. But Sikorsky faces stiff competition in the field of pilotless flight. A number of domestic and foreign companies are vying for defense contracts and are further along in developing their products, Coleman said. The Pentagon already has a contract with Canadair to conduct a six-month test of that firm's CL227, or Peanut, he said. The British company ML Aviation has developed a pilotless vehicle called the Sprite, which resembles a flying barbecue grill. ``The unmanned air vehicle market is expected to grow dramatically in the next 10 years,'' said Mark Bobbi of Forecast International, an independent market research firm specializing in aerospace and defense. ``But I don't think the Cypher will help Sikorsky much in the next five years.'' Sikorsky recently submitted information about the Cypher to the Army, in hopes the Army will decide to order some vehicles so production can begin. Larry Dickerson, another Forecast International analyst who is watching the UAV industry, said Sikorsky's success will depend on how it markets the Cypher. ``It's very new and looks different, but the military is pretty conservative-minded about new and different things,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Wilt On Wet Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by steep losses in the corn market after the National Weather Service predicted wetter weather for the Midwest. Several contracts for delivery of new-crop corn plunged the permitted daily limit of 10 cents a bushel, largely in reaction to a six-to-10-day outlook issued Wednesday by the weather service. The forecast was for normal temperatures and above-normal rainfall over most of the Corn Belt during the latter half of next week. Some private forecasters continue to predict an extended period of hot, dry weather in the southern Corn Belt. But analysts said the National Weather Service forecasts typically take precedence over private forecasts in influencing the market. ``When the National Weather Service comes out with that kind of news, it kind of sets the tone for everybody,'' said Michael Gazall, a research analyst with Refco Corp. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 5\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.18\ a bushel; corn was 4 cents to 10 cents lower with July at $2.85} a bushel; oats were 4{ cents to 5{ cents lower with July at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 23 cents lower with July at $6.29 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Help Wanted Ads Lackluster In May
DOC.NOTE: For release after 6 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Help-wanted advertising registered a lackluster performance in May, indicating a cautious attitude among many employers around the nation, the Conference Board reported Friday. The seasonally adjusted Help-Wanted Advertising Index, compiled from a survey of ad volume in 51 newspapers across the country, registered 137 in May, down 2 points from April and 15 points below the year-ago level, the board said. ``The word `cautious' best describes the labor market right now,'' said Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein. ``There is a definite softness in demand: consumers, government and some elements of business investment appear quite sluggish.'' Most regions of the country _ particularly New England and the middle Atlantic states _ registered declines in help-wanted ads, and Goldstein noted that the drops show no sign of ending soon. But many southern states as well as parts of Texas and Oklahoma registered gains. Goldstein said export-driven economic growth is expected to boost labor markets in the West later this year and then sweep eastward. Ad volume has proven to be sensitive to labor market conditions and helps gauge changes in the local, regional and national supply of jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Tumble, Then Rebound Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished lower but above the session's bottom levelsThursday after prices recovered amid renewed buying. Trading was slow on the New York Mercantile Exchange with many market participants still absent after the mid-week holiday break. Markets and many businesses were closed Wednesday for Independence Day. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate slumped 30 cents to $16.50 per 42-gallon barrel, resuming the slide that was temporarily interrupted by Tuesday's 8-cent gain. Contracts for delivery during September through November also posted losses. Crude prices headed downward early in the day due to selling motivated in part by resolution of a strike that disrupted oil output from the Norwegian sector of the North Sea. A bearish supply and demand report from the American Petroleum Institute late Tuesday also provided a selling incentive. But the August contract rebounded from its low point of below $16.30 a barrel when buyers looking for bargains entered the market. Among refined products traded on the New York Merc, unleaded gasoline for August delivery slid 1.14 cents to 54.95 cents a gallon after losing 0.59 cent on Tuesday. Later contracts also settled lower. Wholesale home heating oil for August delivery settled at 48.33 cents a gallon, off 0.13 cent. The contract fell 0.10 cent Tuesday. The September through November contracts declined also. In natural gas trading, the August contract fell to $1.514 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.525 Tuesday. It was $1.519 on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Late-June Sales Rise
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Strong sales of North American-made light trucks and Japanese cars assembled in the United States pushed the late-June vehicle sales rate 11.9 percent higher than last year, automakers said Thursday. However, sales for the entire month, with imported cars and trucks included, were 1.9 percent behind last year's pace. Car and truck sales for the first six months of this year were 4.3 percent lower than last year. The 10 major U.S. car and truck makers reported they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 46,293 during the June 21-30 period this year compared with a rate of 41,372 during the same period last year. Car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. rose 3.7 percent while sales of U.S.-made Japanese cars increased 62.3 percent. The Big Three commanded 80.7 percent of the market during the period. Truck sales by GM, Ford and Chrysler rose 12.7 percent over last year. Economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va., said the late-June numbers don't necessarily reflect a change in the sluggish trend of the U.S. auto market this year. He said the assessment could change if the next two or three sales periods unexpectedly maintain the pace set in late June. Webb said he was surprised at the vigor in the late-June truck sales figures for GM and Ford. ``The strength you see in the truck model is the APV (minivans) for General Motors and the Explorer (sport-utility vehicle) for Ford,'' he said. GM's light truck sales during the period rose 29.9 percent and Ford's increased 14.1 percent. Chrysler's fell 10.8 percent. ``June ended strong for GM with car and truck sales up,'' said J.B. Fitzpatrick, GM's marketing and product planning staff vice president. ``Our lower inventory position should provide for a smooth transition into the 1991 model year.'' GM was the only one of the Big Three to post a gain in late-June sales of its domestically made cars, increasing 12.9 percent over last year based on double-digit increases in sales from its two largest divisions, Chevrolet and Pontiac. Ford's car sales dropped 4.7 percent during the period and Chrysler, which has been struggling with sluggish car sales for months, reported an 11.3 percent decline in late-June sales. Among the Japanese ``transplants,'' only Nissan Motor Co. Ltd.'s U.S.-made cars showed a decrease in late June, falling 19.9 percent. The auto industry has been plagued recently by a sluggish U.S. economy and reports of sagging consumer confidence. Automakers use incentives to spark sales and reduce inventories of unsold new vehicles, but lately they've been shying away from wholesale use of the enticements. Incentives, whether cash rebates or low-interest loan offers, carve into companies' profits and can create price confusion in the market. Consequently, the programs offered now cover fewer vehicles than programs last year and generally offer consumers lower rebates and less attractive financing deals. Also, inventories are estimated to be in the 60-selling-day range, considered a good level for this time of year. Each of the Big Three recently announced modest price increases.

DOC.HEAD: Visa, Mastercard, File Major Suit Against Nationwide Telemarketers
DOC.TEXT: The largest telemarketing fraud ever uncovered by Visa and Mastercard recruited small businesses to launder credit card charges, the companies contend in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit unsealed Thursday. Federal criminal investigations also are under way in the case, described as a chain of operations conducting business nationwide from bases in Florida, Texas, Arizona, California and other states. The suit says the scam began with postcards telling consumers they had won free cars, watches or $5,000 prizes. When they phoned they reached ``boiler rooms'' and were pressured to buy water purifiers, security systems, travel packages and vitamins, it says. The defendants claimed that winners' identities were verified through their credit card numbers. The defendants also implied that Visa and Mastercard sponsored the giveaways, the suit says. The suit also alleges the telemarketers misrepresented goods, failed to deliver them and sent multiple bills for the same product. ``Defendants' scheme undermines a cornerstone of the charge card system: that member financial institutions be able to evaluate the honesty, integrity and credit worthiness of those from whom they accept charge card deposits,'' Visa and Mastercard said in the suit in Los Angeles federal court. The suit seeks unspecified millions of dollars in actual damages and $10 million in punitive damages, alleging racketeering, fraud, trademark infringement and interfering with contractual relationships. ``It's the largest single telemarketing operation that Visa and Mastercard ever came across,'' said Visa spokesman David Brancoli. He estimated such schemes cost the companies up to $200 million per year. Federal Trade Commission officials believe consumers have lost $1 billion a year to telemarketing fraud for the past five years. A central aim of the suit is to stop boiler room operators from using third parties to process sales drafts. Banks usually won't set up Visa and Mastercard accounts for telephone sales operations because too many customers refuse to pay, leaving the banks holding the bag, the suit says. The suit alleges that some defendants were ``brokers'' who advertised in newspapers like the Los Angeles Times for businesses to launder sales drafts for a fee, typically 6 percent of sales. Counting broker fees, telemarketers may pay 20 percent or more of the gross sales to have their drafts deposited, said Daniel H. Bookin, a San Francisco attorney for Visa and Mastercard. That compares to 2 percent to 3 percent at legitimate businesses with merchant accounts at banks. ``If these guys couldn't launder, they'd be out of business,'' Bookin said. Visa and Mastercard persuaded U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie last week to issue a temporary restraining order barring the telemarketers from using third parties to process credit card drafts. A hearing on a permanent injunction is set for July 16. The Postal Service and the Secret Service are conducting criminal probes, according to the suit and one of the defendants, Lorraine G. Doty. ``This thing is much bigger than what is laid out in this lawsuit,'' Ms. Doty said in a telephone interview from Florida. Ms. Doty said she and another defendant, Lillian Whitman, had shut down their boiler room operation in Clearwater, Fla., after learning that using third parties to process sales drafts violated credit card agreements with banks. She declined further comment, saying she hadn't talked to a lawyer. A central defendant is Donald Gaines of Clearwater, who the complaint accuses of running boiler rooms and, through a Phoenix business, acting as a broker for small businesses willing to launder charges. Reached at another business in Overland, Kan., Gaines declined comment, saying he had not seen the lawsuit. Altogether, the suit names 10 individuals and 11 companies as defendants. ``We have documented $4 million in losses, but we're sure the total is far larger,'' Bookin said. Processing of third-party sales drafts is outlawed in only three states: California, Florida and Wisconsin. There is no federal law against it, although abuses can be prosecuted under other federal statutes such as mail fraud and wire fraud. Mastercard and Visa have joint programs to warn businesses that laundering is banned by their agreements with banks and to detect the practice. They also are jointly lobbying to have such laundering made a federal crime.

DOC.HEAD: Fell $2.24 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds fell $2.24 billion in the latest week to $382.70 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $444.9 million decline the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group . Fund assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 250 general purpose funds fell $723.9 million to $133.21 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $1.29 billion to $157.88 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds declined $222.8 million to $91.61 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.68 percent from 7.67 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield was unchanged at 7.67 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, up from 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.16 percent as of Wednesday from 6.18 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.04 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.91 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 8.10 percent on 1-year CDs, unchanged; 8.10 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 8.17 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Says Pharmacy Board Badgered Rite Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: May be updated
DOC.TEXT: Rite Aid Corp., charged along with its president with trying to bribe a state pharmacy board member, was singled out and badgered by Ohio regulators, the company's attorney charged before a jury Thursday. Attorney George Moscarino contended the Ohio State Board of Pharmacy had a vendetta against Rite Aid and launched a flawed investigation into the bribery claim. He said the panel had become angry over Rite Aid's questioning of certain drugstore rules. ``There was a (pharmacy board) blitz of only the Rite Aid stores,'' Moscarino said in opening statements in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court. ``The evidence will show they were peeved at Rite Aid.'' An indictment unsealed in August charged Rite Aid and President Martin L. Grass, 36, with trying to bribe Melvin Wilczynski, a voting member of the pharmacy board. The indictment included a charge against Grass of possession of a criminal tool, an aircraft he used to fly to Cleveland for the alleged deal. Prosecutors say Grass on April 27, 1989, gave Wilczynski a check for $33,000 with the stipulation that he step down from the board. Prosecutors say the company was trying to pack the board, whose members are appointed by the governor, with members to its liking. Rite Aid, based in Shiremanstown, Pa., and one of the nation's biggest drugstore chains, has denied the charges, saying the corporate check was a legal buyout of Wilczynski's consulting contract with a troubled chain that Rite Aid acquired. Assistant Cuyahoga County Prosecutor William Caine said Thursday that Wilczynski, a licensed pharmacist and still a member of the board, was surprised to learn that Rite Aid planned to buy out his contract with Lane Drug Co., a Peoples Drug Store Inc. division Rite Aid acquired last year. Caine said Wilczynski was summoned to Rite Aid offices in Toledo and told by Grass that the company wanted him to resign from the pharmacy board. When Wilczynski told Grass he wanted to remain, Caine said, Grass' response was, ``You're out in left field.'' ``I think it's very telling in this whole transaction that, as Mr. Grass sat there in this small room ... he couldn't look Mel Wilczynski in the eye,'' Caine said. Prosecutors said they will show a videotape, made secretly with Wilczynski's cooperation, showing Grass handing Wilczynski a check and copies of resignation letters for him to sign. The videotape was made at a hotel near Cleveland's airport, prosecutors said. The government said it seized the undated, variously-worded resignation letters to Gov. Richard Celeste, among other documents, during Grass' arrest in the hotel room.

DOC.HEAD: Rainy Forecast Swamps Corn, Soybean Futures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf pvs, Meanwhile, a ... to CORRECT day of week and length of strike to five days sted nine. Picks up 19th graf, Copper futures ...
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices wilted Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade after the National Weather Service issued a rainy forecast for the Midwest. Wheat and oat futures also fell but not as steeply as corn and beans, which are grown mainly in the Midwest and would benefit from additional moisture. On other commodity markets, most oil futures fell; copper futures advanced; precious metals were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Corn futures settled 4{ cents to 10 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $2.86 a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 23 cents lower with July at $6.28{ a bushel; Wheat was 1{ cents to 5\ cents lower with July at $3.18\ a bushel; oats were 4{ cents to 5{ cents lower with July at $1.35{ a bushel. Most contracts for delivery of new-crop corn plunged the permitted daily limit of 10 cents a bushel, largely in reaction to a six-to-10-day outlook issued Wednesday by the weather service. The forecast was for normal temperatures and above-normal rainfall over most of the Corn Belt during the the latter half of next week. The losses wiped out gains that had mounted over the past week in reaction to predictions, mostly by private meteorologists, that a pattern of unusually warm, dry air was setting up in the Corn Belt. Some private forecasters continued to predict an extended period of hot, dry weather in the Mississippi Delta region, where some soybeans are grown. ``There's enough conflict out there to satisfy the bulls and the bears,'' said Michael Gazall, a research analyst with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc. ``But when the National Weather Service comes out with this kind of news, it kind of sets the tone for everybody,'' he said. Walter Spilka, grain analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the forecast provided an opportunity for profit-taking. ``The bottom line is probably that those traders who were buying in anticipation of a weather event now are selling in anticipation of a non-event,'' he said. Oil futures finished mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the first trading day since Tuesday's bearish petroleum stocks report from the American Petroleum Institute. The markets were closed Wednesday for Independence Day. The API report showed an unexpected 429,000-barrel increase last week in U.S. crude oil stocks. Traders had expected crude stocks to fall by about 1 million barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 30 cents lower to 6 cents higher with August at $16.50 a barrel; heating oil was .08 cent to .23 cent lower with August at 48.33 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.14 cents lower to .10 cent higher with August at 54.95 cents a gallon. Copper futures rose strongly on New York's Commodity Exchange as troubles mounted at copper mines in various locations. Prices spurted higher early in the session following news of an explosion at a Chilean Copper Co. mine in Chile that was expected to decrease production by 20,000 metric tons this year. Meanwhile, a strike at Asarco Inc.'s Ray copper mine in Arizona stretched into its fifth day Thursday, and unionized miners in Peru opened a three-day national assembly to discuss a possible strike against Peruvian mining companies. Copper futures settled 1.9 cents to 2.95 cents higher with July at $1.171 a pound. Gold and silver futures slipped on the Commodity Exchange, giving back some of the moderate gains posted over the past five sessions. Gold futures finished 80 cents to $1.10 lower with July at $363.30 a troy ounce; silver futures were 5 cents to 6.1 cents lower with July at $4.869 a troy ounce. Hog futures climbed sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid a combination of higher cash prices and bullish chart signals. Near-term pork bellies fell sharply on signs of burdensome supplies. Cattle futures were mixed. Live cattle ended .28 cent lower to .25 cent higher with August at 73.02 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .62 cent higher with August at 83.87 cents a pound; hogs were .20 cent to .98 cent higher with July at 62.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .33 cent higher to the limit 1.5 cents lower with July at 56.17 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Chief Urges Governments to Cut Debts of Poland, Others
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to change to $45 billion sted $45 million in Polish debt. Also moving on general news wires. ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: World Bank President Barber Conable on Thursday urged the United States and other creditor nations to reduce debts owed them by Poland and other ``middle income'' countries. The bank, the world's biggest source of aid to developing nations, considers the middle income countries as ranging from Bolivia, where the average citizen earns about $570 a year, to a country like Greece, where the average annual income is $4,800. Poland's per capita income is about $2,750 a year. ``Poland's debt situation must be dealt with in some way,'' Conable said, noting that Poland is nearly $45 billion in debt. ``Clearly the debt service ... would make it very difficult for Poland to resume growth and to make the necessary investments for getting a functioning economy with moving parts,'' he said. ``Debt service'' refers to payments of interest and principal. Most Polish debt is owed to governments, with West Germany and France the biggest creditors. About $3 billion is owed to the U.S. government's Export-Import Bank and Commodity Credit Corp. The World Bank has lent Poland $780 million in the past 12 months. Conable said that was done on the assumption that some international settlement would be made on the remainder of Poland's official debt. He said the debt burden makes it difficult for such countries to lure the investment they need to raise standards of living. Their own earnings go to keep up with the debt and foreign investors are wary as long as the burden exists. He noted that President Bush last week suggested that help with official debt be given in Latin America. ``Clearly there are middle income countries elsewhere and other creditors besides the United States which must addresses this issue,'' he said. ``We hope it will be discussed at Houston and ... it will be constructive if something could be worked out.'' Bush and leaders of six other major industrial countries hold their annual economic summit in Houston beginning Monday. Conable mentioned Eastern European countries, North Africa, Nigeria and the Ivory Coast as candidates for help. He pointed out that there already has been considerable reduction of official debt for the poorest countries _ especially in Africa _ and that a plan pressed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady deals with debts to commercial banks. The World Bank estimates that of $1.039 trillion worth of long-term debt owed by Third World countries, $517 billion comes from official sources. That includes tens of billions owed to the World Bank itself, which Conable did not discuss. He suggested that government creditors might offer help of the same kind they have given the poorest countries. These ``Toronto terms,'' named after the city where creditor governments agreed on them, include reduction in total debt, reduction of interest payments, and a long stretch-outs of repayments.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Ordered To Defend Conflict of Interest Charges
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs grafs 3-4 to CORRECT that property purchases as well as loans included in $100 million; pick up 5th graf: Bush in ...
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Thursday ordered President Bush's son, Neil, to appear at a public hearing to explain why as a savings and loan officer he approved loans to a business partner. Administrative charges of conflict of interest against the president's son will be taken up at the September hearing, regulators said. The loans to business partner Bill L. Walters and purchases of property from him totaled more than $100 million, according to the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. At the time of the transactions, the younger Bush was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver. Bush in a reply denied that he had violated his duty as a director. He denied a number of specific charges and said in response to others that he ``lacks sufficient present knowledge or information to form a belief as to the allegations.'' The administrative charges filed in February and Bush's reply a month later both were made public for the first time Thursday under a new thrift office policy. The House Banking Committee released a preliminary draft of the charges in June. An administrative law judge is scheduled to hear the Bush case Sept. 25 in Denver before making a recommendation to thrift office director Timothy Ryan. James Nesland, an attorney for the younger Bush, said a public hearing could be exploited for political purposes but expressed confidence that the judge would render a fair opinion. ``I think it's unfortunate if it creates a political sideshow or a media sideshow, but I'm still confident the administrative law judge will decide the case on its merits,'' he said. Separately, the thrift office announced it was seeking a record $24 million in restitution and civil penalties from the former chairman of Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif. The office alleged that Thomas Spiegel spent millions of the thrift's eposits on limousines, corporate jets, luxury condominiums in resort areas, trips to Europe for himself, $7,000 in tickets to a Michael Jackson concert and a $55,000 gun collection, including Uzi submachine guns. Spiegel, a close associate of former Drexel Burnham junk bond chief Michael Milken, built Columbia into one of the nation's largest thrifts and the industry's biggest holder of junk bonds, with $3.7 billion at the end of 1989. Columbia is still operating, but analysts predict it eventually will be seized by the government. Spiegel stepped down in December. Edward Harshfield, Columbia's current chief executive, said in a statement that the institution's current management cooperated with the thrift office and said the allegations do not reflect on current management or the institution as a whole. Spiegel, meanwhile, denied the charges and accused the agency of waging a politically-motivated ``trial by press release.'' Bush served on the board of Silverado from August 1985 to August 1988. It collapsed in December 1988 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. He has denied any wrongdoing. The charges said Bush as a director of Silverado voted to approve loans totaling $45 million to Walters, an investor in and lender to Bush's oil exploration company, JNB Exploration Co. He also voted to approve Silverado's purchase of $58.4 million in properties from Walters, the document said. The thrift office also said Bush inadequately disclosed his ties to Kenneth Good, a developer who defaulted on loans to Silverado. Ryan will decide after reviewing the administrative hearing on the case whether or not to issue a cease-and-desist order against Bush prohibiting him from violating regulations in the future. The agency is not seeking any more serious penalties, such as financial restitution or banning Bush from working for a bank or S&L. From now on, the agency generally will release charges and conduct hearings in public for the officers of thrifts already closed or seized by the government. In order to avoid the danger of depositor runs, proceedings against open S&Ls generally will continue to be conducted in private, Ryan told a news conference. ``The public has a major stake in the cleanup of the thrift industry, and as a general rule I believe it is reasonable to make enforcement proceedings open when dealing with government controlled thrifts,'' Ryan said. He said he offered Treasury Department officials a chance to offer advice on the policy, but they declined. The documents on three other unrelated cases also were released.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says National Intergroup's Poison Pill Has To Go Before Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. said Thursday it would appeal a Delaware judge's ruling that shareholders must be allowed to vote on changes in the company's anti-takeover provisions. National Intergroup amended its poison pill strategy in January, diluting the voting power and market value of its shares for investors who own more than 10 percent of the company. The threshold had stood at 20 percent. Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of Delaware's Chancery Court on Tuesday said National Intergroup acted improperly and called the 10 percent limit ``extremely low.'' Hartnett said National Intergroup's board must present the changes to the stockholders at its July 25 meeting in Pittsburgh. The ruling is a boost to Centaur Partners, a New York partnership that owns 16.53 percent of National Intergroup, and Walker Street, another partnership that owns 8.4 percent of the company. Centaur Partners, which earlier this year tried unsuccessfully to gain control of National Intergroup's board, and Walker Street had brought the court action against the company. National Intergroup issued a statement saying they would appeal the decision. The company said lowering the threshold was ``a necessary and appropriate response to the threat to shareholders posed by Centaur's acquisition program.'' National Intergroup, formerly the majority owner of National Steel Corp., has announced the sale of most of its metals and other businesses, leaving behind its drug distribution company. Last month, National Intergroup announced it would change its name to FoxMeyer Corp., the name of its drug company and move to Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Partial Verdict in Futures Traders Trial
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday rejected a partial verdict in the fraud and racketeering trial of three commodities traders and directed the jury to continue their deliberations. In the ninth day of their deliberations, the jurors sent U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams a note saying they had reached verdicts on some of the counts, and were deadlocked on the others. ``We feel further deliberations would be unproductive,'' wrote Benita Engledinger, the jury's foreman. After 20 minutes of discussion among lawyers at the judge's bench, Williams brought the jurors into the courtroom and told them, ``You must continue your deliberations.'' The jury was weighing charges against Robert M. Mosky, 34, Danny L. Scheck, 28, and David Zatz, 43. Mosky is a Chicago Mercantile Exchange floor broker portrayed by prosecutors as the leader of a fraud scheme in the Merc's Swiss franc futures trading pit. He is the only defendant charged with racketeering. The Swiss franc traders were the first to stand trial on charges stemming from a continuing FBI probe of corruption at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's biggest commodity markets. The jury began deliberating June 22 after nearly seven weeks of testimony. Mosky's lawyer, Elliott Samuels, said the prolonged deliberations were wearing on the defendants and their lawyers. ``It's tough. It's hard on the nerves,'' said Samuels. The defendants were accused of shifting their personal losses from trading errors into their customers' accounts, then hiding their practices by changing or destroying trading records. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz were charged last August with more than a dozen counts each of mail or wire fraud, and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Each count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $150,000 fine. If convicted of racketeering conspiracy, Mosky faces a maximum prison term of 20 years. He also could be forced to forfeit personal assets.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda To Begin Marketing Cars in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Co. will begin selling cars in East Germany this fall, opening about 50 dealerships in East Berlin, company officials said Friday. Following similar moves by Japan's other large auto manufacturers, Mazda said it plans to sell between several hundred and 1,000 cars this year. Officials said that already more than 500 East Germans have applied for dealership contracts. Nissan Motor Co. announced late last month that it intended to open between 60 and 70 dealer outlets in East Germany by the end of 1990. Toyota Motor Co., Japan's largest car manufacturer, and Mitsubishi Motor Co. have also indicated that they plan to begin marketing their vehicles in East Germany. Though car sales in East Germany totaled a modest 195,000 vehicles in 1989, potential demand is very strong as East Germany moves toward economic and political unification with West Germany, company officials said. Japanese automakers estimate 1990 sales in the East at around 350,000 vehicles.
